('41', 0, 1, 2, 41) 1. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CHICACOLE
('41', 0, 2, 3, 80) December 3, 1927
('41', 0, 3, 4, 97) You seem to be dividing all the good things with poor Utkal 1. I flattered myself with the assumption that my arrival here is one of the good things, for I was going to devote all the twenty days to seeing the skeletons of Orissa; but as you, the Andhras, are the gatekeepers of Orissa on this side, you have intercepted my march.
('41', 0, 3, 5, 428) But I am glad you have anticipated me also.
('41', 0, 3, 6, 472) After entering Andhra Desh, I have been doing my business with you and I know God will reward all those unknown people who have been co operating with me who am a self appointed representative of Daridranarayana.
('41', 0, 3, 7, 685) And here, too, you have been doing the same thing.
('41', 0, 3, 8, 736) Last night, several sister came and presented me with a purse.
('41', 0, 3, 9, 799) But let me tell you this is not after all my tour in Andhra.
('41', 0, 3, 10, 860) I am not going to let you alone so easily as this, nor will Deshabhakta Konda Venkatappayya let me alone, because I have toured in some parts of Ganjam.
('41', 0, 3, 11, 1013) I am under promise to tour Andhra during the early part of next year, and let me hope what you are doing is only a foretaste of what you are going to do next year.
('41', 0, 3, 12, 1177) You have faith in true non co operation.
('41', 0, 3, 13, 1218) There is the great drink evil, eating into the vitals of the labouring population.
('41', 0, 3, 14, 1301) I would like you to non co operate with that evil without a single thought and I make a sporting proposal, viz., that those who give up drink habit should divide their savings with me on behalf of Daridranarayan.
('41', 0, 3, 15, 1514) Then I see that many of you are making chimneys of your mouths by the vicious smoke habit.
('41', 0, 3, 16, 1605) You, who smoke, do not know what a filthy habit it is.
('41', 0, 3, 17, 1660) I saw that many of the people, when I made the appeal, threw away their cigars and cigarettes.
('41', 0, 3, 18, 1755) The elderly people by indulging in this vicious habit do not know what a legacy they are leaving to their children.
('41', 0, 3, 19, 1871) You know, as I know, that many children steal money in order to satisfy their curiosity to somke.
('41', 0, 3, 20, 1969) I ask you therefore to non co operate with the smoke habit, and again divide you savings with me.
('41', 0, 3, 21, 2067) So also must Hindus non co operate with the devil of un touchability.
('41', 0, 3, 22, 2137) I give you my assurance that devil is keeping us from God, and it is a barrier created for our own destruction.
('41', 0, 4, 23, 2249) 1 Another name for Orissa
('41', 1, 0, 1, 2275) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 1, 1, 2, 2315) Mahatmaji then proceeded to answer some questions handed to him by someone in the audience.
('41', 1, 1, 3, 2407) The first question was: “What are the means now to be adopted by young men for the uplift of the Mother country?” Mahatmaji said: There are many things that I can suggest, but there is one thing which is the easiest for them to do and that is khadi work.
('41', 1, 1, 4, 2662) They can set apart a certain sum every month or every year to be devoted for khadi work.
('41', 1, 1, 5, 2751) If they have the time, they can devote it to organizing khadi work in their own district.
('41', 1, 1, 6, 2841) If they cannot do so or if they have given what is best in them.
('41', 1, 1, 7, 2906) If they cannot do so or if they have not confidence enough to be able to do organizing work, they can give half an hour a day to spinning and their yarn to the All India Spinners’ Association and become a member.
('41', 1, 2, 8, 3119) The second question dealt with the educational and other qualifications required for a public worker.
('41', 1, 2, 9, 3221) Mahatmaji said: So far as educational qualifications are concerned, besides knowing the provincial vernacular, they must know also the Rashtrabhasha 1—Hindi.
('41', 1, 2, 10, 3379) But the other qualifications are even far more important.
('41', 1, 2, 11, 3437) They must be strictly honest and their private character must be pure.
('41', 1, 2, 12, 3508) Men whose eyes are not straight and whose heart is full of animal passion are not fit for doing political work.
('41', 1, 2, 13, 3620) And in my opinion, unless he believes in truth and non violence at any cost, he has no business to be a politician.
('41', 1, 3, 14, 3736) Answering the third question, Mahatmaji said : Whilst all our leaders are conceiving and cooking all kinds of schemes, we, the rank and file, cannot do better than achieving the message of khadi to its fullest extent.
('41', 1, 3, 15, 3954) It is not a small thing for you and me to take part in an effort to save sixty crores of rupees.
('41', 1, 3, 16, 4051) You and I cannot pack the Councils, Assembly and Municipalities.
('41', 1, 3, 17, 4116) Even if we would, we could not have all the qualifications.
('41', 1, 3, 18, 4176) But every one of us is born with the qualification for khadi.
('41', 1, 3, 19, 4238) It requires not much training except the training of the heart.
('41', 1, 3, 20, 4302) By doing khadi work you will find that the power is descending upon you.
('41', 1, 4, 21, 4375) The Hindu, 9 12 1927
('41', 1, 5, 22, 4396) 1 National language
('41', 2, 0, 1, 4416) VOL. 41 : 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 3
('41', 2, 1, 2, 4457) 2. ESSAY ON KHADI
('41', 2, 2, 3, 4475) Readers will recall that essays in English were invited on the subject of khadi, in view of the prize announced by Shri Revashanker Jagjivan 1. Accordingly, the essay written jointly by Professor Puntambekar and Shri Varadachari was awarded the prize.
('41', 2, 2, 4, 4727) As this is well worth study, it has been translated [into Gujarati] for the Jamnadas Bhagwandas Memorial Series.
('41', 2, 2, 5, 4840) Shri Chhaganlal Joshi of the Satyagraha Ashram has done the translation and it has now been published.
('41', 2, 2, 6, 4943) It is priced at Re.
('41', 2, 2, 7, 4963) 1. The total number of pages is 260. The translation runs into 215 pages, the rest being appendices.
('41', 2, 2, 8, 5064) All the apppendices are useful.
('41', 2, 2, 9, 5096) The last appendix gives a short history of khadi in Gujarat; in other words, it shows where khadi was formerly produced in Gujarat and how that priceless industry came to be ruined.
('41', 2, 2, 10, 5278) The language used in the translation is simple.
('41', 2, 2, 11, 5326) Gujarati readers will have no difficulty in understanding it.
('41', 2, 2, 12, 5388) Those who wish to understand well the secret underlying the activity of spinning must positively go through this book.
('41', 2, 2, 13, 5507) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 12 1927
('41', 2, 3, 14, 5544) 3. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, BERHAMPUR 2
('41', 2, 4, 15, 5586) Decembr 4, 1927
('41', 2, 5, 16, 5602) SISTERS, You have presented two purses for the khadi work.
('41', 2, 5, 17, 5661) I acknowledge your present with gratitude.
('41', 2, 5, 18, 5704) You must not think that I consider some of you as Oriyas and some as Telugus.
('41', 2, 5, 19, 5782) You should feel that all are Indians.
('41', 2, 5, 20, 5820) Some say that they belong to Andhra and some say that they belong to Orissa.
('41', 2, 5, 21, 5897) Let all of you belong to India.
('41', 2, 5, 22, 5929) Let all of you share each other’s misery and happiness.
('41', 2, 5, 23, 5985) Only thus can you become like Sita.
('41', 2, 5, 24, 6021) Sita did not consider herself a citizen of Ayodhya.
('41', 2, 5, 25, 6073) She always considered hereself as belonging to the whole of India.
('41', 2, 5, 26, 6140) I am really glad that you have written this welcome address in the national language, that is, Hindi.
('41', 2, 5, 27, 6242) Let all of you give up foreign saris.
('41', 2, 5, 28, 6280) Let all of you use only khadi.
('41', 2, 5, 29, 6311) There is no necessity for a woman to wear beautiful saris and ornaments.
('41', 2, 5, 30, 6384) The only thing a woman needs is purity.
('41', 2, 5, 31, 6424) Let all of you wear khadi.
('41', 2, 5, 32, 6451) Let all of you be pure and truthful.
('41', 2, 6, 33, 6488) 1 Revashanker Jagjivan Zaveri of Bombay 2 In Orissa
('41', 3, 0, 1, 6540) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 3, 1, 2, 6580) You should not consider anyone as untouchable.
('41', 3, 1, 3, 6627) In India, that is, Bharatvarsha, it is a great sin to consider anyone as an untouchable.
('41', 3, 1, 4, 6716) For heaven’s sake do not commit that sin.
('41', 3, 1, 5, 6758) Love those who are poor, diseased and hungry.
('41', 3, 1, 6, 6804) Let all of you prove that you love them by spinning yarn on the charkha for at least half an hour every day.
('41', 3, 1, 7, 6913) I appeal to those who have not contributed anything towards this Khadi Fund to contribute money or ornaments.
('41', 3, 1, 8, 7023) [From Oriya] The Samaj, 10 12 1927
('41', 3, 2, 9, 7058) 4. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, BERHAMPUR
('41', 3, 3, 10, 7100) December 4, 1927
('41', 3, 4, 11, 7117) PROFESSORS, STUDENTS AND BROTHERS, Our programme in this meeting will be unlike the programmes followed in other meetings.
('41', 3, 4, 12, 7240) In our Satyagraha Ashram, for many years now, at 4.15 a.m.
('41', 3, 4, 13, 7299) in the morning and at 7 p.m.
('41', 3, 4, 14, 7328) in the evening, we hold congregational prayers.
('41', 3, 4, 15, 7376) When the Ashramites go to other places this schedule is observed even there.
('41', 3, 4, 16, 7453) Knowing that it is difficult to hold prayers at 7 p.m.
('41', 3, 4, 17, 7508) in the evening regularly [during tours], we have ruled that prayer must be held at night before going to bed.
('41', 3, 4, 18, 7618) On Friday, December 2, it was very late in the night when we entered into Ganjam district.
('41', 3, 4, 19, 7709) I forgot to pray before going to bed due to heavy work.
('41', 3, 4, 20, 7765) When I woke up in the dawn, I trembled in fear.
('41', 3, 4, 21, 7813) I could see that I had committed a great mistake before the Lord.
('41', 3, 4, 22, 7879) So we decided that anyone forgetting to offer prayers must do some kind of penance.
('41', 3, 4, 23, 7963) We also decided that wherever we were, we must remember the name of Rama at least once in the evening.
('41', 3, 4, 24, 8066) I was scheduled to come to this meeting at 7 p.m.
('41', 3, 4, 25, 8116) and we were supposed to pray together; but while coming the motor car from Chhatrapur I found that it was already 7 p.m.
('41', 3, 4, 26, 8237) So I prayed by myself in the motor car; but when we have decided on collective prayer, I beg you to pray here and now.
('41', 3, 4, 27, 8356) Those students and others who have faith in prayer, let them pray with closed eyes.
('41', 3, 4, 28, 8440) After the prayer, I will try to explain its utility.
('41', 3, 4, 29, 8493) Those who are unwilling to pray, I request them to sit quietly.
('41', 3, 5, 30, 8557) 1 The first two paragraphs are translated from The Samaj, an Oriya paper.
('41', 3, 5, 31, 8631) What follows is from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”, published in Young India, 15 12 1927. Mahadev Desai adds: “The students’ meeting had been timed at 7 p.m.
('41', 3, 5, 32, 8791) Although we did not reach the meeting at 7 and had to have our prayers whilst in motion, Gandhiji decided to have the congregational prayer at the meeting.
('41', 3, 5, 33, 8947) So we had it, the students keeping pin drop silence.
('41', 4, 0, 1, 9000) VOL. 41 : 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 5
('41', 4, 1, 2, 9041) As food is necessary for the body, prayer is necessary for the soul.
('41', 4, 1, 3, 9110) A man may be able to do without food for a number of days,— as MacSwiney did for over 70 days—but believing in God, man cannot, should not, live a moment without prayer.
('41', 4, 1, 4, 9280) You will say that we see lots of people living without prayer.
('41', 4, 1, 5, 9343) I dare say they do, but it is the existence of the brute which, for man, is worse than death.
('41', 4, 1, 6, 9437) I have not the shadow of a doubt that the strife and quarrels with which our atmosphere is so full today are due to the absence of the spirit of true prayer.
('41', 4, 1, 7, 9595) You will demur to the statement, I know, and contend that millions of Hindus, Mussalmans and Christians do offer their prayers.
('41', 4, 1, 8, 9723) It is because I had thought you would raise this objection that I used the words ‘true prayers’.
('41', 4, 1, 9, 9820) The fact is we have been offering our prayers with the lips but hardly ever with our hearts, and it is to escape, if possible, the hypocrisy of the lip prayer, that we in the Ashram repeat every evening the last verses of the second chapter of the Bhagavad Gita.
('41', 4, 1, 10, 10083) The condition of the ‘Equable in Spirit’ that is described in those verses, if we contemplate them daily, is bound slowly to turn our hearts towards God.
('41', 4, 1, 11, 10237) If you students would base your education on the true foundation of a pure character and pure heart there is nothing so helpful as to offer your prayers every day truly and religiously.
('41', 4, 2, 12, 10423) The Samaj, 10 12 1927 and Young India, 15 12 1927

('41', 5, 2, 3, 10737) BERHAMPUR, Silence Day [December 5, 1927] 1
('41', 5, 3, 4, 10781) SISTERS, I got your letter written by Manibehn.
('41', 5, 3, 5, 10829) I have very little time to write today.
('41', 5, 3, 6, 10869) I am convinced that we should not permit jewels in the Ashram.
('41', 5, 3, 7, 10932) As long as there is terrible starvation in our land it is a sin for us to keep or to put on a ring weighing even a grain.
('41', 5, 3, 8, 11054) Our clothes must be just sufficient to cover our nakedness and to protect us against heat and cold.
('41', 5, 3, 9, 11154) All of you should try to reach this ideal.
('41', 5, 3, 10, 11197) I shall not write today about how the desire for ornaments arises.
('41', 5, 3, 11, 11264) It looks as though you have also not understood my question properly.
('41', 5, 3, 12, 11334) How is it that Lakshmibehn is ill?
('41', 5, 3, 13, 11369) She never used to fall ill.

('41', 5, 6, 16, 11461) 7. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('41', 5, 7, 17, 11501) December 5, 1927
('41', 5, 8, 18, 11518) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I missed one mail this time.
('41', 5, 8, 19, 11568) I could not attend to things regularly while I was in Ceylon.
('41', 5, 8, 20, 11630) There was plenty of travelling to do.
('41', 5, 8, 21, 11668) When, however, I miss a mail you should not feel worried or followed my example.
('41', 5, 8, 22, 11749) You will be free to miss a mail when both of you become as busy as I am if you have not learnt by then to get over my weaknesses.
('41', 5, 8, 23, 11879) Truly speaking, however, a real heir is one who enhances the legacy he has inherited.
('41', 5, 8, 24, 11965) Sushila is right when she says that in the realm of art there can be no distinction between indigenous and foreign, but her statement calls for some reflection.
('41', 5, 8, 25, 12126) Lovers of art take a superficial view of art and use it as a cover for many weaknesses.
('41', 5, 8, 26, 12214) We should, therefore, examine what we mean by art.
('41', 5, 8, 27, 12265) Not everything which appeals to the eye is art.
('41', 5, 8, 28, 12313) What is accepted as art by many expert may not be art.
('41', 5, 8, 29, 12368) I have read conflicting opinions about many paintings and statues

('41', 6, 1, 2, 12517) expressed by art critics who have become famous in the world.
('41', 6, 1, 3, 12579) We should, therefore, think what art means.

('41', 6, 1, 5, 12645) 1 has been translated [into Gujarati].
('41', 6, 1, 6, 12684) Sushila should read it.
('41', 6, 1, 7, 12708) If you cannot get it there, Please write to me.
('41', 6, 1, 8, 12756) Devdas suffered very much during his illness.
('41', 6, 1, 9, 12802) There is some affection in the nose.

('41', 6, 3, 15, 13001) 8. SPEECH AT CHHATRAPUR 2
('41', 6, 4, 16, 13027) [On or before December 6, 1927]
('41', 6, 5, 17, 13059) I am pining for a day when all this unhealthy competition between sister languages of India will have ceased.
('41', 6, 5, 18, 13169) Why should we not love all of them equally, as a brother holding a number of sisters in the same affection?
('41', 6, 5, 19, 13277) The result of the wretched competition has been that we forget our vernaculars and are jealous of others, and fondly believe that English would take the place of the common language of India, and even of the vernaculars.
('41', 6, 5, 20, 13498) Indeed a suggestion had come to me to address the meeting here in English.
('41', 6, 5, 21, 13573) Well, I take this as disaffection towards the daughter language of the motherland, and an unhealthy affection for a foreign tongue.
('41', 6, 5, 22, 13705) Not that I hate English, but I love Hindi more.
('41', 6, 5, 23, 13753) That is why I am beseeching the lettered classes of India to make Hindi their common language.
('41', 6, 5, 24, 13848) It is through Hindi that we can get into touch with and promote the growth of the other vernaculrs of the provinces.
('41', 6, 5, 25, 13965) If our intellects and hearts had not been atrophied owing to our having to learn through a foreign medium, there would be no reason why we should not all be knowing five or six vernaculars.
('41', 6, 5, 26, 14155) And my remarks regarding the competition betw een languages apply also to our narrow provincialism.
('41', 6, 5, 27, 14255) It is that provi 
('41', 6, 6, 28, 14273) 1 By Leo Tolstoy 2 Mahadev Desai says in his “Weekly Letter”: “In Chicacole the youngsters sang the Janaganamana.
('41', 6, 6, 29, 14387) The lines enumerating the provinces including Madras and Utkal were mutilated by some parochial Andhra who had dropped Utkal and added Andhra instead !
('41', 6, 6, 30, 14539) The Chhatrapur meeting was the first quiet meeting we had after many noisy ones, and Gandhiji took an opportunity to animadvert upon this narrow spirit.”
('41', 7, 0, 1, 14693) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 7, 1, 2, 14733) ncialism that has prevented the full growth of nationalism in us.
('41', 7, 1, 3, 14799) The golden rule for the promotion of nationalism is that the stronger should help and sacrifice for the weaker as much as is possible.
('41', 7, 1, 4, 14934) And now you will understand the rationale of khadi, which is intended to promote a healthy nationalism, and which embraces within its fold the poor and the downtrodden.

('41', 7, 2, 6, 15127) 9. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI Tuesday [December 6, 1927] 1
('41', 7, 3, 7, 15185) MAGANLAL, I got your letter.
('41', 7, 3, 8, 15214) I look forward to a letter from you on the due dates; if, however, I don’t get one, I understand.
('41', 7, 3, 9, 15312) Your name is always on my lips.
('41', 7, 3, 10, 15344) When it becomes necessary to say anything unpleasant like a note out of tune, even then it will, in fact, be perfectly in tune since it will be the truth and truth is always in tune.
('41', 7, 3, 11, 15527) Do not, therefore, omit to tell me what you think I must be told.
('41', 7, 3, 12, 15593) I did not receive the letters which you mention.
('41', 7, 3, 13, 15642) Letters addressed to me do not generally get lost, but these ones at any rate did not reach me.
('41', 7, 3, 14, 15738) I am sure many errors remain in My Experiments with Truth.
('41', 7, 3, 15, 15797) I exercise great care but, when memory betrays me, to whom shall I complain about the misfortune?
('41', 7, 3, 16, 15895) Please to not omit to draw my attention to any fact, whether important or unimportant.
('41', 7, 3, 17, 15982) “So tenacious is life, it does not leave even now.” 2 I do fear this.
('41', 7, 3, 18, 16052) Mahadev, of course, sang the line for his own purpose.
('41', 7, 3, 19, 16107) You may hear the history behind it when he narrates it to you.
('41', 7, 3, 20, 16170) You have done very well in absorbing yourself in your present work.
('41', 7, 3, 21, 16238) 3 It is also a good thing that you get an opportunity to visit the Ashram form time to time.
('41', 7, 3, 22, 16331) Do continue to send your suggestions and criticisms.
('41', 7, 3, 23, 16384) Give your very life in making a model village a really model one; men with real life will then come and live in it.
('41', 7, 3, 24, 16500) Ba has gone there, that is, to live with Devdas.
('41', 7, 3, 25, 16549) There is no time to write more.
('41', 7, 3, 26, 16581) Blessings from BAPU

('41', 8, 1, 2, 17029) 10. DISTORTION OF TRUTH A correspondent has been endeavouring with the help of the head master of a high school to introduce the teaching of the Gita among its boys.
('41', 8, 1, 3, 17195) But at a recent meeting convened to organize Gita readings a bank manager got up and disturbed the even tenor of the proceedings by saying that students had not the adhikara, ‘qualification’, for studying the Gita; it was not a play thing to be placed before students.
('41', 8, 1, 4, 17464) The correspondent sends me a long and argued letter about the incident and sends in support of his contention some apt saying from Ramakrishna Paramahamsa from which I cull the following :
('41', 8, 2, 5, 17653) Boys and youths should be encouraged to seek God.
('41', 8, 2, 6, 17703) They are like unpecked fruits, being totally untainted by worldly desires.
('41', 8, 2, 7, 17778) Once such desires have entered their minds, it is very difficult to make them tread the path to salvation.
('41', 8, 3, 8, 17885) Why do I love young men so much?
('41', 8, 3, 9, 17918) Because they are masters of the whole (16 annas) of their minds which get divided and sub divided as they grow up.
('41', 8, 3, 10, 18033) One half of the mind of a married man goes to his wife.
('41', 8, 3, 11, 18089) When a child is born it takes away one fourth (four annas), and the remaining one fourth (four annas) is scattered over parents, wordly honours, dress, etc.
('41', 8, 3, 12, 18246) Therefore a young mind can easily know God.
('41', 8, 3, 13, 18290) It is very difficult for old people to do so.
('41', 8, 4, 14, 18336) The parrot cannot be taught to sing if the membrane of its throat becomes hardened with age.
('41', 8, 4, 15, 18429) It must be taught while it is young.
('41', 8, 4, 16, 18466) Similarly, in old age it is difficult for the mind to be fixed on God.
('41', 8, 4, 17, 18537) It can be easily done so in youth.
('41', 8, 5, 18, 18572) If a seer of adulterated milk contains a chhatank (sixteenth part of a seer) of water, it can be thickened into kshira (condensed milk) with very little labour and consumption of fuel.
('41', 8, 5, 19, 18757) But should there be three paos (quarter seer) of water in a seer, the milk cannot be easily thickened and a large consumption of fuel will be required.
('41', 8, 5, 20, 18909) A young mind, being but slightly adulterated with worldly desires, can be easily turned towards God; this cannot be done with the minds of old people which are highly adulterated with such desires.
('41', 8, 6, 21, 19107) The tender bamboo can be easily bent, but the full grown bamboo breaks when an attempt is made to bend it.
('41', 8, 6, 22, 19214) It is easy to bend young hearts towards God, but the heart of the old escapes the hold when so drawn.
('41', 8, 7, 23, 19316) The human mind is like a package of mustard seed.
('41', 8, 7, 24, 19366) As it is very difficult to gather the seeds that escape out of a torn package and are scattered in all directions, so when the human mind runs in diverse directions and is occupied with many worldly things, it is not a very easy task to collect and concentrate
('41', 9, 0, 1, 19627) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 9, 1, 2, 19668) The mind of a youth, not running in diverse directions, can be easily fixed on anything; but the mind of an old man being totally occupied with worldly things, it is very hard for him to draw it away from them and fix it on God.
('41', 9, 1, 3, 19897) I have heard of adhikara in connection with the Vedas, but I never knew that the Gita required the qualifications that the bank manager had in mind.
('41', 9, 1, 4, 20046) It would have been better if he had stated the nature of the qualifications he required.
('41', 9, 1, 5, 20135) The Gita clearly states that it is meant for all but scoffers.
('41', 9, 1, 6, 20198) If Hindu students may not read the Gita they may not read any religious works at all.
('41', 9, 1, 7, 20284) Indeed the original conception in Hinduism is that the student life is the life of a brahmachari who should begin it with a knowledge of religion coupled with practice so that he may digest what he learns and weave religious conduct into his life.
('41', 9, 1, 8, 20532) The student of old began to live his religion before he knew what it was, and this conduct was followed by due enlightenment, so that he might know the reason for the conduct prescribed for him.
('41', 9, 1, 9, 20727) Adhikara then there certainly was.
('41', 9, 1, 10, 20762) But it was the adhikara of right conduct known as the five yamas or cardinal restraints—ahimsa (innocence), satya (truth), asteya (non stealing), aparigraha (non possession), and brahmacharya (celibacy).
('41', 9, 1, 11, 20966) These were the rules that had to be observed by anybody who wished to study religion.
('41', 9, 1, 12, 21052) He may not go to religious books for proving the necessity of these fundamentals of religion.
('41', 9, 1, 13, 21146) But today the word adhikara like many such potent words has suffered distortion, and a dissolute man, simply because he is called Brahmin, has adhikara to read and expound Shastras to us, whereas a man, if he is labelled an untouchable because of his birth in a particular state, no matter how virtuous he may be, may not read them.
('41', 9, 1, 14, 21479) But the author of the Mahabharata of which the Gita is a part wrote his great work for the purpose of meeting this insane objection, and made it accessible to all irrespective of the so called caste, provided, I presume, that he complied with the observances I have described: I add the qualifying expression “I presume” for, at the time of writing, I do not recall the observance of the yamas as a condition precedent to a person studying the Mahabharata.
('41', 9, 1, 15, 21936) Experience however shows that the purity of heart and the devotional frame of mind are necessary for a proper understanding of religious books.
('41', 9, 1, 16, 22080) The printing age has broken down all barriers and scoffers read
('41', 10, 0, 1, 22144) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 11
('41', 10, 1, 2, 22185) religious books with the same freedom (if not greater) that the religiously minded have.
('41', 10, 1, 3, 22274) But we are here discussing the propriety of students reading the Gita as per of religious instruction and devotional exercise.
('41', 10, 1, 4, 22401) Here I cannot imagine any class of persons more amenable to the restraints and thus more fitted than students for such instruction.
('41', 10, 1, 5, 22533) Unfortunately, it is to be admitted that neither the students nor the instructors in the majority of cases think anything of the real adhikara of the five restraints.
('41', 10, 1, 6, 22700) Young India, 8 12 1927
('41', 10, 2, 7, 22723) 11. GOD’S TEMPLE
('41', 10, 3, 8, 22740) Here in Ceylon where I am writing for Young India amid surroundings where Nature has bountifully poured her richest treasures, I recall a letter written by a poetically inclined friend from similar scenes.
('41', 10, 3, 9, 22946) I share with the reader a paragraph from that letter.
('41', 10, 4, 10, 23000) A lovely morning!
('41', 10, 4, 11, 23018) Cool and cloudy, with a drowsy sun whose rays are as soft velvet.
('41', 10, 4, 12, 23084) It is a strangely quiet morning—there is a hush upon it, as of prayer.
('41', 10, 4, 13, 23155) And the mists are like incense, and the trees worshippers in a trance, and the birds and insects pilgrims come to chant bhajans.
('41', 10, 4, 14, 23284) how I wish one could learn true abandonment from Nature!
('41', 10, 4, 15, 23341) We seem to have forgotten our birthright to worship where and when and how we please.
('41', 10, 4, 16, 23427) We build temples and mosques and churches to keep our worship safe from prying eyes and away from outside influences, but we forget that walls have eyes and ears, and the roofs might be swarming with ghosts—who know!
('41', 10, 4, 17, 23644) Good Gracious, I shall find myself preaching next!
('41', 10, 4, 18, 23695) How foolish, on a lovely morning like this?
('41', 10, 4, 19, 23739) A little child in the garden adjoining is singing as unconsciously and joyously as a bird.
('41', 10, 4, 20, 23830) I feel inclined to go and take the dust of its little feet.
('41', 10, 4, 21, 23890) And since I cannot pour out my heart in sound as simply as that little one, my only refuge is in silence!
('41', 10, 4, 22, 23996) Churches, mosques and temples, which cover so much hypocrisy and humbug and shut the poorest out of them, seem but a mockery of God and His worship, when one sees the eternally renewed temple of worship under the vast blue canopy inviting every one of us to real worship, instead of abusing His name by quarrelling in the name of religion.
('41', 10, 4, 23, 24336) Young India, 8 12 1927

('41', 14, 4, 10, 30495) 16. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BOLGARH December 10, 1927 Fear is more deadly than disease, such as cholera, smallpox or malaria.
('41', 14, 4, 11, 30623) Disease wastes only the body, while fear destroys the soul; and men of fear cannot understand God.
('41', 14, 4, 12, 30722) He who is godfearing, takes the name of God, cannot fear men.
('41', 14, 4, 13, 30784) I cannot dismiss as untrue reports of friends who have informed me that you have been frightened by the Police and others who have told you that Government would arrest all those who came to me.
('41', 14, 4, 14, 30979) I am aware of nothing for which Government should make arrests and for aught I know Government has not till now asked people not to contribute to funds raised by me.
('41', 14, 4, 15, 31145) I understand that Orissa being poor, zamindars and officials want to keep people under fear for their own selfish interests.
('41', 14, 4, 16, 31270) I have found something striking in the atmosphere since Banpur.
('41', 14, 4, 17, 31334) I cannot make out how it will satisfy Government if people are kept off from me, or khadi work is interfered with, I cannot bear the thought that anyone should oppress another and feel ashamed that such poor unsophi sticated people receive such treatment.
('41', 14, 4, 18, 31590) I feel humiliated that whereas I cannot put up with oppression from foreigners, my own country’s zamindars or officials have been frightening people.
('41', 14, 4, 19, 31740) If the names of those who have been frightened are given to me I propose visiting them and if the names of the zamindars are also given I shall go and discuss the subject with them.
('41', 14, 4, 20, 31922) Fear is more deadly than diseases, and I ask them to give up fear, so that the work of those who frighten might automatically cease.
('41', 14, 4, 21, 32055) Give up drink, gambling and prostitution, so that you can be pure enough to attain God.
('41', 14, 4, 22, 32143) Though I have not come to raise purses in Orissa I do not hesitate to beg even from the poor for the sake of khadi.
('41', 14, 4, 23, 32259) May God bless you.

('41', 18, 9, 20, 38511) MY DEAR SRI PRAKASA, You must forgive me for not replying to your letter for such a long time, but I have been worked beyond my strength and have had no time left for dealing with voluminous correspondence.
('41', 18, 9, 21, 38718) It is only
('41', 19, 0, 1, 38729) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 19, 1, 2, 38770) because I am having enforced rest at an unknown and out of the way village in Utkal, that I am able to deal with the arrears, and in the natural course I have come upon your letter.
('41', 19, 1, 3, 38952) Here is the receipt sent to me with your letter from the Ashram.
('41', 19, 1, 4, 39017) The Aaj people should not complain.
('41', 19, 1, 5, 39053) Complimentary copies have been sent only to well known English papers.
('41', 19, 1, 6, 39124) Even well known friends have not been supplied with copies simply because after all Young India and Navajivan are at present very poor concerns.
('41', 19, 1, 7, 39269) They do not command the circulation of 1920 and 1921, and yet the rigid rule of remaining self supporting in spite of the handicaps in the shape of not taking advertisements, etc., is observed, and whenever there is anything left over from the running of these papers, the whole of it goes for public cause.
('41', 19, 1, 8, 39577) Should Aaj then expect a free copy, it would be simply taking so much out of poor people’s pockets.
('41', 19, 1, 9, 39677) If, in spite of this explanation, you or the workers at the Aaj office expect a free copy, tell me and I shall ask Swami Anand to send one.
('41', 19, 1, 10, 39817) Of course I know that Aaj is a leading paper on your side as is Basumati for instance in Calcutta.
('41', 19, 1, 11, 39916) But so far as I am aware, no vernacular paper has had the English copy.
('41', 19, 1, 12, 39988) Do please take me in your confidence either by letter or by coming to me.
('41', 19, 1, 13, 40062) I would love to share your burdens.
('41', 19, 1, 14, 40098) Do regard me therefore as a friend who would treasure your confidence and endeavour to lighten your burdens.
('41', 19, 1, 15, 40207) I am at Sabarmati in January.
('41', 19, 1, 16, 40237) I am sorry I shall have to go to Kathiawr for a few days during that month.
('41', 19, 1, 17, 40313) 1 But if you will be there for the whole of the month you can go with me to Kathiawar also and see that weird country.
('41', 19, 1, 18, 40432) Do take up the charkha regularly and once you have obtained mastery over it, you will not want to give it up, and it will be a faithful companion speaking to you only at your behest.
('41', 19, 1, 19, 40615) But you will find all the joy in the handling of it only if you will connect it and through it yourself with the meanest of our people.
('41', 19, 1, 20, 40751) And why should there be any shame in carrying on the takli, if there is no shame in identifying with the poorest.
('41', 19, 1, 21, 40865) I suppose you do know that the shepherds in Almora and in many other parts of India carry their taklis, spinning wool wherever they go.

('41', 20, 1, 2, 41175) 24. LETTER TO HARJIVAN KOTAK
('41', 20, 2, 3, 41204) BOLGARH, ORISSA, December 11, 1927 When the mind is disturbed by impure thoughts, instead of trying to drive them out one should occupy it in some work, that is, engage it in purposeful thoughts.
('41', 20, 2, 4, 41400) Or one may engross it in Raman ama, engage it in reading or in some bodily labour which requires mental attention too.
('41', 20, 2, 5, 41519) Never let the eyes follow their inclination.
('41', 20, 2, 6, 41564) If they fall on a woman, withdraw them immediately.
('41', 20, 2, 7, 41616) It is scarcely necessary for anyone to look straight at a man’s or woman’s face.
('41', 20, 2, 8, 41697) This is the reason why brahmacharis, and others too, are enjoined to walk with their eyes lowered.
('41', 20, 2, 9, 41796) If we are sitting, we should keep steady in one direction.
('41', 20, 2, 10, 41855) This is an external remedy, but a most valuable one.
('41', 20, 2, 11, 41908) You may undertake a fast if and when you find one necessary.
('41', 20, 2, 12, 41969) It is not necessary for you to go to Satavalekarji.
('41', 20, 2, 13, 42021) He will certai nly teach you some asanas.
('41', 20, 2, 14, 42063) If you wish to go to him to learn them, you may certainly do so.
('41', 20, 2, 15, 42128) I know him very well.
('41', 20, 2, 16, 42150) He is a fine man.
('41', 20, 2, 17, 42168) You should not be afraid even if you get involuntary discharges during a fast.
('41', 20, 2, 18, 42247) Vaids say that, even when impure desires are absent, such discharges occur because of pressure in the bowels.
('41', 20, 2, 19, 42357) But, instead of believing that, it helps us more to believe that they occur because of impure desires.
('41', 20, 2, 20, 42460) We are not always conscious of such desires.
('41', 20, 2, 21, 42505) I had an involuntary discharge in sleep twice during the last two weeks.
('41', 20, 2, 22, 42578) I cannot recall any dream.
('41', 20, 2, 23, 42605) I never practised masturbation.
('41', 20, 2, 24, 42637) One cause of these discharge is of course my physical weakness, but I also know that there are impure desires deep down in me.
('41', 20, 2, 25, 42764) I am able to keep out such thoughts during waking hours.
('41', 20, 2, 26, 42821) But what is present in the body like some hidden posion, always makes its way, even forcibly sometimes.
('41', 20, 2, 27, 42925) I feel unhappy about this, but am not nervously afraid.
('41', 20, 2, 28, 42981) I am always vigilant.
('41', 20, 2, 29, 43003) I can suppress the enemy but have not been able to expel him altogether.
('41', 20, 2, 30, 43076) If I am truthful, I shall succeed in doing that too.
('41', 20, 2, 31, 43129) The enemy will not be able to endure the power of truth.
('41', 20, 2, 32, 43186) If you are in the same condition as I am, learn from my experience.
('41', 20, 2, 33, 43254) In its essence, desire for sex pleasure is equally impure, whether its object is one’s wife or some other woman.
('41', 20, 2, 34, 43367) Its results differ.
('41', 20, 2, 35, 43387) At the moment, we are thinking of the enemy in his essential nature.
('41', 20, 2, 36, 43456) Understand, therefore, that so far as one’s wife is concerned you are not likely to find anyone as lustful as I was.
('41', 20, 2, 37, 43573) That is why I have described my
('41', 21, 0, 1, 43605) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 21, 1, 2, 43646) pitiable condition to you and tried to give you courage.
('41', 21, 1, 3, 43703) If Ba is as a mother to me now, this is the result of long struggle and God’s grace.
('41', 21, 1, 4, 43788) The legacy of that unclean life, however, afflicts me.
('41', 21, 1, 5, 43843) I, in return, try to overcome it and, with God’s grace, shall overcome it in this very life.

('41', 21, 7, 18, 44538) 26. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('41', 21, 8, 19, 44565) BOLGARH, Silence Day, December 12, 1927
('41', 21, 9, 20, 44605) SISTERS, There is profound solitude around me, but it is the solitude of a sick man’s room.
('41', 21, 9, 21, 44697) When I see the state of people here my heart burns within me, and I very much long to stay on here.
('41', 21, 9, 22, 44797) If any of you is willing to come here, I would invite her to do so.
('41', 21, 9, 23, 44865) All the women here observe purdah.
('41', 21, 9, 24, 44900) The people have neither enough clothes to wear nor food to eat.
('41', 21, 9, 25, 44964) When Mirabehn suggested, before I went to Orissa, that it was our duty to put on still fewer clothes, I felt embarrassed.
('41', 21, 9, 26, 45086) But when I see things here, I feel that her suggestion was indeed proper.
('41', 21, 9, 27, 45160) Women here put on only one dhoti, one half covers the lower part, and the other half the upper part of their bodies.
('41', 21, 9, 28, 45277) They get neither milk nor ghee.
('41', 21, 9, 29, 45309) They are terror stricken.
('41', 21, 9, 30, 45335) Because of some policeman’s threat, they do not even come anywhere near me.
('41', 21, 9, 31, 45411) I left Mirabehn in a house

('41', 23, 1, 2, 47375) 28. LETTER TO RAMESHCHANDRA ON TOUR, December 13, 1927
('41', 23, 2, 3, 47430) BHAI RAMESHCHANDRAJI, I preserved your letter till now in the hope of answering it.
('41', 23, 2, 4, 47514) Only today can I do so.
('41', 23, 2, 5, 47538) Eating flesh and eating vegetables both involve violence but without the latter man can survive nowhere, while without the former he can ordinarily survive anywhere.
('41', 23, 2, 6, 47704) If sensitivity to pain differs among creatures, the pain experienced by a cow in the throes of death cannot be experienced by plants.
('41', 23, 2, 7, 47838) For all living beings, violence in some form is unavoidable.
('41', 23, 2, 8, 47899) The votary of non violence will commit the minimum of violence.
('41', 23, 2, 9, 47963) The other religions do not enjoin flesh eating; they just do not forbid it.
('41', 23, 2, 10, 48039) It is well to know the custom in the other religions or even in Hindu dharma, but if our reason considers vegetarianism superior from the moral point of view, we must accept it.
('41', 23, 2, 11, 48217) The votary of non violence will progressively restrict himself, even in the use of vegetables.
('41', 23, 2, 12, 48312) It is difficult, not impossible, to remain a vegetarian in places like Greenland.
('41', 23, 2, 13, 48394) Even if proved impossible, it cannot establish the necessity of flesh eating everywhere.
('41', 23, 2, 14, 48483) Though our acts are seldom without a fault, we abstain from many on the basis of comparative merit.
('41', 23, 2, 15, 48583) Abstinence is constantly on the increase in the life of a seeker after moksha, and it is essential too.
('41', 23, 2, 16, 48687) Eggs and milk differ.
('41', 23, 2, 17, 48709) Eggs are not essential.
('41', 23, 2, 18, 48733) Milk too is not essential for crores of people.
('41', 23, 2, 19, 48781) I have eaten eggs in England under a delusion, as I ate meat in India.
('41', 23, 2, 20, 48852) But on coming to my senses I left them and even in the company of vegetarian friends I accepted only those dishes that did not contain eggs.
('41', 23, 2, 21, 48993) I have now come to know that a great number of unfertilized eggs are laid.
('41', 23, 2, 22, 49068) This can be systematically checked and generally unfertilized eggs alone are eaten.
('41', 23, 2, 23, 49152) But this cannot make eggs an item of our food.
('41', 23, 2, 24, 49199) Non violence is a comprehensive dharma.
('41', 23, 2, 25, 49239) Violence does not consist only in taking life away from the body.
('41', 23, 2, 26, 49305) Abandoning brahm acharya too is violence in my eyes.
('41', 23, 2, 27, 49358) It is well known that a brahm achari must abstain from fleshdiet, eggs and milk too.
('41', 23, 2, 28, 49443) Brahm acharya is more easily attainable with vegetable diet alone.
('41', 23, 2, 29, 49510) In conclusion, though the question of diet is very important for a religious man, yet it is not the be all and end all of religion or non violence; nor is it the most vital factor.
('41', 23, 2, 30, 49691) The observance of religion and
('41', 24, 0, 1, 49722) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 25
('41', 24, 1, 2, 49763) non violence has more to do with the heart.
('41', 24, 1, 3, 49807) He who does not feel the necessity of abstaining from meat for inner purification need not abstain from it.
('41', 24, 2, 4, 49915) Yours, MOHANDAS From a photostat of the Hindi: G.N. 6279

('41', 24, 6, 10, 50146) 30. LETTER TO CAPTAIN J. W. PETAVEL (CAMP) BALASORE, December 14, 1927
('41', 24, 7, 11, 50217) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter written on the train.
('41', 24, 7, 12, 50271) It is pathetic, for, though I believe that I have a most accommodating temperament, I see vital differences between us, where you seem to say only differences in mere matters of detail.
('41', 24, 7, 13, 50457) Our outlooks appear to me to be wholly different.
('41', 24, 7, 14, 50507) Whereas you have before your mind’s eye that microscopic minority, the educated Indian, I have before my mind’s eye the lowliest illiterate India living outside the railway beat.
('41', 24, 7, 15, 50686) Important as the former class undoubtedly is, it has no importance in my estimation except in terms of the latter and for the sake of the latter.
('41', 24, 7, 16, 50832) The educated class can justify its existence only if it is willing to sacrifice itself for the mass.
('41', 24, 7, 17, 50933) Your scheme therefore makes no appeal to me.
('41', 24, 7, 18, 50978) I have read Sir P. C. Ray’s preface and I have read the other writings you have been sending me; but though I admire these great men, they cannot move me from my fundamental position.
('41', 24, 7, 19, 51162) I want you therefore to recognize the fundamental difference between us and love me in spite of that difference if you can.
('41', 24, 7, 20, 51286) For my part, the existence of that difference does not prevent me from loving you and therefore writing to you as often as I can in reply to your communications and striving
('41', 25, 0, 1, 51460) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 25, 1, 2, 51501) to make clear the differences between our temperaments so that we may quickly agree to differ and hope one day that one or the other will become a convert.

('41', 26, 3, 8, 53391) 33. INDICTMENT
('41', 26, 4, 9, 53406) Do you agree that it is the primary duty of an ideal Government and more so of a Great Soul to put down the wicked and to protect the righteous?
('41', 26, 4, 10, 53551) If so, may we know how your political philosophy is consistent with this age long dictum?
('41', 26, 4, 11, 53641) Was not this the keynote of Shri Krishna’s preaching to Arjuna on the battle field of Kurukshetra?
('41', 26, 5, 12, 53740) Was this not the shrewd policy of the avataras 1, that brought about the dethronement of the renowned Bali, the destruction of Vali, and the annihilation of Jarasandha?
('41', 26, 6, 13, 53909) How can you expect ordinary mortals, and and that too large numbers at a time, to withstand the attacks of unscrupulous enemies without retaliation?
('41', 26, 6, 14, 54058) In view of the above, are we not justified in considering your emotional preachings and teachings as impracticable and not within the realization of ordinary persons?
('41', 26, 6, 15, 54225) Your temporary and piecemeal success in South Africa had been exaggerated greatly by your admirers, and the Indians of average intelligence, innocently (sheep like) following your lead, have been entangled in difficulties, not realizing that the parrallel of South Africa does not hold good in the case of a vast country of different languages and religious sections like India.
('41', 26, 6, 16, 54604) Have you not yourself realized, at the cost of the life interests of a large number of young patriots, that all your talk of “swaraj within a year” has proved vainglorious?
('41', 26, 6, 17, 54777) Don’t you admit that your somersault 2
('41', 26, 7, 18, 54816) in the Bardoli 3 affair caused much havoc to the people of Guntur who boldly and manfully withheld payment of taxes for a considerable period, 4 in pursuance of your programme?
('41', 26, 7, 19, 54993) May we know the net result of your participation in the Khilafat agitation
('41', 26, 8, 20, 55068) 1 Vaman, Rama and Krishna 2Vide “Speech on New Congress Creed, Nagpur”, December 28, 1920 and Appendix “Brahmin Non Brahmin Question”, November 24, 1927. 3 That is, suspension of satyagraha in Bardoli on February 12, 1922; vide “Working Committee’s Resolutions at Bardoli”, February 12, 1922. 4Vide “Note on Civil Disobedience in Guntur”, before February 10, 1922.
('41', 27, 0, 1, 55433) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 27, 1, 2, 55474) and the consequent playing of the Congress into the hands of a few fanatical Mussalmans?
('41', 27, 1, 3, 55563) Has not the Hindu Muslim unity of which you spoke and wrote so much, and in the name which you appealed to all Hindus to join their Mohammedan brethren in the hour of their trial, proved a veritable castle of cards, the moment the need of the Mohammedans was over?
('41', 27, 1, 4, 55828) Can you ever expect by your pious teachings to bring about any real unity between the bigoted and brave Mohammedans and caste ridden and timid Hindus?
('41', 27, 1, 5, 55979) Have you ever realized the fact that the communal feuds are increasing all the more, ever since you came into prominence in the Congress by virtue of your creed of non violence?
('41', 27, 2, 6, 56157) Will you not admit that Pandit Malaviya, C. R. Das, Lala Lajpat Rai, Vijayaraghavachariar, Kelkar, Dr. Moonje and other all India leaders were disgusted with your political philosophy, however much it might be garbed in the language of dharma?
('41', 27, 3, 7, 56401) Have you not recognized the leadership of that great soul Tilak at least at the beginning?
('41', 27, 3, 8, 56492) But how is it, you are today raking up intricate controversies of a social and religious character, to the detriment of the national cause?
('41', 27, 3, 9, 56632) Do you not realize that these tend only to accentuate dissensions all the more among the docile Hindus?
('41', 27, 3, 10, 56736) Are you not thereby indirectly playing into the hands of the enemies of our cause, whose one argument against us is that we are socially unfit for poliitcal freedom?
('41', 27, 4, 11, 56902) It is worthy on your part to set up and encourage Panchamas to enter the holy temples of caste Hindus for whom and by whom they were built exclusively?
('41', 27, 4, 12, 57054) Do you consider yourself to be a Trinetra (God Rudra) to set at naught those time honoured customs at one stroke?
('41', 27, 4, 13, 57168) Rcently, we are surprised to note that you have taken up the the cause of widows and boldly advised immature youths to marry widows.
('41', 27, 4, 14, 57301) Don’t you consider that Swami Vivekananda and others were prudent enough not to advocate widow marriage as they realized the the difficulties which confront us even in the case of the marriages of maids, as they are taking place today?
('41', 27, 4, 15, 57537) May we know how far it will help to create harmony by mixing up such highly controversial problems with the question of swaraj which is purely political and on which all of us are expected to make a united stand?
('41', 27, 5, 16, 57750) Your charkha cannot be popularized in this advanced age of science.
('41', 27, 5, 17, 57818) Don’t you think that you will do well, in the light of practical experience, to confine your activities to the field of labour organizations?
('41', 27, 6, 18, 57960) As a real believer in ahimsa dharma is it not your clear duty to refuse addresses from municipalities which are harbouring slaughter houses?
('41', 27, 6, 19, 58101) The foregoing is a condensation of a letter sent to me by a
('41', 28, 0, 1, 58161) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 29
('41', 28, 1, 2, 58202) correspondent while I was in Berhampur.
('41', 28, 1, 3, 58242) As I have reason to think that the correspondent has boldly voiced what many are harbouring in their breasts, I feel that the indictment deserves an answer.
('41', 28, 1, 4, 58399) It is hardly necessary to answer he questions in detail.
('41', 28, 1, 5, 58456) Many of us make the very serious mistake of taking literally what is accepted as scriptures, forgetting that the letter killeth and the spirit giveth life.
('41', 28, 1, 6, 58612) The Mahabharata and the Puranas are neither history nor simple religious maxims.
('41', 28, 1, 7, 58693) They appear to me to be wonderfully designed to illustrate the religious history of man in a variety of ways.
('41', 28, 1, 8, 58803) The heroes described therein are all imperfect mortals, even as we are—the difference being one of degree only.
('41', 28, 1, 9, 58915) Their alleged actions are not infallible guides for us.
('41', 28, 1, 10, 58971) The Mahabharata sums up its teachings by declaring emphatically that truth outweighs everything else on earth.
('41', 28, 1, 11, 59082) But I do no seek to justify everything written under the name of scriptures.
('41', 28, 1, 12, 59159) I take, as all to be true must take, the sum total of the effect produced on me by a prayerful reading of such books.
('41', 28, 1, 13, 59277) Thus I hold that my belief in truth and non violence is derived from and bases on the scriptural teaching of the very books from which the correspondent presents me with conundrums.
('41', 28, 1, 14, 59459) Nay more, my belief today having become part of my fundamental being is capable of standing independent of these books or any other Surely there must come a time in the life of a very religiously minded man when his faith must be self sustained.
('41', 28, 1, 15, 59705) Whatever therefore the avataras may be proved to have done or not done is of little moment to me.
('41', 28, 1, 16, 59803) My experience daily growing stronger and richer tells me that there is no peace for individuals or for nations without practising truth and non violence to the uttermost extent possible for man.
('41', 28, 1, 17, 59998) The policy of retaliation has never succeeded.
('41', 28, 1, 18, 60045) We must not be confounded by the isolated illustrations of retaliation, including frauds and force, having attained temporary and seeming success.
('41', 28, 1, 19, 60192) The world lives because there is more love than hate, more truth than untruth in it.
('41', 28, 1, 20, 60277) This is a proposition capable of being verified by everyone who will take the trouble to think.
('41', 28, 1, 21, 60373) Fraud and force are diseases, truth and non violence is health.
('41', 28, 1, 22, 60437) The fact that the world has not perished is an ocular demonstration of the fact that there is more health than disease in it.
('41', 28, 1, 23, 60563) Let us, then, who realize this, live up to the rules of health even in the midst of circumstances the most adverse.
('41', 28, 1, 24, 60679) My preaching and teaching are not emotional or unpractical, for I teach what is ancient and strive to practice what I preach.

('41', 29, 1, 2, 60846) claim that what I practise is capable of being practised by all, because I am a very ordinary mortal open to the same temptations and liable to the same weaknesses as the least among us.

('41', 38, 1, 16, 78538) A votary of ahimsa therefore continually strives to reduce the extent of himsa to a minimum.
('41', 38, 1, 17, 78631) Please tell me if you want me to return the manuscript of your book.
('41', 38, 2, 18, 78700) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('41', 38, 2, 19, 78722) K. S. KARANTH C/O, K. S. ACHARLU, M. A. TEACHER, DAVANGERE

('41', 39, 9, 16, 79726) CUTTACK, Silence Day [December 19, 1927] 3

('41', 39, 10, 20, 79960) I shall not do so now, but you may reopen the point when we meet.
('41', 39, 10, 21, 80026) As long as we retain an attraction for fineries in the deepest recesses of our heart, it is useless
('41', 39, 11, 22, 80126) 1Vide “Satyagraha in South Africa (Chapter XXII: Opposition and Assault)”.

('41', 40, 1, 2, 80412) to give up wearing them or adopt any other change just to imitate others who have given them up.
('41', 40, 1, 3, 80509) But if our infatuation for fineries passes off, and still the mind is drawn towards them, then we should make the necessary outward changes, whether through a sense of shame or by way of imitation of others, and ultimately root out this craving.

('41', 40, 1, 7, 81109) This refers to the hypocrite.

('41', 43, 0, 1, 84428) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 43, 1, 2, 84469) 52. TALKS TO KHADI WORKERS, CUTTACK 1
('41', 43, 2, 3, 84507) December 20, 1927 I The directors should be as vigilant and as jealous of the interests of their concern as the directors of the Bank of England, one of the greatest co operative corporations in the world.
('41', 43, 2, 4, 84713) But they have to be even more unselfish than they, inasmuch as the khadi company was not for exploitation, but for service of the poorest in the land.
('41', 43, 2, 5, 84864) Their ability lay in attention to the most minor details in mastering the science of spinning.
('41', 43, 2, 6, 84959) It is impossible for them to achieve any result unless they were expert spinners and expert organizers.
('41', 43, 2, 7, 85063) Some of the questions you have asked showed how unpractical you are.
('41', 43, 2, 8, 85132) Some of you want to know if I would have you put on loin cloth and to have a particular diet.
('41', 43, 2, 9, 85226) Well, I have no desire to regulate either your dress or diet.
('41', 43, 2, 10, 85288) What I want you to do is to realize the spirit of the movement and shape your life accordingly.
('41', 43, 2, 11, 85384) To you who want to serve Orissa I say, make Orissa a khadi depot for the whole of India.
('41', 43, 2, 12, 85473) And you cannot do so until all the spirit of rivalry goes out and all concentrate on production.
('41', 43, 2, 13, 85570) There can be no rivalry between khadi and khadi.
('41', 43, 2, 14, 85619) I can understand your objection to khadi from other provinces, but you should make no distinction between khadi produced in different parts of Orissa.
('41', 43, 2, 15, 85770) Concentrate on unifying your efforts and co ordinating your sales.
('41', 43, 2, 16, 85837) I heard the other day some young men talking of the development of agriculture.
('41', 43, 2, 17, 85917) If someone can prove to me that it is practicable and for the millions we have in view now, and can keep all the impoverished population from poverty and want, I will change my opinion about spinning.
('41', 43, 2, 18, 86118) But I warn you in the present conditions you will not be successful.
('41', 43, 2, 19, 86187) I have been working to build a model farm.
('41', 43, 2, 20, 86230) There are foolish friends to entrust me with money to indulge in experiment, and I squander money on them.
('41', 43, 2, 21, 86337) I had a talk with the late Sir Ganga Ram and supplied him with all the information about my lands, but he could not present me with a ready made workable plan
('41', 43, 3, 22, 86496) 1 These talks were delivered on 18th, 19th and 20th December, 1927. They are here reproduced under the date of the last talk.
('41', 43, 3, 23, 86622) Mahadev Desai says about these talks: “Advice to those who wanted to run a khadi joint stock company was on the lines to the Rajapalayam merchants”; vide “Speech at Khadi Vastralaya, Rajapalayam”, 4 10 1927.
('41', 44, 0, 1, 86830) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 45
('41', 44, 1, 2, 86871) to improve our agriculture.
('41', 44, 1, 3, 86899) I ask you to go to the villages and bury yourselves there, not as their masters or benefactors, but as their humble servants.
('41', 44, 1, 4, 87025) Let them know what to do and how to change their modes of living from your daily conduct and way of living.
('41', 44, 1, 5, 87133) Only feeling will be of no use just like steam which by itself is of no account unless it is kept under proper control when it becomes a mighty force.
('41', 44, 1, 6, 87284) I aks you to go forth as messengers of God carrying balm for the wounded soul of India.
('41', 44, 1, 7, 87372) II Do not be troubled by the question of the disposal of your production.
('41', 44, 1, 8, 87446) I could, if need be, disengage you from the obligation of selling.
('41', 44, 1, 9, 87513) Go on producing as much as you can.
('41', 44, 1, 10, 87549) There cannot be a better field for the production of khaddar than Orissa.
('41', 44, 1, 11, 87623) Only Orissa can make khaddar a proved proposition.
('41', 44, 1, 12, 87674) Intuitively of course it was a proved proposition to me in 1908, but you should demonstrate it practically.
('41', 44, 1, 13, 87782) Show to the world that you cannot exist without khadi.
('41', 44, 1, 14, 87837) Don’t derive your faith from me, but derive it from yourselves and then refuse to be moved even if Gandhi changes his faith.
('41', 44, 1, 15, 87962) Show to the people that they must work if they want more food, and the work can be none else than you can give them and on your terms.
('41', 44, 1, 16, 88097) Remember that you cannot go on indefinitely relying merely on the patriotism of the people.
('41', 44, 1, 17, 88189) You must produce khadi which is in quality superior to any other cloth.
('41', 44, 1, 18, 88261) I ask you to remember that unless the people understand that khadi is their only salvation, unless they feel that they cannot be without khadi, you cannot succeed.
('41', 44, 1, 19, 88425) Mind you, I am not conducting this campaign to bring about a boycott of foreign cloth for its own sake.
('41', 44, 1, 20, 88529) It is a necessary condition of our living, and an incident of our producing our own cloth if we must live.
('41', 44, 1, 21, 88636) Go then to the villages and become villagers.
('41', 44, 1, 22, 88682) The story that the schoolmaster revealed at Charbatia was an eye opener.
('41', 44, 1, 23, 88755) It was a typical village.
('41', 44, 1, 24, 88781) What a field of operation he has!
('41', 44, 1, 25, 88815) You can take charge of the village school, make the children flesh of your flesh and bone of your bone and work amongst the villagers through the children.
('41', 44, 1, 26, 88971) You will enter into their sorrows, ask them why they send their men to those pestilential hovels in Calcutta instead of working for their bread in their own homes.
('41', 44, 1, 27, 89135) Go and get into their homes, handle their wheels, their carding bows, show them their defects, see how they live, teach them the elementary principles of sanitation.
('41', 44, 1, 28, 89301) It is this spinning of a constructive type that can bring swaraj and it is in this land that the charkha can sing its finest music.
('41', 44, 1, 29, 89433) Make every village self contained, make every home produce and use its own khadi, and as for the
('41', 45, 0, 1, 89530) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 45, 1, 2, 89571) surplus khadi, take a written guarantee from me to sell it all if it is of standard quality.
('41', 45, 1, 3, 89664) Remember that only that worker will be worth his salt who makes the village he lives in self reliant.
('41', 45, 1, 4, 89766) The upshot of it all is the personal equation.
('41', 45, 1, 5, 89813) No learning is necessary, except learning in the school of love.
('41', 45, 1, 6, 89878) Have we workers honest, true, defiant, and burning with love of the country?
('41', 45, 1, 7, 89955) III One word, that I would like to leave with you, doubly afflicted people of this afflicted land, is that you will lose yourselves in the ocean of the submerged humanity about you.
('41', 45, 1, 8, 90137) Because it is submerged, the problem is simple.
('41', 45, 1, 9, 90185) The way is straight, even though it is narrow.
('41', 45, 1, 10, 90232) And you must treat it in the right and prayerful spirit.
('41', 45, 1, 11, 90289) We have been praying here for three days.
('41', 45, 1, 12, 90331) Prayer brings a peace, a strength and a consolation that nothing else can give.
('41', 45, 1, 13, 90411) But it must be offered from the heart.
('41', 45, 1, 14, 90450) When it is not offered from the heart, it is like the beating of a drum, or just the vocal effect of the throat sounds.
('41', 45, 1, 15, 90570) When it is offered from the heart, it has the power to melt mountains of misery.
('41', 45, 1, 16, 90651) Those who want are welcome to try its power.
('41', 45, 2, 17, 90696) Young India, 29 12 1927

('41', 49, 6, 12, 96606) 60. OUR SHAME AND THEIR SHAME
('41', 49, 7, 13, 96636) The long deferred Orissa visit has come to fill the bitter cup of sorrow and humiliation.
('41', 49, 7, 14, 96726) It was at Bolgarh, thirty one miles from the nearest railway station, that whilst I was sitting and talking with Dinabandhu Andrews on the 11th instant, a man with a half bent back wearing only a dirty loin cloth came crouching in front of us.
('41', 49, 7, 15, 96970) He picked up a straw and put it in his mouth and then lay flat on his face with arms outstretched and then raised himself, folded his hands, bowed, took out the straw, arranged it in his hair and was about to leave.
('41', 49, 7, 16, 97186) I was writhing in agony whilst I witnessed the scene.
('41', 49, 7, 17, 97240) Immediately the performance was finished, I shouted for an interpreter, asked the friend to come near and began to talk to him.
('41', 49, 7, 18, 97368) He was an untouchable living in a village six miles away, and being in Bolgarh for the sale of his load of faggots and having heard of me had come to see me.
('41', 49, 7, 19, 97526) Asked why he should have taken the straw in his

('41', 50, 1, 2, 97648) mouth, he said that was to honour me.
('41', 50, 1, 3, 97686) I hung my head in shame.
('41', 50, 1, 4, 97711) The price of honour seemed to me to be too great to bear.
('41', 50, 1, 5, 97769) My Hindu spirit was deeply wounded.
('41', 50, 1, 6, 97805) I asked him for a gift.
('41', 50, 1, 7, 97829) He searched for a copper about his waist.
('41', 50, 1, 8, 97871) “I do not want your copper, but I want you to give me something better,” I said.
('41', 50, 1, 9, 97952) “I will give it,” he replied.
('41', 50, 1, 10, 97982) I had ascertained from him that he drank and ate carrion because it was custom.
('41', 50, 1, 11, 98062) “The gift I want you to give me is a promise never again to take the straw in your mouth for any person on earth, it is beneath man’s dignity to do so; never again to drink because it reduces man to the condition of a beast, and never again to eat carrion, for it is against Hinduism and no civilized person would ever eat carrion.” “But my people will excommunicate me, if I do not drink and eat carrion,” the poor man said.
('41', 50, 1, 12, 98488) “Then suffer excommunication and if need be leave the village.” This downtrodden humble man made the promise.
('41', 50, 1, 13, 98598) If he keeps, it, his threefold gift is more precious than the rupees that generous countrymen entrust to my care.
('41', 50, 1, 14, 98712) This untouchability is our greatest shame.
('41', 50, 1, 15, 98755) The humiliation of it is sinking deeper.

('41', 51, 2, 23, 101675) 61. NOTHING TOO SMALL
('41', 51, 3, 24, 101697) A friend sends me for publication a charkha dialogue.
('41', 51, 3, 25, 101751) I am not printing it as I have discovered no plot about the story, but I gladly publish the following instructive verses the writer has quoted and put into the mouth of a little girl telling her little brother that they should begin to work the charkha for the sake of the poor even though they were youngsters :
('41', 51, 4, 26, 102064) Suppose the little cowslip Should hang its golden cup, And say, ‘I’m such a tiny flower,
('41', 52, 0, 1, 102153) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 53
('41', 52, 1, 2, 102194) ‘I’d better not grow up :’ How many a weary traveller Would miss its fragrant smell?
('41', 52, 1, 3, 102279) How many a little child would grieve To lose it from the dell ?
('41', 52, 2, 4, 102343) Suppose the glistening dewdrop Upon the grass should say, ‘What can a little dewdrop do?
('41', 52, 2, 5, 102432) ‘I’d better roll away :’ The blade on which it rested, Before the day was done, Without a drop to moisten it, Would wither in the sun.
('41', 52, 3, 6, 102567) Suppose the little breezes, Upon a summer’s day, Should think themselves too small to cool The traveller on his way : Who would not miss the smallest And softest ones that blow, And think they made a great mistake If they were talking so?
('41', 52, 4, 7, 102806) How many deed of kindness A little child may do; Although it has so little strength And little wisdom too.
('41', 52, 4, 8, 102913) It wants a loving spirit, Much more than strength, to prove How many things a child may do For others by his love.
('41', 52, 4, 9, 103028) These beautiful verses apply equally to many of us grown up people who talk no better than the little children in the imaginary story.
('41', 52, 4, 10, 103163) We may not excuse ourselves from sacrificial spinning on the flimsy excuse that it is too little to be of use.
('41', 52, 4, 11, 103274) Not for us thus to argue ourselves into laziness; ours is but to do our little best and leave to God to use it as He wills.

('41', 59, 9, 14, 112900) 73. SPEECH AT KHADI AND HINDI EXHIBITIONS, MADRAS
('41', 59, 10, 15, 112950) December 23, 1927
('41', 59, 11, 16, 112968) Mahatmaji, before declaring the Exhibition open, made a speech in English which was translated into Tamil by Mr. C. Rajagopalachari.
('41', 59, 11, 17, 113101) He said that it was a great privilege to be called upon to open the exhibitions.
('41', 59, 11, 18, 113182) He was not physically fit to raise his voice to such a pitch as to be heard by all.
('41', 59, 11, 19, 113266) He was not going to make a long speech and he was not able, in his present state of health, to address such a large
('41', 59, 12, 20, 113382) 1 From V. K. Sankara Menon, Manager, Pulaya Colony, Chalakudi, a colony run by the Depressed Classes Development Society.
('41', 59, 12, 21, 113504) He had invited Gandhiji’s suggestions and advice.
('41', 60, 0, 1, 113554) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 61
('41', 60, 1, 2, 113595) audience.
('41', 60, 1, 3, 113605) He need not dwell long on the necessity for khaddar for he was just returning from Utkal where he had seen with his own eyes emachiated men and women on account of starvation.
('41', 60, 1, 4, 113781) To such people khaddar would do an immense good.
('41', 60, 1, 5, 113830) If the people present at the meeting has seen those famished people of Utkal they would readily agree with him that khadi was the only thing that could save them from such a low condition.
('41', 60, 1, 6, 114019) Khadi was a movement in which Tamils and Telugus, and people of the north and south of India could take part without any distinction of caste or creed.
('41', 60, 1, 7, 114171) A visit to Utkal would make them instinctively support the khadi movement.
('41', 60, 1, 8, 114246) The khadi exhibition by the side of the industrial exhibition looked like an ant before an elephant.
('41', 60, 1, 9, 114347) In the bigger exhibition there were both foreign and indigenous articles.
('41', 60, 1, 10, 114421) In the khadi exhibition they would find only indigenous goods, hand spun and hand woven and there was no competition here, the only competition being ‘how shall I serve, how shall I serve best’.
('41', 60, 1, 11, 114616) In the khadi exhibition they would find goods manufactured by poor men and women and those goods must have given food to a number of poor people.
('41', 60, 1, 12, 114762) Manchester goods and Indian mill made goods went to enrich English and Indian capitalists, whereas khaddar provided food for the poorest labourers who had no other means of living.
('41', 60, 1, 13, 114943) The khadi movement had given food to seventy five thousand spinners scattered in 2,000 villages and also six thousand weavers lived by weaving khaddar cloth.
('41', 60, 1, 14, 115101) He had mentioned only spinners and weavers in connection with the movement and had not taken into consideration others engaged in printing, dyeing, etc., who were benefited by it.
('41', 60, 1, 15, 115281) In addition to these poor people about one thousand young men belonging to middle class had also taken up the khadi work.
('41', 60, 1, 16, 115403) Khadi would also give employment to the unemployed and solve the problem of unemployment among the middle classes which was agitating the minds of many.
('41', 60, 1, 17, 115556) Khadi would give work to the people of India—Brahmins and Non Brahmins, Hindus and Mussalmans and the so called untouchables.
('41', 60, 1, 18, 115682) Very soon they would go round the stalls to see the exhibits for themselves.
('41', 60, 1, 19, 115759) When they did so, he would ask them to go round the exhibition with a feeling of sympathy for the poor and to consider what amount of energy and time must have been spent upon those products by the poor people to earn something to keep body and soul together.
('41', 60, 1, 20, 116019) They would also find that the cost of the khaddar products was much reduced.
('41', 60, 2, 21, 116096) Next to the khadi exhibition, they would find the Hindi exhibition.
('41', 60, 2, 22, 116164) The Hindi movement was conceived in the interests of millions of Indians.
('41', 60, 2, 23, 116238) Hindi or Hindustani was spoken by 21 crores of people and it was the mother tongue of many Mussalmans.
('41', 60, 2, 24, 116341) It was the only language which could be inter provincial.
('41', 60, 2, 25, 116399) For some time past attempts had been made to propagate Hindi in South India.
('41', 60, 2, 26, 116476) The Hindi Prachar Sabha had been instituted and had been giving instruction in Hindi to a large number of people in the Tamil Nadu and Andhra Desha.
('41', 60, 2, 27, 116625) Many people in those two provinces had learnt Hindi and passed examinations.
('41', 60, 2, 28, 116702) The Hindi exhibitions was to have been opened by Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya but, he having not arrived, he (Mahatmaji)
('41', 61, 0, 1, 116822) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 61, 1, 2, 116863) had been asked to open the exhibition.
('41', 61, 1, 3, 116902) He would ask them to learn Hindi and would inform them that it could be learnt easily.
('41', 61, 1, 4, 116989) After learning it, they would find it a beautiful language.
('41', 61, 2, 5, 117049) With these words he declared the khadi and Hindi exhibitions open.

('41', 61, 7, 14, 117415) 75. THE INDRARAJ SPINNING WHEEL
('41', 61, 8, 15, 117447) In the issue of the Khadipatrika dated 1 12 27 Shri Harjivandas Kotak has written an article on the place that khadi occupies in Kashmir.
('41', 61, 8, 16, 117585) I would recommend the article to all lovers of khadi.
('41', 61, 8, 17, 117639) Its merit lies in Shri Harjivandas’s personal experience.
('41', 61, 8, 18, 117697) He has written the article after having observed things for himself during his stay in Kashmir.
('41', 61, 8, 19, 117793) Three facts become clear from this.
('41', 61, 8, 20, 117829) (1) The importance of the spinning wheel, (2) The place it still occupies in Kashmir, (3) The ruin of this invaluable industry in Kashmir.
('41', 61, 8, 21, 117968) We can get proofs of the value of the spinning wheel in the south in Nagercoil right up to Kanyakumari.
('41', 61, 8, 22, 118072) We get these right up to Assam in the east and we have now found them as far north as Kashmir.
('41', 61, 8, 23, 118167) In the west, we find them right up to Kathiawar.
('41', 61, 8, 24, 118216) I do not mention Karachi in the west because Karachi is a new city and, it is natural that people there being enamoured of wealth do not realize the value of the spinning wheel—although even there, because of the efforts of such lovers of khadi as the late Shri Ranchhoddas even up to this day, propaganda for the spinning wheel is being carried on in a
('41', 61, 9, 25, 118570) 1 This note follows M. K. Pandya’s article complaining that untouchables were forbidden to enter the temple of Ranchhodaraiji at Dakor and to bathe in the Gomati tank near the temple.

('41', 62, 2, 7, 119535) 76. WHAT SHOULD A HINDU WIDOW DO ?
('41', 62, 2, 8, 119570) A gentleman from Ajmer writes in Hindi to say : I wish you to answer the following questions of mine, in Navajivan : How should Hindu widows not wishing to remarry spend the rest of their lives?
('41', 62, 2, 9, 119765) Maharshi Dayanand has written to say that they should practise celibacy, educate themselves and also educate young girls.
('41', 62, 2, 10, 119887) Do you agree with this view?
('41', 62, 2, 11, 119916) If so, keeping in mind the present plight of our country, what would you like to add to this?
('41', 62, 2, 12, 120010) Maharshi Dayanand did not hold that all widows should spend their time in learning and teaching; this could only be by way of an example.
('41', 62, 2, 13, 120148) In this case teaching means imparting a knowledge of letters.
('41', 62, 2, 14, 120210) This knowledge is necessary to some extent; in my opinion, however, the more important teaching is how to stave off starvation.
('41', 62, 2, 15, 120338) And every day, I am more firmly convinced that this lies in the spinning wheel.
('41', 62, 2, 16, 120418) If we of the middle class who are educated, and who look upon ourselves as belonging to the higher castes give a thought to the condition of the poorer classes, nothing else but the spinning wheel will occur to us.
('41', 62, 2, 17, 120633) The spinning wheel will be plied mainly by women as it is primarily they who have time to spare.
('41', 62, 2, 18, 120730) Hence I have been crying from the house tops at various places, day and night, that
('41', 63, 0, 1, 120814) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 63, 1, 2, 120855) it is through them that we would prevent crores of rupees from being drained out of the country and secure true swaraj—Ramarajya 1. It is women who can readily approach others of their sex.
('41', 63, 1, 3, 121045) Here in the Province of Orissa where I happen to write this, and where even the poorer women observe purdah, who can set aside purdah and approach them?
('41', 63, 1, 4, 121198) I sent Mirabehn who has accompanied me to the women of a certain village.
('41', 63, 1, 5, 121272) About fifty women surrounded her and became crazy with joy they started asking her about many things and the spinning wheel came up for discussion.
('41', 63, 1, 6, 121420) These women were absolutely naive, simple and ignorant.
('41', 63, 1, 7, 121476) It is innumerable women of this type who should really be educated.
('41', 63, 1, 8, 121544) Widows with pure character can readily impart such education, serve their own interest and, at the same time, help India solve its problems.
('41', 63, 1, 9, 121685) Widows who are benevo lently inclined can easily learn this work and do justice to it.
('41', 63, 1, 10, 121772) However, an important prior condition for this is that they should be keen on going to villages and, while living there, should not get impatient.
('41', 63, 1, 11, 121919) A widow who takes the vow of celibacy is not a helpless, crippled individual.
('41', 63, 1, 12, 121997) If she is fit for self realization, she is a strong independent woman capable of protecting herself.
('41', 63, 1, 13, 122098) Compared with this, the education given to girls today is, I thing, of little consequence.
('41', 63, 1, 14, 122189) If however a widow refuses to go to the villages, idles away her time or, year after year, runs’ from one place of supposed pilgrimage to another, mistaking this for dharma, it is obviously better if she stayed even in the city and engaged herself in teaching children.
('41', 63, 1, 15, 122459) She has before her the vast field of nursing the sick.
('41', 63, 1, 16, 122514) Very few Hindu women take up the profession of nursing.
('41', 63, 1, 17, 122570) Widows in Maharashtra are found undergoing this training.
('41', 63, 1, 18, 122628) Outside Maharashtra, very few widows are prepared to undergo this training.
('41', 63, 1, 19, 122704) However, the jobs that I have suggested should also be regarded only as examples.
('41', 63, 1, 20, 122786) Every sensible widow who wishes to practise celibacy should seek out some useful activity for herself and devote her whole life to it.
