('41', 66, 3, 11, 126771) 82. RESOLUTION ON INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('41', 66, 4, 12, 126813) [December 27, 1927] 1
('41', 66, 5, 13, 126835) This Congress, while acknowledging the relief received by the Indian settlers in South Africa and regarding the signing of the Indo Union Agreement as a token of the desire of the Union Government to Accord better treatment to the Indian settlers, cannot be satisfied till the status of the settlers is brought on par with that of the enfranchised inhabitants of the Union and appeals to the Union Government to consolidate the goodwill created between the two countries by repealing all class legislation, especially the Colour Bar Act of 1926, the clause in the Liquor Bill of 1927 prohibiting the employment of Indians as waiters in hotels and the Municipal Land Alienation Ordinances or Natal in so far as the latter involve racial segregation.
('41', 66, 5, 14, 127584) This Congress places on record its sense of deep gratitude to Deenabandhu C.F. Andrews for his great and humanitarian work in South Africa and East Africa in connection with the status of the Indian settlers in those countries.
('41', 66, 6, 15, 127812) Report of the Forty second Indian National Congress at Madras, 1927, p.

('41', 66, 7, 17, 127926) Dr. M. A. Ansari, the President, moved it at the annual session of the Indian National Congress at Madras on 27 12 1927. The resolution was carried unanimously.

('41', 68, 1, 2, 129607) 85. POLITICAL PRISONERS
('41', 68, 2, 3, 129631) Lala Dunichand of Ambala has sent me a copy of the statement published by him in England about political prisoners who are undergoing incarceration in the various jails of India.
('41', 68, 2, 4, 129810) The statement contains nothing new for the Indian public and might easily have been fuller and more precise for the purpose intended by the author.
('41', 68, 2, 5, 129958) In a convering note he administers to me a gentle rebuke for rarely mentioning these prisoners.
('41', 68, 2, 6, 130054) If the absence of mention of these countrymen of ours means apathy or negligence on my part, the rebuke is well deserved.
('41', 68, 2, 7, 130176) But I claim that I yield to no one in my desire to see these prisoners released.
('41', 68, 2, 8, 130257) But the omission to mention these cases is deliberate.
('41', 68, 2, 9, 130312) I hope that the pages of Young India do not contain any idle words.
('41', 68, 2, 10, 130380) Whatever is written in these pages has a definite purpose.
('41', 68, 2, 11, 130439) Time was when I used to analyse these cases and expose the injustice done in many of them.
('41', 68, 2, 12, 130530) But that was when I had faith in the British system and when I used to take pride in its ultimate goodness.
('41', 68, 2, 13, 130638) Having lost that faith, I have lost also the power of making an effective appeal to the administrators of that system.
('41', 68, 2, 14, 130757) I can no longer write about British fair play and the British sense of justice.
('41', 68, 2, 15, 130837) On the contrary, I feel that the administrators are precluded by their system from dealing out fair play or justice when their system is or seems to them to be in jeopardy.
('41', 68, 2, 16, 131010) It is still possible, I admit, to secure justice from them when their system is not at stake in any shape or form.
('41', 68, 2, 17, 131125) But when that system is or is felt by them to be in danger they lose not only their sense of justice and fair play but they lose their balance and no means appear to them to be too dishonourable or despicable for adoption to sustain it.
('41', 68, 2, 18, 131362) Dyerism and O’Dwyerism 1 were no isolated phenomena.
('41', 68, 2, 19, 131415) Only I was blind to them before Jallianwala.
('41', 68, 2, 20, 131460) As a matter of fact, they have been resorted to in all climes and at all times whenever they have felt the need of them.
('41', 68, 2, 21, 131581) I am satisfied that the political prisoners who are held under restraint with or without trial, decorous or farcical, are so held in the interest of that system.
('41', 68, 2, 22, 131743) The administrators would far rather discharge a murderer caught red handed and found guilty of murder committed for private ends than discharge a political prisoner suspected of designs on their system, especially if he, the suspect, is believed to
('41', 68, 3, 23, 131992) 1 General Dyer and O’Dwyer were responsible for the massacre of Jallianwala Bagh in April 1919.
('41', 69, 0, 1, 132088) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 69, 1, 2, 132129) have violent means in view.
('41', 69, 1, 3, 132157) It seems to me therefore to be waste of time and inconsistent with respect to make any appeal to the administrators in behalf of the political prisoners Lala Dunichand has in view.
('41', 69, 1, 4, 132338) And he has in mind the prisoners of the Gadr party, the Punjab Martial Law prisoners and the Bengal detenus.
('41', 69, 1, 5, 132447) Nor need we be led astray by solitary discharges like that of Sjt.
('41', 69, 1, 6, 132514) Subhas Bose.
('41', 69, 1, 7, 132527) In spite of the agitation that was set on foot he would in all probability not have been discharged if his precarious health had not come to the rescue.
('41', 69, 1, 8, 132680) Indeed, have they not said in the plainest language possible that they were released purely on grounds of ill health?
('41', 69, 1, 9, 132798) Has not Earl Winterton 1 flatly declined to release the Bengal detenus in answer to the appeal to create a favourable atmosphere for their precious Statutory Commission?
('41', 69, 1, 10, 132968) Let those who still have faith in the system by all means make an appeal to the British sense of justice and fair play.
('41', 69, 1, 11, 133088) My course is clear.
('41', 69, 1, 12, 133108) We have not yet paid anything like adequate price for the freedom we would fain breathe.
('41', 69, 1, 13, 133197) I therefore regard these imprisonments as only a small part of the price we have to pay if we would have the freedom which is the birthright of man.
('41', 69, 1, 14, 133346) And we shall have to march as willing victims to the slaughter house and not helplessly like goats and sheep.
('41', 69, 1, 15, 133456) We may do this violently or non violently.
('41', 69, 1, 16, 133499) The way of violence can only lead us to a blind alley and must cause endless suffering to unwilling ignorant men and women who do not know what freedom is and who have no desire to buy the valuable article.
('41', 69, 1, 17, 133706) The way of non violence is the surest and the quickest way to freedom and causes the least suffering and that only to those who are prepared for it, indeed would gladly court it.
('41', 69, 1, 18, 133885) But suffering, intense, extensive and agonizing, there must be in every case.
('41', 69, 1, 19, 133963) What we have gone through is but a sample of what is to come.
('41', 69, 1, 20, 134025) Therefore the task before those, who share my views about the inherent evil of the system, is to cease to appeal to the administrators, and ceaselessly and with unquenchable faith in our cause and the means to appeal to the nation.
('41', 69, 1, 21, 134257) Not until the nation has developed enough strength to open the prison gates, can these prisoners be released with honour and dignity for it and them.
('41', 69, 1, 22, 134407) Till then let us with becoming patience and courage submit to the imprisonment of the prisoners and ourselves prepare joyfully to share their fate.
('41', 69, 1, 23, 134555) We shall certainly not hasten the advent of freedom by appealing to deaf ears
('41', 69, 2, 24, 134633) 1 Under Secretary of State for India
('41', 70, 0, 1, 134670) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 71
('41', 70, 1, 2, 134711) for mercy and thus unconsciously inducing in the people a mentality that would dread the prisons and the gallows.
('41', 70, 1, 3, 134825) Lovers of freedom have to learn to regard these as welcome friends and deliverers.
('41', 70, 1, 4, 134908) Young India, 29 12 1927
('41', 70, 2, 5, 134932) 86. INTERVIEW TO “INDIAN DAILY MAIL” BOMBAY December 30, 1927
('41', 70, 3, 6, 134994) In reply to a question by the interviewer as to which of the three draft constitutions 1 drawn up by the Madras leaders he considered best suited to India, Mr. Gandhi said that he had no decisive opinion about the future Constitution of India.
('41', 70, 3, 7, 135238) He, however, added : The Constitution of India is not a matter for a single individual to decide.
('41', 70, 4, 8, 135336) Seated in the midst of his friends and disciples, playing the inseparable charkha, Mr. Gandhi politely invited our representative to put questions to him.
('41', 70, 4, 9, 135491) “What are your impressions of the Madras Session of the Congress?”, was the first question by the interviewer.
('41', 70, 5, 10, 135602) ANSWER: The Madras Session was a unique one inasmuch as it seems to have laid the foundation of Hindu Muslim unity.
('41', 70, 5, 11, 135718) This, I say, not because of the quality of the resolutions, but because of the manner in which they were presented and accepted.
('41', 70, 5, 12, 135847) Pandit Malaviyaji’s happy speech and the still happier response made by Ali Brothers appeared to me to be a good augury for future.
('41', 70, 5, 13, 135979) I was not present when the scene of Maulana Mahomed Ali in ecstacy falling at Malaviyaji’s feet and Maulana Shaukat Ali fanning him after he had finished his great speech took place; but it was described to me by the President of the Congress.
('41', 70, 5, 14, 136223) It filled me with great joy and hope.
('41', 70, 5, 15, 136261) I hope this spirit of cordiality and mutual trust will prove infectious and we shall be able to find such trust amongst the rank and file.
('41', 70, 5, 16, 136400) Both Dr. Ansari and Mr. S. Aiyengar deserve the gratitude of the nation for this happy event.
('41', 70, 6, 17, 136494) Asked why he was not present when the Independence Resolution 2 was
('41', 70, 7, 18, 136562) 1 Submitted before the Madras Session of the Congress; the Working Committee was given power to confer with other bodies and place a revised draft before a Special Convention for approval.
('41', 70, 7, 19, 136751) 2 In a separate resolution, the Congress declared “the goal of the Indian people to be complete National Independence”.

('41', 71, 1, 2, 136912) discussed, Mr. Gandhi said that he was not expected to be present at any of the meetings of the Committee because of his health.
('41', 71, 1, 3, 137041) It was against the instruction of doctors and against the wishes of his friends that he had gone to Madras which he did only in order to help to the best of his ability Mr. Srinivasa Aiyengar and Dr. Ansari and to be available to them if at all it was necessary.

('41', 71, 1, 5, 137436) He never attended any of the Committee meetings except one informal meeting and attended the Congress at the opening only for a few minutes.
('41', 71, 2, 6, 137577) Our representative asked: “But is it true that you did not approve of the Independence Resolution?” ANSWER: That is an open secret.
('41', 71, 2, 7, 137709) But my disapproval of the Independence Resolution is based upon grounds that are not common to those who generally condemn the Independence Resolution.
('41', 71, 2, 8, 137861) I dealt with the subject last year when the Independence resolution was passed and I have given my reasons for my attitude towards it.
('41', 71, 2, 9, 137996) Let me, however, guard myself against any possible misunderstanding.
('41', 71, 2, 10, 138065) I do not for one moment consider that India is not fit for independence, or that she is not ripe for it.
('41', 71, 3, 11, 138170) Our representative next mentioned the death 1 of Hakim Ajmal Khan and Mr. Gandhi made the following statement : It is a great and grievous loss at this juncture.
('41', 71, 3, 12, 138332) Hakim Ajmal Khan was one of the truest servants of India and for the cause of Hindu Muslim unity he was one of the most invaluable men.
('41', 71, 3, 13, 138468) I can but hope that what we did not do and learn during his lifetime we shall now learn after and by his death.
('41', 71, 3, 14, 138580) If the accounts that have been published, viz., that Hindus took part in paying respect to the memory of the deceased in just as large numbers as the Mussalmans, are true, it is a very healthy sign and I hope that the spirit of brotherhood and friendliness that has been evoked in Delhi by his death will continue and become permanent and percolate throughout the length and breadth of the land.
('41', 71, 3, 15, 138976) For me the death of Hakimji is a deep personal loss.
('41', 71, 3, 16, 139029) I entirely associate myself with the appeal issued by Dr. Ansari and other leaders that the National Muslim University at Delhi which Hakimji nursed with very delicate care should be placed beyond any risk by patriotic Indians subscribing to the Fund that Hakimji was raising for putting its finances on a firm footing.
('41', 71, 3, 17, 139349) But, of course, the best monument to be raised to the memory of the great patriot would be to

('41', 72, 2, 4, 139624) 87. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI December 31, 1927
('41', 72, 3, 5, 139683) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I got both your letters.
('41', 72, 3, 6, 139729) I have now returned to the Ashram, and shall know, therefore, what letters arrive.
('41', 72, 3, 7, 139812) You gave at least one particular in your letter, and that was good.
('41', 72, 3, 8, 139880) I understand what you say about Sastriji.
('41', 72, 3, 9, 139922) You can boldly, but courteously, tell him what you may wish to.
('41', 72, 3, 10, 139986) You have given a good description of your conversation with him.
('41', 72, 3, 11, 140051) I certainly like the idea of closing the Durban Office.
('41', 72, 3, 12, 140107) Personally, I believe that, if the paper does not run on its own merit, we should not be too eager to continue it.
('41', 72, 3, 13, 140222) If it runs on its own merit, it should without difficulty run even from Phœnix.
('41', 72, 3, 14, 140302) Do not run it by incurring debts or simply for the sake of running it.
('41', 72, 3, 15, 140373) In this matter, at any rate, please do accept my advice.
('41', 72, 3, 16, 140430) If you find it difficult to stay there on this condition, both of you should return here.
('41', 72, 3, 17, 140520) Do not wait till it is too late.
('41', 72, 3, 18, 140553) You have not replied to what I said about the money you owe to the Ashram.
('41', 72, 3, 19, 140628) This is to remind you again.
('41', 72, 3, 20, 140657) And now to Sushila : Your letters are dull.
('41', 72, 3, 21, 140701) Manilal is justified in saying that, being very busy with work, he cannot write much, but you certainly ought to write.
('41', 72, 3, 22, 140821) If you have interest in life, you will find much to write about.
('41', 72, 3, 23, 140886) Sons and daughters fill sheets and sheets when writing to their parents about their happy and unhappy experiences, but your letters contain no more than a few lines.
('41', 72, 3, 24, 141052) Your physique does not seem yet to have become stronger.
('41', 72, 3, 25, 141109) If you wish, you may consult some doctor there.
('41', 72, 3, 26, 141157) Do anything, but get strong.
('41', 72, 3, 27, 141186) If you wish to return here, discuss the matter between you two.
('41', 72, 3, 28, 141250) So far as I am concerned, you have my permission.
('41', 72, 3, 29, 141300) It will also be for you to decide where you will live.
('41', 72, 3, 30, 141355) You may live either here or at Akola.
('41', 72, 3, 31, 141393) Think of me not as a father in law but as a father.
('41', 72, 3, 32, 141445) In order that you may be able to do some service, it is also your duty to take care of your body.
('41', 72, 3, 33, 141543) Do not neglect that duty.

('41', 78, 3, 4, 149107) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I feel that you love me too well to resent what I am about to write.
('41', 78, 3, 5, 149196) In any case I love you too well to restrain my pen when I feel I must write.
('41', 78, 3, 6, 149273) You are going too fast.
('41', 78, 3, 7, 149297) You should have taken time to think and become acclimatized.
('41', 78, 3, 8, 149358) Most of the resolutions you framed and got carried could have been delayed for one year.
('41', 78, 3, 9, 149447) Your plunging into the ‘republican army’ was a hasty step.
('41', 78, 3, 10, 149506) But I do not mind these acts of yours so much as I mind your encouraging mischief makers and hooligans.
('41', 78, 3, 11, 149610) I do not know whether you still believe in unadulterated non violence.
('41', 78, 3, 12, 149681) But even if you have altered your views, you could not think that unlicensed and unbridled violence is going to deliver the country.
('41', 78, 3, 13, 149814) If careful observation of the country in the light of your European experiences convinces you of the error of the current ways and means, by all means enforce your own views, but do please form a disciplined party.
('41', 78, 3, 14, 150029) You know the Cawnpore experiences.
('41', 78, 3, 15, 150064) In every struggle bands of men who would submit to discipline are needed.
('41', 78, 3, 16, 150138) You seem to be overlooking this factor in being careless about your instruments.
('41', 78, 3, 17, 150219) If I can advise you, now that you are the working secretary of the Indian National Congress, it is your duty to devote your whole energy to the central resolution, i.e., Unity, and the important but secondary resolution, i.e., boycott of the Simon Commission.

('41', 79, 3, 5, 151286) 98. IN MEMORIAM
('41', 79, 4, 6, 151302) In the death of Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan the country has lost one of its truest servants.
('41', 79, 4, 7, 151390) Hakim Saheb’s was a many sided personality.
('41', 79, 4, 8, 151434) He was not merely an able physician who practised his art as much for the rich as for the poor.
('41', 79, 4, 9, 151530) But he was a courtier patriot.
('41', 79, 4, 10, 151561) Though he passed his time among potentates, he was a thorough going democrat.
('41', 79, 4, 11, 151639) He was a great Mussalman and equally great Indian.
('41', 79, 4, 12, 151690) He loved equally Hindus and Mussalmans and was in turn equally respected and loved by both.
('41', 79, 4, 13, 151782) Hindu Muslim unity was the breath of his nostrils.
('41', 79, 4, 14, 151833) His later days were soured because of our dissensions.
('41', 79, 4, 15, 151888) But he never lost faith in his country or his people.
('41', 79, 4, 16, 151942) He felt that both the communities were bound in the end to unite.
('41', 79, 4, 17, 152008) Having that unchangeable faith, he never ceased to work for unity.
('41', 79, 4, 18, 152075) Though he took time, he finally threw in his lot with the non co operators and did not hesitate to put in peril his fondest and greatest creation, the Tibbia College.
('41', 79, 4, 19, 152242) He loved this College with a passion which only those who knew him well could realize.
('41', 79, 4, 20, 152329) In Hakimji I have lost not merely a wise and steadfast co worker, I have lost a friend on whom I could rely in the hour of need.
('41', 79, 4, 21, 152458) He was my constant guide in the matter of Hindu Muslim unity.
('41', 79, 4, 22, 152520) His judge ment, sobriety and knowledge of human nature enabled him for the most part to give correct decisions.
('41', 79, 4, 23, 152632) Such a man never dies.
('41', 79, 4, 24, 152655) Though he is no longer in the flesh with us, his spirit shall be ever with us and calls us even now to a faithful discharge of our duty.
('41', 79, 4, 25, 152792) And no memo rial that we can raise to perpetuate his memory can be complete until we have achieved real Hindu Muslim unity.
('41', 79, 4, 26, 152916) May God grant that we may learn to do through his death what we failed to do in his lifetime.
('41', 79, 4, 27, 153010) But Hakimji was no idle dreamer.
('41', 79, 4, 28, 153043) He believed in realizing his dream.
('41', 79, 4, 29, 153079) As he realized his dream about medicine through the Tibbia College, so he sought partially to realize his political dream through the Jamia Millia.
('41', 79, 4, 30, 153227) When this national university was almost on the point of dying, he, almost single handed, carried out a plan of removing the institution from Aligarh to Delhi.
('41', 79, 4, 31, 153387) But the removal meant more worry

('41', 81, 3, 3, 155800) The special feature of Dr. Ansari’s speech was its intense hunger for unity.
('41', 81, 3, 4, 155877) He knew that he was expected to bring it about.
('41', 81, 3, 5, 155925) And if any single person could do it, it was certainly Dr. Ansari.
('41', 81, 3, 6, 155992) He accepted the highest honour in the gift of the nation because he had confidence in the nation, the cause and himself.
('41', 81, 3, 7, 156113) He certainly left no stone unturned to achieve his ambition.
('41', 81, 3, 8, 156174) Stars favoured him.
('41', 81, 3, 9, 156194) Srinivasa Aiyengar helped him by his very recklessness.
('41', 81, 3, 10, 156250) No other president would perhaps have dared as he did after the partial failure at Simla.
('41', 81, 3, 11, 156340) But Sjt.
('41', 81, 3, 12, 156349) Aiyengar was not the man to shrink.
('41', 81, 3, 13, 156385) He took Dr. Ansari, the Ali Brothers, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and others with him and with his accustomed impetuosity carried his resolution.
('41', 81, 3, 14, 156527) He was not committed to any formula.
('41', 81, 3, 15, 156564) When the almost fatal flaw in the resolution about the cow and music was pointed out and a substitute submitted, he whole heartedly, frankly and generously admitted the flaw and accepted the substitute as a great improvement on the original.
('41', 81, 3, 16, 156806) The Mussalmans present rose to the occasion and, though not without some reluctance and hesitation at first, accepted the substitute without reserve.
('41', 81, 3, 17, 156956) Pandit Malaviyaji had come with the full intention of accommodating himself to the general wish so far as it was possible for him.
('41', 81, 3, 18, 157087) He knew and everybody realized that it was within his power to block the way.
('41', 81, 3, 19, 157165) He did not.

('41', 81, 3, 21, 157327) Pandit Malaviyaji is probably the oldest Congressman.

('41', 81, 3, 23, 157428) His patriotism is of the highest order.

('41', 82, 0, 1, 158237) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 83
('41', 82, 1, 2, 158278) better secured by Malaviyaji.
('41', 82, 1, 3, 158308) If there be one Hindu who can guarantee such protection on behalf of Hindus it is Malaviyaji.
('41', 82, 1, 4, 158402) But whether he can ‘deliver goods’ or not, I would like the Maulana and the other Mussalmans and all minorities once for all to renounce the idea of expecting or getting protection from a third party.
('41', 82, 1, 5, 158603) It were better, if such protection be not given voluntarily by the majority, to wrest it by force from unwilling hands than that a third party should be invited to intervene and should weaken and humiliate both and hold the nation under bondage.
('41', 82, 1, 6, 158849) The greatest contribution of the Congress then to me was this apparent change of heart.
('41', 82, 1, 7, 158937) So far as the vast mass of Hindus are concerned, they are interested only in the cow and music resolution.

('41', 82, 1, 14, 159617) A definite realization of the folly of fratricide and corresponding action will be the best and the most dignified answer to Lord Birkenhead’s insolent flaunting of British might in the nation’s face.
('41', 82, 1, 15, 159818) It is, therefore, profitable to examine the meaning of the Congress appeal.
('41', 82, 1, 16, 159894) I know what would spare the Hindus’ feeling in the matter of the cow.
('41', 82, 1, 17, 159964) It is nothing short of complete voluntary stoppage of cow slaughter by Mussalmans whether for sacrifice or for food.
('41', 82, 1, 18, 160081) The Hindu dharma will not be satisfied if some tyrant secured by force of arms immunity of the cow from the slaughter.
('41', 82, 1, 19, 160200) Islam in India cannot make a better gift to the Hindus than this voluntary self denial.
('41', 82, 1, 20, 160288) And I know enough of Islam to be able to assert that Islam does not compel cow slaughter and it does compel its followers to spare and respect to the full the feelings of their neighbours whenever it is humanly possible.
('41', 82, 1, 21, 160509) For me, music before mosques is not on a par with cow slaughter.
('41', 82, 1, 22, 160574) But it has assumed an importance which it would be folly to ignore.
('41', 82, 1, 23, 160642) It is for the Mussalmans to say what would spare Mussalman feelings.
('41', 82, 1, 24, 160711) And if complete stoppage of music before mosques will be the only thing that will spare the Mussalman feelings, it is the duty of the Hindus to do so without a moment’s thought.

('41', 84, 2, 14, 165072) THE ELEPHANT AND THE ANT

('41', 90, 6, 19, 176176) 107. DISCOURSES ON THE “GITA” 2
('41', 90, 7, 20, 176208) January 7, 1928
('41', 90, 8, 21, 176224) This chapter 3 is as sweet as the manner in which it has been sung.
('41', 90, 8, 22, 176292) It is balm for people like us who suffer from inner torments.
('41', 90, 8, 23, 176354) We are all troubled by evil desires, and the Lord holds out an assurance here to all those who seek refuge in Him that He will free them from such desires.
('41', 90, 8, 24, 176510) We can also see from this chapter that at the time when the Gita was composed, distinctions of high and low had already made their appearance in the varnashrama system and some had come to be regarded as lower than others.
('41', 90, 8, 25, 176733) In truth, however, can we describe anyone as higher or lower than others?
('41', 90, 8, 26, 176807) Let him who is completely free from evil desires point an accusing finger at another.
('41', 90, 8, 27, 176893) All of us are equal in this regard, and this chapter points out the unfailing means of winning freedom from evil cravings, namely, total surrender to the
('41', 90, 9, 28, 177047) 1 From the postmark 2Young India, 12 1 1928, and Navajivan, 15 1 1928, also carried reports of the discourses which were delivered on January 6 and 7. 3 IX
('41', 91, 0, 1, 177203) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 91, 1, 2, 177244) We should not of course conclude from this that such surrender will by itself, without further effort on our part, purify us of our evil.
('41', 91, 1, 3, 177382) If a person who is dragged by his senses, against his will, to objects of pleasures turns to God for help, with tears in his eyes, as he ceaselessly struggles against them, the Lord will certainly free him from the evil desires which trouble him.
('41', 91, 1, 4, 177629) Another thought also arises out of it, but we shall consider it tomorrow.
('41', 91, 1, 5, 177703) That thought is that this also explains the means of expiation of one’s sins.
('41', 91, 1, 6, 177781) Such expiation consists not in fasting, but in bhakti, in self surrender.
('41', 91, 1, 7, 177855) I fully understand the usefulness of fasting but there are also limits to it.
('41', 91, 1, 8, 177933) Fasting can never expiate a sin; it may, on the contrary, serve to cover it up.
('41', 91, 1, 9, 178013) A sinner is one who has committed a sin, but papayoni means one born of sin itself and therefore the most wicked of all sinners.
('41', 91, 1, 10, 178142) We cannot say to whom this notion first occurred, but everyone is assured of freedom through total surrender to the Lord.
('41', 91, 1, 11, 178264) Expiation of sin consists in bhakti.
('41', 91, 1, 12, 178301) Fasting may seem necessary sometimes as a means of filling the heart with bhakti, and everyone may decide for himself when it is so.
('41', 91, 1, 13, 178434) The real means, however, is bhakti, and bhakti means reducing oneself to a cipher, erasing the ‘I’.
('41', 91, 1, 14, 178534) If we can do this, no matter how many our sins in the past, they will not stand in the way of our freedom.
('41', 91, 1, 15, 178641) The thoroughly wicked mentioned in this chapter are none else but ourselves.
('41', 91, 1, 16, 178718) We, who commit all manner of sins in our hearts and move in the world as respectable people, are sinners, all of us, and in this chapter the Lord holds out an assurance to us.
('41', 91, 1, 17, 178894) Chapter XIV contains a description of the three gunas and Chapter XV a description of Purushottama 1. Thirty years ago I read Drummond’s 2 book in which he had established by means of several examples that the rules of the material world apply to the spiritual world also.
('41', 91, 1, 18, 179167) We see it proved in this world which is made of the three gunas.
('41', 91, 1, 19, 179232) There are not three gunas but many; those three are the major divisions of the many.
('41', 91, 1, 20, 179317) He who transcends those three becomes one with Purushottama.
('41', 91, 1, 21, 179378) None has been born in this world who could exist with only one guna.
('41', 91, 1, 22, 179447) Even if a man possesses a high degree of the sattvik guna, the latter still includes something of the gunas of tamas
('41', 91, 2, 23, 179564) 1 The Supreme Being 2 Dr. Henry Drummond, author of The Natural Law in the Spiritual World and The Greatest Thing in the World
('41', 92, 0, 1, 179691) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 93
('41', 92, 1, 2, 179732) and rajas.
('41', 92, 1, 3, 179743) The example of water occurs to me.
('41', 92, 1, 4, 179778) In the form of ice, it remains like a stone.
('41', 92, 1, 5, 179823) But when it boils and becomes steam, it rises in the sky.
('41', 92, 1, 6, 179881) As ice it lacks the capacity to rise, but as steam, it ascends higher and higher.
('41', 92, 1, 7, 179963) Its highest power appears in the form of steam.
('41', 92, 1, 8, 180011) And finally, ceasing to be steam, it becomes a cloud and benefits the world in the form of rain.
('41', 92, 1, 9, 180108) However, if steam becomes ice, it lies dead and still.
('41', 92, 1, 10, 180163) Ice too has its uses.
('41', 92, 1, 11, 180185) Melted ice flows in the form of rivers.
('41', 92, 1, 12, 180225) It also causes floods but we are not concerned with that.
('41', 92, 1, 13, 180283) It is a proven fact that without the sun, even water cannot turn into steam.
('41', 92, 1, 14, 180360) But that shows that it cannot do without someone else’s help.
('41', 92, 1, 15, 180422) The long and short of what I want to say is that steam points to a state of moksha.
('41', 92, 1, 16, 180506) It benefits the world in its state of moksha.
('41', 92, 1, 17, 180552) This is how we should understand the meaning of these two chapters.
('41', 92, 1, 18, 180620) [From Gujarati]
('41', 92, 2, 19, 180636) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('41', 93, 1, 2, 181289) 109. THE EFFICACY OF MUD In my book on health and hygiene 1 I wrote at length on the use of mud in treating ailments.Having read it, Shri Vithaldas Purushottam who has been giving a trial to this treatment writes to say : 2
('41', 93, 2, 3, 181513) On reading this, I asked him to enlighten me about his own experience whereupon he wrote the following letter 3 : The suggestions put forward in both these letters may be freely utilized in treating many ailments.
('41', 93, 2, 4, 181727) I am of the opinion that mud cannot be placed directly on the skin where there is an wound or the skin has peeled off.
('41', 93, 2, 5, 181846) It can certainly be applied in this manner on the lower part of the abdomen and those who do not benefit by using a pack of mud wrapped up in cloth may certainly place it directly over the skin.
('41', 93, 2, 6, 182041) Even at present, I am experimenting with mud in ordinary cases and am getting good results.
('41', 93, 2, 7, 182133) This remedy is so simple, inexpensive and so easy that everyone could make use of it within limits.
('41', 93, 2, 8, 182233) True, the treatment of placing mud on the abdomen can be carried out only on an empty stomach.
('41', 93, 2, 9, 182328) One should also remember that the mud should always be taken from a clean place.
('41', 93, 2, 10, 182409) Ice is used for headache or fever; in such cases, mud is generally more efficacious than ice.
('41', 93, 2, 11, 182503) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 8 1 1928

('41', 97, 1, 2, 187075) 116. LETTER TO NAJUKLAL N. CHOKSI
('41', 97, 2, 3, 187109) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Monday [January 10, 1928] 1
('41', 97, 3, 4, 187167) BHAISHRI NAJUKLAL, It is good that you have started the mud pack treatment.
('41', 97, 3, 5, 187243) After moistening the earth once, you need not do it again.
('41', 97, 3, 6, 187302) If the pack dries up and if it is still necessary to continue the application, you may prepare another pack.
('41', 97, 3, 7, 187411) If the pack is about an inch thick, it does not dry up.
('41', 97, 3, 8, 187467) A pack applied on the stomach at night remains damp the whole night.
('41', 97, 3, 9, 187536) One applied on the head during the noon is likely to dry up.
('41', 97, 3, 10, 187597) Never put a pack on the stomach during the day, because the process of digestion is going on then.
('41', 97, 3, 11, 187696) My experience about fragrant, i.e., clean red earth is good, but you may use black earth if you can get only that.
('41', 97, 3, 12, 187811) The only thing is that it should be clean.
('41', 97, 3, 13, 187854) You should be careful about two things only as regards blood pressure.
('41', 97, 3, 14, 187925) You should not overwork either physically or mentally, and the motion must always be clear.
('41', 97, 3, 15, 188017) If you do not have a clear motion every day, take an enema or a laxative.
('41', 97, 3, 16, 188091) Never strain.
('41', 97, 3, 17, 188105) Eat very light food.
('41', 97, 3, 18, 188126) One need not worry about blood pressure at all, if there is no other complaint.
('41', 97, 3, 19, 188206) Since, however, you have had an attack of paralysis, you should certainly be careful.
('41', 97, 3, 20, 188292) In addition to what you are doing, you may certainly take the injections, if advised by the doctor, since they have helped you.
('41', 97, 3, 21, 188420) The headache should certainly be cured by the mud pack.
('41', 97, 3, 22, 188476) Even for this purpose, however, the stomach should be light.
('41', 97, 3, 23, 188537) Prabodh seems to be a very fine boy.
('41', 97, 3, 24, 188574) May God fulfil all our hopes about him.

('41', 100, 5, 8, 191506) 121. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('41', 100, 6, 9, 191538) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 11, 1928
('41', 100, 7, 10, 191585) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL, You letter.

('41', 101, 2, 3, 192522) [Before January 12, 1928] I have to give you this evening an instance of a folly of which three of us have an equal share.

('41', 101, 3, 9, 193171) So he asked one of us to put something there as a screen.
('41', 101, 3, 10, 193229) This friend asked another who immediately brought in the carpenter with a board.
('41', 101, 3, 11, 193310) He naturally thought a shutter would be better than a screen, and asked if Gandhiji would like it.
('41', 101, 3, 12, 193409) Gandhiji agreed, but soon after the carpenter began his work, he seemed to have perceived that he had not done the right thing.
('41', 101, 3, 13, 193537) Now this is not what we who are pledged to poverty may do.
('41', 101, 3, 14, 193596) It ought to have occurred to me that a piece of cardboard or a piece of cloth would serve as well as this shutter which costs a couple of rupees and three hours’ labour for the carpenter.
('41', 101, 3, 15, 193784) The cardboard or the piece of old cloth would have cost nothing and anyone could have fixed it there with a couple of nails.
('41', 101, 3, 16, 193909) It is in these simple little things that our creed is tested.

('41', 102, 3, 10, 195272) SABARMATI, [Before January 12, 1928] This talk of passive non resistance has been the bane of our national life.
('41', 102, 3, 11, 195385) Forgiveness is a quality of the soul, and therefore a positive quality.
('41', 102, 3, 12, 195457) It is not negative.
('41', 102, 3, 13, 195477) “Conquer anger,” says Lord Buddha, “by non anger.” But what is that “non anger”?

('41', 102, 3, 15, 195632) You must be roused to this supreme virtue which must express itself in your going to the angry man, ascertaining from him the cause of his anger, making amends if you have given any cause for offence and then bringing home to him the error of his way and convincing him that it is wrong to be provoked.
('41', 102, 3, 16, 195935) This consciousness of the quality of the soul, and deliberate exercise of it, elevate not only the man but the surrounding atmosphere.

('41', 103, 1, 2, 197339) 125. INDEPENDENCE v.
('41', 103, 2, 3, 197360) It is said that the Independence Resolution is a fitting answer to Lord Birkenhead.
('41', 103, 2, 4, 197444) If this be a serious contention, we have little notion of the answer that we should make to the appointment of the Statutory Commission and the circumstances attending the announcement of the appointment.
('41', 103, 2, 5, 197649) The act of appointment needs, for an answer, not speeches, however heroic they may be, not declarations, however brave they may be, but corresponding action adequate to the act of the British Minister, his colleagues and his followers.
('41', 103, 2, 6, 197885) Supposing the Congress had passed no resolution whatsoever, but had just made a bonfire of every yard of foreign cloth in its possession, and induced a like performance on the part of the whole nation, it would have been some answer, though hardly adequate, to what the act of appointment means.
('41', 103, 2, 7, 198181) If the Congress could have brought about a strike of every Government employee beginning with the Chief Judges and ending with the petty peons, not excluding soldiers, that act would have been a fairly adequate answer.
('41', 103, 2, 8, 198400) It would certainly have disturbed the comfortable equanimity with which the British ministers and those concerned are looking upon all our heroics.
('41', 103, 2, 9, 198548) It may be said this is merely a counsel of perfection which I should know is not capable of execution.
('41', 103, 2, 10, 198651) I do not hold that view.
('41', 103, 2, 11, 198676) Many Indians who are not speaking today are undoubtedly preparing in their own manner for the happy day when every Indian, now sustaining the system of Government which holds the nation in bondage, will leave the denationalizing service.
('41', 103, 2, 12, 198914) It is contended that it is courage, it is undoubtedly wisdom, to restrain the tongue whilst one is unprepared for action.
('41', 103, 2, 13, 199036) Mere brave speech without action is letting off useless steam.
('41', 103, 2, 14, 199099) And the strongest speech shed its bravery when, in 1920, patriots learnt to court imprisonment for strong speeches.
('41', 103, 2, 15, 199215) Speech is necessary for those who are dumbstruck.
('41', 103, 2, 16, 199265) Restraint is necessary for the garrulous.
('41', 103, 2, 17, 199307) The English administrators chaff us for our speech and occasionally betray by their acts their contempt of our speeches and thereby tell us more effecti vely than by words: ‘Act if you dare.’ Till we can take up the challenge, every single threatening speech or gesture of ours is, in my opinion, a humiliation, and admission of impotence.
('41', 103, 2, 18, 199647) I have seen prisoners in chains spitting forth oaths only to provide mirth for their jailors.
('41', 103, 2, 19, 199741) Moreover, has independence suddenly become a goal in answer
('41', 104, 0, 1, 199801) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 105
('41', 104, 1, 2, 199843) to something offensive that some Englishman has done?
('41', 104, 1, 3, 199897) Do men conceive their goals in order to oblige people or to resent their action?
('41', 104, 1, 4, 199978) I submit that, if it is a goal, it must be declared and pursued irrespective of the acts or threats of others.
('41', 104, 1, 5, 200089) Let us, therefore, understand what we mean by indepen dence.
('41', 104, 1, 6, 200150) England, Russia, Spain, Italy, Turkey, Chile, Bhutan have all their independence.
('41', 104, 1, 7, 200232) Which independence do we want?
('41', 104, 1, 8, 200263) I must not be accused of begging the question.
('41', 104, 1, 9, 200310) For, if I were told that it is Indian independence that is desired, it is possible to show that no two persons will give the same definition.
('41', 104, 1, 10, 200452) The fact of the matter is that we do not know our distant goal.
('41', 104, 1, 11, 200516) It will be determined not by our definitions but by our acts, voluntary and involuntary.
('41', 104, 1, 12, 200605) If we are wise, we will take care of the present and the future will take care of itself.
('41', 104, 1, 13, 200695) God has given us only a limited sphere of action and a limited vision.
('41', 104, 1, 14, 200766) Sufficient unto the day is the good thereof.
('41', 104, 1, 15, 200811) I submit that swaraj is an all satisfying goal for all time.
('41', 104, 1, 16, 200872) We the English educated Indians often unconsciously make the terrible mistake of thinking that the microscopic minority of English speaking Indians is the whole of India.
('41', 104, 1, 17, 201043) I defy anyone to give for independence a common Indian word intelligible to the masses.
('41', 104, 1, 18, 201131) Our goal at any rate may be known by an indigenous word understood of the three hundred millions.
('41', 104, 1, 19, 201229) And we have such a word in ‘swaraj’ first used in the name of the nation by Dadabhai Naoroji.
('41', 104, 1, 20, 201323) 1 It is infinitely greater than and includes independence.
('41', 104, 1, 21, 201382) It is a vital word.
('41', 104, 1, 22, 201402) It has been sanctified by the noble sacrifices of thousands of Indians.
('41', 104, 1, 23, 201474) It is a word which, if it has not penetrated the remotest corner of India, has at least got the largest currency of any similar word.
('41', 104, 1, 24, 201608) It is a sacrilege to displace that word by a foreign importation of doubtful value.
('41', 104, 1, 25, 201692) This Independence Resolution is perhaps the final reason for conducting Congress proceedings in Hindustani and that alone.
('41', 104, 1, 26, 201815) No tragedy like that of the Independence Resolution would then have been possible.
('41', 104, 1, 27, 201898) The most valiant speakers would then have ornamented the native meaning of the word ‘swaraj’ and attempted all kinds of definitions, glorious and inglorious.
('41', 104, 1, 28, 202056) Would that the independents would profit by their experience and resolve henceforth to work among the masses for whom they desire freedom and taboo English speech in its entirety in so far as mass meetings such as the Congress are concerned.

('41', 105, 1, 2, 202480) Personally, I crave not for ‘independence’, which I do not understand, but I long for freedom from the English yoke.
('41', 105, 1, 3, 202597) I would pay any price for it.

('41', 105, 1, 13, 203384) In order to protect its immoral commerce, this rule regards no means too mean, and in order to keep three hundred millions under the heels of a hundred thousand, it carries a military expenditure which is keeping millions in a state of semi starvation and polluting thousands of mouths with intoxicating liquor.
('41', 105, 1, 14, 203696) But my creed is non violence under all circumstances.

('41', 105, 1, 16, 203844) I know that method to be infallible.

('41', 105, 1, 18, 203997) People generally do not understand the philosophy of all their acts.
('41', 105, 1, 19, 204066) My ambition is much higher than independence.
('41', 105, 1, 20, 204112) Through the deliverance of India, I seek to deliver the so called weaker races of the earth from the crushing heels of Western exploitation in which England is the greatest partner.
('41', 105, 1, 21, 204294) If India converts, as it can convert, Englishmen, it can become the predominant partner in a world commonwealth of which England can have the privilege of becoming a partner if she chooses.
('41', 105, 1, 22, 204484) India has the right, if she only knew, of becoming the predominant partner by reason of her numbers, geographical position and culture inherited for ages.
('41', 105, 1, 23, 204639) This is big talk, I know.
('41', 105, 1, 24, 204665) For a fallen India to aspire to move the world and protect weaker races is seemingly an impertinence.

('41', 105, 1, 26, 204883) Mine is an ambition worth living for and worth dying for.
('41', 105, 1, 27, 204941) In no case do I want to reconcile myself to a state lower than the best for fear of consequences.
('41', 105, 1, 28, 205039) It is, therefore, not out of expedience that I oppose independence as my goal.
('41', 105, 1, 29, 205118) I want India to come to her own and that state cannot be better

('41', 106, 3, 7, 205502) I am enclosing herewith a cutting from the Sind Observer of Karachi wherein you will find your name among others used in support of medicines sought to be popularized and sold through the medium of such advertisements.
('41', 106, 4, 8, 205721) I can hardly believe you could have spoken or written appreciatively of the medicines, mixtures, pills or potions of the pharmacy in question.

('41', 106, 5, 11, 205956) It is taking an unlawful liberty with my name and, I doubt not, the names of other leaders.
('41', 106, 5, 12, 206048) It is remarkable the freedom these pharmacies take in order to find custom for their wretched traffic.
('41', 106, 5, 13, 206151) In my opinion this use of names of persons without their permission is an illegality punishable in law.
('41', 106, 5, 14, 206255) Since, as a non co operator, I may not seek the protection of the law, I must be satisfied with warning the public against being misled by the use of my name in connection with any drug whatsoever.
('41', 106, 5, 15, 206453) My disbelief in drugs in general is as strong as ever notwithstanding the very limited use by me in recent times of one or two comparatively harmless and well known opening drugs and quinine.
('41', 106, 5, 16, 206645) I have no desire to see pharmacies multiplied in this country, I would rather see people freed from the slavery of drugs.

('41', 111, 1, 2, 214929) 133. DISCUSSION ON FELLOWSHIP 1
('41', 111, 2, 3, 214961) [Before January 15, 1928] In order to attain a perfect fellowship, every act of its members must be a religious act and an act of sacrifice.
('41', 111, 2, 4, 215102) I came to the conclusion long ago, after prayerful search and study and discussion with as many people as I could meet, that all religions were true and also that all had some error in them, and that whilst I hold by my own, I should hold others as dear as Hinduism, from which it logically follows that we should hold all as dear as our nearest kith and kin and that we should make no distinction between them.
('41', 111, 2, 5, 215514) So we can only pray, if we are Hindus, not that a Christian should become a Hindu, or if we are mussalmans, not that a Hindu or a Christian should become a Mussalman, nor should we even secretly pray that anyone should be converted, but our inmost prayer should be that a Hindu should be a better Hindu, a Muslim a better Muslim and a Christian a better Christian.
('41', 111, 2, 6, 215879) That is the fundamental truth of fellowship.
('41', 111, 2, 7, 215924) That is the meaning of the wonderful passion, the story of which Andrews read out to you, of the song and verses that Khare, Shastri and Imam Saheb recited.
('41', 111, 2, 8, 216081) If Andrews invited them to give their song and verses for mere courtesy or by way of patronizing toleration, he was false to the fellowship.
('41', 111, 2, 9, 216222) In that case, he should not have done so, but I have known Charlie Andrews too well, and I know that he has given the same love to others as he has for his own, and thereby broadened his Christianity, as I broaden my Hinduism by loving other religions as my own.
('41', 111, 2, 10, 216485) If however there is any suspicion in your minds that only one religion can be true and others false, you must reject the doctrine of fellowship placed before you.
('41', 111, 2, 11, 216648) Then we would have a continuous process of exclusion and found our fellowship on an exclusive basis.
('41', 111, 3, 12, 216749) 1 Members of the Council of International Federation and their friends stayed in the Ashram and held discussions on “the fundamental objective of the fellowship”.
('41', 111, 3, 13, 216912) Mahadev Desai in his article “The Week” under the caption “The Foundation of Fellowship” records: “The discussion lasted for two days .
('41', 111, 3, 14, 217048) It led to a free and frank exchange of views ultimately bound to establish a better understanding.
('41', 111, 3, 15, 217147) There was no difference of opinion as to the object of all to work for the widest toleration, to combine and side with the forces of light against the forces of darkness, or as Deenabandhu Andrews said, those who blankly leave God out and become materialists.
('41', 111, 3, 16, 217407) Everyone seemed to be agreed on this, but many seemed to run away from what would appear to be the necessary corollary of the proposition.
('41', 111, 3, 17, 217546) This was defined by Gandhiji at some length at this and other meetings.
('41', 112, 0, 1, 217618) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 113
('41', 112, 1, 2, 217660) Above all I plead for utter truthfulness.
('41', 112, 1, 3, 217702) If we do not feel for other religions as we feel for our own, we had better disband ourselves, for we do not want a wishy washy toleration.
('41', 112, 1, 4, 217842) My doctrine of toleration does not include toleration of evil, though it does the toleration of the evil minded.
('41', 112, 1, 5, 217955) It does not therefore mean that you have to invite each and every one who is evil minded or tolerate a false faith.
('41', 112, 1, 6, 218071) By a true faith I mean one the sum total of whose energy is for the good of its adherents, by a false I mean that which is predominantly false.
('41', 112, 1, 7, 218215) If you, therefore, feel that the sum total of Hinduism has been bad for the Hindus and the world, you must reject it as a false faith.
('41', 112, 2, 8, 218350) Gandhiji’s insistence on a member of the fellowship not even secretly wishing that a member of another faith should be converted to his own led to a general discussion on the question of conversion.
('41', 112, 2, 9, 218549) Gandhiji again defined his position more clearly than before : I would not only not try to convert but would not even secretly pray that anyone should embrace my faith.
('41', 112, 2, 10, 218718) My prayer would always be that Imam Saheb should be a better Mussalman, or become the best he can.
('41', 112, 2, 11, 218817) Hinduism with its message of ahimsa is to me the most glorious religion in the world—as my wife to me is the most beautiful woman in the world—but others may feel the same about their own religion.
('41', 112, 2, 12, 219015) Cases of real honest conversion are quite possible.
('41', 112, 2, 13, 219067) If some people for their inward satisfaction and growth change their religion, let them do so.
('41', 112, 2, 14, 219162) As regards taking our message to the aborigines, I do not think I should go and give my message out of my own wisdom.
('41', 112, 2, 15, 219280) Do it in all humility, it is said.
('41', 112, 2, 16, 219315) Well, I have been an unfortunate witness of arrogance often going in the garb of humility.
('41', 112, 2, 17, 219406) If I am perfect, I know that my thought will reach others.
('41', 112, 2, 18, 219465) It taxes all my time to reach the goal I have set to myself.
('41', 112, 2, 19, 219526) What have I to take to the aborigines and the Assamese hillmen except to go in my nakedness to them?
('41', 112, 2, 20, 219627) Rather than ask them to join my prayer, I would join their prayer.
('41', 112, 2, 21, 219694) We were strangers to this sort of classification—“animists”, “aborigines”, etc.,—but we have learnt it from English rulers.
('41', 112, 2, 22, 219818) I must have the desire to serve and it must put me right with people.
('41', 112, 2, 23, 219888) Conversion and service go ill together.
('41', 112, 3, 24, 219928) The next day early morning the friends met for an an informal conversation with Gandhiji when again the same question was asked by many of them.
('41', 112, 3, 25, 220073) “Would you have a ruling of such a character that those who had a desire to convert should not be eligible for membership?” Personally, I think they should not be eligible.
('41', 112, 3, 26, 220246) I should have framed a resolution to that effect as I regard it as the logical outcome
('41', 113, 0, 1, 220333) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 113, 1, 2, 220375) of fellowship.
('41', 113, 1, 3, 220390) It is essential for inter religious relationship and contact.
('41', 113, 2, 4, 220452) “Is not the impulse to proselytize God given?”, inquired another friend.
('41', 113, 2, 5, 220525) I question it.
('41', 113, 2, 6, 220540) But if all impulses are God given, as some of our Hindus believe, He has also given us discrimination.
('41', 113, 2, 7, 220643) He will say, ‘I have given you many impulses so that your capacity to face temptation may be tested.’
('41', 113, 3, 8, 220745) “But you do believe in preaching an economic order?”, inquired one of the fair sex.
('41', 113, 3, 9, 220829) I do, as I believe in preaching laws of health.
('41', 113, 4, 10, 220877) Then why not apply the same rule in religious matters?
('41', 113, 4, 11, 220932) It is a relevant question.
('41', 113, 4, 12, 220959) But you must not forget that we have started with the fundamental principle that all religions are true.
('41', 113, 4, 13, 221064) If there were different but good and true health laws for different communities, I should hesitate to preach some as true and some as false.
('41', 113, 4, 14, 221205) I am positive that, with people not prepared to tolerate one another’s religious belief, there can be no international fellowship.
('41', 113, 4, 15, 221336) Moreover, physical analogies when applied to spiritual matters are good only up to a certain point.
('41', 113, 4, 16, 221436) When you take up an analogy from Nature, you can stretch it only to a certain point.
('41', 113, 4, 17, 221521) But I would take an illustration from the physical world and explain what I mean.
('41', 113, 4, 18, 221603) If I want to hand a rose to you, there is definite movement.
('41', 113, 4, 19, 221664) But if I want to transmit its scent, I do so without any movement.
('41', 113, 4, 20, 221731) The rose transmits its own scent without a movement.
('41', 113, 4, 21, 221784) Let us rise a step higher, and we can understand that spiritual experiences are self acting.
('41', 113, 4, 22, 221877) Therefore, the analogy of preaching sanitation, etc., does not hold good.
('41', 113, 4, 23, 221951) If we have spiritual truth, it will transmit itself.
('41', 113, 4, 24, 222004) You talk of the joy of a spiritual experience and say you cannot but share it.
('41', 113, 4, 25, 222083) Well, if it is real joy, boundless joy, it will spread itself without the vehicle of speech.
('41', 113, 4, 26, 222176) In spiritual matters we have merely to step out of the way.
('41', 113, 4, 27, 222236) Let God work His way.
('41', 113, 4, 28, 222258) If we interfere, we may do harm.
('41', 113, 4, 29, 222291) Good is a self acting force.
('41', 113, 4, 30, 222320) Evil is not, because it is negative force.
('41', 113, 4, 31, 222363) It requires the cloak of virtue before it can march forward.
('41', 113, 5, 32, 222424) Did not Jesus Himself teach and preach?
('41', 113, 5, 33, 222464) We are on dangerous ground here.
('41', 113, 5, 34, 222497) You ask me to give any interpretation of the life of Christ.
('41', 113, 5, 35, 222558) Well, I may say that I do not accept
('41', 114, 0, 1, 222595) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 115
('41', 114, 1, 2, 222637) everything in the gospels as historical truth.
('41', 114, 1, 3, 222684) And it must be remembered that he was working amongst his own people, and said he had not come to destroy but to fulfil.
('41', 114, 1, 4, 222805) I draw a great distinction between the Sermon on the Mount and the Letters of Paul.
('41', 114, 1, 5, 222889) They are a graft on Christ’s teaching, his own gloss apart from Christ’s own experience.

('41', 116, 4, 13, 225823) 137. SPEECH AT CONVOCATION OF GUJARAT VIDYAPITH January 15, 1928 Deenabandhu Andrews 1 is not only a good Englishman who has sacrificed everything for this country; he is also an artist, poet and fluent orator.
('41', 116, 4, 14, 226034) Those who have studied his speeches and his deeds can realize that there is art in whatever he does.
('41', 116, 4, 15, 226135) He is a poet because he understands what the future should be and what it may be.
('41', 116, 4, 16, 226217) He is a fluent orator, not because he can speak volubly or because his style and pronunciation are excellent, but because all his words flow from his heart.
('41', 116, 4, 17, 226374) One may form a certain impression on reading his speeches, but they must have made a different impression on his immediate listeners.
('41', 116, 4, 18, 226508) Ordinarily we take it that one who can speak continuously for hours together is a fluent orator.
('41', 116, 4, 19, 226605) Some may think that Mr. Andrews read out a written speech because he could not speak extempore.
('41', 116, 4, 20, 226701) But it would be foolish to think so.
('41', 116, 4, 21, 226738) He made his written speech so interesting that we got completely engrossed in it.
('41', 116, 4, 22, 226820) It was so absorbingly interesting because his speech came straight from his heart.
('41', 116, 4, 23, 226903) He referred in his speech to the late Hakim Saheb.
('41', 116, 4, 24, 226954) On a superficial view one may wonder what a convocation address has to do with the death of Hakim Saheb; reference to it would show a lack of artistic sense!
('41', 116, 4, 25, 227112) I feel that in this very thing he has revealed his artistic skill and has achieved his aim.
('41', 116, 4, 26, 227204) Andrews is quite old compared to you.
('41', 116, 5, 27, 227242) 1 C. F. Andrews delivered the convocation address.
('41', 117, 0, 1, 227293) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 117, 1, 2, 227335) He talked about his childhood.
('41', 117, 1, 3, 227366) He spoke of the beginning of his training under Hakim Saheb.
('41', 117, 1, 4, 227427) Hakim Saheb had become a well known physician, and used to serve the rich and the poor through his knowledge of medicine; then it was that Andrews realized that he was taking training from him.
('41', 117, 1, 5, 227621) He spoke from his own experience and said that he did not remember the lectures deli vered by his teachers, but the greatest and the holiest thing he remem bered was how one his teachers whose memory he cherished was able to penetrate his heart.

('41', 117, 1, 15, 228597) But if I tell the origin of the college in which I had studied, you will be surprised and you will see a ray of hope, because it was started in a mere small cottage and that too by a brave widow, who had lost her husband on the very day of her marriage.
('41', 117, 1, 16, 228851) She could have remarried, but she dedicated herself to the religion of service.
('41', 117, 1, 17, 228931) She found out saints and sadhus and asked them to give education to students; she had huts built for them to stay in.

('41', 125, 6, 9, 243933) 146. AJMAL JAMIA FUND
('41', 125, 7, 10, 243955) I have now heard from Dr. Ansari regarding the fund to be raised in memory of the late Hakim Saheb Ajmal Khan and for the purpose of putting the Muslim National University on a firm footing.
('41', 125, 7, 11, 244146) Dr. Ansari authorizes me to say that he and Principal Zakir Husain join me in making this appeal.
('41', 125, 7, 12, 244244) Sheth Jamnalalji Bajaj has consented to be the treasurer of the Fund.
('41', 125, 7, 13, 244314) In the existing raw state of feeling between Hindus and Mussalmans, it has not been thought advisable to issue this appeal under many names.
('41', 125, 7, 14, 244455) But our hope is that all those who revere the deceased’s memory and who approve of the idea of connecting the proposed memorial with the National Muslim University will help the movement as if they were joint partners in this appeal.
('41', 125, 7, 15, 244689) In my humble opinion, it is the duty of Hindus and Mussalmans who believe in unity to perpetuate Hakim Saheb’s memory in the tangible form proposed.
('41', 125, 7, 16, 244838) It is their duty to ensure the stability of the Jamia, for it was a creation of the times when it was thought that the two communities were united for ever.
('41', 125, 7, 17, 244995) And if the non co operating national colleges do not stand for, work for and finally ensure unity, nothing else can or will.
('41', 125, 7, 18, 245120) I hope, therefore, that all the lovers of unity will liberally subscribe to the Fund.
('41', 125, 7, 19, 245206) There are today two hundred students studying in the central institution and seventy four in the city branch.
('41', 125, 7, 20, 245316) There are more over two night schools which draw nearly two hundred students.
('41', 125, 7, 21, 245394) The Jamia
('41', 125, 8, 22, 245404) 1 Names are omitted.
('41', 126, 0, 1, 245425) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 127
('41', 126, 1, 2, 245467) has a staff of twenty three workers.
('41', 126, 1, 3, 245504) The highest salary being paid is Rs. 265, the lowest being Rs. 35. The idea constantly before the Principal is to have volunteers who would draw just enough for their wants.
('41', 126, 1, 4, 245678) The salaries amount in all to Rs. 2,300 per month, the house rent is Rs. 425 per month.
('41', 126, 1, 5, 245766) The total monthly expenditure is Rs. 4,800. The regular income, including boarding fees Rs. 1,300, is Rs. 2,700. There is thus a deficit of Rs. 2,100. This was somehow met whilst Hakim Saheb was alive.
('41', 126, 1, 6, 245968) Before the teachers create for themselves a name and a prestige enough to command help, the deficit must be met by the public.
('41', 126, 1, 7, 246095) And the memorial cannot be considered lasting till the Jamia has a building of its own.
('41', 126, 1, 8, 246183) The subscribers will, therefore, in deciding the amount of donation bear in mind what is required.
('41', 126, 1, 9, 246282) Dr. Ansari tells me that the Central Bank has generously offered to receive subscriptions for the Ajmal Jamia Fund and to cash all cheques and drafts at par in all its branches.
('41', 126, 1, 10, 246460) The address of the treasurer is 395, Kalbadevi Road, Bombay.

('41', 126, 3, 13, 246723) 147. TO NO CHANGERS
('41', 126, 4, 14, 246743) I see that the news that there was to be at Sabarmati a meeting of ‘No Changers’ some time this month has found its way to the Press.
('41', 126, 4, 15, 246877) Prehaps this was inevitable.
('41', 126, 4, 16, 246906) But I am sorry to have to inform all concerned that the idea has been dropped for the time being at any rate.
('41', 126, 4, 17, 247016) Many No Changers have been long suggesting such a meeting with a view to the formation of a programme and a general interchange of views.
('41', 126, 4, 18, 247154) The demand became insistent at Madras when the No Changers who attended the Congress felt that on several resolutions they should have a definite joint policy and that they should be able to act as a distinct party within the Congress.
('41', 126, 4, 19, 247390) Though I was not enamoured of the idea of forming a party, I was not averse to the calling of a meeting of No Changers for the purpose of discussion.
('41', 126, 4, 20, 247540) But as I came to the drafting of a circular letter, I saw that it was a difficult performance and it was an equally dfficult thing to select the names of invitees.
('41', 126, 4, 21, 247704) I found both to be hopeless tasks.
('41', 126, 4, 22, 247739) On going into the thing deeper, I found that the convening of such a
('41', 127, 0, 1, 247808) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 127, 1, 2, 247850) meeting might embarrass Dr. Ansari and make the working of the national programme of boycott more difficult by drawing the attention of country away from the boycott and distracting it by a discussion of matters that may well await a better opportunity.
('41', 127, 1, 3, 248104) I discovered further that the formation of a ‘No Change’ party without me in it was not likely to function fully and vigorously so long as I was alive, available and retained a fairly healthy and active mind.
('41', 127, 1, 4, 248313) And the idea behind the suggested meeting was to form a party in which I need not take any part.
('41', 127, 1, 5, 248410) It may be theoretically possible, but in practice reference would always be made to me for opinion on many matters, which opinion would be more likely to be faulty than it would be if I was present at the discussion from which the matters for opinion might have risen.
('41', 127, 1, 6, 248679) These considerations made me incline to the view that the meeting might at least be postponed.
('41', 127, 1, 7, 248774) Vallabhbhai, with whom I first shared my revised opinion, agreed with me.
('41', 127, 1, 8, 248848) Other friends came to the same conclusion on other and independent grounds.
('41', 127, 1, 9, 248924) The idea of the meeting, therefore, remains under suspension for the time being.
('41', 127, 1, 10, 249005) I hope that the suspension will not disappoint the No co Changers.
('41', 127, 1, 11, 249072) I am not sure that it is not a better arrangement.
('41', 127, 1, 12, 249123) Whilst non operation as a national programme is partially suspended, individual non co operators have an opportunity of testing the strength of their faith.
('41', 127, 1, 13, 249280) Their faith will be all the stronger for standing alone without the warmth of a party.
('41', 127, 1, 14, 249367) When anything assums the strength of a creed which non co operation must be with those who still remain true to it, it becomes self sustained and derives the needed support from within.
('41', 127, 1, 15, 249553) Let us also have faith in the country that, when a forward movement becomes possible, all those who left non co operation will rejoin it whole heartedly.
('41', 127, 1, 16, 249707) I have no forward step to suggest at the present moment.
('41', 127, 1, 17, 249764) Anything intermediate I can suggest may disturb the joint programme that various parties in the country are trying to evolve.
('41', 127, 1, 18, 249890) Meanwhile, I can only invite the attention of No Changers to the great constructive programme of khadi.
('41', 127, 1, 19, 249994) Those who do not appreciate it do not understand the most potent and the most operative part of non co operation, viz., non violence.
('41', 127, 1, 20, 250128) Non co operation without non violence can never rise to the dignity of a creed and becomes merely one among many strategies in a campaign.
('41', 127, 1, 21, 250267) Non violent non co operation has been conceived as an infallible remedy replacing all others.
('41', 127, 1, 22, 250361) And khadi is the corner stone of its positive side.
('41', 127, 1, 23, 250413) Here is a reluctant testimony in favour of khadi given by Mr. Harcourt Robertson in the
('41', 128, 0, 1, 250501) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 129
('41', 128, 1, 2, 250543) Daily Despatch.
('41', 128, 1, 3, 250559) The writer is claimed by the editor to be “one who has spent many years in British India where he was engaged in occupations demanding an intimate knowledge of market conditions and the Indian psychology”.
('41', 128, 1, 4, 250765) I am indebted to The Leader of the 12th instant for the following: 1
('41', 128, 2, 5, 250834) He (Mr. Robertson) ascribes the heavy drop in the amount of British cotton fabrics purchased by India not to post war dislocation and economic stress, nor to the poverty of the masses, .
('41', 128, 2, 6, 251021) nor to famines .
('41', 128, 2, 7, 251038) but to the competition of Indian and Japanese mills and most of all to khaddar.
('41', 128, 2, 8, 251118) He regards khaddar as the real enemy.
('41', 128, 2, 9, 251156) He says:
('41', 128, 3, 10, 251165) “Khaddar is a native made cloth, woven on primitive looms from hand spun yarn by unskilled, amateurish workers.
('41', 128, 3, 11, 251277) It is coarse, stiff, full of knots and faults, and always looks dirty—yet there is a positive vogue for it, even wealthy natives taking a pride in garments made from it.
('41', 128, 3, 12, 251447) For khaddar represents in concrete form the slogan of the rapidly growing Nationalist party: ‘India for the Indians’.
('41', 128, 3, 13, 251565) Not a penny of the money spent on it leaves the country.
('41', 128, 3, 14, 251622) He who wears it helps to feed India’s starving millions, proclaims his country’s independence and shows himself a patriot of the first water.
('41', 128, 3, 15, 251764) Khaddar is one of the weapons used by, and, indeed, invented by, Mahatma Gandhi in his fight against foreign rule in India.
('41', 128, 3, 16, 251888) Half saint, half fanatic, and wholly patriot, Mahatma Gandhi now speaks, in his person and through the native Press, to the very hearts of India’s educated classes.
('41', 128, 3, 17, 252053) Non co operation is not dead in India because it is no longer talked.
('41', 128, 3, 18, 252123) It has now reached the stage of silent and dangerous activity.
('41', 128, 3, 19, 252186) Let Mr. Gandhi’s missionaries once rope in the masses, and India will no longer be a poor buyer, she will be no buyer at all.
('41', 128, 3, 20, 252312) The blow is aimed not only at cotton.
('41', 128, 3, 21, 252350) It is a definite attempt to ruin the market for all British goods.”
('41', 128, 4, 22, 252418) These remaks cannot but hearten those who have been working, under the inspiring leadership of Mahatma Gandhi, for the spread of khaddar .
('41', 128, 4, 23, 252557) Mr. Robertson is alarmed and .
('41', 128, 4, 24, 252588) he suggests that something should be done to give wide publicity in India to ideas such as “Lancashire fabrics of Indian cotton”, “India’s best customer is Lancashire”, “To buy Lancashire cloth is to help India’s cultivators”.

('41', 129, 8, 12, 253785) 149. LETTER TO DR.
('41', 129, 8, 13, 253804) B. C. ROY
('41', 129, 9, 14, 253814) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 19, 1928
('41', 129, 10, 15, 253861) DEAR DR.
('41', 129, 10, 16, 253870) ROY, I thank you and Dr. Sircar for your letter and the medicine you have kindly sent me.
('41', 129, 10, 17, 253960) You know my repugnance to medicine.
('41', 129, 10, 18, 253996) I would not take anything that contained something taken from the human body except mother’s milk.
('41', 129, 10, 19, 254095) The tabloids sent by you contain kidney and pancreas.
('41', 129, 10, 20, 254149) Isn’t this something taken from a human body?
('41', 129, 10, 21, 254195) Supposing that it is taken from a sub human animal, my objection will still stand.
('41', 129, 10, 22, 254278) You know my weakness for dietetical experiments.
('41', 129, 10, 23, 254327) And ever since your discovery of excess of uric acid in my system, I have felt impelled to make a radical dietetic change.
('41', 129, 10, 24, 254450) The comparative stability in the Ashram has given me the opportunity and I am now taking simply fresh fruits and nuts.
('41', 129, 10, 25, 254569) The diet now consists of raisin tea,
('41', 129, 11, 26, 254606) 1 About the Pulaya Colony; vide “Letter to K. Kelappan”, 23 12 1927.
('41', 130, 0, 1, 254675) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 131
('41', 130, 1, 2, 254717) which means about 40 raisins boiled and the skin and seeds removed.
('41', 130, 1, 3, 254785) This I take three times a day, and I add to it half an ounce of almond paste each time and twice two tolas of coconut milk and one or two oranges each time.
('41', 130, 1, 4, 254942) Coconut milk is prepared by pounding a fresh ripe coconut and extracting the juice by adding a little water and straining it through a stout piece of khadi.
('41', 130, 1, 5, 255099) This I had been doing for a fortnight without any way comming to harm.
('41', 130, 1, 6, 255170) The bowels are much more regular.
('41', 130, 1, 7, 255204) I have not been weighed nor have I had the blood pressure taken, but the feeling about me is good.
('41', 130, 1, 8, 255303) I have purposely refrained from taking the blood pressure and weight beacuse it seems to me to be of no consequence, if I otherwise keep fit.
('41', 130, 1, 9, 255445) As you have taken so much interest in my health, I thought I owed you the information of the change I have made and the reason why I will not take the medicine so thoughtfully sent by you.
('41', 130, 1, 10, 255634) I wish Indian medical men would make original researches and explore the possibilities of dietetic changes.
('41', 130, 1, 11, 255742) It may be that the general body of people will not take to what may be called austere ways of treating diseases, but may not poor fanatics like myself have a corner in the minds and hearts of medical men?
('41', 130, 1, 12, 255947) Has Indian medicine no fresh contribution to make to the medical science?
('41', 130, 1, 13, 256021) Or must it always rely upon the patented nostrums that, together with other foreign goods, are dumped down upon this unfortunate soil?
('41', 130, 1, 14, 256156) Why should the West have a monopoly of making researches?
('41', 130, 1, 15, 256214) This letter is not written to you for acknowledgement and reply unless you want to give me any direction.
('41', 130, 1, 16, 256320) You may therefore throw it into the waste paper basket if there is nothing more to be said to me by way of advice and guidance.
('41', 130, 2, 17, 256448) Yours sincerely, DR.
('41', 130, 2, 18, 256469) BIDHAN ROY CALCUTTA

('41', 133, 1, 2, 259725) 154. SPEECH AT KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE, PORBANDAR 1
('41', 133, 2, 3, 259784) January 22, 1928 With a view to avoiding the possibility of any misunderstanding between the rulers and the ruled, and with a view to fuller recognition of its own limitations, as also in confirmation of the custom which has been for some time in operation, this Conference resolves that it shall not pass any resolution condemning or criticizing any individual State.
('41', 133, 3, 4, 260153) Moving the above resolution Gandhi said: Young people would not appreciate the restriction imposed today, but I must realize my responsibility before I suggest that swaraj means the right to make mistakes.
('41', 133, 3, 5, 260359) Not only have I thought over it and then suggested it, but I have drafted the resolution myself.
('41', 133, 3, 6, 260456) Day before yesterday I advised the Subjects Committee not to pass the two resolutions criticizing individual States when the resolutions were moved in the Committee.
('41', 133, 3, 7, 260622) It came to me as an after thought that the advice given by me should hold good for some time more for the same reasons for which it was tendered.
('41', 133, 3, 8, 260768) It we do not resolve to this effect, our existence is in jeopardy.
('41', 133, 3, 9, 260835) But one may also argue why we should have such a restriction only to postpone the death.
('41', 133, 3, 10, 260924) The Committee would have turned down the resolution if it had been sponsored by any other person, but the Committee and the Kathiawaris have added to my responsibility by reposing faith in me.
('41', 133, 3, 11, 261117) I hope you would do the same by passing the resolution.
('41', 133, 3, 12, 261173) Young people will have to tolerate words such as ‘misunderstanding’, etc., which are found in the resolution.
('41', 133, 3, 13, 261283) At the Bhavnagar Session of the Conference 3 the question of only Jamnagar and Gondal States was discussed.
('41', 133, 3, 14, 261391) I had met the Jamsaheb and had discussions with him.
('41', 133, 3, 15, 261444) I know what the issue was and it, but due to pressure of work, I could not derive full benefit from the discussions.
('41', 133, 3, 16, 261561) I cannot say at the moment whether I won or lost.
('41', 133, 4, 17, 261611) 1 This was the fourth Conference.
('41', 133, 4, 18, 261645) 2 This resolution is reproduced from “Weekly Letter”, published in Young India, 26 1 1928. According to Mahadev Desai, Gandhiji was “the author of the resolution”.
('41', 133, 4, 19, 261809) 3 Held on January 8, 1925; Gandhiji presided; vide “Presidential Address at Kathiawar Political Conference, Bhavnagar”.
('41', 134, 0, 1, 261929) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 135
('41', 134, 1, 2, 261971) suffered defeat at the hands of Thakore of Gondal; even then I did not allow any criticism of him individually.
('41', 134, 1, 3, 262083) At present the Conference is weak, lame and blind, and because I hold that we should not indulge in personal criticism I demanded here as well as in Bhavnagar that in the Conference no resolution or criticism on individual States should be allowed.
('41', 134, 1, 4, 262332) The participants as well as the office bearers of the Conference should be vigilant about such resolutions.
('41', 134, 1, 5, 262440) They should do what is worthy of them.
('41', 134, 1, 6, 262479) The ruler and the subjects should love each other and, in spite of their eagerness to point out to the ruler his shortcomings, they should put curbs on their speech and pen.
('41', 134, 1, 7, 262653) Such restraint would help us a lot.
('41', 134, 1, 8, 262689) Knowing our weakness, we should in future also adhere to the restraint which we have accepted in the two conferences.
('41', 134, 1, 9, 262807) A person who is conscious of his inadequacy feels relieved when he confesses it before the world.
('41', 134, 1, 10, 262905) If someone asks me what the brave people would do after the imposition of the restriction, I should say that such brave people have no place in the Conference.
('41', 134, 1, 11, 263065) Their place is outside the Conference.
('41', 134, 1, 12, 263104) They may form another association but this Conference is not meant for satyagrahis.
('41', 134, 1, 13, 263188) Even the congress is not for them.
('41', 134, 1, 14, 263223) This Conference does not restrain them.
('41', 134, 1, 15, 263263) They may criticize but should not malign others.
('41', 134, 1, 16, 263312) If I am asked what should be done if there is maladm inistration in a particular State, my answer would be that we should acquire the courage to criticize the State.
('41', 134, 1, 17, 263478) If the subjects being docile bear everything quietly, we should go to work amidst them in order to help them.
('41', 134, 1, 18, 263588) Injustice is there, but we should find out some other platform for its redress.
('41', 134, 1, 19, 263668) The princes are mutual friends and they won’t allow any one of them to be criticized.
('41', 134, 1, 20, 263754) Of course, the Conference as such cannot indulge in the criticism or censure of individual States.
('41', 134, 1, 21, 263853) Apart from such criticism, you have enough work to do for khadi and for redressing the injustice inflicted on Antyajas by the sanatanis which is more severe than the injustice prevailing in the princely States.
