('41', 135, 7, 8, 264386) 156. SPEECH AT VARTEJ 2
('41', 135, 8, 9, 264410) January 24, 1928 If a Hindu does service to an untouchable he does not at all oblige the latter, he obliges only himself.
('41', 135, 8, 10, 264532) The Hindus, who were responsible for the existence of their so called untouchable brothers, have committed many sins.
('41', 135, 8, 11, 264650) Whatever they may do by way of self purification and expiation for these sins would be inadequate.
('41', 135, 8, 12, 264749) Therefore, whenever I have a chance to serve the untouchables, I consider it a God sent opportunity to do some slight atonement for past sins.
('41', 135, 8, 13, 264892) No one should feel elated, thinking that since he does some service he has no need at all for expiation.
('41', 135, 8, 14, 264997) I want to make it clear to you that we are all jointly responsible for the ill treatment given by a single Hindu.
('41', 135, 8, 15, 265111) It is a universal rule that the whole world is responsible for the sin committed by any one person.
('41', 135, 8, 16, 265211) Both Hindus and Muslims should accept this rule.
('41', 135, 8, 17, 265260) As long as there are barriers of caste and community in this world, the group as a whole is responsible for sin of every individual member.
('41', 135, 8, 18, 265400) A temple is not merely an edifice of brick or marble, nor does it become a temple by the installation of the image of a deity.
('41', 135, 8, 19, 265527) It can be called a temple only when life has been breathed into the image.
('41', 135, 8, 20, 265602) There may be hypocrisy in calling the priest and making sacrificial
('41', 135, 9, 21, 265670) 1 Sister of Mirabehn 2 A village in the then princely State of Bhavnagar in Saurashtra.
('41', 135, 9, 22, 265758) Gandhiji laid the foundation stone of the temple of Rama for the untouchables.

('41', 136, 1, 2, 265879) offerings at the time of laying the foundation of the temple.
('41', 136, 1, 3, 265941) The truth is that those who made a pious resolve to build a temple should, from that very moment, spend their life in deeds of penance and should surrender to the temple the fruits of all their good deeds.
('41', 136, 1, 4, 266147) The managers and the priests of the temple should be leading a life of austerity so that one’s heart is moved as soon as one enters the temple.
('41', 136, 1, 5, 266291) If this is not going to be that type of a temple, if sufficient purity of heart and mind is not behind it, it is merely a building and, take it, it is a burden on the earth.
('41', 136, 1, 6, 266465) Since it would be called a temple, the area occupied by it would go waste; it can be put to no use and it may turn out to be a pernicious institution and even a haunt of many sins.
('41', 136, 1, 7, 266646) I have laid the foundation stone of this temple in the belief that no such defects are here.
('41', 136, 1, 8, 266739) To lay the foundation stone as soon as the idea of constructing a temple occurs and then to live in the hope of erecting a temple some day is not good.
('41', 136, 1, 9, 266891) Nothing is achieved in haste; the plants of religion do not grow fast.
('41', 136, 1, 10, 266962) True faith, industry and patience are the prerequisities for this.
('41', 136, 1, 11, 267029) I should lie to say only this to the untouchable brethren: the Hindu precept which says that no one can go to heaven before death is perfectly true.
('41', 136, 1, 12, 267178) You have to work yourselves for your own uplift.

('41', 136, 1, 14, 267333) If you wish to show your mettle, wake up.

('41', 136, 1, 16, 267441) Please make it a rule that those amongst you who are given to drinking, meat eating and so on do not enter the temple.

('41', 136, 1, 18, 267624) As the saying goes, “those in power can do no wring”, the world will forgive them but not you.
('41', 136, 1, 19, 267719) Whatever may be the defects of others, you must try to remove your own.

('41', 137, 1, 2, 267869) 157. SPEECH AT MORVI 1
('41', 137, 2, 3, 267892) [January 24, 1928] 2
('41', 137, 3, 4, 267913) I sincerely thank the Maharaja Saheb, the people and members of the Modh 3 community for having welcomed my companions and myself and for presenting me with an address.
('41', 137, 3, 5, 268082) I should, at any rate, tell my brothers belonging to the Modh caste that I have no right whatsoever to accept an address of welcome from them.
('41', 137, 3, 6, 268225) Not even in my dreams have I imagined that I have in any manner served this caste as such; there are some gentlemen who believe that I have not only not served this caste but rather have caused it some harm.
('41', 137, 3, 7, 268433) If I accept this allegation for the moment, your address merely suggests your large heartedness.
('41', 137, 3, 8, 268530) However, I am not content with this large heartedness because, although it may be a sign of generosity, there is always an implicit understanding between the giver and the receiver of an address of welcome that the giver blesses and approves of the work that is being done by the receiver.
('41', 137, 3, 9, 268820) I hesitate to accept your address, as there is no such understanding between us.
('41', 137, 3, 10, 268901) There is a purpose behind what I am saying about your small caste; for I believe that these small barriers must be broken down.
('41', 137, 3, 11, 269029) I am clear in my mind that there is no room for castes in the Hindu faith; I say this to those belonging to the Modh or any other caste who happen to be present here.
('41', 137, 3, 12, 269196) In the true Shastras there is no reference to castes; there is a reference only to the four varnas, God has washed his hands off after creating these four varnas.
('41', 137, 3, 13, 269359) There is not even a trace of castes in the varnadharma.
('41', 137, 3, 14, 269415) I wish to tell all of you, and plead with all, through the Modhs, that you should forget the barriers created by caste.
('41', 137, 3, 15, 269535) Make use of the castes that exist today in destroying the caste system, offer them to the sacrificial fire and, if there is anything in them that teaches you self control, practise it.
('41', 137, 3, 16, 269720) A foul smell is emitted by such puddles if we do not clear them.
('41', 137, 3, 17, 269785) The doctors advise us to fill up puddles.
('41', 137, 3, 18, 269827) In addition to giving off a foul smell, they breed mosquitoes and these in turn prove fatal.
('41', 137, 3, 19, 269920) You must realize that these caste puddles are likewise fatal to man.
('41', 137, 3, 20, 269989) You must realize that God would never create such a deadly organization.
('41', 137, 3, 21, 270062) You will be happy if
('41', 137, 4, 22, 270083) 1 One of the princely States in Saurashtra 2 From the reference to Ramdas Gandhi’s marriage which took place on January 27 3 Gandhiji belonged to this sub caste of Banias.
('41', 138, 0, 1, 270255) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 139
('41', 138, 1, 2, 270297) you act upon these words which I speak out of my own experience.
('41', 138, 1, 3, 270362) Time goes on, doing its own work.
('41', 138, 1, 4, 270396) You can go and raise your hand against it if you wish to, but you must realize that it is all futile.
('41', 138, 1, 5, 270498) If we foolishly delay things, trying to defend these barriers against the march of time, it would be like the game of trying to throw dust on the sun and throwing it in our own eyes.
('41', 138, 1, 6, 270681) I would not have spoken thus to you nor would I have had the occasion to do so if you had not presented me this address.
('41', 138, 1, 7, 270802) Do not regard this as an insignificant matter.
('41', 138, 1, 8, 270849) For many years now we have been steeped in superstition and ignorance; do not give these the name of knowledge.
('41', 138, 1, 9, 270961) Comparative studies of different religions are being made in the world today, and if you examine these without any prejudice, you will find that these castes act as barriers to progress, to dharma, to swaraj and to the Ramarajya of which I speak so often.
('41', 138, 1, 10, 271217) I would like to ask you: ‘What are the achievements of the Modh caste that should prompt us to sing its praises exclusively?’ We find that many cases there is a contradiction between our thoughts and actions.
('41', 138, 1, 11, 271426) Our conduct is at variance with our proclaimed beliefs.
('41', 138, 1, 12, 271482) This is like the track remaining even after the disappearance of the snake.
('41', 138, 1, 13, 271558) Make a Bhagiratha prayatna 1 to bring about conformity between your beliefs and your conduct.
('41', 138, 1, 14, 271652) In return for the address of welcome that you have given me I would ask you to make this effort.
('41', 138, 1, 15, 271749) If you also accept the implicit understanding of which I spoke, I shall feel that I did well to have accepted your address and to have been born in your caste.
('41', 138, 1, 16, 271909) I have been making the most sincere efforts to bring about conformity between my thought and action and hence it was that the Modh caste used to boycott me, although the Modhs realized later on that I did not deserve boycott as I never even thought of taking any advantage of the caste system.
('41', 138, 1, 17, 272203) I wish to carry forward this attempt of mine to break down caste barriers.
('41', 138, 1, 18, 272278) Perhaps you do not know that I got one of my sons married outside my caste and have lost nothing by doing so.
('41', 138, 1, 19, 272388) My son got bride from a devout Vaishnava family, for which he is grateful to me.
('41', 138, 1, 20, 272469) I could claim that by doing so I have stolen a gem belonging to another caste.
('41', 138, 1, 21, 272548) I ask those belonging to the smaller castes to hand their daughters over to me, if the latter cannot be married off.
('41', 138, 1, 22, 272665) I shall get them married to good upright boys belonging to other castes, the marriage expenditure being no more

('41', 143, 1, 2, 282597) 158. BOYCOTT OF BRITISH GOODS
('41', 143, 2, 3, 282627) It is not at all surprising that the nation should wish to show resentment of the studiously insulting and defiant acts of the British Government.
('41', 143, 2, 4, 282774) Every new discovery in the direction adds fuel to the fire.
('41', 143, 2, 5, 282834) The latest is the abhorrence the late King Edward VII and his son, the present King, are reported to have betrayed of ‘natives’ and that in connection with Lord Sinha.
('41', 143, 2, 6, 283002) The representatives of the nation have for years past endeavoured to demonstrate their resentment by bringing about a partial or complete boycott of British goods.
('41', 143, 2, 7, 283166) It is the nation’s right to bring it about if it so wishes.
('41', 143, 2, 8, 283226) There is no doubt that it will produce a great effect if it could succeed to the necessary extent.
('41', 143, 3, 9, 283325) But it has been my misfortune or good fortune consistently to oppose the cry for the boycott of British goods.
('41', 143, 3, 10, 283436) Though I adhere to the fundamental ground that the proposed boycott is contrary to non violence, I wish to confine myself at present to an examination of its possibility.
('41', 143, 3, 11, 283607) The fact that we have hitherto made no headway whatsoever with it, in spite of the agitation for so long a time, is proof presumptive of its very great difficulty.
('41', 143, 3, 12, 283771) If we were to take even such a simple instance as soap, we shall discover that we have made no progress even in the boycott of British made soap.
('41', 143, 3, 13, 283917) The Committee appointed by the Congress recommended certain articles for boycott.
('41', 143, 3, 14, 283999) So far as I am aware, no such effort has yet been made in the direction of excluding even one such article from the nation’s use.
('41', 143, 3, 15, 284129) The use of a punitive boycott lies in the effectiveness.
('41', 143, 3, 16, 284186) Anyone studying the articles of import will soon discover the utter futility of spending labour on achieving the boycott of most of these articles from the standpoint of creating an impression on the British Government.
('41', 143, 3, 17, 284406) It should not be forgotten that for all these long long years, we have not been able to have a body of specialists devoted to this single task.
('41', 143, 3, 18, 284550) It is the fashion in some quarters nowadays to blame me for the failure of any and every resolution that the Congress passes.
('41', 143, 3, 19, 284676) I am told that a particular resolution does not succeed because I oppose it or do not work at it.
('41', 143, 3, 20, 284774) There can be nothing more humiliating for a nation than to be in such an impotent state.
('41', 143, 3, 21, 284863) Surely boycott of British goods was conceived and vehemently advocated before I returned from South Africa.
('41', 143, 3, 22, 284971) The real and the more natural reason for the failure of the British goods boycott resolution lies in the obvious fact that no committee of
('41', 144, 0, 1, 285110) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 145
('41', 144, 1, 2, 285152) experts has yet been able to arrive at a satisfactory plan of working it out.
('41', 144, 1, 3, 285230) It has been suggested that we can succeed if China has succeeded.
('41', 144, 1, 4, 285296) Yes, we can if we have the will, the courage and the opportunity to regulate the boycott by armed force, by creating an army of open revolutionaries, by forcing for that specific purpose a strike of dock labourers and others connected with the handling of British goods.
('41', 144, 1, 5, 285567) It seems to me that even if we have the will, we have neither the means nor yet the capacity for managing such an open armed revolution.
('41', 144, 1, 6, 285704) And neither those who have advocated boycott of British goods nor the special Committee appointed by the Civil Disobedience Inquiry Committee have ever contemplated armed force.
('41', 144, 1, 7, 285882) I hold, therefore, that it will be more consistent with national dignity, prestige and welfare to give up the cry, proved to be useless, and almost impossible, of boycott of British goods.
('41', 144, 1, 8, 286071) The permanent necessity of advocating true swadeshi in all things capable of being produced at home is untouched by the argument against the punitive boycott.
('41', 144, 1, 9, 286230) But there is no cause whatsoever for despair.
('41', 144, 1, 10, 286276) We have a means ready made and most effective of signifying our resentment over the series of wrongs being continuously heaped upon our devoted heads.
('41', 144, 1, 11, 286427) If we have the will, I claim that we have the present capacity of achieving a complete boycott not merely of British cloth but of all foreign cloth.
('41', 144, 1, 12, 286576) And if we do this, we not only successfully demonstrate our resentment, but we serve the masses in a manner we have never done before and we secure their co operation in a national effort.
('41', 144, 1, 13, 286765) We have got an army of workers for doing this work.
('41', 144, 1, 14, 286817) We have experts who have first hand knowledge of the thing.
('41', 144, 1, 15, 286877) There is no division of opinion on the propriety of the thing.
('41', 144, 1, 16, 286940) The only thing that retards our progress towards the completion of boycott of foreign cloth is our own disbelief.
('41', 144, 1, 17, 287054) It is strange but tragic that through our ignorance we believe more in the possibility of achieving a boycott of certain British goods than of foreign cloth.
('41', 144, 1, 18, 287212) But even this boycott of foreign cloth cannot be achieved without a well thought out and prepared plan.
('41', 144, 1, 19, 287316) If it is the mere boycott we want rather than the higher and the more permanent result in the shape of the economic well being of the masses, we can do so quickly enough if we receive the co operation of mills on our terms.
('41', 144, 1, 20, 287540) Without honest and hearty co operation of our weaving and spinning mills, to attempt to achieve the boycott with mill cloth would be to court suicide and to run into the arms of profiteering mill owners.

('41', 145, 0, 1, 287822) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 145, 1, 2, 287864) must come to terms with the Congress as to the kind of production and the prices to be charged.

('41', 145, 1, 4, 288154) Then, with khadi, foreign cloth can be successfully and permanently banished from the land.

('41', 154, 6, 13, 303330) January 28, 1928 It is not my intention to disqualify the graduates or to say that the executive committee has not functioned well .
('41', 154, 6, 14, 303463) The reason for forming a non elective trust is that it should, instead of being opportunistic, pursue its aims.
('41', 154, 6, 15, 303575) And if it does not have the strength to do so, it should entrust the work to those who have it.

('41', 155, 1, 2, 304530) 173. A SISTER’S DIFFICULTY 1
('41', 155, 2, 3, 304559) [January 29, 1928] A sister writes :
('41', 155, 3, 4, 304596) A year ago I heard you speaking on the supreme necessity of every one of us wearing khadi and thereupon decided to adopt it.
('41', 155, 3, 5, 304721) But we are poor people.
('41', 155, 3, 6, 304745) My husband says that khadi is costly.
('41', 155, 3, 7, 304783) Belonging as I do to Maharashtra, I wear a sari nine yards long.
('41', 155, 3, 8, 304848) Now if I reduced the length of my sari to six yards, there would be a great saving, but the elders will not hear of any such reduction.
('41', 155, 3, 9, 304984) I reason with them that wearing khadi is the more important thing and that the style and length of the sari is absolutely immaterial, but in vain.
('41', 155, 3, 10, 305131) They say that it is my youth that puts all these new fangled notions into my head.
('41', 155, 3, 11, 305214) But I expect that they will agree to the proposed reduction in length if you are good enough to write to me, saying that khadi ought to be used, even at the cost of style of clothing.
('41', 155, 3, 12, 305398) I have sent the desired reply 2 to the sister.
('41', 155, 3, 13, 305445) But I take note of her difficulty here, as I know that the same difficulty is encountered by many other sisters as well.
('41', 155, 3, 14, 305566) The letter in question bears witness to the strong patriotic feeling of the writer, for there are not many sisters who, like her, are ready to give up old styles or old customs on their own initiative.
('41', 155, 3, 15, 305768) The number of such sisters and brothers is legion as would gladly have swaraj if it could be attained without suffering any discomfort or incurring any expenditure and in spite of their sticking to old customs, regardless of their propriety or the reverse.
('41', 155, 3, 16, 306025) But swaraj is not such a cheap commodity.
('41', 155, 3, 17, 306067) To attain swaraj implies the cultivation of a spirit of self sacrifice, including the sacrifice of provincialism.
('41', 155, 3, 18, 306181) Provincialism is a bar not only to the realization of national swaraj, but also the achievement of provincial autonomy.
('41', 155, 3, 19, 306301) Women perhaps are more responsible than men for keeping up this narrow spirit.
('41', 155, 3, 20, 306380) Variety is worth cherishing up to a certain limit, but if the limit is exceeded, amenities and customs masquerading under the name of variety are subversive of nationalism.
('41', 155, 3, 21, 306553) The Deccani sari is a thing of beauty, but the beauty must be let go if it can be secured only by sacrificing the nation.
('41', 155, 3, 22, 306675) We should consider the Kachchhi style of short sari or the Punjabi odhani to be really artistic if the wearing of khadi can be cheapened and facilitated by their means.
('41', 155, 3, 23, 306844) The Deccani,
('41', 155, 4, 24, 306857) 1 Translated by V. G. Desai from the Gujarati original published in Navajivan, 29 1 1928 2 This letter is not available.
('41', 156, 0, 1, 306978) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 157
('41', 156, 1, 2, 307020) Gujarati, Kachchhi and Bengali styles of wearing sari are all of them various national styles, and each of them is as national as the rest.
('41', 156, 1, 3, 307160) Such being the case, preference should be accorded to that style which requires the smallest amount of cloth consistently with the demands of decency.
('41', 156, 1, 4, 307311) Such is the Kachchhi style, which takes up only 3 yards of cloth, that is, about half the length of the Gujarati sari, not to mention the saving of trouble in having to carry a smaller weight.
('41', 156, 1, 5, 307504) If the pachhedo and the petticoat are of the same colour one cannot at once make out whether it is only a pachhedo or full sari.
('41', 156, 1, 6, 307633) The mutual exchange and imitation of such national styles is eminently desirable.
('41', 156, 1, 7, 307715) Well to do people might well keep in their wardrobes all possible provincial styles of clothing.
('41', 156, 1, 8, 307812) It would be very courteous and patriotic on the part of a Gujarati host and hostess to put on the Bengali style of dress when they entertain Bengali guests, and vice versa.
('41', 156, 1, 9, 307985) But such procedure is open only to the patriotic rich.
('41', 156, 1, 10, 308040) Patriotic people of the middle and poorer classes should take pride in adopting that particular provincial style which cheapens as well as facilitates the wearing of khadi.
('41', 156, 1, 11, 308213) And even there they should fix their eye upon the clothing style of the poorest of the poor.
('41', 156, 1, 12, 308306) Swadeshi does not mean drowning oneself in one’s own little puddle but making it tributary to the ocean that is the nation.
('41', 156, 1, 13, 308430) And it can claim to contribute to the ocean only if it is and keeps itself pure.
('41', 156, 1, 14, 308511) It is therefore clear that only such local or provincial customs should have a nation wide vogue as are not impure or immoral.
('41', 156, 1, 15, 308638) And when once this truth is grasped, nationalism is transmuted into the enthusiasm of humanity.
('41', 156, 1, 16, 308734) What is true of clothing is equally true of language, food, etc.
('41', 156, 1, 17, 308799) As we might imitate the dress of other provinces on a suitable occasion, so might we utilize the language and other things.
('41', 156, 1, 18, 308923) But at present all our energy is wasted in the useless, impossible and fatal attempt to give English the pride of place to the neglect, conscious or unconscious, of our mother tongue and all the more so, of the languages of other provinces.
('41', 156, 2, 19, 309164) Young India, 2 2 1928
('41', 157, 0, 1, 309186) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 157, 1, 2, 309228) 174. KATHIAWAR POLITICAL CONFERENCE
('41', 157, 2, 3, 309264) The Conference met and is now over.
('41', 157, 2, 4, 309300) I have no comments to offer on Shri Thakkar Bapa’s 1 speech, on the attendance of the public, on the welcome given by the reception committee, on the gentleness and courtesy of the honourable Rana Saheb 2, on his presence in the Conference or the hospitality that he extended to the guestes.
('41', 157, 2, 5, 309592) Sheth Devidas left nothing undone so far as the reception was concerned.
('41', 157, 2, 6, 309665) He acted very well on behalf of Sheth Omar Haji Amod Zaveri who had been elected the chairman of the reception committee and did not hesitable to spend his own money in providing a welcome.
('41', 157, 2, 7, 309855) The speech of the President was worthy of the priest of Bhils and the Dheds.
('41', 157, 2, 8, 309932) The resolutions passed by the Conference were innocuous.
('41', 157, 2, 9, 309989) These did not interest me as they did not reflect any firm determination or power to put them into actual practice.
('41', 157, 2, 10, 310105) It seemed that many of those who put forward the resolutions thought that with the mere moving of them their duties were discharged.
('41', 157, 2, 11, 310238) I realized that this was not a khadi conference and inwardly experienced a sense of defeat.
('41', 157, 2, 12, 310330) I was alone concentrating on that subject.
('41', 157, 2, 13, 310373) I realized that I had been unsuccessful; my faith in khadi, however, did not waver.
('41', 157, 2, 14, 310457) I do not, therefore, wish to spell out my sorrow.
('41', 157, 2, 15, 310507) I wish to comment on one resolution alone.
('41', 157, 2, 16, 310550) I am the author of that resolution and I feel that, by framing it and getting it passed, I have served the Conference and Kathiawar.
('41', 157, 2, 17, 310683) That resolution runs as follows: 3
('41', 157, 3, 18, 310718) The acceptance of this resolution became possible because of my devotion to truth.
('41', 157, 3, 19, 310801) I found that this Conference could be held in Porbandar only because of some implicit understanding with the honourable Rana Saheb and that for some years to come it would be possible to hold such conferences only with such an understanding.
('41', 157, 3, 20, 311043) This reflected the measure of the weakness of the Conference.
('41', 157, 3, 21, 311105) No conference should be helpless to this extent.
('41', 157, 3, 22, 311154) There is something wrong somewhere when such helplessness is found to exist.
('41', 157, 3, 23, 311231) However, it is not got rid of by hiding it from view.
('41', 157, 3, 24, 311285) Those who try to be
('41', 157, 4, 25, 311305) 1 Amritlal V. Thakkar of the Servants of India Society, who presided over the Conference 2 The ruler of Porbandar 3 For the text of the resolution, vide “Speech at Kathiawar Political Confer ence, Porbandar”, 22 1 1928.
('41', 158, 0, 1, 311525) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 159
('41', 158, 1, 2, 311567) secretive about their sickness merely increase its intensity; they ignore remedial measures and become their own enemies.
('41', 158, 1, 3, 311689) There were two occasions in the Subjects Committee when the members introduced two resolutions criticizing individual States.
('41', 158, 1, 4, 311815) I cannot claim that there was no reason for introducing these resolutions.
('41', 158, 1, 5, 311890) However, I clearly saw that it was beyond the power of the Conference to admit such resolutions or act on them.
('41', 158, 1, 6, 312002) The committee ruled out these resolutions.
('41', 158, 1, 7, 312045) However, I felt that the Conference could not continue to function long if it brought forward such resolutions.
('41', 158, 1, 8, 312157) Hence, I advised the Conference to declare to the world its own weakness, its own limitations.
('41', 158, 1, 9, 312252) I suggested that, by proclaiming the truth, the Conference will soon overcome its weakness and save itself.
('41', 158, 1, 10, 312360) This was a very bitter pill for the Subjects Committee to swallow.
('41', 158, 1, 11, 312427) I, too, did not like to give such advice; however, I could see clearly what my dharma was.
('41', 158, 1, 12, 312518) One should act in accordance with the truth, whether it happens to be pleasurable or painful.
('41', 158, 1, 13, 312612) Does not true happiness often appear to be like poison?
('41', 158, 1, 14, 312668) Although some members did not approve of this resolution, they as well as others accepted my advice because of their generosity and far sightedness.
('41', 158, 1, 15, 312817) Thereby, my responsibility has increased.
('41', 158, 1, 16, 312859) I know that I will be blamed if this resolution leads to any undesirable consequences.
('41', 158, 1, 17, 312946) Not only am I not afraid of these but I believe that, if the Conference implements that resolution in good spirit and does everything that is implied by it, the result must necessarily be rewarding.
('41', 158, 1, 18, 313145) Restrictions which are volun tarily imposed, self control which is voluntarily practised, are always beneficial to anyone who undertakes them.
('41', 158, 1, 19, 313288) There is no other condition which need be applied to a restriction thus voluntarily undertaken.
('41', 158, 1, 20, 313384) If the Conference abides by this resolution in thought, word and deed, it will thereby increase its capacity to fulfil its obligations within its province.
('41', 158, 1, 21, 313540) Before this restriction was imposed, rulers were hesitant to allow the Conference to be held, for fear of personal criticism and censure.
('41', 158, 1, 22, 313678) As the members were not clearly aware of their limitations, they made attempts, apparently glamorous but in fact futile, to rid the States of their individual shortcomings and, by doing so, were inattentive towards those tasks which, though apparently without glamour, were capable of being carried out.
('41', 158, 1, 23, 313982) Now, they will either perform these useful, though uninteresting, tasks or shut up shop.
('41', 158, 1, 24, 314071) As no one likes to become bankrupt, let us hope that the office bearers of
('41', 159, 0, 1, 314146) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 159, 1, 2, 314188) the Conference will accomplish, willingly or unwillingly, those tasks which are worth accomplishing.
('41', 159, 1, 3, 314289) No one will interpret the above resolution to mean that in passing it we admit before the world that the States do not deserve any criticism.
('41', 159, 1, 4, 314431) We should not speak ill of anyone.
('41', 159, 1, 5, 314466) Although these States deserve criticism, we do admit that as we live within the boundaries of Kathiawar we do not have the capacity to criticize at the moment any State in Kathiawar or even elsewhere.
('41', 159, 1, 6, 314667) We have imposed the restriction for this very reason and in the hope that we shall be able to develop the strength to make such criticisms in the future.
('41', 159, 1, 7, 314821) The Committee of the Conference has the right, or rather the duty, to utilize the means at its disposal for the redressing of any grievances that it may find in any State, without bringing in resolutions in the Conference to that effect and without making any criticism against any individual State either directly or in an indirect manner at the Conference.
('41', 159, 1, 8, 315180) For instance, at the time when the Conference is in session, any member of the Subjects Committee can describe the drawbacks of any State in Kathiawar to his fellow members and ask for the guidance of the Committee on the matter.
('41', 159, 1, 9, 315410) The only restriction is that he cannot move a resolution on it in the session of the Conference.
('41', 159, 1, 10, 315507) He could meet that rulers or their officers and request them for redress, or if the grievances prove to be untrue he should declare them as such.
('41', 159, 1, 11, 315653) In other words, the Committee can approach each and every State through proper channels, in a friendly manner.
('41', 159, 1, 12, 315764) There is a possibi lity that if the States in question, after having come to know the idea behind this restriction, have not suddenly started acting in an irrespon sible manner and do not wholly disregard public opinion, they would wel come this step taken by the Committee and would even use it as a shield.
('41', 159, 1, 13, 316073) Here we should bear in mind that the Committee should not take undue advantage of such an investigation and publicly discuss the facts which have come to light; it should suffer in silence even if it cannot gain access to the States in question or gets no satisfaction even after gaining access, and realize that the remedy for the disease lies beyond its powers.
('41', 159, 1, 14, 316437) The outcome of such limited interference, or investigation if you wish to call it by that name, depends on the tact, industry and courtesy of the Committee.
('41', 159, 1, 15, 316594) It will be able to achieve nothing if it forms preconceived notions about those States and becomes prejudiced against them.
('41', 159, 1, 16, 316718) It should have the self confidence to melt the hearts of rulers.
('41', 159, 1, 17, 316783) Such self confidence can be acquired only through
('41', 160, 0, 1, 316833) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 161
('41', 160, 1, 2, 316875) supreme service to both the ruler and the ruled.
('41', 160, 1, 3, 316924) Both should be served in a dispassionate manner for their ultimate good and not in order to placate them.
('41', 160, 1, 4, 317030) The members of the Committee should not even dream of serving their own self interest through such service.
('41', 160, 1, 5, 317138) The belief that we do not wish to do away with the existence of Indian States but only ask for an improvement in these is at the very heart of this idea.
('41', 160, 1, 6, 317292) The Conference does not deserve to be held in the States at all if the idea behind it is to put an end to the system of princely States.
('41', 160, 1, 7, 317429) It is change and not destruction that can be brought about through non violence.
('41', 160, 1, 8, 317510) Democracy can be realized through the rulers; neither the ruler nor the ruled should be destroyed and whatever is good in both these can be harmoniously harnessed.
('41', 160, 1, 9, 317674) In short, the relationship between the two should be one of dharma and not of brute force.
('41', 160, 1, 10, 317765) The modern trend is towards destruction, whereas ancient culture is in favour of growth and nurture.
('41', 160, 1, 11, 317866) Non violence achieves the good of all, whereas violence bases the prosperity of one upon the destruction of another.
('41', 160, 1, 12, 317983) Democracy is not an advantage in all respects nor is monarchy altogether harmful.
('41', 160, 1, 13, 318065) Each has its own uses and it is the duty of the Political Conference to find these out, for it wishes to reach its goal by following the path of truth and non violence.
('41', 160, 1, 14, 318234) Let us examine what the Conference can do.
('41', 160, 1, 15, 318277) Khadi, the service of the untouchables, social reforms, etc., are of course there.
('41', 160, 1, 16, 318360) By taking up these activities the Conference should nurture democracy.
('41', 160, 1, 17, 318431) Administrative problems are not few—prohibition, education, the railway department, storage of rain water for the whole of Kathiawar, preservation of trees and their multiplication, introducing uniformity in the excise levy throughout Kathiawar as well as uniformity in its administration.
('41', 160, 1, 18, 318721) Other matters, too, which would be advantageous to both the ruler and the ruled can be enumerated.
('41', 160, 1, 19, 318820) Such matters are of the utmost importance and Kathiawar can subsist on these alone.
('41', 160, 1, 20, 318904) By disregarding them Kathiawar will bring about its own ruin.
('41', 160, 1, 21, 318966) In order to accomplish these tasks, the help of the officer class is required more than that of the rulers.
('41', 160, 1, 22, 319074) If the former are selfish or narrow minded, even the reforms decreed by the rulers cannot be brought about.
('41', 160, 1, 23, 319182) The officers are the limbs of the rulers and the officer class means the people.
('41', 160, 1, 24, 319263) The ruler would necessarily improve if the people improve; however, the larger section of the public which is vocal, happens to belong to the officer class.
('41', 160, 1, 25, 319420) Hence, so long as that section does not give up its self interest and adopt the path of
('41', 161, 0, 1, 319508) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 161, 1, 2, 319550) morality, so long as it does not cease to worry over earning its livelihood, so long as these fearless persons do not comprehend the nature of public activities and take interest in them, there is little hope of any true reforms being introduced in the Indian States.
('41', 161, 1, 3, 319818) The greater part of the effort of the Political Conference should, therefore, be directed towards and concentrated on the people, as it is the people who are like roots whereas the rulers are like fruits.
('41', 161, 1, 4, 320023) If roots become sweet, fruits are bound to be sweet too.
('41', 161, 1, 5, 320080) Moreover, if the Kathiawar Political Conference is destined to add prestige to itself, there should be separate Conferences of State people in each of the more important States; these conferences may certainly criticize their own States in all matters, within the bounds of decency.
('41', 161, 1, 6, 320363) These conferences should develop their own strength; even in order to do so they should engage themselves in constructive activity.
('41', 161, 1, 7, 320495) The development of its strength depends on this.
('41', 161, 1, 8, 320544) Selfless and fearless workers are required for these activities.
('41', 161, 1, 9, 320609) Where to find them?
('41', 161, 1, 10, 320629) It those that are there, whatever their number, would keep on doing their duties silently, their number would multiply.
('41', 161, 1, 11, 320749) No one should entertain the cowardly thought: ‘What could I achieve all by myself?’ 1
('41', 161, 2, 12, 320835) So far I have addressed my words to the people.
('41', 161, 2, 13, 320883) If the rulers could realize it, the above mentioned resolution has greatly added to their responsibilities.
('41', 161, 2, 14, 320991) To this day, they avoided and some even ignored the Conference for fear of its criticism and harsh words against them.
('41', 161, 2, 15, 321110) However, in my humble opinion, they should respect the Conference by appreciating its civilized nature, satisfy its demands and use it as a bridge between the people and themselves.
('41', 161, 2, 16, 321292) The evidence I have before me leads me to believe that it is not the case that all the States in Kathiawar are above criticism.
('41', 161, 2, 17, 321420) I have been told that there are some very major shortcomings in these.
('41', 161, 2, 18, 321491) They should come to recognize this age.
('41', 161, 2, 19, 321531) The chaos that is there in the world and has affected India too, is an important symptom.
('41', 161, 2, 20, 321621) It is certainly harmful in its chaotic form; however, the purpose underlying it is an honest one.
('41', 161, 2, 21, 321719) People worship morality, although they follow consciously or unconsciously a path that deviates from it.
('41', 161, 2, 22, 321824) They are tired of the blind forces of authority; they have become impatient.
('41', 161, 2, 23, 321901) And, in their impatience, although they may forget that the remedy adopted by them is even more dangerous than the disease itself, they are eager for reforms and for moral power.
('41', 161, 3, 24, 322080) 1 The following paragraph was addressed to the rulers.

('41', 162, 2, 8, 322683) 175. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
('41', 162, 3, 9, 322709) A worker asked whether a school for untouchables should be started in State ‘A’.
('41', 162, 3, 10, 322790) Gandhiji replied: I have heard at many places and from many persons that ‘A’ is an unholy State; if that is true, we should not go there for any sacred work.
('41', 162, 3, 11, 322948) The only exception to this would be the work of removing the unholiness of that State.
('41', 162, 3, 12, 323035) As we have been living under British rule, it has acquired a certain kind of prestige; however, as we wish to break up this unjust administration from within, no other alternative is open to us.
('41', 162, 3, 13, 323230) Otherwise, for any good person to go or to live in an unholy State in order to carry out any other sacred work would amount to his going there to increase the prestige of that State.
('41', 162, 4, 14, 323413) Q. Is it necessary to have an all India satyagraha organization for introducing reforms in Indian States?
('41', 162, 5, 15, 323519) There were 60,000 people associated with my work in South Africa; how many of them continue to be satyagrahis today?
('41', 162, 5, 16, 323636) However, all the twenty two of you have been selected for the purpose of giving a helping hand whenever it becomes necessary.
('41', 162, 5, 17, 323762) Whenever you take up the work—and you will not do so without exercising discretion—you will find many other people who will join hands with you.
('41', 162, 5, 18, 323907) If you are discreet satyagrahis the all India satyagraha organization that you envisage is not necessary.
('41', 162, 5, 19, 324013) The talent that lies hidden within you and in the country will manifest itself when occasion arises.
('41', 162, 6, 20, 324114) Q. How should the Satyagraha Dal grow in numbers and in quality?
('41', 162, 7, 21, 324179) 1 This and the following questions were asked by members of the Satyagraha Dal.
('41', 163, 0, 1, 324259) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 163, 1, 2, 324301) A. Every satyagrahi should remain alert.
('41', 163, 1, 3, 324342) He should not be idle or lazy, he should not be lethargic or sick, so that he can be introspective.
('41', 163, 1, 4, 324442) He should keep on evaluating his own contribution to the activity which he has chosen for himself.

('41', 163, 3, 11, 325121) He would treat the poor before all others and would disregard me and others like myself who can get the services of doctors whenever they wish to.
('41', 163, 3, 12, 325268) He would ask a poor man whether he required a set of false teeth because he has lost his natural ones.

('41', 163, 3, 15, 325645) Dr. Wanless has per formed thousands of operations, people donate thousands of rupees to his institution, but he does not take a single pie out of it.

('41', 163, 3, 18, 325987) Yes, we do have our Dr. Chandulal 2; he acts in a similar fashion, he knows his own job very well, he does not take a single pie for himself and the poor can readily approach him.
('41', 163, 3, 19, 326167) The satyagrahi should dedicate himself to his chosen field of activity in a spirit of purity, and adhere to it.
('41', 163, 3, 20, 326279) His unflinching faith will be recognized by his truthful adherence to something which he has regarded as true although it may be untrue.

('41', 163, 3, 22, 326556) Though it is ever non existent, one cannot get rid of it.”

('41', 172, 3, 5, 341246) 188. GUJARAT VIDYAPITH
('41', 172, 4, 6, 341269) This National University, the first of its kind established when non co operation was at its height, has been struggling for existence for the past three or four years.
('41', 172, 4, 7, 341438) The attendance of boys has gone down considerably.
('41', 172, 4, 8, 341489) Several schools affiliated to it have closed or sought Government recognition.
('41', 172, 4, 9, 341568) There would be nothing to worry over this decline, if there were no internal causes for it.
('41', 172, 4, 10, 341660) But most of us including myself have felt that we have not done all we might have for this most useful national work of reconstruction.
('41', 172, 4, 11, 341796) But whilst, if all had been vigilant, the defections might have been not so large as they have been, there are for the decline causes over which no one had any control.

('41', 172, 4, 16, 342787) The preliminary cleansing step was taken on Sunday 2 last when the Senate handed over charge of the valuable property and the still more valuable responsibility connected with the Vidyapith to a Board of Trustees by means of a resolution of which I give the translation below:
('41', 172, 5, 17, 343064) 1 In Gujarat, in July 1927 2 January 29, 1928
('41', 173, 0, 1, 343110) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 173, 1, 2, 343152) “This meeting of the Senate of the Gujarat Vidyapith is of opinion that 1. By having established the Gujarat Vidyapith in connection with the non co operation movement and by maintaining it in spite of a set back in the movement, Gujarat has rendered essential service to the nation.
('41', 173, 1, 3, 343436) 2. The Vidyapith has however continued year after year to suffer in point of numbers.
('41', 173, 1, 4, 343522) 3. The Vidyapith could have achieved better results in point of quality, had the internal conditions been favourable; and, 4. The Vidyapith has now reached a stage in its evolution, when, in order to make it work more effectively and in order to ensure an unswerving observance of the principles hereinafter enunciated, the administration of the Vidyapith should be entrusted to a Board of Trustees.
('41', 173, 1, 5, 343922) 5. Therefore, and in pursuance of the resolution for the reconstruction of the Vidyapith passed by this Senate on the 4th of December 1927, the Senate appoints a Board of Trustees called the Gujarat Vidyapith Mandal to be composed of those who, from the list herein below, pledge themselves to subscribe to and observe the principles hereinafter enunciated; hands over charge of all the institutions connected with the Vidyapith, along with their property, movable and immovable, as also all the rights and responsibilities pertaining thereto, to the said Vidyapith Mandal; and authorizes the Mandal to add to its membership subject to the same qualifications so as not to exceed 25; and authorizes it to exercise all other rights including that of filling vacancies caused by resignation, death, or dismissal of any member for breach of the pledge or similar other reason, the latter to take place by a vote of four fifths of their number.
('41', 173, 2, 6, 344863) NAMES OF MEMBERS 1. Sjt.
('41', 173, 2, 7, 344888) Vallabhbhai Patel 2. ,, Nrisimhaprasad Bhatt 3. ,, Kaka Kalelkar 4. ,, Shankerlal Banker 5. ,, Mahadev Desai 6. ,, Abdul Kadar Bavazir

('41', 174, 2, 3, 345360) PRINCIPLE 1. The principal object of the Vidyapith shall be to prepare workers of character, ability, education and conscientiousness, necessary for the conduct of the movements connected with the attainment of swaraj.
('41', 174, 2, 4, 345579) 2. All the institutions conducted by and affiliated to the Vidyapith shall be fully non co operating and shall therefore have nothing to do with any help from Government.
('41', 174, 2, 5, 345750) 3. Whereas the Vidyapith has come into being in connection with swaraj, and non violent non co operation as a means thereof, its teachers and trustees shall restrict themselves to those means only which are not inconsistent with truth and non violence and shall consciously strive to carry them out.
('41', 174, 2, 6, 346050) 4. The teachers and the trustees of the Vidyapith, as also all the institutions affiliated to it, shall regard untouchability as a blot on Hinduism, shall strive to the best of their power for its removal, and shall not exclude a boy or girl for reason of his or her untouchability nor shall give him or her differential treatment having once accorded admission to him or her.
('41', 174, 2, 7, 346427) 5. The teachers and the trustees of and all the institutions affiliated to the Vidyapith shall regard hand spinning as an essential part of the swaraj movement and shall therefore spin regularly, except when disabled, and shall habitually wear khadi.
('41', 174, 2, 8, 346678) 6. The language of the Province shall have the principal place in the Vidyapith and shall be the medium of instruction.
('41', 174, 2, 9, 346798) EXPLANATION.
('41', 174, 2, 10, 346811) Languages other than Gujarati may be taught by direct method.
('41', 175, 0, 1, 346873) 176 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 175, 1, 2, 346915) 7. The teaching of Hindi Hindustani shall be compulsory in the curricula of the Vidyapith.
('41', 175, 1, 3, 347006) 8. Manual training shall receive the same importance as intellectual training and only such occupations as are useful for the life of the nation shall be taught.
('41', 175, 1, 4, 347168) 9. Whereas the growth of the nation depends not on cities but its villages, the bulk of the funds of the Vidyapith and a majority of the teachers of the Vidyapith shall be employed in the propagation of education conducive to the welfare of the villagers.
('41', 175, 1, 5, 347424) 10. In laying down the curricula, the needs of village dwellers shall have principal consideration.
('41', 175, 1, 6, 347524) 11. There shall be complete toleration of all established religions in all institutions conducted by and affiliated to the Vidyapith, and for the spiritual development of the pupils, religious instruction shall be imparted in consonance with truth and non violence.
('41', 175, 1, 7, 347790) 12. For the physical development of the nation, physical exercise and physical training shall be compulsory in all the institutions conducted by and affiliated to the Vidyapith.

('41', 185, 1, 2, 363490) 204. AFTER HARTAL?
('41', 185, 2, 3, 363509) With great deliberation and not without the exercise of great self restraint have I hitherto refrained practically from writing anything about the boycott of the Statutory Commission.
('41', 185, 2, 4, 363693) I recognized the force of the appeal made to me by the Leader of Allahabad not to meddle with or influence the boycott movement, but to let the various parties manage it themselves.
('41', 185, 2, 5, 363875) I recognized that my interference was bound to bring in the masses more prominently into the movement and might possibly embarrass the promoters.
('41', 185, 2, 6, 364021) Now that the great demonstration is over, I feel free to say a word.
('41', 185, 2, 7, 364090) I tender my congr atulations to the organizers for the very great success they achieved on the hartal day 1. It did my soul good to see Liberals, Independents and Congressmen ranged together on the same platform.
('41', 185, 2, 8, 364303) I could not but admire the courage of the students of Government colleges in absenting themselves from their colleges for the sake of the national cause.
('41', 185, 2, 9, 364457) All the world over students are playing a most important and effective part in shaping and strengthening national movements.
('41', 185, 2, 10, 364582) It would be monstrous if the students of India did less.
('41', 185, 2, 11, 364639) My object now is to draw attention to the fact that the very success of the hartal will be turned against us if it is not followed up by sufficient and persistent action.
('41', 185, 2, 12, 364810) We must belie the prophecy of Lord Sinha that the hartal was but a passing cloud.
('41', 185, 2, 13, 364892) Let us bear in mind that, notwithstanding our opposition, the Commission, backed as it is by British bayonets, will go its own way.
('41', 185, 2, 14, 365024) Where it cannot get bona fide recognition, it will be manufactured for it.
('41', 185, 2, 15, 365099) Did not a so called deputation on behalf of ‘untouchables’ welcome the Commi ssion as its true deliverers?
('41', 185, 2, 16, 365206) Claiming to know the untouchables more than the members of the deputation, I make bold to assert that they no more represented the untouchables than would a party of Japanese, for instance.
('41', 185, 2, 17, 365396) If then we are to ensure a complete boycott, not only will there have to be a joint organization by all the parties for carrying it out and possibly picketing, wherever the Commission goes, but there must be some further demonstration of the nation’s strength.
('41', 185, 2, 18, 365657) Even though mine may be a voice in the wilderness and even at the risk of repeating a thousandth time the same old story, I suggest that there is
('41', 185, 3, 19, 365803) 1 February 3, 1928
('41', 186, 0, 1, 365822) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 187
('41', 186, 1, 2, 365864) nothing before the nation other than boycott of foreign cloth which can be brought about effectively and quickly.
('41', 186, 1, 3, 365978) But like all great undertakings, it requires planning and organizing.
('41', 186, 1, 4, 366048) It requires sustained and vigilant effort by a party of earnest, able and honest men and women exclusively devoted to the task.
('41', 186, 1, 5, 366176) It is not an easy task.
('41', 186, 1, 6, 366200) If it was, it would not produce the great results that are promised for it.
('41', 186, 1, 7, 366276) It must evoke the best in the nation, before it is accomplished.
('41', 186, 1, 8, 366341) But let us also frankly recognize that if we cannot organize this one thing, we shall organize nothing else.
('41', 186, 1, 9, 366450) Let me make my own position clear.
('41', 186, 1, 10, 366485) I have no desire even now to interfere with the present evolution of the national movement except through occasional writings.
('41', 186, 1, 11, 366612) This is written, therefore, by way of a humble appeal to the different parties who are jointly acting in order to vindicate national honour.
('41', 186, 2, 12, 366753) Young India, 9 2 1928
('41', 186, 3, 13, 366775) 205. NOTES
('41', 186, 4, 14, 366786) UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA Though through the heroic efforts of the Rt.
('41', 186, 4, 15, 366853) Srinivasa Sastri the social status of our countrymen in South Africa has undoubtedly improved and life is becoming less unbearable for self respecting Indians, reminders come now and then from that sub continent that much yet remains to be done before the Indian settlers enjoy the ordinary civic rights and feel their position safe.
('41', 186, 4, 16, 367187) The latest shock comes through a cable just received from Mr. Albert Christopher, the new Deputy President of the South African Indian Congress.
('41', 186, 4, 17, 367332) Mr. Christopher was one of the volunteers who served as well during the Boer War as during the late War.
('41', 186, 4, 18, 367437) He is South Africa born and has just returned after finishing his education in England.
('41', 186, 4, 19, 367525) The cable runs as follows:
('41', 186, 5, 20, 367552) Second reading Liquor Bill now going through Parliament notwithstanding strong protest.
('41', 186, 5, 21, 367640) Bill seeks deprive three thousand Indians their families and dependents of livelihood ultimately drive them out of country.
('41', 186, 5, 22, 367764) Bill direct conflict letter spirit Cape Town Agreement.
('41', 186, 5, 23, 367820) Clear racial legislation.
('41', 186, 5, 24, 367846) Indians greatly alarmed Government’s attitude.
('41', 186, 5, 25, 367893) If Bill passes Cape Town Agreement smashed.
('41', 186, 5, 26, 367937) Earnestly appeal your immediate interven tion.
('41', 186, 5, 27, 367984) Even the respectable South African Press agrees with the opinion of the South African Congress that the Bill violates the
('41', 187, 0, 1, 368106) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 187, 1, 2, 368148) Agreement which resulted from the Round Table Conference.
('41', 187, 1, 3, 368206) That it is aimed even at those who are already earning an honest livelihood in hotels and bars is unquestioned.
('41', 187, 1, 4, 368318) If the Union Parliament persists in the Bill, it simply means that being the stronger party to the contract, it can safely commit breach of contract whenever it wills.
('41', 187, 1, 5, 368486) Our hope lies in Sjt.
('41', 187, 1, 6, 368508) Sastri’s gentle diplomacy saving not only the situation, but the honour of the Union Government, the Union Parliament and the white people of South Africa in spite of themselves.
('41', 187, 1, 7, 368687) He, however, needs energetic support from the Indian Press and the Indian public.
('41', 187, 2, 8, 368769) A PARALLEL FROM CHINA A friend sends me a cutting from the New York Times containing the report of an interview with Mr. Ku Hung Ming, one of the most prominent Chinese, referring to the cultural greatness of the Chinese people and its being belittled by foreigners.
('41', 187, 2, 9, 369036) And referring to the inroads of foreign merchants upon China, Mr. Ku says:
('41', 187, 3, 10, 369111) “I was similarly blind when I first returned from my long years abroad,” he admits with disarming frankness.
('41', 187, 3, 11, 369220) “At first I was ashamed to admit I was Chinese; now I am so proud of my heritage that I am conceited enough to think the rest of you are all barbarians.
('41', 187, 4, 12, 369373) “You see, our main trouble is economic.
('41', 187, 4, 13, 369413) You Americans, for instance, thought a great influx of Chinese labourers would upset your industry and lower your standard of living.
('41', 187, 4, 14, 369547) You acted promptly and shut your door against Chinese.
('41', 187, 5, 15, 369602) “But we in China have suffered an invasion of your foreign machines and of cheap machine made goods, and those things have ruined us, just [as] an influx of several million Chinese coolie labourers would have ruined your industrial scheme.
('41', 187, 6, 16, 369842) “When I was a young man, for instance, even the women in our own families spun and wove.
('41', 187, 6, 17, 369931) At the time fully 100,000,000 Chinese women spun and wove.
('41', 187, 6, 18, 369990) Then came cheap foreign cotton goods and these 100,000,000 women have no productive life, but must live on the labours of their menfolk.
('41', 187, 6, 19, 370127) We are prevented from following your example of shutting the door by the fact that the treaties forbid our taking any action.
('41', 187, 6, 20, 370253) We do not have even tariff autonomy.
('41', 187, 7, 21, 370290) “If I were an artist, I would draw you a cartoon which would show you what I think of the unequal treaties.
('41', 187, 8, 22, 370398) “Picture a Chinese prone upon the ground and a foreigner standing over him holding him down with his foot.
('41', 187, 8, 23, 370505) ‘Get up,’ say the foreigner.
('41', 187, 8, 24, 370534) ‘Take your foot off first,’ says the Chinese.
('41', 187, 8, 25, 370580) ‘No, you get up first,’ says the foreigner,
('41', 188, 0, 1, 370624) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 189
('41', 188, 1, 2, 370666) putting more weight upon the foot.” AJMAL JAMIA FUND The following sums only have been hitherto received in answer to the appeal in these pages: Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj Rs. 1,000 0 0 Sjt.

('41', 189, 2, 6, 373098) M. A. ANSARI SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 11, 1928
('41', 189, 3, 7, 373159) DEAR DR.
('41', 189, 3, 8, 373168) ANSARI, Don’t you worry about my health.
('41', 189, 3, 9, 373209) Doctors will frighten one.
('41', 189, 3, 10, 373236) This time the registered blood pressure does not seem to produce any impression on me.
('41', 189, 3, 11, 373323) I am keeping fairly [fit].
('41', 189, 3, 12, 373350) I have strength to walk, and I only lie on my back because doctors are impera tive and tell me that some blood pressure cases are most illusive and specially dangerous when the patient himself feels no visible effects.
('41', 189, 3, 13, 373569) This letter I am dictating in connection with Ajmal Jamia Fund.
('41', 189, 3, 14, 373633) Whilst you are in the midst of all the big people, I want you to buttonhole them and get them to subscribe, no matter how much.
('41', 189, 3, 15, 373761) I fear that there will be little spontaneous response or it will come when noted men and women have subscribed.
('41', 189, 3, 16, 373873) If I had not become bedridden, I would have done lobbying this side of India.
('41', 189, 3, 17, 373951) And I have not yet lost hope of being able to do it.
('41', 189, 3, 18, 374004) I am not at all sure of your scheme of deputations going round succeeding.
('41', 189, 3, 19, 374079) I know it is cruel to ask you to spare the time when it is occupied between your practice and direct Congress work.
('41', 189, 3, 20, 374195) But you have got to find it for this work too.
('41', 189, 3, 21, 374242) If you have not seen my article “After Hartal?” 1, please look at it.
('41', 189, 3, 22, 374312) Unless you take up this universal and possible thing, boycott of foreign cloth, the energy created by the boycott of the Statutory Commission will be all waste of effort.
('41', 189, 3, 23, 374483) Every negative action without corresponding positive action becomes useless in the end.

('41', 195, 2, 3, 382861) DEAR FRIEND, Mira has translated your latest letter for me.
('41', 195, 2, 4, 382921) My whole soul goes out to you in your grief especially because it comes over a letter which makes you suspect me of hardness of heart.
('41', 195, 2, 5, 383056) I appreciate your desire to find me correct in all I do and think.
('41', 195, 2, 6, 383123) I do indeed want to stand well with you, but I must be true to myself if I am to continue to deserve your warm friendship.
('41', 195, 2, 7, 383246) Let me first tell you that Mira’s letter reflected her own views though they were found to coincide with mine.
('41', 195, 2, 8, 383357) Neither Mira, so far as I know her, nor I had the remotest idea of judging those two good peasants.
('41', 195, 2, 9, 383457) 1 Their action was undoubtedly one of heroism.
('41', 195, 2, 10, 383504) What we had in our minds was the heroism of a war resister, and from the record sent by you and as it was interpreted to me by Mira, I missed that particular type of heroism which a war resister demonstrates in his own life.
('41', 195, 2, 11, 383729) Joan of Arc was a heroine.
('41', 195, 2, 12, 383756) So were Leonidas and Horatius.
('41', 195, 2, 13, 383787) But the heroism in each case was of a different type, each noble and admirable in its own sphere.
('41', 195, 2, 14, 383885) In the answers given by the peasants, I do not notice any definite repugnance to war as war and a determination to suffer to the uttermost in their resistance to war.
('41', 195, 2, 15, 384052) These peasant friends, if my recollection serves me right, are heroes representing and defending the simple rustic life.
('41', 195, 2, 16, 384173) These heroes are no less precious than those of a militant war resister type.
('41', 195, 2, 17, 384251) We want to treasure all this heroism, but what I feel is that we will serve the heroes and the cause of truth better if we treated each type separately.
('41', 195, 2, 18, 384404) You have curiously raised the question of my participation in the late War.

('41', 197, 5, 8, 387037) What happened to the students during the Rowlatt Act agitation is repeating itself now.
('41', 197, 5, 9, 387125) During those precious days, one of them wrote to me that he felt like committing suicide because he was rusticated.
('41', 197, 5, 10, 387241) A student now writes:
('41', 197, 6, 11, 387263) The students of.
('41', 197, 6, 12, 387280) heard the mother’s call and responded to it.
('41', 197, 6, 13, 387325) We observed hartal on the 3rd.
('41', 197, 6, 14, 387356) For this courageous deed of ours, we are being fined Rs. 2 per head.
('41', 197, 6, 15, 387425) The poor students are losing their freeships, half freeships and scholarships.
('41', 197, 6, 16, 387504) Please write to Mr. .
('41', 197, 6, 17, 387526) the Principal, or advise him through Young India.
('41', 197, 6, 18, 387576) Tell him we are no criminals, we have committed no crime.
('41', 197, 6, 19, 387634) Tell him we listened and responded to the mother’s call, we saved her, to our utmost, from dishonour.
('41', 197, 6, 20, 387736) Tell him we are no cowards.
('41', 197, 6, 21, 387764) Please come forward to our aid.
('41', 197, 6, 22, 387796) I cannot follow the advice to write the Principal.
('41', 197, 6, 23, 387847) If he is not to lose his ‘job’, I suppose he has to take some disciplinary measures.
('41', 197, 6, 24, 387932) So long as educational institutions remain under the partronage of the Government, they will be, as they must be, used for the support of the Government, and the students or the teachers who support anti Government popular measures must count the cost and take the risk of being dismissed.
('41', 197, 6, 25, 388222) From the patriot’s standpoint, the students did well and braverly in making common cause with the people.
('41', 197, 6, 26, 388328) They would have laid themselves open to the charge of want of patriotism, if not wrose, if they had not responded to country’s call.
('41', 197, 6, 27, 388461) From the Government standpoint, they undoubtedly did wrong and incurred their severe displeasure.
('41', 197, 6, 28, 388559) The students cannot blow hot and cold.
('41', 197, 6, 29, 388598) If they will be with the people’s cause, they must hold their scholastic
('41', 197, 7, 30, 388671) 1 Gandhiji had fainted while spinning on February 5, and had been advised complete rest
('41', 198, 0, 1, 388759) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 199
('41', 198, 1, 2, 388801) career sub servient to the cause and sacrifice it when it comes in conflict with the interest of the country.
('41', 198, 1, 3, 388911) I saw this quite clearly in 1920 and subsequent experience has confirmed the first impression There in no doubt that the safest and the most honourable course for the student world is to leave Government schools and colleges at any cost.
('41', 198, 1, 4, 389149) But the next best course for them is to hold themselves in readiness to be thrown out whenever a conflict occurs between the Government and the people.
('41', 198, 1, 5, 389301) If they will not be, as they have been elsewhere, leaders themselves in the revolt against the Government, they must at least become staunch and true followers.
('41', 198, 1, 6, 389462) Let their facing of the consequences be as was their response to the nation’s call.
('41', 198, 1, 7, 389546) Let them not humiliate themselves, let them not surrender their self respect in trying to re enter colleges and schools from which they may have been dismissed.
('41', 198, 1, 8, 389707) The bravery of their response will be counted as bravado, if it succumbs on the very first trial.
('41', 198, 1, 9, 389805) I hear that, during the days preceding the hartal, the students discarded foreign cloth and very largely patronized khadi.
('41', 198, 1, 10, 389928) Let it not be said of them that this was but a passing show and that they have, on pressure from without or temptation from within, discarded khadi as quickly as they discarded foreign cloth.
('41', 198, 1, 11, 390120) To me foreign cloth for this country means foreign Government.
('41', 198, 1, 12, 390183) I wish this was accepted as a self evident proposition.

('41', 198, 3, 14, 390262) 218. MY HEALTH
('41', 198, 4, 15, 390277) It is a matter of great sorrow to me that my health should cause anxiety to many friends.
('41', 198, 4, 16, 390367) Hitherto I have allowed Mahadev Desai, subject to censorship, to write whatever he has wished about my health, seeing that the break downs, important or unimportant, occurred whilst I was travelling, and were supposed to be due to fatigue, and because those who were in charge of me during the travels had a responsibility about my bodily condition.
('41', 198, 4, 17, 390717) But circumstances have now altered.
('41', 198, 4, 18, 390753) I am having a respite from travels and onerous public duties.
('41', 198, 4, 19, 390815) I am taking part only to the extent that I wish in reorganizing some of the activities in Gujarat, specially educational, for which I am perhaps predominantly responsible.
('41', 198, 4, 20, 390987) I have, therefore, felt called upon to take up what has been a hobby of a lifetime, namely, dietetic experiments.
('41', 198, 4, 21, 391101) They are to me as important as many of the most important activities which have engrossed me from time to time, and it was in the course
('41', 199, 0, 1, 391238) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 199, 1, 2, 391280) of these experiments that the present so called break down has occurred.
('41', 199, 1, 3, 391353) The alarming registrations of doctors’ instruments have had no reponse in my own feeling.
('41', 199, 1, 4, 391443) But I have accepted the statement of medical friends that very often blood pressure patients feel no evil effects, although they may be stealthily present in the body and must, therefore, be guarded against.
('41', 199, 1, 5, 391651) Happily, however, even these instruments registered last Sunday a very great improvement, a fall from 214mm.
('41', 199, 1, 6, 391760) systolic to 178mm.
('41', 199, 1, 7, 391779) and a rise from 120mm.
('41', 199, 1, 8, 391802) [sic] diastolic to 118mm.
('41', 199, 1, 9, 391828) I am also taking the rest prescribed by Dr. Haribhai Desai and his medical companions, and carrying on my dietetic experiments under their observations and guidance.
('41', 199, 1, 10, 391994) Dr. Muthu who seems to have made special study of dietetics is also kindly guiding me by correspondence.
('41', 199, 1, 11, 392099) Having given all this information, I would implore newspaper correspondents to curb their pen and kindly to forget me and my health for the time being.
('41', 199, 1, 12, 392251) And I would ask anxious friends not to worry about my health, accepting my assurance that I am in no hurry to die and that, therefore, I shall be taking all the care of my body that is humanly possible for me, and is consistent with the ideals to which the body is dedicated and which I hold to be more precious than the body.
('41', 199, 1, 13, 392578) Let the friends rest assured that, if the nation has any use for this body of mine, it is because a serious attempt has been made for many a long year to hold it in trust for those ideals.
('41', 199, 1, 14, 392767) I would ask them also the share my belief, which I hold even at the risk of being dubbed a fatalist, that not one hair of anyone’s body can be touched without His will and that when He has no use for our bodies, He defies all the care, attention and skill that money, prestige, patriotism, friendship and what not can summon to one’s assistance.
('41', 199, 1, 15, 393113) This belief does not mean that I do not want to take advantage of the assistance that medical friends all over India ungrudgingly and most generously render to me.
('41', 199, 1, 16, 393277) I take that assistance gladly and faithfully.
('41', 199, 1, 17, 393323) For God has given me no inkling of His intentions, but He has imposed upon me the duty of taking care of the body consistently with other more imperative obligations which, in my opinion, He has imposed upon me in common with the rest of humanity.
('41', 199, 2, 18, 393571) Young India, 16 2 1928
('41', 200, 0, 1, 393594) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 201
('41', 200, 1, 2, 393636) 219. FLOOD RELIEF WORK IN SIND I gladly publish the following first instalment 1 of notes by Prof.
('41', 200, 1, 3, 393735) N. R. Malkani about the distress in Sind which was truly no less acute than in Gujarat.
('41', 200, 1, 4, 393823) But as I have already remarked before, Gujarat attracted the widest attention not merely because of its being the store house of India’s donors, but also, and perhaps more, because it found an army of workers under Vallabhbhai Patel ready and determined to handle and organize the task of relieving distress.
('41', 200, 1, 5, 394132) Sind no less than Orissa suffered because they could not produce such an organization.
('41', 200, 1, 6, 394219) But no lack of organization can be allowed to excuse any avoidable misery.
('41', 200, 1, 7, 394294) The public should know that Prof.
('41', 200, 1, 8, 394328) Malkani is himself personally organizing the relief operations under the supervision of the Central Committee which, I hope, is giving him all the assistance he may need.
('41', 200, 1, 9, 394499) Young India, 16 2 1928
('41', 200, 2, 10, 394522) 220. CORRESPONDENCE If for nothing else, I cannot refrain from publishing the foregoing 2 for its subtle wit and sarcasm.
('41', 200, 2, 11, 394644) Unfortunately for me, I am responsible for the phrase ‘blot on Hinduism’, notwithstanding my claim, often repudiated I know, to be a sanatani Hindu.
('41', 200, 2, 12, 394793) If the institution of war, in spite of its being contrary to the spirit of the Christian teaching, may be said to be a blot upon Christianity because war is universal in Christendom, untouchability may safely be regarded as a blot Hinduism in spite of the contention of a growing number of Hindus that untouchability has no place in true Hinduism.
('41', 200, 2, 13, 395141) If the expression pains some Hindus, it is a healthy sign.
('41', 200, 2, 14, 395200) When it pains the majority of Hindus and they repudiate the charge, there will be no occasion to repeat it.
('41', 200, 2, 15, 395308) And if it is a blot, why may not a Mussalman who believed in the truth and purity of Hinduism hold with his Hindu co member that it is a blot ?
('41', 200, 2, 16, 395452) Young India, 16 2 1928

('41', 200, 3, 20, 395750) He had suggested that it could be changed to “blot on humanity” or deleted altogether.

('41', 203, 6, 19, 400056) The Simon Commission is a public thing, whereas the wedding is a private affair.
('41', 203, 6, 20, 400137) A wedding cannot affect the future of three hundred millions of India but the doings of the Simon Commission are calculated for better or for worse to affect the future of the whole of India.
('41', 203, 6, 21, 400329) You can now understand the public resentment over the Simon Commission.
('41', 203, 6, 22, 400401) Nobody thinks anything of the misdeeds of private Englishmen or other white men.
('41', 203, 6, 23, 400482) But when an Englishman does anything wrong in his official capacity, it is immediately resented and quite properly too.
('41', 203, 6, 24, 400602) If you have not yet understood or do not appreciate the distinction I have made, please write to me.
