('41', 204, 4, 8, 401411) 225. HAKIM AJMAL KHAN MEMORIAL
('41', 204, 5, 9, 401442) Readers know that this memorial is with regard to the Nationalist Muslim University in Delhi.
('41', 204, 5, 10, 401536) This Vidyapith is not meant exclusively for Muslims.
('41', 204, 5, 11, 401589) Hindus may also join it.
('41', 204, 5, 12, 401614) The teachers too are not exclusively Muslim; Hindus and Christians also are there.
('41', 204, 5, 13, 401697) However, as in the case of the Gujarat Vidyapith, where the students are mostly Hindus, since Muslim students rarely join it, so at the Jamia Millia too, few Hindus are enrolled.
('41', 204, 5, 14, 401876) If the authorities of the Gujarat Vidyapith could be blamed for the reluctance of Muslim students the authorities of the Muslim university can also be blamed for the reluctance of Hindu students to join them.
('41', 204, 5, 15, 402085) Considering the present vitiated atmosphere we should be content and grateful to God if the management and the staff of both the institutions are free from rancour and mutually accomodating.
('41', 204, 5, 16, 402276) It is my belief that just as the Gujarat Vidyapith will contribute substantially towards the attainment of swaraj and will help to safeguard it, that is, in implementing such constructive programmes as Hindu Muslim unity, etc., so too will this Vidyapith at Delhi.
('41', 204, 5, 17, 402541) This prophecy of mine may or may not come true but if we owe anything to Hakim Saheb, and if it brings us credit to have a memorial to him for ever with us, we should all, to the best of our abilities, contribute to his Fund.
('41', 204, 5, 18, 402767) The Fund is growing at less thana snail’s pace, from which I gather that the Gujaratis do not respond to this cause as they do to other causes.
('41', 204, 5, 19, 402911) I regard it my duty to say that
('41', 205, 0, 1, 402943) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 205, 1, 2, 402985) this is not the correct attitude.
('41', 205, 1, 3, 403019) Those who wish to achieve Hindu Muslim unity should help this cause.
('41', 205, 1, 4, 403088) Everyone is inclined to contribute to a popular cause.
('41', 205, 1, 5, 403143) People remain indifferent to a fund which is not popular, though it be beneficial in the long run, if there is no one to rouse them.
('41', 205, 1, 6, 403276) This is my appeal to that indifferent class.
('41', 205, 1, 7, 403321) It is not that the readers of Navajivan always encourage only what is popular.
('41', 205, 1, 8, 403400) The readers of Navajivan have contributed in other ways, if not in the form of money, to funds that were not popular but would increase people’s strength.
('41', 205, 1, 9, 403555) They must now show that liberal spirit and power of discretion.
('41', 205, 1, 10, 403619) Let not the Jamia Millia be crushed between the two opposing forces.
('41', 205, 1, 11, 403688) Since the Jamia Millia does not nourish the present atmosphere of hatred, the general Muslim masses appear indifferent towards it, and if the Hindus too should be indifferent under the presumption that Muslims alone should support it, the Jamia Millia would be nowhere and Hakimji’s memorial would meet with the same fate.
('41', 205, 1, 12, 404011) It is the special duty of Swarajists, Hindus as well as Muslims, not to let this happen.
('41', 205, 1, 13, 404100) I hope the readers of Navajivan will observe this dharma.
('41', 205, 1, 14, 404158) I suggest donors should not rest content after giving in their personal contributions but should also try to collect as much as possible from their neighbours.
('41', 205, 1, 15, 404318) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 2 1928
('41', 205, 2, 16, 404355) 226. TO THE PEASANTS OF BARDOLI
('41', 205, 3, 17, 404387) There is not a corner of India familiar with the word ‘swaraj’ which is not also familiar with Bardoli.
('41', 205, 3, 18, 404491) The country has, therefore, a right to expect something distinctive and courageous in all the tasks that are undertaken by this taluk.
('41', 205, 3, 19, 404626) You have taken the very grave step of offering satyagraha.
('41', 205, 3, 20, 404685) You have now no alternative but to prove yourselves worthy of it.
('41', 205, 3, 21, 404751) No one could have found fault with you if you had not taken that step.
('41', 205, 3, 22, 404822) However, having once taken it, you will make yourselves an object of ridicule in the eyes of the whole of India if you beat a retreat now.
('41', 205, 3, 23, 404961) No one can blame Bardoli for the postponement of the fight for swaraj that it had pioneered.
('41', 205, 3, 24, 405054) People in a far off province committed an act of indiscretion and the Bardoli movement had to be postponed.
('41', 205, 3, 25, 405162) I have not the slightest doubt that it was all to the good.
('41', 205, 3, 26, 405222) However, on this occasion, I think it is proper to remind you that thereafter you have not been keeping to the extent you should your vows about khadi, untouchability and so on.
('41', 206, 0, 1, 405400) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 207
('41', 206, 1, 2, 405442) because of this laxity on your part, I have my doubts about how far you will adhere to the pledge you have taken this time.
('41', 206, 1, 3, 405566) I hope you will dispel this fear by your determined conduct.
('41', 206, 1, 4, 405627) Shri Vallabhbhai Patel had given you a clear warning.
('41', 206, 1, 5, 405681) It is not in his hands to make a success of your struggle.
('41', 206, 1, 6, 405740) The key to success is in your own hands.
('41', 206, 1, 7, 405781) Even if he goes to the gallows, Vallabhbhai cannot fulfil your pledge.
('41', 206, 1, 8, 405852) As the saying goes: “One cannot go to heaven unless one dies.” So also one has to fulfil one’s own pledges.
('41', 206, 1, 9, 405960) I do not think there are two opinions about the justice of your cause.
('41', 206, 1, 10, 406031) If, however, you do not have the strength to prove it you will not triumph despite its justice.
('41', 206, 1, 11, 406127) If you understand it, rather than till the land only to pay the vighoti 1 it would be saving yourselves a great deal of trouble if those who collect this tax confiscated your land.
('41', 206, 1, 12, 406308) If the Government will not listen to you and you do not bow down to them—and if the Government aims at ruining you, it will not send you to jails, but will rather seize your property.
('41', 206, 1, 13, 406492) As in Kheda, here too they would confiscate your utensils and your land.
('41', 206, 1, 14, 406565) Nevertheless, you have one invaluable thing which they cannot attach and that is your soul, your self respect.
('41', 206, 1, 15, 406676) If you put your person and all your property in one scale and your self respect in the other, the latter will always be found heavier.
('41', 206, 1, 16, 406811) Satyagraha is the mantra for safeguarding it.
('41', 206, 1, 17, 406857) Victory is is yours if you are prepared to withstand whatever loss you may incur while safeguarding it and you will prove worthy of having a leader like Vallabhbhai; moreover, you yourselves will be included in the catergory of the courageous.
('41', 206, 1, 18, 407101) You must see to it that by fulfilling your pledge you enhance your own prestige as well as that of Vallabhbhai, Gujarat and the whole of India.

('41', 210, 4, 9, 411535) 234. LETTER TO HENRY NEIL
('41', 210, 5, 10, 411561) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 22, 1928
('41', 210, 6, 11, 411602) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 1. Under British rule, millions of children are starving for want of nourishing food and they are shivering in winter for want of sufficient clothing.
('41', 210, 6, 12, 411785) And this I say not of the cities of India, which contain but a microscopic minority of the population of India, but I say this without fear of contradiction about the seven hundred thousand villages of the country scattered over a surface 1,900 miles long and 1,500 miles broad.
('41', 210, 6, 13, 412064) I suppose your first question ‘under non Christian Religions’ is included in the second.
('41', 210, 6, 14, 412153) But, if your first question relates to India before British rule, I can only give you my inference that the little ones were infinitely happier than they are now under British rule.
('41', 210, 6, 15, 412335) Your third question is difficult to answer.
('41', 210, 6, 16, 412379) Which Jesus have you in mind?
('41', 210, 6, 17, 412409) The Jesus of history?
('41', 210, 6, 18, 412431) Not being a critical student of history, I do not know the Jesus of history.

('41', 214, 1, 2, 418392) 239. REMINDING OF OLD TIMES Sjt.
('41', 214, 1, 3, 418425) Shankarrao Dev and Sjt.
('41', 214, 1, 4, 418449) V. B. Harolikar were convicted the other day at Poona under Section 124 A and sentenced to undergo imprisonment for two years with hard labour.
('41', 214, 1, 5, 418593) There were two charges against them: waging war against the King (Section 121) and attempting to excite disaffection against the Government established by law in British India (Section 124 A).
('41', 214, 1, 6, 418786) Dev as editor of Swarajya wrote the article which was the subject matter of the offence and Sjt.
('41', 214, 1, 7, 418883) Harolikar was the publisher.
('41', 214, 1, 8, 418912) I print elsewhere the authorized translation of the offending article as produced before the court by the prosecution.
('41', 214, 1, 9, 419031) Though it admits of improvement, it cannot be called an unfair presentation of the original.
('41', 214, 1, 10, 419124) The accused will not be defended by counsel though free assistance was volunteered by Dadasaheb Karandikar and other lawyers of distinction.
('41', 214, 1, 11, 419265) Friends advised them to be defended.
('41', 214, 1, 12, 419302) They were told that everybody nowadays sought legal advice without any slur being cast on them.
('41', 214, 1, 13, 419398) But these non co operators were adamant.
('41', 214, 1, 14, 419439) They did not care what others did.
('41', 214, 1, 15, 419474) They were non co operators on principle and therefore did not wish to listen to any advice based on prudential considerations.
('41', 214, 1, 16, 419601) I knew Sjt.
('41', 214, 1, 17, 419613) Dev in Yeravda.
('41', 214, 1, 18, 419629) He with Sjt.
('41', 214, 1, 19, 419642) Dastane had undertaken a severe fast from which it was difficult for me to wean them.
('41', 214, 1, 20, 419728) I tender my congratulations to these friends on their firmness in abiding by their own convictions.
('41', 214, 1, 21, 419828) For I am convinced that of such will the Kingdom of Swaraj be made.
('41', 214, 1, 22, 419896) They have undoubtedly brought swaraj nearer by their crystal like sacrifice.
('41', 214, 1, 23, 419973) Let no one think that such solitary individual sacrifice has no place in national upbuilding, or that it does not produce great consequences.
('41', 214, 1, 24, 420115) Indeed, it is the purest sacrifice alone that will count in the end.
('41', 214, 1, 25, 420184) It lays the surest and the purest foundation of swaraj.
('41', 214, 1, 26, 420240) The article is undoubtedly written to promote disaffection against the existing Government.
('41', 214, 1, 27, 420332) To promote such disaffection is the bounden duty of every nationalist.
('41', 214, 1, 28, 420403) Every Congressman is, I hope, an avowed enemy of the existing Government.
('41', 214, 1, 29, 420477) We have no quarrel with men, but if we are worthy of swaraj, we must destroy the existing system of Government by all legitimate and peaceful means.
('41', 214, 1, 30, 420626) The recent debate in the Assembly on the Statutory Com mission was an object lesson in disaffection in which all parties, be it said to their eternal credit, whole heartedly joined.
('41', 214, 1, 31, 420808) The late Harchandrai Vishandas
('41', 215, 0, 1, 420839) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 215, 1, 2, 420881) risked his life in travelling to Delhi for the sake of registering his vote in favour of disaffection.
('41', 215, 1, 3, 420984) One daily comes across stronger articles than Dev’s in point of disaffection.
('41', 215, 1, 4, 421062) His is a reasoned appeal to Hindus and Mussalmans to disown the protection of a Government that enslaves the country and if fight they must, fight fairly, squarely, honourably.
('41', 215, 1, 5, 421239) I have read the article more than once and whilst I may not use the same language, there is nothing in the argument that I cannot adopt.
('41', 215, 1, 6, 421376) A prejudiced critic may cavil at the verse quoted from the Mahabharata.
('41', 215, 1, 7, 421448) But, read together with the context, its meaning is clear.
('41', 215, 1, 8, 421507) We have no King.

('41', 215, 1, 11, 421599) They come and go.

('41', 215, 1, 14, 421724) The cost that Dev and people like him are prepared to pay has to be consistent with their creed of non violence.
('41', 215, 1, 15, 421837) They seek to establish the rule of real law not by killing other people, however misguided or cruel they may be, but by being themselves killed, if need be, in the attempt.
('41', 215, 1, 16, 422010) This is the necessary limitation imposed upon them by their very conception of swaraj.
('41', 215, 1, 17, 422097) It is, therefore, most difficult for me to understand why these two innocent workers were singled out for prosecution, or shall I call it, persecution.
('41', 215, 1, 18, 422249) If they are fit for imprisonment, Lala Lajpat Rai and company are surely fit for transportation, if nothing worse.
('41', 215, 1, 19, 422364) If it be said that the Assembly gives members privileges for statutory crimes which ordinary mortals outside do not enjoy, there is then, perhaps, no one who is guilty of such calculated and deliberate disaffection towards the ‘Government established by law’ as I am.
('41', 215, 1, 20, 422632) The whole of my being is worked in order to achieve the destruction of this Government and to that end to spread disaffection as wide as possible, and I think I can lay a fair claim to having a somewhat larger audience than Dev and Harolikar.
('41', 215, 1, 21, 422875) But real consistency, justice and courage are hardly to be expected of governments that are based upon exploitation sustained by violence.

('41', 216, 1, 2, 423079) 240. HANDLOOM v.
('41', 216, 1, 3, 423096) SPINNING WHEEL
('41', 216, 2, 4, 423111) Apropos of the contention often thoughtlessly advanced than the handloom is the only thing worth preserving and that it can only be preserved through the use of mill spun yarn, Sjt.
('41', 216, 2, 5, 423293) C. Balaji Rao writes:
('41', 216, 3, 6, 423315) An effective answer to those who, in order to belittle the charkha, would exalt the handloom, is given here.
('41', 216, 3, 7, 423424) Lord Curzon was voicing the opinions of his departmental scientific advisers when he declared at the Delhi Durbar that it was inevitable that the handloom should be superseded by the powerloom, just as the hand punkah was being superseded by the electric fan.
('41', 216, 3, 8, 423684) Of course, Lord Curzon’s dictum need not be accepted as a conclusive answer if the longevity of the handloom can be sustained through mill yarn or any other means save the spinning wheel.
('41', 216, 3, 9, 423872) And these pages, I hope, are daily making it clear that hand spinning can save the handloom in spite of the prediction of Lord Curzon.
('41', 216, 3, 10, 424007) Indeed, if the wheel regains its ancient status in our national life, the handloom and many other domestic industries must revive automatically.
('41', 216, 3, 11, 424152) Young India, 23 2 1928
('41', 216, 4, 12, 424175) 241. THE ORIGIN OF IT
('41', 216, 5, 13, 424197) I observe that newspaper paragraphs have been going round that I have predicted my own death by the 12th of March next and that, as a consquence, I am in a despondent mood.
('41', 216, 5, 14, 424370) It is also stated that I am my own astrologer.
('41', 216, 5, 15, 424417) I would have passed over this delicious morsel of news but for the fact that many anxious friends have taken it seriously and have, therefore, been upset.
('41', 216, 5, 16, 424572) If the enquiring friends had only followed my advice never to depend upon newspaper paragraphs, but always to ascertain, at their source, the truth of statements seen in the Press, they would have been spared all that anxiety.
('41', 216, 5, 17, 424799) The correspon dent who set the news in motion could also have spared the enquirers considerable anxiety if he had been good enough to test the truth of statements made by him.
('41', 216, 5, 18, 424975) But if the correspondents became more scrupulous about statements they may make, their occupation would be largely gone.
('41', 216, 5, 19, 425096) I may then state for the information of friends that I am not an astrologer, I know nothing of the science of astrology and that I consider it to be a science, if it is a science, of doubtful value, to be severely left alone by those who have any faith in Providence.
('41', 217, 0, 1, 425364) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 217, 1, 2, 425406) am I in a despondent mood, despondency being foreign to my nature.
('41', 217, 1, 3, 425473) What precisely, however, did happen was this.
('41', 217, 1, 4, 425519) When I was convicted six years ago and was asked what I thought about the prospects of swaraj, I said that it was highly likely that there was the hand of God in the limit of six years and that during that time either we should win swaraj or that I should die and that six years’ time was long enough time for the country to win her freedom.
('41', 217, 1, 5, 425861) This statement was based upon an observation of the state of things as then prevailed in India.
('41', 217, 1, 6, 425957) I never attached any importance to it beyond this that I should myself leave no stone unturned to contribute so far as an individual could to the attainment of our freedom.
('41', 217, 1, 7, 426130) The statement was on a par with the conditional statement made by me in 1920 about attainment of swaraj within one year.
('41', 217, 1, 8, 426251) 1 That statement has served the purpose, if of nothing else, of giving satisfaction to my critics of laughing at my folly and to me that of seeing a tremendous effort being made by the country during that eventful year.
('41', 217, 1, 9, 426471) I did not hesitate to say at the end of the year, when the Congress was held in Ahmedabad, that whilst we had not been able to achieve statutory swaraj, the freedom that politically minded India gave itself and the unity that seemed to exist among the various communities amounted to substantial swaraj, and that if the people had carried out the conditions mentioned by me at Calcutta and Nagpur, they could have even attained statutory swaraj within the year.
('41', 217, 1, 10, 426933) But even as I remained unaffected, in spite of the failure to attain statutory swaraj within the year specified, so do I remain unaffected in spite of the approaching termination of six years which, by the by, is not the 12th of March but the 17th of March next 2 .
('41', 217, 1, 11, 427199) Not only am I not preparing for the imminent approach of the dissolution of my body, but I am making every effort to put it in as good order and condition as is possible, and have already fixed some provisional appointments for the coming summer and the rainy season.
('41', 217, 1, 12, 427467) After all the relevant portion of my talk six years ago, twice repeated to friends, was the attainment of India’s freedom.
('41', 217, 1, 13, 427590) Nothing depends upon the death of an individual, be he ever so great, but much depends upon the freedom of India.
('41', 217, 1, 14, 427704) Let us, therefore, all forget individuals and concentrate upon attaining that precious freedom which will never be
('41', 217, 2, 15, 427819) 1Vide “Swaraj in One Year”, September 22, 1920 and also Appendix “Congress Resolution on Non Cooperation”, December 30, 1920.
('41', 217, 3, 16, 427945) 2 Gandhiji was sentenced to six years’ imprisonment on March 18, 1922; vide “The Great Trial”.
('41', 218, 0, 1, 428040) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 219
('41', 218, 1, 2, 428082) showered upon us from Downing Street or elsewhere, but which can be ours the for taking any day even inside of the 17th of March.
('41', 218, 1, 3, 428212) No great preparation save a mental revolution is necessary for us— Hindus, Mussalmans, Parsis, Sikhs, Christians and Jews and others—to feel as one indivisible nation and as having a common stake in the country, nor is more than a mental revolution required for Hindus to forget that anyone is to be considered superior to any other and to regard the so called ‘untouchables’ to be their own kith and kin, nor is much effort required if we but make the resolve to achieve complete boycott of foreign cloth.
('41', 218, 1, 4, 428719) I repeat what I have said so often, at the risk of exciting laughter, that if we achieve this triple programme, no power on earth can prevent us from attaining our birthright.
('41', 218, 1, 5, 428895) It is for us to work out our own salvation as it is in us to compass our own undoing.

('41', 220, 1, 2, 431078) 244. LETTER TO BOYD W. TUCKER
('41', 220, 2, 3, 431108) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 24, 1928
('41', 220, 3, 4, 431149) MY DEAR FRIEND, I have your very delightful letter which I deeply appreciate.
('41', 220, 3, 5, 431227) I must not however accept your advice.
('41', 220, 3, 6, 431266) ‘Resist not evil’ with me has never meant passive resistance.
('41', 220, 3, 7, 431328) The word ‘passive resistance’ I have described as a misnomer for the resistance which I have known and offered.
('41', 220, 3, 8, 431440) The paraphrase of ‘resist not evil’ means resist not evil with evil, and therefore necessarily means resist evil with good.
('41', 220, 3, 9, 431564) And, if at the present moment, I do not seem to be actively resisting evil, it is a mere appearance.
('41', 220, 3, 10, 431665) For, if you are a constant reader of Bhagavad Gita, you will recall the passage, “He who sees action in inaction and inaction in action sees truly.” 1 Or is there not the corresponding English saying “He also serves who waits and prays” or something like that?
('41', 220, 3, 11, 431926) Anyway such is absolutely my position today.
('41', 220, 3, 12, 431971) If I could see my way clear leading to boycott movement, do not imagine for one moment that I would sit still for a single moment.
('41', 220, 3, 13, 432102) But the way is not clear.
('41', 220, 3, 14, 432128) It may clear any day.
('41', 220, 3, 15, 432150) I want a living faith on the part of known workers in the boycott as I have prescribed from time to time in the pages of Young India.
('41', 220, 3, 16, 432284) I am positive that no other boycott can possibly succeed, as I am equally positive that this boycott must succeed if there is enough work behind it.
('41', 220, 3, 17, 432433) Huge demonstrations that have been taking place in Calcutta are good in their way, but not good enough for me.
('41', 220, 3, 18, 432544) There is no reality behind them.
('41', 220, 3, 19, 432577) They have their use too, but they cannot enthuse me as an active soldier.
('41', 220, 3, 20, 432651) I hope I am clear.
('41', 220, 3, 21, 432670) If not, do please tackle me again.
('41', 220, 3, 22, 432705) I am anxious for you to understand me and my movement through and through.
('41', 220, 4, 23, 432780) Yours sincerely, REV.
('41', 220, 4, 24, 432802) BOYD W. TUCKER COLLINS HIGH SCHOOL 140 DHARAMTALA STREET CALCUTTA

('41', 221, 1, 2, 432939) 245. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('41', 221, 2, 3, 432972) SABARMATI, February 24, 1928
('41', 221, 3, 4, 433001) CHHAGANLAL, I received your first letter today and the second letter three days earlier.
('41', 221, 3, 5, 433090) I have given them to Mahadev for everyone to read.
('41', 221, 3, 6, 433141) You have done a good job if you have seen in a short period all those institutions as closely as possible.
('41', 221, 3, 7, 433248) Look after your health and for doing so, you have to use a mosquito net.
('41', 221, 3, 8, 433321) Do not have the least hesitation in using it there.
('41', 221, 3, 9, 433373) You might come across people who would criticise it the first day, the next day the same people would praise you for your well maintained health, and on the third, they would follow your example.
('41', 221, 3, 10, 433569) Mosquito net is just an example.
('41', 221, 3, 11, 433602) Do not hesitate to write to me.
('41', 221, 3, 12, 433634) I have always liked your letters.
('41', 221, 3, 13, 433668) Reading your handwriting is never a problem.
('41', 221, 3, 14, 433713) I knew that you were hesitant to go to Orissa because of my health, but it is your dharma to overcome that hesitation and to help you in that is my dharma.
('41', 221, 3, 15, 433869) I believe that my health is very good.
('41', 221, 3, 16, 433908) The experiment with milkless diet seems to be successful so far.
('41', 221, 3, 17, 433973) I take 8 tolas of wheat, 3/4 tola olive oil, 4 tolas almonds, one seer tandarjo 1and 6 to 9 oranges.
('41', 221, 3, 18, 434074) I still need to increase my diet.
('41', 221, 3, 19, 434108) If I can do that gradually, I hope to regain part or entire weight I have lost.

('41', 225, 0, 1, 438550) 226 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 225, 1, 2, 438592) 251. WHO WILL RESCUE THIS HUMAN COW?
('41', 225, 1, 3, 438629) A gentleman, nearly 70 years old, belonging to the Brahmabhatt caste was married four times.
('41', 225, 1, 4, 438722) All four wives are dead.
('41', 225, 1, 5, 438747) He has no son, only a daughter who is fifteen.
('41', 225, 1, 6, 438794) She has already been married.
('41', 225, 1, 7, 438824) He now wishes to marry for the fifth time in order to have someone to run his household and fulfil his desire for a son.
('41', 225, 1, 8, 438945) This gentleman has been abroad.
('41', 225, 1, 9, 438977) He held a decent post in the Gaekwar’s State.
('41', 225, 1, 10, 439023) He has lost his eyesight owing to cataract.
('41', 225, 1, 11, 439067) This, much married old man is waiting for some cruel father who is prepared to sell his daughter.
('41', 225, 1, 12, 439165) Some young men of the Brahmabhatt community are trying to save the meek cow from being sent in this way to the slaughter house.
('41', 225, 1, 13, 439293) One of them wrote a letter to the old man in order to persuade him not to commit such an act.
('41', 225, 1, 14, 439387) The gentleman has replied to it at length.
('41', 225, 1, 15, 439430) A copy of this has been sent to me.
('41', 225, 1, 16, 439466) I give below extracts 1 from it : I publish this letter at the risk of being considered foolish.
('41', 225, 1, 17, 439563) If there is an absence of feeling for young girls in the Brahmabhatt community, if sensitive people in the community lack courage and if there is no such thing as public opinion in it, no one will be able to prevent this ill mat ched union.
('41', 225, 1, 18, 439804) However, the handful of kind hearted young men or women belonging to that community must not neglect their duty.
('41', 225, 1, 19, 439917) Reform, if it is to be carried out in a peaceful manner, can be carried out only through love and patience.
('41', 225, 1, 20, 440025) We must put up with anger in any form if it is the re sult of self interest.
('41', 225, 1, 21, 440102) We should not be dazzled by anyone trying to impress by his knowledge.
('41', 225, 1, 22, 440173) Within the last one year, two such marriages could be prevented through diligence and by arousing public opinion.
('41', 225, 1, 23, 440287) An engagement that had already taken place was broken off whereas in this instance there has only been talk of an engagement.
('41', 225, 1, 24, 440413) If public opinion can be created the meek cow is likely to be rescued from being slaughtered.
('41', 225, 1, 25, 440507) Let us now examine the letter from this gentleman, who had been to England.
('41', 225, 1, 26, 440583) I am unable to understand what he intends to prove by giv ing instances of men becoming fathers at an advanced age.
('41', 225, 1, 27, 440699) His arguments are the same old ones that have always been advanced by sinners.
('41', 225, 1, 28, 440778) In novels, we have come across murderers describing the benefits of murder in beautiful language.
('41', 225, 1, 29, 440876) And we have also come across robbers singing praises of their deeds.
('41', 225, 1, 30, 440945) These acts may well have benefited those who committed them; but they have not benefited the world.
('41', 225, 1, 31, 441045) Let us take the practice of ill matched unions.
('41', 225, 1, 32, 441093) In the instances
('41', 225, 2, 33, 441110) 1 Not translated here
('41', 226, 0, 1, 441132) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 227
('41', 226, 1, 2, 441174) which have been cited in the above extract, the men concerned may well have seen in it advantage to themselves.
('41', 226, 1, 3, 441286) However, these old men of experience who are motivated by self interest and a desire to gratify their lust are misinterpreting these instances in trying to get their own acts approved.
('41', 226, 1, 4, 441471) This gentleman does not have the time and does not feel the need to think what these young girls must have thought when marrying these old men, how often they must have sighed.
('41', 226, 1, 5, 441648) If one old man has the right to marry a girl of thirteen or fifteen, all old men should have this right and, if all of them were to follow this practice, we can easily imagine what consequences it would have on the people.
('41', 226, 1, 6, 441871) Nowhere in the world have wise men been known to commend ill matched unions.
('41', 226, 1, 7, 441948) They have been condemned in all countries and in India we actually see the many evil consequences that follow from them.
('41', 226, 1, 8, 442069) Hence, I hope this gentleman would review his own letter, written in an angry and impulsive mood, in a new light and gain control over his lust.
('41', 226, 1, 9, 442214) And, if the cannot do it, he should look for a widow who is prepared to marry him of her own free will.
('41', 226, 1, 10, 442318) The craving for a male offspring needs to be given up.
('41', 226, 1, 11, 442373) It cannot be said that this desire is always noble.
('41', 226, 1, 12, 442425) Amongst a people where the birth and death ratio is regularly balanced it is noble to restrain rather than indulge the desire for a son.
('41', 226, 1, 13, 442562) In India today because we are slaves, everyone is in a state of fear, and because we have lost the capacity to protect ourselves, our relatives as well as our property, I regard it as a sin to beget children.
('41', 226, 1, 14, 442771) Now about the desire to be nursed.
('41', 226, 1, 15, 442806) What a misconceived idea that only one’s own people can render this help.
('41', 226, 1, 16, 442880) I regard it as the limit of audacity to grab an innocent girl by bribing or luring her father and then regarding her as one’s own.
('41', 226, 1, 17, 443011) Instead of calling that girl one’s own, it would be nearer the truth to say that ‘a slave girl has been bought’.
('41', 226, 1, 18, 443124) As for service one can still get good loyal servants if one is prepared to pay well.
('41', 226, 1, 19, 443209) I wish to leave aside now the other atrocious ideas in the letter.
('41', 226, 1, 20, 443276) If he happens to read this article, I humbly request him to calmly reflect on it and save himself from the misadventure on which he is about to embark.
('41', 226, 1, 21, 443428) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 26 2 1928
('41', 227, 0, 1, 443465) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 227, 1, 2, 443507) 252. STUDENTS’ NOBLE SATYAGRAHA 1
('41', 227, 2, 3, 443541) In referring to the universality of satyagraha I have time and again observed in these columns that it is capable of application in the social no less than in the political field.
('41', 227, 2, 4, 443721) It may equally be employed against Government, society, or one’s own family, father, mother, husband or wife, as the case may be.
('41', 227, 2, 5, 443851) For it is the beauty of this spiritual weapon that, when it is completely free from the taint of himsa and its use is actuated purely and solely by love it may be used with absolute impunity in any connection and in any circumstances whatever.
('41', 227, 2, 6, 444095) A concrete instance of its use against a social evil was furnished by the brave and spirited students of Dharmaj (in Kheda District) a few days back.
('41', 227, 2, 7, 444245) The facts as gleaned from the various communications about the incident received by me were as follows : A gentleman of Dharmaj, some days back, gave a caste dinner in connection with the twelfth day ceremony of the death of his mother.
('41', 227, 2, 8, 444482) It was preceded by a keen controversy about the subject among the young men of the place who shared with a number of other local inhabitants their strong dislike of this custom.
('41', 227, 2, 9, 444660) They felt that, on this occasion, something must be done.
('41', 227, 2, 10, 444718) Accordingly, most of them took all or some of the following three vows : 1. Not to join their elders at the dinner or otherwise partake of the food served on that occasion.
('41', 227, 2, 11, 444891) 2. To observe fast on the day of the dinner as an emphatic protest against this practice.
('41', 227, 2, 12, 444981) 3. To bear patiently and cheerfully any harsh treatment that might be accorded to them by their elders for taking this step.
('41', 227, 2, 13, 445106) In pursuance of this decision, quite a large number of students, including some children of tender age, fasted on the day on which the dinner was given and took upon themselves the wrath of their so called elders.
('41', 227, 2, 14, 445320) Nor was the step free from the dangers of serious pecuniary consequences to the students.
('41', 227, 2, 15, 445410) The ‘elders’ threatened to stop the allowances of their boys and even to withdraw any financial aid that they were giving to local institutions, but the boys stood firm.
('41', 227, 2, 16, 445580) As many as two hundred and eighty five students thus refused to take part in the caste dinner and most of them fasted.
('41', 227, 3, 17, 445699) 1 The Gujarati original, of which this is a translation, was published in Navajivan.
('41', 227, 3, 18, 445784) 26 2 1928.
('41', 228, 0, 1, 445795) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 229
('41', 228, 1, 2, 445837) I tender my congratulations to these boys and hope that everywhere students will take a prominent part in effecting social reform.
('41', 228, 1, 3, 445968) They hold in their pocket, as it were, the key to social reform and the protection of their religion, just as they have in their possession the key to swaraj—though they may not be aware of it owing to their negligence or carelessness.
('41', 228, 1, 4, 446204) But I hope that the example set by the students of Dharmaj will awaken them to a sense of their power.
('41', 228, 1, 5, 446307) In my opinion, the true shraddha of the deceased lady was performed by these young men fasting on that day, while those who gave the dinner wasted good money and set a bad example to the poor.
('41', 228, 1, 6, 446500) The rich, monied class ought to use their God given wealth for philanthropic purposes.
('41', 228, 1, 7, 446587) They should understand that the poor cannot afford to give caste dinners on wedding or on funeral ceremonies.
('41', 228, 1, 8, 446697) These bad practices have proved to be the ruin of many a poor man.
('41', 228, 1, 9, 446764) If the money that was spent in Dharmaj on the caste dinner had been used for helping poor students, or poor widows, or for khadi or cow protection or the amelioration of the untouchables, it would have borne fruit and brought peace to the departed soul.
('41', 228, 1, 10, 447018) But, as it is, the dinner has already been forgotten, it has profited nobody and it has caused pain to the students and the sensile section of the Dharmaj public.
('41', 228, 1, 11, 447181) Let no one imagine that the satyagraha has gone in vain because it did not succeed in preventing the dinner in question from taking place.
('41', 228, 1, 12, 447320) The students themselves knew that there was little possibility of their satyagraha producing any immediate tangible result.
('41', 228, 1, 13, 447444) But we may safely take it that, if they do not let their vigilance go to sleep, no shethia 1 will again dare to give a post mortem dinner.
('41', 228, 1, 14, 447583) A chronic and long standing social evil cannot be swept away at a stroke; it always requires patience and perseverance.
('41', 228, 1, 15, 447703) When will the ‘elders’ of our society learn to recognize the signs of the times?
('41', 228, 1, 16, 447784) How long will they be slaves to custom instead of using it as a means for the amelioration of society and the country?
('41', 228, 1, 17, 447903) How long will they keep their children divorced from a practical application of the knowledge which they are helping them to acquire?
('41', 228, 1, 18, 448037) When will they rescue their sense of right and wrong from its present state of trance and wake up and be mahajans 2 in the true sense of the word?
('41', 228, 1, 19, 448184) Young India, 1 3 1928
('41', 228, 2, 20, 448206) 1 Rich man 2 Leaders

('41', 231, 4, 9, 452569) 256. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI February 26, 1928
('41', 231, 5, 10, 452629) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I got your letters.
('41', 231, 5, 11, 452670) I also got the cable, to which I have already replied.
('41', 231, 5, 12, 452725) If I were seriously ill, I would certainly have had a cable sent to you.
('41', 231, 5, 13, 452798) Others, too, would have cabled, but do you think a man who was so seriously ill would wait till the steamer had arrived?

('41', 233, 1, 23, 457271) If we are to achieve the full result of the struggle of 1906 to 1914, we must act on the square and cleanse our stables, and I feel sure that if those who have entered surreptitiously will cease to be greedy, will make a clear confession and truthfully, not encourage any single fraudulent entrant in future, the position can be saved and the condition of the resident population steadily improved.
('41', 233, 1, 24, 457670) If, however, the desire is not only to cover surreptitious entries already accomplished, but to leave the door open for more, I think that the community will be unable to remain in South Africa with any degree of self respect.

('41', 234, 1, 3, 458261) If we play the game in South Africa, it is possible in course of time to secure full rights of citizenship.

('41', 241, 6, 14, 468799) 1 In his letter of February 24, Motilal Nehru had written: “.
('41', 241, 6, 15, 468861) I am sorry it will not be possible for me and Jawahar to leave for Sabarmati on the 26th.
('41', 241, 6, 16, 468951) The very day that I wrote to you giving the points of agreement and disagreement between the various parties, Mr. Jinnah announced that it was wrong to say that anything had been agreed upon by the Muslim League which had not yet formally appointed its representatives to the Conference.
('41', 241, 6, 17, 469239) He added that he was no doubt personally of the opinions he had expressed, but he felt that, in the absence of definite authority from his League, he was not competent even to bind himself with those opinions.
('41', 241, 6, 18, 469449) Thus it was that the long sittings and elaborate discussions occupying ten days came practically to nothing.
('41', 241, 6, 19, 469558) It was also found that the attendance at the Conference was thinning away from day to day until it came down to 14 on the 21st.
('41', 241, 6, 20, 469686) The Executive of the Muslim League is meeting on the 26th and Mr. Jinnah has promised to do his best to bring them round to his point of view.
('41', 241, 6, 21, 469829) In all these circumstances, I thought it was futile to go on with the Conference and suggested that a sub committee be appointed to go into the whole question and make its report as soon as possible to an adjourned sitting of the Conference.
('41', 241, 6, 22, 470071) This was agreed to and the Conference was adjourned to the 8th March, a committee of 20 being appointed to enter upon their work at once.
('41', 241, 6, 23, 470209) We have a large field to cover, but will either be able to get on better after the 26th or give up the attempt.
('41', 241, 6, 24, 470321) I feel that my presence here is necessary till either of the two contingencies I have mentioned happens.
('41', 241, 6, 25, 470426) I shall write or wire as soon as I am free.”

('41', 244, 2, 3, 473523) I have no desire to start any hot controversy over the question of foreign propaganda, but I publish the foregoing as it summarizes the views of many workers who hold them in no sense weakly because they do not express them in public.
('41', 244, 2, 4, 473758) If the pure Non co operation of 1920 is not witnessed on an extensive scale at the present moment, it is most decidedly going deeper with some and everything that is happening today in the land goes to strengthen their belief.

('41', 244, 3, 8, 474264) 274. CHAOS v.
('41', 244, 3, 9, 474278) MISRULE An esteemed friend writes : 2
('41', 244, 4, 10, 474316) It is not often that I intrude upon your expressions of political opinion.
('41', 244, 4, 11, 474391) But a sentence of yours in a recent editorial, repeating a heresy uttered by you long ago, compels me to ask you whether you have measured your words with the care that one expects of an expounder of moral issues.
('41', 244, 4, 12, 474605) You declare that you would accept chaos in exchange for freedom from the English yoke.
('41', 244, 4, 13, 474692) That an Indian should desire and work for freedom from any foreign yoke is perfectly natural, normal and healthy.
('41', 244, 4, 14, 474806) That anyone in his senses should exchange any kind of orderly government for chaos is simply incomprehensible, for the one implies some sort of discipline, whether imposed or stimulated, whereas the latter is the very negation of self discipline.
('41', 244, 5, 15, 475053) If non violence be, as you claim it to be, creative, purposeful, and divine in its nature, then chaos cannot be its consequence or characteristic.
('41', 244, 5, 16, 475200) If you have used the term with deliberation, then I should comment that you have rendered no service to mankind, who need rather a reminder that they should acquire the cosmic vision rather than the chaotic one to which they are already prone.
('41', 244, 5, 17, 475444) There is no mistaking the earnestness running through the letter.
('41', 244, 5, 18, 475510) And I have so much regard for the friend’s views, that if I could have
('41', 244, 6, 19, 475581) 1 For C. Rajagopalachari’s article bearing this title, vide Appendix “Foreign Propaganda”, March 1, 1928. 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('41', 245, 0, 1, 475724) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 245, 1, 2, 475766) suited mine to his, I would gladly have done so.
('41', 245, 2, 3, 475815) But I must say that my choice was deliberate.
('41', 245, 2, 4, 475861) Chaos means no rule, no order.
('41', 245, 2, 5, 475892) Rule or order can come, does come out of no rule or no order, but never directly out of misrule or disorder masquerading under the sacred name of rule or order.
('41', 245, 2, 6, 476053) My friend’s difficulty arises, I presume, out of his assumption that the present Government of India represents “some sort of discipline whether imposed or stimulated”.
('41', 245, 2, 7, 476222) It is likely that our estimates of the existing system differ.
('41', 245, 2, 8, 476285) My own estimate of it is that it is an unmitigated evil.
('41', 245, 2, 9, 476342) No good therefore can come out of this evil.
('41', 245, 2, 10, 476387) I hold misrule to be worse than no rule.
('41', 245, 2, 11, 476428) Nor need my words cause any confusion in the minds of the ignorant or the violent.
('41', 245, 2, 12, 476511) For I admit my correspondent’s contention that chaos can be the result only of violence.
('41', 245, 2, 13, 476600) Have I not often said in these pages that if I were compelled to choose between this rule and violence I would give my vote for the latter though I will not, I could not, assist a fight based on violence?
('41', 245, 2, 14, 476805) It would be a matter for me of Hobson’s choice.
('41', 245, 2, 15, 476853) The seeming quiescence of today is a dangerous form of violence kept under suppression by greater violence or rather readiness for it.
('41', 245, 2, 16, 476988) Is it not better that those who, out of a cowardly fear of death or dispossession, whilst harbouring violence refrain from it, should do it and win freedom from bondage or die gloriously in the attempt to vindicate their birthright?
('41', 245, 2, 17, 477221) My non violence is not an academic principle to be enunciated on favourable occasions.
('41', 245, 2, 18, 477308) It is a principle which I am seeking to enforce every moment of my life in every field of activity.
('41', 245, 2, 19, 477408) In my attempt, often frustrated through my own weakness or ignorance, to enforce non violence, I am driven for the sake of the creed itself to countenance violence by way of giving mental approval to it.
('41', 245, 2, 20, 477612) In 1921 I told the villagers near Bettiah 1 that they had acted like cowards in that they had instead of resisting the evil minded Amlas left their wives and homes on their approach.
('41', 245, 2, 21, 477795) On another occasion I expressed myself ashamed of a priest who said he had quietly slipped away and saved himself when a ruffian band had entered his temple to loot it and break the idol.
('41', 245, 2, 22, 477983) I told him that if he could not die at his post defending his charge non violently, he should have defended it by offering violent resistance.
('41', 245, 2, 23, 478126) Similarly do I hold that, if India has no faith in non violence, nor patience for it to work its way, then it is better for her to attain her freedom from the present misrule even by
('41', 245, 3, 24, 478309) 1 Vide “Speech at Bettiah”, December 8, 1920.
('41', 246, 0, 1, 478355) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 247
('41', 246, 1, 2, 478397) violence than that she should helplessly submit to a continuing rape of her belongings and her honour.
('41', 246, 1, 3, 478500) Look at the shameless manner in which, for sustaining the spoliation of India, British statesmen (?) are setting one party against another.
('41', 246, 1, 4, 478640) They have suddenly discovered the untouchables, for they seem to fear that the Hindu Muslim dissensions alone might not prove enough secu rity for retaining possession of the ‘most glorious diadem in the British Crown’.
('41', 246, 1, 5, 478860) They are trying to set the helpless princes against the people.
('41', 246, 1, 6, 478924) Sir John Simon finds it necessary to play the same game.
('41', 246, 1, 7, 478981) The penetrating intellect he is said to possess does not penetrate the very thin veil that covers the frauds that are set up for his edification and he finds nothing seriously amiss in the Indian atmosphere.
('41', 246, 1, 8, 479189) This sort of ‘orderly discipline’ has unmanned and unn erved the people as nothing in their previous history has ever done.
('41', 246, 1, 9, 479313) My own position and belief are clear and unequivocal.
('41', 246, 1, 10, 479367) I neither want the existing rule nor chaos.
('41', 246, 1, 11, 479411) I want true order established without having to go through the travail of chaos.
('41', 246, 1, 12, 479492) I want this disorder to be destroyed by non violence, i.e., I want to convert the evil doers.
('41', 246, 1, 13, 479586) My life is dedicated to that task.
('41', 246, 1, 14, 479621) And what I have written in the previous paragraphs directly flows from my knowledge of the working of non violence which is the greatest force known to mankind.
('41', 246, 1, 15, 479782) My belief in its efficacy is unshakable, so is my belief unshakable in the power of India to gain her freedom through non violent means and no other.
('41', 246, 1, 16, 479932) But this power of hers cannot be evoked by suppressing truth or facts however ugly they may for the moment appear to be.
('41', 246, 1, 17, 480053) God forbid that India should have to engage in a sanguinary duel before she learns the lesson of non violence in its fullness.
('41', 246, 1, 18, 480180) But if that intermediate stage, often found to be necessary, is to be her lot, it will have to be faced as a stage inevitable in her march towards freedom and certainly preferable to the existing order which is only so called but which is like a whited sepulchre hiding undiluted violence underneath.
('41', 246, 1, 19, 480481) Young India, 1 3 1928

('41', 249, 1, 2, 484647) 279. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('41', 249, 2, 3, 484676) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 3, 1928
('41', 249, 3, 4, 484713) DEAR MOTILALJI, I have your letter.
('41', 249, 3, 5, 484749) I have discussed it with Jawaharlal, but he suggests, and I agree, that it will be better for me to reduce to writing the views I have expressed to him so that there may be no misunderstanding about the correct interpretation of my views, and so that he may also know whether he understood me correctly.
('41', 249, 3, 6, 485053) ELECTORATE: I am of the same opinion that I expressed years ago at Delhi that we should not be party to separate electorates or to reservation of seats, the latter should be by mutual voluntary arran gement if such is necessary.
('41', 249, 3, 7, 485282) But unless the Mussalmans agree, there is no going back by us on reservation of seats.
('41', 249, 3, 8, 485369) The Congress is committed to it.
('41', 249, 3, 9, 485402) I think, therefore, that we must simply adhere to the Congress resolution and expect Hindus and Mussalmans to carry out that resolution.
('41', 249, 3, 10, 485539) If the All Parties Conference cannot discover another method acceptable to all, we must simply work out the Congress formula.
('41', 249, 3, 11, 485665) THE C ONSTITUTION: Personally I am of opinion that we are not ready for drawing up a constitution till we have developed sanction for ourselves.
('41', 249, 3, 12, 485810) Any constitution that we may arrive at must be a final thing in the sense that we may improve upon but we may not recede from it even by an inch.
('41', 249, 3, 13, 485956) There seems to be no atmosphere for arriving at such a constitution.
('41', 249, 3, 14, 486025) I would personally therefore prefer instead of a constitution, a working arrangement between all parties upon which all may be agreed.
('41', 249, 3, 15, 486160) This would be not a constitution but chief heads of it, as for instance, the Hindu Muslim arrangement, the franchise, the policy as to the Native States.
('41', 249, 3, 16, 486314) If we are to make this thing popular, I should bring in total prohibition and exclusion of foreign cloth as an indispensable condition.
('41', 249, 3, 17, 486450) Of course we should guarantee equality of treatment of all religions as also of the so called untouchables.
('41', 249, 3, 18, 486558) I am not exhaustive in the list of things on which there should be an agreement, but I have simply given a few things by way of illustration.
('41', 249, 3, 19, 486700) I think that if we go beyond such a general agreement, we would be making mistake.
('41', 249, 3, 20, 486783) In any case, I do hope that the Conference will not break up without doing anything, and even if it does, the Working
('41', 250, 0, 1, 486901) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 251
('41', 250, 1, 2, 486943) Committee should take the matter in its own hands and issue its own authoritative statement on behalf of the Congress on all the matters for which the Conference has been convened.
('41', 250, 1, 3, 487124) SANCTION: More important than the two foregoing things, in my opinion, is the sanction.
('41', 250, 1, 4, 487212) Unless we have created some force ourselves, we shall not advance beyond the position of beggars, and I have given all my time to thinking over this one question, and I can think of nothing else but boycott of foreign cloth with the assistance of mills if possible, without if necessary.

('41', 251, 3, 7, 488987) 282. CATTLE IN KATHIAWAR An expert in cattle breeding writes from Kathiawar to say : 2
('41', 251, 4, 8, 489074) This letter deserves the attention of rulers (of Indian States) and their officers.
('41', 251, 4, 9, 489158) The several methods of cattle protection shown here have been discussed in various ways in the letter itself.
('41', 251, 4, 10, 489268) However, I mention them here as they have been stated with reference to the local conditions by a person who has lived in Kathiawar.
('41', 251, 4, 11, 489401) The cows and bullocks of Kathiawar were at one time famous.
('41', 251, 4, 12, 489461) It is a matter of shame for every State in Kathiawar that today they are being sent to the slaughter house and that economically they are regarded as a burden.
('41', 251, 4, 13, 489621) This reform requires neither a large sum of money nor any great courage.
('41', 251, 4, 14, 489694) It is only a matter of giving up lethargy and sparing a little time from politics.
('41', 251, 4, 15, 489777) It requires no great effort to get scrub bulls castrated or to regulate cattle fodder.
('41', 251, 4, 16, 489864) The States should train some students by offering them scholarships.
('41', 251, 4, 17, 489933) In the mean while, they should carry on the work with whatever help they can get.
('41', 251, 4, 18, 490015) The heads of pinjrapoles too should take note of the above suggestions.
('41', 251, 4, 19, 490087) Infirm cattle ought to be looked after.
('41', 251, 4, 20, 490127) However, it is a thousand times more important to prevent useful cattle from being sent to the slaughter house.
('41', 251, 4, 21, 490239) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 4 3 1928

('41', 252, 1, 2, 490452) 283. SATYAGRAHA IN BARDOLI In this issue the reader will find the letters exchanged between the Government and Shri Vallabhbhai.
('41', 252, 1, 3, 490581) In a way this correspondence is a sorry chapter.
('41', 252, 1, 4, 490630) So far as I can see, the facts mentioned by Shri Vallabhbhai or the arguments that he has based on them lack nothing.
('41', 252, 1, 5, 490748) The Government’s reply is marked by cunning and equivocation and amounts to a snub.
('41', 252, 1, 6, 490832) It makes one sad that power thus makes a person arrogant and that he in his arrogance loses his humanity and forgets himself.
('41', 252, 1, 7, 490958) Although we may have known thousands of such instances of human weakness, each new one is bound to cause pain.
('41', 252, 1, 8, 491069) This is because though man is not free from fault, at heart he wants to do good.
('41', 252, 1, 9, 491150) Hence he is pained by insolence, discourtesy, etc., from others.
('41', 252, 1, 10, 491215) I shall not enter into the correctness or otherwise of the facts and the arguments.
('41', 252, 1, 11, 491299) The reader may not have before him all the literature which would enable him to examine the pros and cons; if he has it, he may not have the patience to read and reflect upon it.
('41', 252, 1, 12, 491478) However, Shri Vallabhbhai’s demands will be found reasonable by the disinterested reader even on the basis of justice alone.
('41', 252, 1, 13, 491603) Vallabhbhai does not insist that his arguments should be accepted by the Government.
('41', 252, 1, 14, 491688) What he in fact says is that, while the Government is on one side, the people are on the other.
('41', 252, 1, 15, 491784) There is a difference of opinion between the two regarding the facts themselves.
('41', 252, 1, 16, 491865) There should be a third party to arbitrate in this dispute.
('41', 252, 1, 17, 491925) Whatever award is given by this party will be accepted by Vallabhbhai on behalf of the people.
('41', 252, 1, 18, 492020) This is the crux, the essence, of Vallabhbhai’s letter.
('41', 252, 1, 19, 492076) The question that now arises is whether there could be such arbitration to settle disputes between the Government and the people.
('41', 252, 1, 20, 492206) Is not the former the supreme authority?
('41', 252, 1, 21, 492247) In matters relating to law, even this Government is theoretically prepared to stand in the dock in a court of law.
('41', 252, 1, 22, 492362) The Government regards the question of land revenue as extra judicial.The reason for this is beyond the common man’s powers of comprehension.
('41', 252, 1, 23, 492504) Let us not enter into the intricacies of this argument at this moment.
('41', 252, 1, 24, 492575) However, if the question of land revenue is outside the juris diction of courts, what could Vallabhbhai do but ask for arbitration?
('41', 252, 1, 25, 492707) Should he advise the people to appeal to the Government and then sit quiet?
('41', 252, 1, 26, 492783) Even if he wished to give such advice, the people had not left the door open to him; they had already appealed to the Government.
('41', 253, 0, 1, 492913) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 253, 1, 2, 492955) Vallabhbhai would not help them make such appeals, so they approached those who would.
('41', 253, 1, 3, 493042) Having been unsuccessful there, they returned to Vallabhbhai to make him accept their leadership in offering satyagraha.
('41', 253, 1, 4, 493163) In accordance with the rules of satyagraha, Vallabhbhai approached the Government with a polite offer of peace.
('41', 253, 1, 5, 493275) He said that the Government might not be wrong, it was possible that the people might have misled him.
('41', 253, 1, 6, 493378) He asked the Government to appoint an arbitrator and ask him to dispense justice.
('41', 253, 1, 7, 493460) He hoped the Government would not claim infallibility.
('41', 253, 1, 8, 493515) The Government, by committing the grave mistake of rejecting this proposal, cleared the way for the people to offer satyagraha.
('41', 253, 1, 9, 493643) The Government, however, claims that Vallabhbhai is an outsider and does not belong there, that he is an alien and, if he and his alien friends had not entered Bardoli, people would have certainly paid up the revenue—that is the trend of the Government’s letter.
('41', 253, 1, 10, 493906) This is like the thief trying to punish the policeman.
('41', 253, 1, 11, 493961) As long as Bardoli is in India neither Vallabhbhai nor anyone else amongst us will understand how either he or any Indian living within the territory between Kashmir in the north and Kanyakumari in the south and between Karachi in the west and Dibrugarh in the east, can be called an outsider.
('41', 253, 1, 12, 494255) It is the British officers of the Government who are foreigners, outsiders who do not belong here, and, to speak more plainly, all the officers—whether they are black or white—who serve this foreign, outside authority belong to this category.
('41', 253, 1, 13, 494498) Those who owe their livelihood to the Government would of course be on its side.
('41', 253, 1, 14, 494579) Even persons like Drona and Bhishma had to tell Yudhishthira that they were on the side of those who provided them their livelihood.
('41', 253, 1, 15, 494712) How crooked of this foreign Government, to call a person like Vallabhbhai an outsider in Bardoli!
('41', 253, 1, 16, 494810) This is like darkness at noon!
('41', 253, 1, 17, 494841) It is because of such things that people like me regard it a sin to be loyal to such a Government, and practise non co operation.
('41', 253, 1, 18, 494971) How can we hope for any justice where such gross impertinence prevails?
('41', 253, 1, 19, 495043) Who can teach justice to this Government?
('41', 253, 1, 20, 495085) Only a satyagrahi.
('41', 253, 1, 21, 495104) The Govern ment cannot be vanquished by intellectual arguments.
('41', 253, 1, 22, 495168) For the mighty, reason lies in might.
('41', 253, 1, 23, 495206) It weighs justice at the point of the sword.
('41', 253, 1, 24, 495251) This sword becomes blunt when it meets the sword of the satyagrahi.
('41', 253, 1, 25, 495319) If the satyagrahis of Bardoli are capable of standing by
('41', 254, 0, 1, 495376) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 255
('41', 254, 1, 2, 495418) truth, either an arbitrator will be appointed, or Vallabhbhai’s arguments will be accepted and he will cease to be considered an outsider and come to be accepted as a ‘native’.
('41', 254, 1, 3, 495595) The other questions arising out of this correspondence will be dealt with later.
('41', 254, 1, 4, 495676) It is enough for the people of Bardoli to remember that it is for them to win or lose the game.

('41', 258, 1, 2, 500438) 292. WAR AGAINST WAR A correspondent writes:
('41', 258, 2, 3, 500483) My excuse for writing this is that the autobiographical chapter about your attitude towards war as a follower of truth and ahimsa has apparently stirred the thoughts of many, and abler people would be writing to you about it.
('41', 258, 2, 4, 500709) But I wish to present some aspects that have struck me.
('41', 258, 2, 5, 500765) Is it not a fundamental doctrine that to the true disciple of truth and ahimsa, there can be no tampering with bad things even though one connot resist them?
('41', 258, 2, 6, 500923) War is a necessary evil as some say, but that is no excuse for supporting it in the hope that after it there will come to the world a realization of the wickedness of waging war.
('41', 258, 2, 7, 501102) It cannot be.
('41', 258, 2, 8, 501116) On the contrary, the callousness of man is increased further in intensity and the feeling about the sacredness of life is destroyed.
('41', 258, 2, 9, 501249) The anarchist could argue just as you do and say: “We cannot stop European aggression and terrorism.
('41', 258, 2, 10, 501350) We cannot resist terrorism by mass force.
('41', 258, 2, 11, 501392) But if we can only domonstrate to them the wickedness of such methods by using them against them, they will see the folly of their attitude and we shall become free, and we shall also save the world from terrorism.
('41', 258, 2, 12, 501607) So long as himsa is resorted to by our rulers and so long as we hate terrorism, what is the harm in using these weapons provided we do not allow them to obsess us?” Has the Great War actually done any good to the nations and particularly to the victors?
('41', 258, 2, 13, 501861) Materially, morally, and socially they have lost heavily as a result of the victory.
('41', 258, 2, 14, 501946) Their moral standards have all been upset and the strife after the life of the moment, and the disregard for truth and honesty in international dealings is becoming more and more apparent every day.
('41', 258, 2, 15, 502145) Can any good come out of a war, however ‘righteous’ it may be?
('41', 258, 2, 16, 502208) Are we not bound to oppose it and invite suffering for the cause rather than in any way acquiesce in it either passively or actively?
('41', 258, 2, 17, 502342) Do you not believe that the pacifists served the cause better than those who actively engaged in the War?
('41', 258, 2, 18, 502448) What you say might represent the state of your mind in 1914 when you thought there was a sense of justice in the British mentality.
('41', 258, 2, 19, 502580) Do you now feel that it was right?
('41', 258, 2, 20, 502615) If another war was declared tomorrow, would you volunteer your help to England in the hope that you would be making things better after the war?
('41', 258, 2, 21, 502760) I know I have not presented the case in the best way but you can understand what it is that I am trying to tell you, and I shall be glad to have your reply.
('41', 258, 2, 22, 502917) I agree with the correspondent that he has not presented his case ‘in the best way’, but he does represent a type of readers who will not read carefully even writings that are meant to be serious simply because they happen to be found in a weekly journal.
('41', 258, 2, 23, 503173) If readers like
('41', 259, 0, 1, 503189) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 259, 1, 2, 503231) the correspondent will re read the chapter in question they will be able to deduce from it that: 1. I did not offer my services because I believed in war.
('41', 259, 1, 3, 503386) I offered them because I could not avoid participation in it at least indirectly.
('41', 259, 1, 4, 503468) 2. I had no status to resist participation.
('41', 259, 1, 5, 503512) 3. I do not believe that war can be avoided by taking part in it even as I do not believe that evil can be avoided by participation in it.
('41', 259, 1, 6, 503651) This however needs to be distinguished from sincerely helpless participation in many things we hold to be evil or undersirable.
('41', 259, 1, 7, 503779) 4. The anarchist’s argument is irrelevant as his participation in terrorism is deliberate, voluntary and preconceived.
('41', 259, 1, 8, 503898) 5. The War certainly did no good to the so called victors.
('41', 259, 1, 9, 503957) 6. The pacifist resisters who suffered imprisonment certainly served the cause of peace.
('41', 259, 1, 10, 504046) 7. If another war was declared tomorrow I could not with my present views about the existing Government assist it in any shape or form; on the contrary, I should exert myself to the utmost to induce others to withhold their assistance and to do everything possible and consistent with ahimsa to bring about its defeat.
('41', 259, 2, 11, 504365) Young India, 8 3 1928

('41', 260, 2, 7, 505711) 294. NOTES
('41', 260, 3, 8, 505722) THE SUPREME ARBITER In answer to the blind adherence one often sees given to everything written in Sanskrit verse and going under the name of Shastra, Sjt.
('41', 260, 3, 9, 505878) S. D. Nadkarni sends me the following verses taken from sources universally regarded as authoritative and supporting the final authority of reason :
('41', 260, 4, 10, 506027) ‘A Shastra, though man made, should be accepted, if it appeals to reason; and the contrary one rejected, though claiming to be inspired.
('41', 260, 4, 11, 506164) We should be guided by our sense of the just alone.
('41', 260, 4, 12, 506216) A saying sound in reason should be accepted, though it proceed from a child; and the contrary one rejected as a straw, though it purport to proceed from the God Brahma.’
('41', 260, 5, 13, 506386) —From Yogavasishtha (Nyaya prakaranam )
('41', 260, 6, 14, 506426) ‘A convention adopted by the good shall be as good an authority as the Veda.’
('41', 260, 7, 15, 506504) —From the Madhava Smriti (otherwise called the Madhaviya Vyakhya ) The verses show that the Shastras were never intended to supplant reason but to supplement it and never could be pleaded in defence of injustice or untruth.
('41', 260, 8, 16, 506728) FOR THOSE WHO WOULD SUCCEED
('41', 260, 9, 17, 506756) There is so much despondency on the one hand and bluster retarding success on the other, that I gladly reproduce the following maxims handed by a friend and intended to cheer the despondent and warn the blusteres.
('41', 260, 9, 18, 506970) There is practically nothing impossible for those
('41', 261, 0, 1, 507020) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 261, 1, 2, 507062) who would persevere in the face of the heaviest odds.
('41', 261, 1, 3, 507116) Nothing is possible for those who would brag, bluster and merely make a brave show.
('41', 261, 1, 4, 507200) Here are the maxims:
('41', 261, 2, 5, 507221) Every noble work is at first impossible.
('41', 261, 2, 6, 507262) —CARLYLE
('41', 261, 3, 7, 507271) Success in most things depends on knowing how long it takes to succeed.
('41', 261, 3, 8, 507343) —MONTESQUIEU Victory belongs to most persevering.
('41', 261, 3, 9, 507393) —NAPOLEON
('41', 261, 4, 10, 507403) Perpetual pushing and assurance put a difficulty out of countenance, and make a seeming impossibility give way.
('41', 261, 4, 11, 507515) —JEREMY COLLIER
('41', 261, 5, 12, 507531) Unstable as water, thou shalt not excel.
('41', 261, 5, 13, 507572) The nerve that never relaxes, the eye that never blanches, the thought that never wanders, these are the masters of victory.
('41', 261, 6, 14, 507697) However discordant or troubled you have been during the day, do not go to sleep until you have restored your mental balance, until your faculties are poised and your mind serene.
('41', 261, 6, 15, 507876) —CARTWRIGHT Young India, 8 3 1928

('41', 262, 0, 1, 508780) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 263
('41', 262, 1, 2, 508822) 296. BARDOLI AND GOVERNMENT The illuminating correspondence that has passed between Sjt.
('41', 262, 1, 3, 508911) Vallabhbhai Patel and the Government of Bombay regard ing the assessment in the Bardoli Taluk affords food for reflection to the public worker and reveals in its true light the nature of the Government under which we are living.
('41', 262, 1, 4, 509140) Vallabhbhai is not unknown to fame or to the Government.
('41', 262, 1, 5, 509197) They have been obliged to acknowledge his worth as a public worker of great capacity, integrity and industry.
('41', 262, 1, 6, 509307) They have acknowledged his great work in the Munici pality of Ahmedabad.
('41', 262, 1, 7, 509380) Only the other day he received unstinted praise for his philanthropic services in connection with the floods in Gujarat.
('41', 262, 1, 8, 509501) But his work seems to have counted for nothing when they found him engaged in an activity calculated to cause them embarrass ment and possibly loss of prestige and what is the same thing to them loss of land revenue.
('41', 262, 1, 9, 509718) Their prestige they need for the sake of their revenue.
('41', 262, 1, 10, 509774) They are no believers in empty prestige.
('41', 262, 1, 11, 509815) And so in their very first letter in the matter, they thought it becoming to insult Sjt.
('41', 262, 1, 12, 509904) Vallabhbhai by calling in question his profess ions of goodwill and describing him as an outsider in Bardoli.
('41', 262, 1, 13, 510014) The last letter emphasizes the insult by leaving no doubt that His Excellency the Governor too was party to it.
('41', 262, 1, 14, 510126) Vallabhbhai had courteously assumed in his letter that whilst His Excellency might be identified with a policy enunciated in Government communications, he need not be identified with the manner of expression, more especially the insulting language often adopted by civilian secretaries incensed over any the least resistance or independence betrayed by the public in their correspondence with them.
('41', 262, 1, 15, 510525) That the Governor has chosen to become a party to the unwarranted insult shows how difficult it is for Governors, however well intentioned and impartial they may be reputed to be as the present Governor is, to escape the bureaucratic coil.
('41', 262, 1, 16, 510765) ‘Pride goeth before destruction and haughtiness before a fall.’ But Vallabhbhai has a back broad enough to bear the wordy insults that the bureaucracy may choose to heap upon him from its safe and entrenched heights.
('41', 262, 1, 17, 510982) My reason for dwelling on the insult is to draw attention to the utterly irresponsible nature of the Government that dares to insult a public worker of the foremost rank.
('41', 262, 1, 18, 511153) But let us see for the moment what it is that has upset the Government.
('41', 262, 1, 19, 511225) Land revenue is a close preserve beyond the pale of law such as it is.
('41', 262, 1, 20, 511296) The regulation of assessment rests entirely with the executive authority.
('41', 262, 1, 21, 511370) Every attempt hitherto made to bring it under
('41', 263, 0, 1, 511416) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 263, 1, 2, 511458) popular or judicial control has failed The Government must somehow or other meet the ever growing expenditure, bulk of which is military.
('41', 263, 1, 3, 511596) Land revenue lends itself to arbitrary increase as it affects the largest class and a class that has no voice, a class that can be squeezed without wincing.
('41', 263, 1, 4, 511753) There would be an end to irresponsible government if the governed are either allowed to have a say in their taxation or to resist it successfully.
('41', 263, 1, 5, 511900) Bardoli does not appreciate the increase made in its assessment.
('41', 263, 1, 6, 511965) Its people approached the Government with petitions and exhausted all the means that are regarded as constitutional to secure redress.
('41', 263, 1, 7, 512100) Having failed they invited Vallabhbhai to advise them and if necessary to lead them in resisting the Government through satyagraha.
('41', 263, 1, 8, 512232) Vallabhbhai investigated their case and though he found it to be just, sought to approach the Government with a view to save them embarrassment and spare the people prolonged suffering and suggested and honourable course, i.e., suggested that if the Government did not admit the justice of the people’s case, they should appoint an impartial tribunal to investigate the case on either side and assured the Government that the people would abide by the decision of such a tribunal.
('41', 263, 1, 9, 512713) This reasonable suggestion the Govern ment has scornfully rejected.
('41', 263, 1, 10, 512781) The public, therefore, are not called upon to accept the popular version as against that of the Government.
('41', 263, 1, 11, 512889) They are asked merely to support the demand for the appointment of an impartial tribunal and failing such appointment to support their heroic resolve peacefully to resist the assessment and suffer all the consequences of such resistance even including confiscation of their land.
('41', 263, 1, 12, 513169) Vallabhbhai has rightly distinguished the proposed saty agraha from the swaraj satyagraha.
('41', 263, 1, 13, 513260) This campaign cannot be properly deemed to be a no tax campaign launched for the attainment of swaraj as Bardoli would have done in 1922. This satyagraha is limited in scope, has a specific local object.
('41', 263, 1, 14, 513464) Every man has the right, nay, it is his duty to resist an arbitrary unjust levy as the Bardoli assessment is claimed to be by its ryots.
('41', 263, 1, 15, 513601) But though the object of the proposed satyagraha is local and specific, it has an all India application.
('41', 263, 1, 16, 513706) what is true of Bardoli is true of many parts of India.
('41', 263, 1, 17, 513762) The struggle has also an indirect bearing on swaraj Whatever awakens people to a sense of their wrongs and whatever gives them strength for disciplined and peaceful resistance and habituates them for corporate suffering brings us nearer swaraj.
('41', 263, 1, 18, 514007) Young India, 8 3 1928
