('41', 271, 8, 18, 524184) 310. MY NOTES
('41', 271, 9, 19, 524198) THE LATE SIR RAMANBHAI Sir Ramanbhai has passed away leaving Gujarat in tears.
('41', 271, 9, 20, 524277) Ramanbhai embodies the history of modernism in Gujarat.
('41', 271, 9, 21, 524333) Ramanbhai stands for social reform.
('41', 271, 9, 22, 524369) Ramanbhai was the friend of the poor.
('41', 271, 9, 23, 524407) He was the warp and woof of the civic life of Ahmedabad.
('41', 271, 9, 24, 524464) His service to the Gujarati language was of a very high standard.
('41', 271, 9, 25, 524530) His high moral code never failed to leave an impression on whosoever came into contact with him.
('41', 271, 9, 26, 524627) Ramanbhai’s humour permeates his works.
('41', 271, 9, 27, 524667) He did not however look upon life as something of a jest.
('41', 271, 9, 28, 524725) He found the fulfilment of his life in devoting it to the performance of duty.
('41', 271, 9, 29, 524804) Ramanbhai would indeed help any good cause.
('41', 271, 9, 30, 524848) In matters of national welfare he always contributed his full share.
('41', 272, 0, 1, 524917) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 273
('41', 272, 1, 2, 524959) He never hesitated or spared himself in anything that he regarded as service.
('41', 272, 1, 3, 525037) In spite of his serious illness and in spite of severe differences in political matters he recognized the value of Vallabhbhai’s service to the municipality and he unfailingly co operated with him to the utmost whenever occasion arose.
('41', 272, 1, 4, 525273) There could hardly be a public institution in Ahmedabad which did not wish to have Ramanbhai’s name associated with it.
('41', 272, 1, 5, 525393) The loss of such a jewel of Gujarat will not be felt by his family members alone; the whole of Gujarat shares this grief of separation.
('41', 272, 1, 6, 525529) Nowadays, it has become customary to underestimate the quiet, unostentatious service of persons who do not take part in politics, especially in active politics.
('41', 272, 1, 7, 525690) In my humble opinion this is a mistake though time will certainly rectify it.
('41', 272, 1, 8, 525768) He who wipes the tears of even a single widow, who saves a single young girl from the immolation miscalled marriage, who renders selfless service to a single Antyaja, serves the country and society in a pure manner, and it is likely that, when the fight put up by a valiant political warrior is forgotten, this other service done in some obscure corner will still keep bearing fruit.
('41', 272, 1, 9, 526152) That service which is accompanied not by ovations but by God’s blessings is indeed true service.
('41', 272, 1, 10, 526249) Such was the service rendered by Ramanbhai.
('41', 272, 1, 11, 526293) He received his share of ovations too, but why describe what Ramanbhai never cared for!
('41', 272, 1, 12, 526381) He was a brave warrior.
('41', 272, 1, 13, 526405) Who has not seen him stick to his views as well as his own place amidst the whistling and shouting of young men?
('41', 272, 1, 14, 526518) Let us pray that we inherit his virtues.
('41', 272, 2, 15, 526559) LORD SINHA
('41', 272, 3, 16, 526570) India has suffered a great loss in the death of Lord Sinha.
('41', 272, 3, 17, 526630) He was a pillar of India.
('41', 272, 3, 18, 526656) He had reached the highest office on the strength of his intellect.
('41', 272, 3, 19, 526724) Although it is true that that office has little value in this age of non co operation, the abilities that were required in order to reach it have much value.
('41', 272, 3, 20, 526882) Lord Sinha did not go out of his way to seek office.
('41', 272, 3, 21, 526935) It could be said on the contrary that offices came seeking him.
('41', 272, 3, 22, 526999) However, I do not wish to discuss here the various offices that he held at different times.
('41', 272, 3, 23, 527091) The reader must have come to know of these from other newspapers.
('41', 272, 3, 24, 527157) I wish to give a short account of my acquaintance with him.
('41', 272, 3, 25, 527217) I saw him for the first time at the Congress in 1915. This was my second experience of the Congress.
('41', 272, 3, 26, 527318) At this session, I came to know only of his intellectual powers.
('41', 272, 3, 27, 527383) Everyone appreciated his erudite
('41', 273, 0, 1, 527416) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 273, 1, 2, 527458) speech.
('41', 273, 1, 3, 527466) His criticism of the Empire carried weight.
('41', 273, 1, 4, 527510) Everyone on the Congress Working Committee admired the way in which he transacted business.
('41', 273, 1, 5, 527602) We cannot all emulate his intellectual powers.
('41', 273, 1, 6, 527649) There was however one quality of his, of which I came to know at a reception in his honour, which we could all imitate, and that is his humility.
('41', 273, 1, 7, 527795) I came to know more of this quality at the time of Desh bandhu Das Memorial Fund.
('41', 273, 1, 8, 527877) All of us felt that the association of his name with the raising of this Fund would indeed be welcome.
('41', 273, 1, 9, 527980) Persons belonging to all parties felt that, if his name was associated with it, it would facilitate the raising of the Fund and that this would make people from all parties readily associate themselves with it.
('41', 273, 1, 10, 528191) I was among those who approached him.
('41', 273, 1, 11, 528229) He was in indifferent health at that time; but he would meet people whenever necessary.
('41', 273, 1, 12, 528317) He willingly agreed to the inclusion of his name and also agreed to give all possible help.
('41', 273, 1, 13, 528409) On these occasions, I became well aware of his humility, his courtesy and his greatness and I felt that India would add to her prestige if all our elder statesmen possessed these qualities.
('41', 273, 1, 14, 528599) I noticed that he did not crave for respect but was always eager to show respect to others.
('41', 273, 1, 15, 528691) Those who do not crave for respect deserve it; privileges cling to those who try to shake them off.
('41', 273, 1, 16, 528791) Lord Sinha happened to be in this happy situation.
('41', 273, 1, 17, 528842) May all of us inherit that humility and that courtesy.
('41', 273, 1, 18, 528897) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 11 3 1928

('41', 274, 1, 2, 529659) 312. LETTER TO JANE HOWARD
('41', 274, 2, 3, 529686) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 12, 1928
('41', 274, 3, 4, 529731) DEAR FRIEND, I was delighted to receive your long letter.
('41', 274, 3, 5, 529789) I endorse every word of what you say about Mrs. Gandhi and the wretched incident I have related in the autobiographical chapters.
('41', 274, 3, 6, 529919) 1 Of course you have not imagined that I am in any way proud of recalling the brutality or that I am today capable of any such brutality.
('41', 274, 3, 7, 530057) But I thought that if people recognize me as a gentle peace loving man, they should also know that at one time I could be a positive beast even though at the same time I claimed to be a loving husband.
('41', 274, 3, 8, 530259) It was not without good cause that a friend once described me as a combination of sacred cow and ferocious tiger.
('41', 274, 3, 9, 530373) It would have been a pity if you had burnt your beautiful letter as at one time you thought you should.
('41', 274, 3, 10, 530477) You have certainly not appeared to me to be rude or ill mannered but most natural and on that account lovable.
('41', 274, 3, 11, 530588) I do indeed wish that I had come in closer contact with your dear brother, but I knew him enough to love him and to appreciate his sterling worth.

('41', 275, 1, 2, 530951) 313. LETTER TO B. W. TUCKER
('41', 275, 2, 3, 530979) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 12, 1928
('41', 275, 3, 4, 531024) MY DEAR FRIEND, I like the manner in which you are combating my views.
('41', 275, 3, 5, 531095) I discovered the difference between us even in Orissa.
('41', 275, 3, 6, 531150) For me, there is no difference between the individual and the social position.
('41', 275, 3, 7, 531229) At the same time there is ample room for the compromise of the nature suggested by you, for the simple reason that I ever compromise my own ideals even in individual conduct not because I wish to but because the compromise was inevitable.
('41', 275, 3, 8, 531468) And so in social and political matters I have never exacted complete fulfilment of the ideal in which I have believed.
('41', 275, 3, 9, 531587) But there are always times when one has to say thus far and no further, and, each time the dividing line has to be determined on merits.
('41', 275, 3, 10, 531724) Generally speaking where the sum total of a movement has been evil, I have held non co operation to be the only remedy and where the sum total has been for the good of humanity, I have held co operation on the basis of compromise to be the most desirable thing.
('41', 275, 3, 11, 531986) If I seem to be holding myself aloof from some of the political movements just now, it is because I believe their tendency to be not for the promotion of swaraj but rather its retarding.
('41', 275, 3, 12, 532173) It may be that I have erred in my judgment.
('41', 275, 3, 13, 532217) If so, it is but human and I have never claimed to be infallible.
('41', 275, 3, 14, 532283) You will see this point somewhat developed in a recent autobiographical chapter dealing with my participation in the late War.
('41', 275, 3, 15, 532410) 1 Tell me now if I have answered your question, even if I have not solved the puzzle.
('41', 275, 3, 16, 532496) Andrews is here and will be for a few days longer.
('41', 275, 3, 17, 532547) How nice it would be if you could come and pass a few days of quiet with me so that we could discuss the important problems you have been raising in your letters.
('41', 275, 3, 18, 532710) This is however not to say that you may not discuss them through correspondence.
('41', 275, 3, 19, 532791) Please do, so long as it is necessary.

('41', 278, 4, 5, 536554) 317. WHAT CAN OUR MILLS DO?
('41', 278, 4, 6, 536582) Everybody is anxious that at this critical juncture in our history, we should be able to exhibit some real strength.
('41', 278, 4, 7, 536699) It is being more and more realized that such strength can be developed and shown only through boycott of foreign cloth as distinguished from British cloth.
('41', 278, 4, 8, 536855) In this boycott it is possible for our mills to play an important, indeed a decisive, part if they wish.
('41', 278, 4, 9, 536960) Some day or other they will have to choose between this alien Government and the people.
('41', 278, 4, 10, 537049) There is no doubt that to a large extent they are dependent for their existence upon the toleration if not the goodwill of the Government.
('41', 278, 4, 11, 537188) Thoreau told the truth when he said that possession of riches under an evil government was a sin and poverty was virtue.
('41', 278, 4, 12, 537309) The riches of the rich are always at the disposal of the government of the day whether it is good or bad.
('41', 278, 4, 13, 537415) But if the mills are dependent for their existence on the toleration or goodwill of the Government, they are no less so on the toleration or goodwill of the people.
('41', 278, 4, 14, 537580) They can afford to ignore the people only so long as the latter remain ignorant, supine or disunited.
('41', 278, 4, 15, 537682) But the past seven years have not been lived in vain by the nation.
('41', 278, 4, 16, 537750) The mass awakening that has taken place will never die.
('41', 278, 4, 17, 537806) No one can tell when and how the people will show their strength.
('41', 278, 4, 18, 537872) But the mills occupy a privileged position.
('41', 278, 4, 19, 537916) By showing a little courage, a little consideration for the true interests of the nation and by exercising a little self sacrifice they can serve both the Government and the people.
('41', 278, 4, 20, 538098) They can convert the government and advance the people’s cause.
('41', 278, 4, 21, 538162) This is now in my humble opinion they can do it: They can standardize their prices taking the lowest average of a number of top and lean years.
('41', 278, 4, 22, 538306) They can come to terms with the leaders organizing boycott as to the qunatity and quality of cloth required for the nation.
('41', 278, 4, 23, 538430) They can refrain from manufacturing those varieties that can be easily and immediately produced by khadi organizations, thus freeing
('41', 279, 0, 1, 538563) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 279, 1, 2, 538605) their energy for manufacturing more of the varieties they can at the present moment more easily manufacture than the khadi orga nizations.
('41', 279, 1, 3, 538744) They can limit their profits to a minimum and let the surplus, if any, be devoted to the fulfilment of the boycott or, if that be unnecessary, to the improvement of the condition of the labourers.
('41', 279, 1, 4, 538941) This would mean all round honesty, perseverance, mutual trust, a voluntary and honourable triple alliance between labour, capital and the consumer.
('41', 279, 1, 5, 539089) It would mean capacity for organization on a vast scale.
('41', 279, 1, 6, 539146) And if we are to attain boycott of foreign cloth through non violence, we shall have some day or other to fulfil the tests just enumerated by me.
('41', 279, 1, 7, 539292) In my humble opinion we are eminently fitted for the task.
('41', 279, 1, 8, 539351) The organization required for the purpose is not unfamiliar to us.
('41', 279, 1, 9, 539418) The only question is, have we the will?
('41', 279, 1, 10, 539458) Have the mill owners enough visi on, enough love of the country?
('41', 279, 1, 11, 539523) If they have, they can take the lead.
('41', 279, 1, 12, 539561) Let me redeclare my own faith.
('41', 279, 1, 13, 539592) For boycott to be swiftly brought about a combination between khadi and truly indigenous mills is desirable, but not absolutely necessary.
('41', 279, 1, 14, 539731) I use the words truly indigenous, because we have bogus mills in India which are Indian only in the sense that they are located in the country but whose shareholders, whose management, whose spirit are mainly, when not wholly, foreign.
('41', 279, 1, 15, 539967) But if the indigenous mills cannot or will not lead or join national movement, I am convinced that khadi alone can achieve the boycott if the politically minded India has the will, the faith and the energy required for the purpose.
('41', 279, 1, 16, 540199) We have not enough horsepower expressed through steam engines, oil engines or electricity, but we have an inexhaustible reservoir of manpower lying idle and pleading to be used, and essentially qualified for the purpose.
('41', 279, 1, 17, 540420) Oh, for a faith that would see and use this supply of living power!
('41', 279, 1, 18, 540488) Young India, 15 3 28

('41', 280, 3, 9, 541428) 319. NOTES
('41', 280, 4, 10, 541439) A.I.S.A. MEMBERSHIP The foregoing summaries 2 tell their own tale.
('41', 280, 4, 11, 541506) There is a drop from the figures of 1927 in all the three classes.
('41', 280, 4, 12, 541573) The reason is that there has been little or no canvassing for membership because the policy of the Association rightly has been not to incur any expenses over sacrificial spinning.
('41', 280, 4, 13, 541754) It loses all merit when it requires to be canvassed and stimulated through paid agency.
('41', 280, 4, 14, 541842) But the membership can be easily doubled if every member were to undertake to find one new member.
('41', 280, 4, 15, 541941) It is worthy of note that whilst the membership has decreased, there has been a marked increase in the production and sale of khadi as well as in the number of spinners who spin for hire.
('41', 280, 4, 16, 542129) For the information of juveniles, I reproduce below the resolution of the Council of the Association.
('41', 280, 4, 17, 542231) National schools can do a great deal for increasing the number of juvenile members:
('41', 280, 5, 18, 542315) Resolved that a B class of juvenile members of the Association be created, consisting of persons below 18 years of age who habitually wear khadi and contribute to the Association an annual subscription of 2,000 yards of self spun yarn well twisted and uniform.
('41', 280, 5, 19, 542576) INSTRUCTIVE FIGURES I have been always repeating at public meetings that 50,000 spinners were being served by the All India Spinners’ Association in 1,500 villages.
('41', 280, 5, 20, 542741) This statement was based on the figures compiled by the All India Spinners’ Association on the basis of yarn production and was made in 1927. Since then more than a year has passed.
('41', 280, 5, 21, 542923) An attempt was made to arrive at the total number from direct evidence,
('41', 280, 6, 22, 542995) 1 The report is not reproduced here.
('41', 280, 6, 23, 543032) 2 Not reproduced here

('41', 281, 1, 2, 543096) i.e., by taking a census of spinners and incidentally of weavers and carders supported by the All India Spinners’ Association.
('41', 281, 1, 3, 543223) The table 1
('41', 281, 2, 4, 543235) appended to this note gives those figures.
('41', 281, 2, 5, 543278) It will be seen that all the provinces have not made their returns to have all the organizations in the provinces that have sent their figures been able to comply with the requirements of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('41', 281, 2, 6, 543503) The figures given below are therefore in every way an underestimate and yet they are a decided advance upon 50,000 spinners and 1,500 villages.
('41', 281, 2, 7, 543647) But this is merely a foretaste of the possibilities of a movement which awaits the tangible support of an enlightened public opinion.
('41', 281, 2, 8, 543781) There is an illimitable scope for production of khadi if demand can only be guaranteed.

('41', 281, 3, 10, 543892) 320. STILL AT IT
('41', 281, 4, 11, 543909) The autobiographical chapter dealing with my participation in the late War continues to puzzle friends and critics.
('41', 281, 4, 12, 544025) Here is one more letter: 2
('41', 281, 5, 13, 544052) No doubt it was a mixed motive that prompted me to parti cipate in the War.
('41', 281, 5, 14, 544128) Two things I can recall.
('41', 281, 5, 15, 544153) Though as an indi vidual I was opposed to war, I had no status for offering effec tive non violent resistance.
('41', 281, 5, 16, 544264) Non violent resistance can only follow some real disinterested service, some heart expression of love.
('41', 281, 5, 17, 544367) For instance, I would have no status to resist a savage offering animal sacrifice until he could recognize in me his friend through some loving act of mine or other means.
('41', 281, 5, 18, 544539) I do not sit in judgment upon the world for its many misdeeds.
('41', 281, 5, 19, 544602) Being imperfect myself and needing toleration and charity, I tolerate the world’s imperfections till I find or create an opportunity for fruitful expostulation.
('41', 281, 5, 20, 544763) I felt that if by sufficient service I could attain the power and the confidence to resist the Empire’s wars and its warlike preparations, it would be a good thing for me who was seeking to enforce non violence in my own life to test the extent to which it was possible among the masses.
('41', 281, 6, 21, 545051) 1 Not reproduced here 2 Not reproduced here.
('41', 281, 6, 22, 545096) Referring to Chapters XXXVIII and XXXIX of Part IV of the Autobiography the correspondent had asked: “What impelled you to participate in the War?
('41', 281, 6, 23, 545243) Was it right to join the War with the hope of gaining something?
('41', 281, 6, 24, 545308) I do not know how to reconcile this with the teaching of the Gita which says that we should never act with a view to the fruits of action.”
('41', 282, 0, 1, 545448) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 283
('41', 282, 1, 2, 545490) The other motive was to qualify for swaraj through the good offices of the statesmen of the Empire.
('41', 282, 1, 3, 545590) I could not thus qualify myself except through serving the Empire in its life and death struggle.
('41', 282, 1, 4, 545688) It must be understood that I am writing of my mentality in 1914 when I was a believer in the Empire and its willing ability to help India in her battle for freedom.
('41', 282, 1, 5, 545853) Had I been the non violent rebel that I am today, I should certainly not have helped but through every effort open to non violence I should have attempted to defeat its purpose.
('41', 282, 1, 6, 546031) My opposition to and disbelief in war was as strong then as it is today.
('41', 282, 1, 7, 546104) But we have to recognize that there are many things in the world which we do although we may be against doing them.
('41', 282, 1, 8, 546220) I am as much opposed to taking the life of the lowest creature alive as I am to war.
('41', 282, 1, 9, 546305) But I continually take such life hoping some day to attain the ability to do without this fratricide.
('41', 282, 1, 10, 546407) To entitle me in spite of it to be called a votary of non violence, my attempt must be honest, strenuous and unceasing.
('41', 282, 1, 11, 546527) The conception of moksha, absolution from the need to have an embodied existence, is based upon the necessity of perfected men and women being completely non violent.
('41', 282, 1, 12, 546694) Possession of a body like every other possession necessitates some violence, be it ever so little.
('41', 282, 1, 13, 546793) The fact is that the path of duty is not always easy to discern amidst claims seeming to conflict one with the other.
('41', 282, 1, 14, 546911) Lastly, the verse referred to from the Gita has a double meaning.
('41', 282, 1, 15, 546977) One is that there should be no selfish purpose behind our actions.
('41', 282, 1, 16, 547044) That of gaining swaraj is not a selfish purpose.
('41', 282, 1, 17, 547093) Secon dly, to be detached from fruits of actions is not to be ignorant of them, or to disregard or disown them.
('41', 282, 1, 18, 547205) To be detached is never to abandon action because the contemplated result may not follow.
('41', 282, 1, 19, 547295) On the contrary, it is proof of immovable faith in the certainty of the contemplated result following in due course.
('41', 282, 2, 20, 547412) Young India, 15 3 1928
('41', 283, 0, 1, 547435) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('41', 285, 6, 10, 550934) 325. LETTER TO SHANKER
('41', 285, 7, 11, 550957) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 16, 1928
('41', 285, 8, 12, 551002) MY DEAR SHANKER, I have your letter.
('41', 285, 8, 13, 551039) I have, so far as letters are concerned, neglected you entirely; but you have never been out of my mind especially because I am myself taking an active part in the conduct of the kitchen and I give early in the morning about an hour shredding vegetables which is my contribution to the joint work.
('41', 285, 8, 14, 551337) Giriraj was feeling weak and overworked.
('41', 285, 8, 15, 551378) He has therefore gone to the model village which is being constructed these days and Pyarelal has taken his charge for the time being.
('41', 285, 8, 16, 551513) I am keeping well.
('41', 285, 8, 17, 551532) I am sorry to say that I was obliged to revert to the milk diet though there is hope of my being able to return to fruits and nuts.
('41', 285, 8, 18, 551664) The massage that you saw me take is still being taken.
('41', 285, 8, 19, 551719) The Swedish lady’s massage is in addition.
('41', 285, 8, 20, 551762) It is a very simple thing.
('41', 285, 8, 21, 551789) Tell Mathuradas that I get no time to write.
('41', 285, 9, 22, 551834) From a photostat: S.N. 13109

('41', 286, 13, 17, 552375) 327. LETTER TO VIOLET SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 17, 1928
('41', 286, 14, 18, 552442) MY DEAR VIOLET, I have your long and interesting letter.
('41', 286, 14, 19, 552499) I honour your opinion but I cannot agree with you.
('41', 286, 14, 20, 552550) It surprises me however to find that you do not see any distinction between a private person committing a private wrong and a public person or a corporation committing a public wrong.
('41', 286, 14, 21, 552734) How can people gag individual conduct in the manner you suggest?
('41', 286, 14, 22, 552799) That is a matter of social reform and therefore of individuals living correct lives and [not] letting them, i.e., lives, afflict and inflict their surroundings.
('41', 286, 15, 23, 552960) Yours sincerely, [SHRIMATI VIOLET C/O] MRS.

('41', 287, 1, 2, 553135) 328. LETTER TO N. D. BHOSLE 1
('41', 287, 2, 3, 553165) SABARMATI, March 17, 1928
('41', 287, 3, 4, 553191) DEAR FRIEND, I have now heard from Mr. Jayakar and I see from it that Sir Purushottamdas is no longer the president.
('41', 287, 3, 5, 553308) This, however, is the opinion he forwards to me :
('41', 287, 4, 6, 553358) He is however of opinion that the scheme is a useful one.
('41', 287, 4, 7, 553416) He suggests one caution to you that any help that you may be inclined to give, if it is to take the form of a collection of funds, should be conditioned that its control in the way of investment or disbursement should be in the hands of a few men of your own choice whose veracity and judgment could be implicitly trusted.
('41', 287, 4, 8, 553739) He assures that the scheme has a strong potentiality of being useful to the community, and deserves your support.
('41', 287, 4, 9, 553853) The funds at present in the hands of the office bearers are only a few hundred rupees, and unless they are supplemented it well be difficult for the institution to commence its work.
('41', 287, 4, 10, 554036) It therefore resolves itself into what I have suggested all along the line that there should be a proper trust deed.
('41', 287, 4, 11, 554153) I can now only suggest that you should see Seth Jamnalalji when he comes to Bombay which he will do in two or three days.
('41', 287, 4, 12, 554275) I am giving him all the papers and if he is satisfied about the trust, I shall be in a position to do something.
('41', 287, 5, 13, 554388) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('41', 287, 6, 14, 554418) Jayakar Private Papers, Correspondence File No.
('41', 287, 6, 15, 554466) 422. Courtesy: National Archives of India

('41', 288, 6, 8, 554904) 330. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI [March 17, 1928] 2
('41', 288, 7, 9, 554958) I got your wire just now.
('41', 288, 7, 10, 554984) This time the newspaper reporters have perpetrated a crime.
('41', 288, 7, 11, 555044) They should be prosecuted for that.
('41', 288, 7, 12, 555080) But what can we do, since we are non co operators?
('41', 288, 7, 13, 555131) I am quite all right.
('41', 288, 7, 14, 555153) [From Gujarati]
('41', 288, 8, 15, 555169) Bapuni Prasadi, p.
('41', 288, 9, 16, 555188) 331. THE WEAPON OF BOYCOTT It has been reported that the satyagrahis of Bardoli are getting ready to use the weapon of boycott against those who agree to pay the revenue to the Government.
('41', 288, 9, 17, 555377) This weapon is a powerful one and the satyagrahi can use it only within limits.
('41', 288, 9, 18, 555457) Boycott can be violent as well as non violent.
('41', 288, 9, 19, 555504) It is only the latter kind that a satyagrahi may use.
('41', 288, 9, 20, 555558) At the moment I will only give examples of the two forms of boycott.
('41', 288, 9, 21, 555627) Non violent boycott may mean not accepting any service.
('41', 288, 9, 22, 555683) Refusal to serve may involve violence.
('41', 288, 9, 23, 555722) Non violent boycott may include a refusal to dine at the house of the person boycotted, refusal to attend marriages and such other functions at his place, doing no business with him and, taking no help from him.
('41', 288, 9, 24, 555934) On the other hand, refusing to nurse the boycotted person if he is sick, Lot allowing doctors to visit him, refusing to help in performing the last rites if he happens to die, refusing to allow him to make use of wells, temples, etc., all this is violent boycott.
('41', 288, 10, 25, 556198) 1 From the source 2 ibid
('41', 289, 0, 1, 556223) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 289, 1, 2, 556265) reflection will reveal that non violent boycott can be continued for a long period and no external force can prove effectual in terminating it, whereas violent boycott cannot continue for long and external force can be used in a large measure to put an end to it.
('41', 289, 1, 3, 556529) Ultimately violent boycott only does disservice to a movement.
('41', 289, 1, 4, 556592) Many such instances can be quoted form the era of non co operation.
('41', 289, 1, 5, 556660) However, on this occasion, the distinction that I have pointed out should be enough for the satyagrahis and the workers of Bardoli.
('41', 289, 1, 6, 556792) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 18 3 1928

('41', 290, 2, 3, 557465) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 19, 1928
('41', 290, 3, 4, 557510) BHAISHRI KHAMBHATTA, I got your letter only today.
('41', 290, 3, 5, 557561) You certainly have my blessings for your son.
('41', 290, 3, 6, 557607) I see no reason why you should feel nervous and run to Europe.
('41', 290, 3, 7, 557670) We must have trust in God.
('41', 290, 3, 8, 557697) If some good doctor there is prepared to take the risk, I see no harm in getting the operation performed locally.
('41', 290, 3, 9, 557811) Have you consulted junior Deshmukh?
('41', 290, 3, 10, 557847) Tell Chi.
('41', 290, 3, 11, 557857) Jal to be brave.
('41', 290, 3, 12, 557874) Write to me again and let me know the developments.
('41', 290, 3, 13, 557926) How is your health now?
('41', 290, 3, 14, 557950) If no doctor there is prepared to take the risk and if you do not feel at peace, certainly go to Europe.
('41', 290, 3, 15, 558055) Do not treat my letter as a prohibitory order.
('41', 290, 3, 16, 558102) I only wish to explain to you that we must do nothing in haste and, realizing that this body is perishable, should not be excessively attached to it.
('41', 290, 4, 17, 558252) Blessings from BAPU

('41', 291, 1, 2, 558538) 336. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('41', 291, 2, 3, 558572) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 19, 1928
('41', 291, 3, 4, 558606) MY DEAR C. R., I have your letter.
('41', 291, 3, 5, 558641) You are out of court about your dietetics for your hopeless protest, namely, your spinning yarns about almonds and poor groundnuts, the food of the Himalayan race.
('41', 291, 3, 6, 558805) Take notice that the experiment is only suspended to enable me to return to it, unhampered by the weight of so called medical opinion.
('41', 291, 3, 7, 558940) I lived on raw groundnuts for at least 6 years without coming to grief of the sort referred to by you.
('41', 291, 3, 8, 559043) But of this later.
('41', 291, 3, 9, 559062) What about Europe?
('41', 291, 3, 10, 559081) My anxiety is to meet Rolland.
('41', 291, 3, 11, 559112) He appears to be the wisest man of Europe.
('41', 291, 3, 12, 559155) He takes an unusual interest in me and feels grieved if he thinks that in any single thing my opinion is wrong.
('41', 291, 3, 13, 559267) It seems to me that it would be a tragedy if we do not meet.
('41', 291, 3, 14, 559328) This is the cause that moves me above all else.
('41', 291, 3, 15, 559376) The rest is thrown in.
('41', 291, 3, 16, 559399) I do not know what Andrews has written to you.
('41', 291, 3, 17, 559446) But your opinion will have with me as much weight as Andrews’s.
('41', 291, 3, 18, 559510) Therefore say without fear what you will have me do.
('41', 291, 3, 19, 559563) Many are grieved that I did not die on the 17th.
('41', 291, 3, 20, 559612) Perhaps I am one among them.
('41', 291, 3, 21, 559641) Perhaps I did die a kind of death.
('41', 291, 3, 22, 559676) We shall see.
('41', 291, 4, 23, 559690) From a photostat: S.N. 13111

('41', 293, 4, 8, 561720) 339. LETTER TO SURESH CHANDRA BANERJI
('41', 293, 5, 9, 561758) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 20, 1928
('41', 293, 6, 10, 561803) MY DEAR SURESH BABU, I have seen the letter from the Secretary regarding the number of spinners served by you.
('41', 293, 6, 11, 561914) Do you not see that it is as essential for you to reach your spinners as it is for you to keep your books in a thoroughly good order?
('41', 293, 6, 12, 562048) If you do not take this precaution, you will find that the organization will one day collapse like a house of cards.
('41', 293, 6, 13, 562165) It does not matter whose yarn in the particular week day you have received but it does matter that you send some reliable person to the people who are actually spinning and find out their condition and talk to them.
('41', 293, 6, 14, 562381) Surely, it is neither an impossible task nor a very elaborate one.
('41', 293, 6, 15, 562448) When the spinners who come to the middle men to sell their yarn return home you have simply to follow them to their homes and, if they avoid you once, they won’t avoid you always.
('41', 293, 6, 16, 562628) They will give you their confidence immediately they cease to distrust you.
('41', 293, 6, 17, 562704) You must have some middle men at least who are fairly honest and who will not mind taking your messenger to the very homes from which they receive their yarn.
('41', 293, 6, 18, 562863) And if this very simple thing is beyond your capacity, you are manifestly at the mercy of the middle men to whom it is open any day to stop their custom or to impose conditions which will be either impossible of acceptance or hurtful to your self respect.
('41', 293, 6, 19, 563119) I wish therefore that you will realize the importance of the suggestion which Mr. Banker has been making from time to time at my instance.
('41', 293, 7, 20, 563258) Yours sincerely,
('41', 293, 8, 21, 563275) From a photostat: S.N. 13113

('41', 297, 1, 2, 567387) 345. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 20, 1928
('41', 297, 2, 3, 567471) DEAR SATIS BABU, It is a sad thing this boycott movement.
('41', 297, 2, 4, 567529) I want you to read carefully my article on mills and boycott 1. I am keeping myself in touch with mill owners also.

('41', 297, 2, 6, 567733) The telegram about my health was wholly libellous this time because it was absolutely without any foundation.
('41', 297, 2, 7, 567843) So far as I know, I have never been in better health.

('41', 298, 1, 2, 568658) 347. INTERVIEW TO ALICE SCHALEK
('41', 298, 2, 3, 568690) March 20, 1928
('41', 298, 3, 4, 568705) Mahatma Gandhi received Miss Alice Schalek on the 20th of March in the Ashram at 4 o’clock.
('41', 298, 3, 5, 568797) When she entered, he said : Please excuse me for my remaining on my seat, I cannot stand up.
('41', 298, 4, 6, 568890) MISS S.: May I ask some questions?
('41', 298, 5, 7, 568925) GANDHIJI: Of course, please do.
('41', 298, 6, 8, 568957) Q. Does your influence grow of decline?
('41', 298, 6, 9, 568997) A. A question difficult to answer, but I fancy it is growing, so far as the masses are concerned.
('41', 298, 7, 10, 569095) Q. Is it true that in your meaning the British have done no good to India?
('41', 298, 7, 11, 569170) And you even regard the railways harmful?
('41', 298, 8, 12, 569212) A. Partly true.
('41', 298, 8, 13, 569228) The total effect of the British rule in India has been nothing but evil.
('41', 298, 8, 14, 569301) The railways have done more harm than good.
('41', 298, 9, 15, 569345) Q. Have they not been useful in famines?
('41', 298, 10, 16, 569386) A. They may serve a temporary useful purpose.
('41', 298, 10, 17, 569432) But they have generally served to carry away from the villager what he needs for himself.
('41', 298, 11, 18, 569522) Q. But he gets money for it?
('41', 298, 12, 19, 569551) A. But he cannot eat the money.
('41', 298, 12, 20, 569583) If you were in the desert of Sahara and you had only as much water as you needed for keeping you alive, would you sell it for any amount of gold?
('41', 298, 13, 21, 569729) Q. But are not they selling only what is superfluous?
('41', 298, 14, 22, 569783) A. They sell their birthright when they sell their raw produce.
('41', 298, 14, 23, 569847) They do so because they know no better.
('41', 298, 14, 24, 569887) If you have my welfare at heart, would you advise me to sell raw hide and get from you manufactured shoes, or to sell my cotton and purchase manufactured cloth?
('41', 298, 14, 25, 570048) I am asking my countrymen to store their cotton and spin it into yarn and make their own cloth.
('41', 298, 15, 26, 570144) Q. They say that where there are railways there is no starvation.
('41', 298, 15, 27, 570210) In case of famine, they take food quickly from a place where it is in abundance to a place where it is needed.
('41', 298, 16, 28, 570321) A. Those who laid out the railways did not think of the welfare
('41', 299, 0, 1, 570385) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 299, 1, 2, 570427) of the people.
('41', 299, 1, 3, 570442) They thought of the interest of the distant shareholders or principals.
('41', 299, 1, 4, 570514) The advantage, in case of a famine, is small when we think of the counterbalancing disadvantages.
('41', 299, 1, 5, 570612) It is like a robber robbing me of my all and then offering me back a trifle.
('41', 299, 2, 6, 570689) Q. Would India have been better if railways had not been here?
('41', 299, 3, 7, 570752) A. I have no doubt, other conditions being satisfied.
('41', 299, 4, 8, 570806) Q. How can the railways be made useful?
('41', 299, 5, 9, 570846) A. The policy should be so conceived as to be consistent with the real interests of the people, that is to say, they should enable people to remain self supporting as they were before the railways came.
('41', 299, 5, 10, 571049) Today they are being pauperized both in mind and body.
('41', 299, 5, 11, 571104) They knew how to make the best use of their raw material.
('41', 299, 5, 12, 571162) They used to turn their cotton into cloth, their hide into shoes, their corn into bread.
('41', 299, 5, 13, 571251) Today the process is being reversed.
('41', 299, 5, 14, 571288) I cannot consider anything more [harmful] than that millions should have to export their raw material which they can manufacture at home, and import finished products.
('41', 299, 5, 15, 571456) The railways can usefully serve to transmit the finished products manufactured by the villagers from one part of the country to another.
('41', 299, 6, 16, 571593) Q. There should be a large movement to teach the people to do all these things?
('41', 299, 7, 17, 571673) A. There was ample interprovincial trade before.
('41', 299, 8, 18, 571722) Q. Is not the foreign method cheaper?
('41', 299, 9, 19, 571760) Even if it was, our own product would be cheaper at a higher cost.
('41', 299, 9, 20, 571827) For instance when we in the Ashram first began to grow our vegetables they cost us more than the market vegetables.
('41', 299, 9, 21, 571943) But now we grow them better and cheaper than elsewhere and our own inmates get work also.
('41', 299, 10, 22, 572033) Q. May I speak frankly?
('41', 299, 10, 23, 572057) I was told in Bengal that khaddar is more expensive and coarser than British cloth and that women who pledge themselves to wear khaddar have their underwear made of foreign cloth.
('41', 299, 11, 24, 572237) A. If khaddar is coarser, patriotism demands that measure of sacrifice.
('41', 299, 11, 25, 572309) There is no doubt that we have made a considerable advance on what we used to produce some years ago and we have been able to effect considerable reduction in prices.
('41', 299, 11, 26, 572476) As for the ladies you were told about, I can only say that it was not proper for them to use any foreign cloth if they were pledged to wear khadi.
('41', 300, 0, 1, 572623) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 301
('41', 300, 1, 2, 572665) Q. What are your aims and ideals?
('41', 300, 2, 3, 572699) A. I want perfect freedom for my country through non violent and truthful means.
('41', 300, 3, 4, 572780) Q. Do you think you can reach so far through non violence?
('41', 300, 4, 5, 572839) A. My own conviction is that we shall obtain it only through non violence and not otherwise.
('41', 300, 4, 6, 572932) I think it more possible of attainment through non violent than through violent means.
('41', 300, 5, 7, 573019) Q. What do you mean by freedom?
('41', 300, 6, 8, 573051) A. I want the freedom to make mistakes, and freedom to unmake them, and freedom to grow to my full height and freedom to stumble also.
('41', 300, 6, 9, 573186) I do not want crutches.
('41', 300, 7, 10, 573210) Q. Don’t you think the British have been very helpful to India?
('41', 300, 8, 11, 573274) A. They have been most harmful in every essential particular.
('41', 300, 8, 12, 573336) By “they” I mean the British Government.
('41', 300, 9, 13, 573377) Q. And why?
('41', 300, 9, 14, 573389) A. Because they have sapped the economic, mental and moral growth of the people.
('41', 300, 10, 15, 573470) Q. Don’t you think they have helped in India’s economic growth?
('41', 300, 11, 16, 573534) A. According to the reports of Government officials them selves, India is poorer today than it was fifty years ago.
('41', 300, 11, 17, 573650) A few individuals may have become rich, but generally poverty is deepening.
('41', 300, 11, 18, 573726) There has been a little transfer of wealth, but no general prosperity of the country.
('41', 300, 12, 19, 573812) Q. Government say there were never before so many purchasers.
('41', 300, 13, 20, 573874) A. It is wrong if they mean that people could not buy then and that they can buy now.
('41', 300, 13, 21, 573960) It is true in the sense that whereas people did not buy many things in those days, they do so today, and there are more goods to buy.
('41', 300, 14, 22, 574094) Q. But what is the sense of boycotting British goods?
('41', 300, 14, 23, 574148) England does not give preference to her own goods.
('41', 300, 14, 24, 574199) There is free competition for all the nations of the world.
('41', 300, 15, 25, 574259) It is wrong.
('41', 300, 15, 26, 574272) It only appears as though there was free competition.
('41', 300, 15, 27, 574326) England does give preference to her goods in a variety of insidious ways.
('41', 300, 15, 28, 574400) There is apparent freedom, but no true freedom.
('41', 300, 15, 29, 574448) But even if the British were impartial in favouring foreigners, I would have my quarrel with them.
('41', 300, 15, 30, 574547) I want preference for Indian interests.
('41', 301, 0, 1, 574587) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 301, 1, 2, 574629) Q. How?
('41', 301, 2, 3, 574637) A. By prohibiting import of all foreign cloth and by levying a heavy tax on all imports that can be manufactured in the country.
('41', 301, 3, 4, 574766) Q. Buy your cost of manufacture will be much higher.
('41', 301, 4, 5, 574819) A. High and low prices are no necessary indication of the prosperity or depression of a country.
('41', 301, 4, 6, 574916) It is infinitely better that I grow my vegetable even if the cost is a trifle higher than that I should depend for them on someone else.
('41', 301, 4, 7, 575053) Then I shall try to reduce the cost by judicious and skilful management.
('41', 301, 4, 8, 575126) The gain in skill, comfort and the knowledge that we grow our vegetables is much greater than the little gain we might have in getting vegetables cheap in Ahmedabad.
('41', 301, 4, 9, 575292) Even in the matter [of] producing cloth we could do it in no time and quite cheap if we were left to our own resources.
('41', 301, 5, 10, 575412) Q. There is no country in the world which is free from foreign competition.
('41', 301, 6, 11, 575488) A. Pardon me.
('41', 301, 6, 12, 575502) Germany was one.
('41', 301, 6, 13, 575519) Germany erected a prohi bitive tariff wall on all foreign sugar and then successfully produced its best sugar.
('41', 301, 6, 14, 575630) Every nation protects its infant industry by bounties and tariffs.
('41', 301, 7, 15, 575697) Q. Do you mean to say that all foreign imports must be stopped and that India must use only indigenous goods?
('41', 301, 8, 16, 575807) A. We may have from foreign countries all the things we cannot produce, e.g., we may have iodine from Britain or Germany, we may have pearls from Arabia, diamonds from Johannesburg, lever watches from England and good readable books from England, America and all countries in the world.
('41', 301, 8, 17, 576094) Indeed I should have need[les] and pins—dangerous weapons both!—from foreign coun tries, and quite a number of other things I can mention.
('41', 301, 8, 18, 576233) And we may profitably export to other countries whatever they need, but we should never impose anything on anybody.
('41', 301, 8, 19, 576349) For instance I may grow opium, but would not think of imposing it on China or America.
('41', 301, 9, 20, 576436) Q. But if you make your own things, would you not have to face the labour question?
('41', 301, 10, 21, 576520) A. Why?
('41', 301, 10, 22, 576528) If it arises, it will solve itself.
('41', 301, 11, 23, 576564) Q. Would you do it all on capitalistic basis or communistic basis?
('41', 301, 12, 24, 576631) A. On a nationalistic basis, in the interests of the people.
('41', 301, 13, 25, 576692) Q. But who will finance the industries?
('41', 301, 14, 26, 576732) Our finance consists in our own men and women, and
('41', 302, 0, 1, 576783) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 303
('41', 302, 1, 2, 576825) we have got them in their millions.
('41', 302, 2, 3, 576861) Q. Should your industry be run by the State or by the country?
('41', 302, 3, 4, 576924) A. It does not matter how it is run, provided it is run in the interests of the millions, not of a class.
('41', 302, 3, 5, 577030) That principle assured, I should not mind who nominally runs it.
('41', 302, 4, 6, 577095) From a photostat: S.N. 14284

('41', 304, 6, 10, 580086) 353. NOTES
('41', 304, 7, 11, 580097) CHARKHA A PROVED WANT Akbarpur in U.P. is a little place where Professor Kripalani’s khadi band worked for seven years.
('41', 304, 7, 12, 580217) For reason into which I need not go, this band had to withdraw from Akbarpur.
('41', 304, 7, 13, 580295) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru describes the touching scenes that followed the withdrawal and how the centre had somehow to be kept up.
('41', 304, 7, 14, 580424) The following from his letter to the All India Spinners’ Association will be read with interest:
('41', 304, 8, 15, 580521) I have told you already that the Gandhi Ashram has left Akbarpur.
('41', 304, 8, 16, 580587) We have taken charge temporarily because we felt that pending your decision we ought to carry on.
('41', 304, 8, 17, 580685) If we had not taken charge there would have been a break and it would have been more difficult to start afresh.
('41', 304, 8, 18, 580797) Besides, on sentimental grounds also it was a little difficult to abandon the place.
('41', 304, 8, 19, 580882) It has been a well known centre for so many years and a large number of weavers and others are intimately connected with it.
('41', 304, 8, 20, 581007) To leave it suddenly would have had a bad effect on the whole neighbourhood and upset the economy of a great number of poor households who were dependent on it.
('41', 304, 8, 21, 581168) Indeed, we were told that some touching incidents were witnessed when the Gandhi Ashram announced that they were closing up.
('41', 304, 8, 22, 581293) Many old women spinners who used to sell their yarn at a distant centre, finding this centre closed, trudged up many miles to headquarters and wept when they found that their yarn was not to be bought.
('41', 304, 8, 23, 581495) Many weavers with their wives and families came up to the Akbarpur office and said they would perform satyagraha.
('41', 304, 8, 24, 581609) For seven years they had been working for the Ashram and now they were being left in the lurch.
('41', 304, 8, 25, 581705) You will realize how difficult it was
('41', 305, 0, 1, 581743) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 305, 1, 2, 581785) for us to refuse to take charge under these circumstances.
('41', 305, 1, 3, 581844) But of course, sentimental considerations cannot decide the question.
('41', 305, 1, 4, 581914) Akbarpur possesses some marked advantages and at the same time a very great disadvantage.
('41', 305, 1, 5, 582004) As a weaving centre it is famous and even now some of the finest weaving in India is done at Tanda in the neighbourhood.
('41', 305, 1, 6, 582125) Unhappily this fine weaving—called jamdani work—is done with foreign yarn.
('41', 305, 1, 7, 582200) On the other hand, there is very little spinning done near Akbarpur if the centre is to be worked it will be necessary to bring yarn from elsewhere.
('41', 305, 1, 8, 582349) The Gandhi Ashram, I believe, used to get their yarn chiefly from across the border in Bihar, also from Muzaffarnagar.
('41', 305, 1, 9, 582468) For us it will be easier to get it from the Northern Districts of the U.P.—Moradabad, Bijnor, etc.
('41', 305, 1, 10, 582567) The cost of sending the yarn is not great.
('41', 305, 1, 11, 582610) If khadi became as current as ghee or grain, there could never have been a thought of withdrawing from any centre.
('41', 305, 1, 12, 582725) If we had funds and workers we would have representatives not only in 1,600 villages but in 7,00,000 villages.
('41', 305, 1, 13, 582836) This is no impracticable ambition, when we remember the fact that there are at least two representatives of the alien Government in each of these villages.
('41', 305, 1, 14, 582992) If anyone before the British advent had suggested any such thing, he would have been laughed out of court.
('41', 305, 1, 15, 583099) But reflection should show that the restoration of the wheel in every one of the villages is not half as laughable as the hope of imperial Britain being represented in the republican villages of India would have been in the 17th century.
('41', 305, 1, 16, 583337) What the women near Akbarpur are reported to have said demonstrates what a felt want the charkha fills or can fill in every village of this ancient land.
('41', 305, 1, 17, 583491) It is no credit to our patriotism that the able weavers of Akbarpur have to fall back upon foreign yarn for their far famed jamdani which it was their pride nearly half a century ago to weave out of yarn spun by the sacred hands of their own sisters living next door to them.
('41', 305, 1, 18, 583767) It won’t be long before the spinners in our villages are able to spin as fine and as strong yarn as any foreign yarn now infesting our market.
('41', 305, 2, 19, 583910) CAN IT BE TRUE?
('41', 305, 3, 20, 583926) The president, Arya Samaj, New Delhi, writes: 1
('41', 305, 4, 21, 583974) The Baghat State is situated in the Simla Hills and its ruler is an enlightened Hindu chief.
('41', 305, 4, 22, 584067) The population of the State is about ten thousand and mainly consists of Rajputs, Kanets and Brahmins.
('41', 305, 4, 23, 584170) The other tribes are Kolis, Chamars, etc., who are regarded as menials.
('41', 305, 4, 24, 584242) Although the Kolis chiefly
('41', 305, 5, 25, 584269) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('41', 306, 0, 1, 584306) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 307
('41', 306, 1, 2, 584348) live on agriculture yet the social disabilities to which they are subject are numerous.
('41', 306, 1, 3, 584436) Moved by the inhuman treatment which these people suffer at the hands of their Hindu brethren, the Arya Samaj, Simla, brought them into their fold with a view to raise their status in life and invested them with the sacred thread, inasmuch as by occupation they are Vaisyas.
('41', 306, 1, 4, 584711) This seems to have given umbrage to the caste Hindus who challenged the right of their being invested with the sacred thread.
('41', 306, 1, 5, 584837) A summary trial consequently held on the 6th January 1928 by the Chief of the State himself and on the subsequent day on the plea of antiquity and customs, the poor kolis who were ten in number were sentenced to undergo six months’ imprisonment in addition to a fine of Rs. 200 each.
('41', 306, 1, 6, 585121) No opportunity was given to these unfortunate persons to defend themselves, nor was permission given to the Pandit of the Arya Samaj who happened to be present on the occasion to explain the point of view of the Arya Samaj in this matter.
('41', 306, 1, 7, 585360) It is now reported that they are being coerced in the jail to take off their sacred thread.
('41', 306, 1, 8, 585452) The information contained in the foregoing seems to me to be unbelievable.
('41', 306, 1, 9, 585527) The Kolis can in no way be considered to be untouchables or to be of the suppressed or the depressed classes.
('41', 306, 1, 10, 585637) If they are their own farmers, according to the definition of the different varnas, they are born Vaisyas and have every right to wear the sacred thread.
('41', 306, 1, 11, 585791) But assuming that they have no right in religion, I was totally unprepared for the news that the wearing of the sacred thread would be considered a crime punishable in law in any State.
('41', 306, 1, 12, 585977) Equally unthinkable it is that the unfortunate men who thought that they had passed through some desirable or meritorious religious ceremony were denied even the right of defending themselves and producing their witnesses.
('41', 306, 1, 13, 586200) And, if the statements about the punishment and farcical trial are true, I should not at all wonder if the sacred thread had been forcibly taken off their persons.
('41', 306, 1, 14, 586364) I would invite the president of the Arya Samaj to send further details, if any, in corroboration of the charges brought by him against the Baghat State and I would invite the State authorities if they wish to send me their version of the incident which I shall gladly publish.
('41', 306, 1, 15, 586641) Young India, 22 3 1928
('41', 307, 0, 1, 586664) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 307, 1, 2, 586706) 354. FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT—SOME QUESTIONS
('41', 307, 2, 3, 586748) A friend intimately connected with mills and desirous of having our mills contributing their full quota to the foreign cloth boycott movement asks :
('41', 307, 3, 4, 586897) 1. On what basis do you want prices standardized?
('41', 307, 3, 5, 586947) For remember all mills are not alike.
('41', 307, 3, 6, 586985) Some are bad, some are good; some use more sizing than others, some have more reserve than others; Bombay mills make less profits than upcountry ones.
('41', 307, 3, 7, 587136) These difference are illustrative of many others that might be stated.
('41', 307, 3, 8, 587207) The one general answer that may be given is “where there’s a will there’s a way”.
('41', 307, 3, 9, 587289) The mills will contribute their quota only when they get rid of inertia, think “furiously”, and that too in terms of the nation, not merely the pockets of share holders, directors or agents.
('41', 307, 3, 10, 587480) But by way of making my position in this matter clearer I may say that all the mills who will join the boycott movement will have to pool all the differences and arrive at a standard price which would at least mean a large slice off from the present profits of at least some mills.
('41', 307, 3, 11, 587762) If their patriotism is sound and progressive the flourishing ones will cover the losing ones, avoidable differences will be avoided.
('41', 307, 3, 12, 587895) In the scheme I have in view the mills need never lose in the aggregate and they must not profit at the expense of the buyer.
('41', 307, 4, 13, 588021) 2. Only some mills will undertake not to manufacture khadi.
('41', 307, 4, 14, 588081) But what about those that only spin low counts?
('41', 307, 4, 15, 588129) What is your test of khadi?
('41', 307, 4, 16, 588157) This is a matter of common honesty and arrangement between khadi organizations and mills.
('41', 307, 4, 17, 588247) At present I am sorry to have to say that even some good mills are not ashamed to label their cloth ‘khadi’ simply in order to take an illegitimate advantage of the growing khadi atmosphere in the mofussil.
('41', 307, 4, 18, 588454) If a workable arrangement is come to, I expect that there will be a line of demarcation for the time being between the cloth to be manufactured by khadi centres and mills.
('41', 307, 4, 19, 588626) The manufacture of cloth will be controlled as it often is in times of war.
('41', 307, 4, 20, 588702) What in a war based on violence we do by compulsion, in this war based on non violence we shall do by choice.
('41', 307, 4, 21, 588812) Our ability voluntarily, i.e., merely under pressure of public opinion, to arrange boycotts, etc., will be the outward but indispensable test of our non violence if we have any in us.
('41', 307, 5, 22, 588996) 3. How will profits be regulated?
('41', 307, 5, 23, 589030) You know as well as I do that prices of cotton fluctuate with irritating irregularity.
('41', 308, 0, 1, 589117) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 309
('41', 308, 1, 2, 589159) This assumes our inability to control the cotton market.
('41', 308, 1, 3, 589216) Surely if the largest manufacturers of the country combine in the patriotic effort, they will control the cotton market.
('41', 308, 1, 4, 589337) America rules our cotton prices because we stupidly, thoughtlessly, and selfishly send out our cotton.
('41', 308, 1, 5, 589440) But boycott means that we shall control the movement of cotton, as we shall control many other things, if we are to achieve complete boycott, as we must if we have developed the true national spirit and have confidence in ourselves and the nation.
('41', 308, 2, 6, 589688) 4. If you lay much stress upon honesty, perseverance, mutual trust, etc., you are doomed.
('41', 308, 2, 7, 589778) As I have no bayonet at my command and would not have it even if I could command it, I must press for the qualities which the friend fears are at a discount.
('41', 308, 2, 8, 589936) I do not share his fear—what is more I have patience enough to wait for the development of those qualities if they are not available in sufficient measure today.
('41', 308, 2, 9, 590098) For this nation will never come to her own unless we exhibit them as a nation.
('41', 308, 2, 10, 590177) I know too that we shall take much longer to discipline ourselves for violence, fraud and the like than we shall for truth and non violence and all that they imply.
('41', 308, 2, 11, 590342) The friend then draws my attention to the following omissions in my previous article : 1
('41', 308, 3, 12, 590431) (a) The mills that join the scheme may not use foreign yarn or foreign artificial silk as many now do.
('41', 308, 3, 13, 590534) (b) They may not insure with foreign companies.
('41', 308, 3, 14, 590582) (c) They may not import foreign cloth and lable it ‘swadeshi’.
('41', 308, 3, 15, 590645) I had assumed that (a) and (c) were a foregone conclusion.
('41', 308, 3, 16, 590704) I should not care to insist on (b) if the insistence would hamper the proposed joint venture.
('41', 308, 3, 17, 590798) Much as I should like indigenous insurance enterprise, I am convinced that it is the foreign cloth that blocks the way as nothing else does.
('41', 308, 3, 18, 590939) If we can put this Himalayan obstacle out of the way, we shall easily cope with hillocks.

('41', 309, 0, 1, 591096) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 309, 1, 2, 591138) 355. DIFFERENCE STATED
('41', 309, 2, 3, 591161) I gladly publish the foregoing.
('41', 309, 2, 4, 591193) 1 It was made clear at those meetings of International Fellowship 2 that I had meant the principal religions of the world and I had maintained that all were true more or less and that all were necessarily imperfect.
('41', 309, 2, 5, 591409) Here therefore there is agreement.
('41', 309, 2, 6, 591444) But Mr. Ireland’s letter leaves on the mind the impression that there is a fundamental difference between him and me regarding conversion, no matter by what name it is called.
('41', 309, 2, 7, 591620) Let me extend the analogy of fragrance, faulty as all analogies are in their very nature.
('41', 309, 2, 8, 591710) The rose imparts its fragrance not in many ways but only one.
('41', 309, 2, 9, 591772) Those who have not the sense of smell will miss it.
('41', 309, 2, 10, 591824) You cannot feel the fragrance through the tongue or the ear or the skin.
('41', 309, 2, 11, 591897) So may you not receive spirituality except through the spiritual sense.
('41', 309, 2, 12, 591969) Hence have all religions recognized the necessity of that sense being awakened.
('41', 309, 2, 13, 592049) It is a second birth.
('41', 309, 2, 14, 592071) A man with intense spirituality may without speech or a gesture touch the hearts of millions who have never seen him and whom he has never seen.
('41', 309, 2, 15, 592216) The most eloquent preacher if he has not spirituality in him will fail to touch the hearts of his audience.
('41', 309, 2, 16, 592324) Therefore I venture to think that most of the effort of modern missions is not only useless but more often than not harmful.
('41', 309, 2, 17, 592449) At the root of missionary effort is also the assumption that one’s own belief is true not only for oneself but for all the world; whereas the truth is that God reaches us 3 through millions of ways not understood by us.
('41', 309, 2, 18, 592669) In missionary effort therefore there is lack of real humility that instinctively recognizes human limitations and the limitless power of God.
('41', 309, 2, 19, 592811) I have no feeling that from a spiritual standpoint I am necessarily superior to the so called savage.
('41', 309, 2, 20, 592913) And spiritual superiority is a dangerous thing to feel.
('41', 309, 2, 21, 592969) It is not 4like many other things which we can perceive, analyse and prove through our senses.
('41', 309, 2, 22, 593064) If it is there, I cannot be deprived of it by any power on earth, and it will have its effect in its own due time.
('41', 309, 2, 23, 593179) But if in matters of medicine and other natural sciences, I feel my superiority over others, a thing of which I may be legitimately conscious, and if I have love for my fellow beings, I would naturally share my knowledge with them.
('41', 309, 2, 24, 593411) But things of the spirit I leave to God and thus keep the bond between fellow beings and myself pure, correct and within limits.
('41', 309, 2, 25, 593540) But I must not carry this argument any further.
('41', 309, 3, 26, 593588) 1 The letter from W. F. Ireland of Cambridge Mission is not reproduced here.
('41', 309, 3, 27, 593665) 2 Vide “Discussion on Fellowship”, Before 15 1 1928. 3 Vide “Two Corrections”, 29 3 1928. 4 ibid
('41', 310, 0, 1, 593762) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 311
('41', 310, 1, 2, 593804) My first feeling was not to publish Mr. Ireland’s letter but to send a brief reply to him privately.
('41', 310, 1, 3, 593905) But my regard for him has prompted me to comply with his wish without any ado knowing full well that this is not a matter which admits of any conclusive argument especially from my side and in view of the position herein described by me.
('41', 310, 1, 4, 594143) Young India, 22 3 1928
('41', 310, 2, 5, 594166) 356. FIJI FOR THE FIJIANS 1

('41', 311, 1, 2, 595452) 358. MARRIAGE OF THE OLD AND CHILD MARRIAGE
('41', 311, 2, 3, 595496) A gentleman from Surat writes to say: 1
('41', 311, 3, 4, 595536) His criticism of child marriages is largely correct.
('41', 311, 3, 5, 595589) If the writer goes through the articles in the previous issues of Navajivan, he will see that they have often severely criticized child marriages.
('41', 311, 3, 6, 595736) And I also know that these articles have averted some child marriages.
('41', 311, 3, 7, 595807) However, there is still room for a great deal of reform.
('41', 311, 3, 8, 595864) Society is not as much averse to child marriage as it is to marriage with old men.
('41', 311, 3, 9, 595947) In my opinion both these are equally objectionable.
('41', 311, 3, 10, 595999) Hence, there is no difference of opinion between this correspondent and myself with regard to condemnation of child marriage.
('41', 311, 3, 11, 596125) If I had the authority or if my pen had enough power, I would use it to prevent every child marriage.
('41', 311, 3, 12, 596227) Parents who marry their children at a tender age become their enemies and are responsible for making them dependent and weak.
('41', 311, 3, 13, 596353) However, the correspondent’s intention appears to be to uphold marriages of old men while discrediting child marriages.
('41', 311, 3, 14, 596473) The advantages of marrying an old man as stated by the correspondent seem to be ludicrous and also to ignore completely the poor girl or if there is any consideration for her it is only for her financial condition.
('41', 311, 3, 15, 596688) The writer appears to forget that consent of the girls who are married off to old men is never secured; perhaps, in his opinion, it is needless to think of it.
('41', 311, 3, 16, 596848) The correspondent seems to be wholly oblivious of the fact that marriage is a religious rite and, worse still, he fails to remember that marriage with an old man amounts to a doubly culpable child marriage, as in all such cases not only is the bride a child but the old man who despite age contemplates marriage can only be deemed a child, or something worse.
('41', 311, 3, 17, 597208) Although the husband may be living it is a kind of widowhood for the girl.
('41', 311, 3, 18, 597283) Society is least likely to be harmed if old men who cannot control their passions or who for some other reason wish to marry, do so with old or mature women prepared to enter into such relationship with them.
('41', 311, 4, 19, 597492) CONGRATULATIONS The result of the above mentioned article has been that a poor girl has been spared as the elderly gentleman who was going to marry her realized his mistake on reading the article and gave up
('41', 311, 5, 20, 597700) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('41', 312, 0, 1, 597737) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 313
('41', 312, 1, 2, 597779) the idea of another marriage.
('41', 312, 1, 3, 597809) I congratulate this gentleman on this welcome result.
('41', 312, 1, 4, 597863) Let us hope that whenever in the future he is moved by passion he will restrain himself, thinking of the girl’s good and of society, and even the country and also remembering God.
('41', 312, 1, 5, 598043) This case should infuse greater enthusiasm in soical workers.
('41', 312, 1, 6, 598105) We find from this as well as other instance that have since occurred that social and other injustices can be prevented if timely steps—restrained yet firm—are taken against them.
('41', 312, 2, 7, 598284) WILL ANOTHER COW BE SAVED?
('41', 312, 3, 8, 598311) Some young girls have been rescued from being sold off to old men.
('41', 312, 3, 9, 598378) Bearing this in mind a gentleman from Ranpur writes to say : 1
('41', 312, 4, 10, 598441) On the strength of this letter, I do request this Modh Vanik gentleman of Bhavnagar not to go through this marriage.
('41', 312, 4, 11, 598558) At the age of 55, he should shrink from the thought of marrying a girl young enough to be his grand daughter.I hope leaders of the Modh community of Bhavnagar will take all steps needed to prevent this marriage.
('41', 312, 4, 12, 598770) In fact in such cases wherever people in general are alert, not only the leaders of small castes, but the entire public and even the State itself, should act as protectors of the young girls and it is their dharma to rescue girls who are being sold in this manner.
('41', 312, 4, 13, 599035) Young men are their guardians and if they don the armour of virtue, humility and courage and do their duty they will be able to rescue all the poor young girls and there is no doubt they can.

('41', 322, 2, 3, 612106) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 28, 1928
('41', 322, 3, 4, 612144) MY DEAR C. R., I have your letter about the proposed European visit.
('41', 322, 3, 5, 612213) I have myself no heart in it, nor have I any confidence in myself about making it successful; but an interview with Rolland still remains an attraction.
('41', 322, 3, 6, 612366) All the reputation I enjoy in the West is borrowed from him and I feel that if I meet him face to face, there may be disillusionment on many points.
('41', 322, 3, 7, 612515) It may be that we should come closer than we ever were.
('41', 322, 3, 8, 612571) I do attach considerable importance to our knowing each other much better than we do.
('41', 322, 3, 9, 612657) I quite agree with you that there is nothing to gain from the health point of view.
('41', 322, 3, 10, 612741) I might possibly suffer, and health is no consideration, whatsoever in the proposed trip.
('41', 322, 3, 11, 612831) From that point of view any hill station in India would be infinitely superior for me.
('41', 322, 3, 12, 612918) I feel also with you that the withdrawal of my presence is likely to unsettle things a bit especially in Bardoli.

('41', 322, 3, 18, 613474) I understand what you say about Ramachandran.

('41', 322, 3, 20, 613606) He is kind of ‘Chetty’ also, for he did wonderfully well in the way of khadi at Jamia.
('41', 322, 3, 21, 613693) I must not forget one thing, though, about your reference to the defalcations.

('41', 324, 1, 2, 615306) 377. ‘THE TRIUMPH OF RACE HATRED’ 1
('41', 324, 2, 3, 615342) I am sure that the Amsterdam International, if it was placed in the same condition as the White Trades Union of Johannesburg, would not behave otherwise than the latter; nor would it have acted otherwise than Mr. Ramsay MacDonald or Mr. Lansbury if its members had found themselves in their position.
('41', 324, 2, 4, 615643) Young India, 29 3 1928
('41', 324, 3, 5, 615666) 378. THE DOCTRINE OF FRIGHTFULNESS In answer to a question put by a member of the late Hunter Committee, General Dyer admitted that Jallianwala was designed to create frightfulness.
('41', 324, 3, 6, 615848) In making the admission the late General enunciated no new doctrine.
('41', 324, 3, 7, 615917) Indeed “the ablest Civil Service in the world” has laid the foundation of its greatness on frightfulnesses.
('41', 324, 3, 8, 616025) In pursuance of this well known policy, according to the information received at the time of going to press it appears that summary steps are now to be taken against the farmers of Bardoli in order to compel submission.
('41', 324, 3, 9, 616245) For eight preliminary notices of forfeiture have been served upon certain satyagrahis of Bardoli.
('41', 324, 3, 10, 616343) The names of these seem to have been carefully chosen, for all of them happen to be banias of note.
('41', 324, 3, 11, 616443) The choice has been so made presumably because banias who have the reputation of being weak and timid are expected to yield under notices of forfeiture.
('41', 324, 3, 12, 616596) What can be more natural, officialdom would argue, than that banias weakening, the others must follow suit.
('41', 324, 3, 13, 616704) Satyagrahis need not be surprised at this first show of frightfulness.
('41', 324, 3, 14, 616775) They have been repeatedly told to expect forfeitures and worse.
('41', 324, 3, 15, 616839) Let them now show their strength if they have it in them.
('41', 324, 3, 16, 616897) Young India, 29 3 1928
('41', 324, 4, 17, 616920) 1 C. F. Andrews’s article, on which Gandhiji comments, is not reproduced here.
('41', 324, 4, 18, 616999) He had written that the International Labour Movement in Europe in its bulletin entitled “The Triumph of Race Hatred” had condemned the South African Trades Union Congress of white workers for its refusal to affiliate the Industrial and Commercial Workers’ Union (I.C.W.U.) of coloured workers which was already affiliated to the Amsterdam International, that is, International Federation of Trades Unions.
('41', 324, 4, 19, 617406) Andrews had also regretted the action of Ramsay MacDonald and the Labour Parliamentary party in England in acquiescing in the appointment of the Simon Commission on a racial basis.
('41', 325, 0, 1, 617587) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 325, 1, 2, 617629) 379. THE NATIONAL WEEK The national week comes upon us with seasonlike regularity and has found us more or less wanting since after 1922. The 6th April to 13th April should be regarded as days of privilege, introspection, intense national activity and self purification.
('41', 325, 1, 3, 617900) These precious seven days should be days of stock taking and heart searching.
('41', 325, 1, 4, 617978) The morning of 6th April 1919 found an India awakened to a sense of her dignity.
('41', 325, 1, 5, 618059) Hindus, Mussalmans and others composing the nation felt themselves united like blood brothers as they are in reality, if they would but recognize themselves as sons of the soil.
('41', 325, 1, 6, 618237) 6th of April 1919 found an India endowed with a true spirit of swadeshi which culminated in khadi and which is now feeding according to the latest figures over 90,000 poor spinners.
('41', 325, 1, 7, 618419) The spirit thus awakened continued to advance during 1920 and 1921 and we seemed to be within an ace of statutory swaraj.
('41', 325, 1, 8, 618541) But that swaraj did not come and there was a set back.
('41', 325, 1, 9, 618596) Apparently since then there has been only an ebb.
('41', 325, 1, 10, 618646) Hindus and Mussalmans are flying at each other’s throats.
('41', 325, 1, 11, 618704) Instead of swadeshi we have the cry for boycott of British goods pending settlement as if support of Japanese goods including Japan’s cheap calico can ever be a substitute for swadeshi, i.e., khadi, exclusive of all foreign cloth.
('41', 325, 1, 12, 618935) After much research, reasoning and experience, we seemed in 1920 21 to have come to the conclusion that the only practical, effective and necessary swadeshi was khadi, not pending any settlement but for all time or such time as we could discover a better and more paying occupation for the starving millions.
('41', 325, 1, 13, 619244) I have seen no new argument in support of boycott of British goods only as distinguished from foreign goods.
('41', 325, 1, 14, 619353) No new situation has arisen to warrant the belief that boycott of British goods is a practical proposition and that the use of foreign cloth other than British is not almost equally detrimental to the best interest of India.
('41', 325, 1, 15, 619578) Would that those who are supporting the cry of boycott of British goods will seriously think over their programme, and, if necessary, revise their plan and join the khadi movement with the whole hearted conviction that it and it alone can bring about complete boycott, not merely of British cloth but of all foreign cloth.
('41', 325, 1, 16, 619901) But whether they do so or not, I am sure they do not make of support to foreign cloth other than British cloth a matter of principle.
('41', 325, 1, 17, 620035) And if I am right in my supposition, let them support the sales of
('41', 326, 0, 1, 620102) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 327
('41', 326, 1, 2, 620144) khadi during the National Week.
('41', 326, 1, 3, 620176) If they will but study the progress of the khadi movement during the past seven years that it has been going on, they will discover that the charkha has more potency than they have ever dreamt of.
('41', 326, 1, 4, 620373) It is potent enough, if it receives the whole hearted and active support of politically minded India, to bring about boycott of foreign cloth even without the assistance of our mills.
('41', 326, 1, 5, 620557) With the active and organized support of the latter, boycott of foreign cloth becomes a much easier proposition.
('41', 326, 1, 6, 620670) Indeed the mill owners hold the trump card if only they would play it for the sake of the nation.
('41', 326, 1, 7, 620768) They have at their disposal a ready made extensive organization, which, if they devote it to the service of the nation, can simplify the campaign of boycott and arm the nation with the power it so much needs.
('41', 326, 1, 8, 620977) And why will not Hindus and Mussalmans recall those precious seven days and shed all fear, mutual distrust and weakness?
('41', 326, 1, 9, 621098) Let me not forget the so called untouchables, the classes that we Hindus have been guilty of suppressing.
('41', 326, 1, 10, 621204) Shall we not have the vision to see that in suppressing a sixth (or whatever the number) of ourselves, we have depressed ourselves?
('41', 326, 1, 11, 621336) No man takes another down a pit without descending into it himself and sinning in the bargain.
('41', 326, 1, 12, 621431) It is not the suppressed that sin.
('41', 326, 1, 13, 621466) It is the suppressor who has to answer for his crime against those whom he suppresses.

('41', 327, 2, 9, 623455) KHADI TOUR IN BENGAL It is perhaps necessary to emphasize in Bengal that the khadi tour organized by Sjt.
('41', 327, 2, 10, 623561) Satis Chandra Das Gupta is also the All India Deshbandhu Memorial tour.
