('41', 327, 2, 15, 623998) There is a wave of swadeshi passing over Bengal at present.
('41', 327, 2, 16, 624058) But I suspect that the true meaning of swadeshi is missed in the forest of words that surround that simple but life giving word.
('41', 327, 2, 17, 624187) Let us adhere to its root meaning and we shall discover nothing but khadi in it.
('41', 327, 2, 18, 624268) Swadehsi is “of one’s own country”.
('41', 327, 2, 19, 624304) Among things of the villagers’ daily use, cloth is the only thing that is “not of one’s own country”.
('41', 327, 2, 20, 624406) That which they can easily make themselves is also cloth.
('41', 327, 2, 21, 624464) Hence the swadeshi that they can realize and without which they must starve is khadi and nothing else.
('41', 327, 2, 22, 624567) Hence is khadi the only real swadeshi for every patriot.
('41', 327, 2, 23, 624624) I hope therefore that Sheth Jamnalalji and his companions will be whole heartedly assisted by Bengal wherever they go.
('41', 327, 2, 24, 624743) Every yard of khadi bought and every donation given to the Memorial is so much help to the boycott movement and to the poorest in the land.
('41', 328, 0, 1, 624883) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 329
('41', 328, 1, 2, 624925) BOYCOTT AND STUDENTS The Principal of a college writes : 1
('41', 328, 2, 3, 624984) The promoters of the boycott movement are dragging the students into their movement.
('41', 328, 2, 4, 625069) When the students leave their schools and colleges and join any demonstration, they mingle with the rowdies of the place and have to be responsible for all the outrages of the badmashes and often receive the first blows from the policeman’s batons.
('41', 328, 2, 5, 625318) They, besides, incur the displeasure of the school and college authorities whose punishment they have to submit to; they further disobey their guardians who might refuse to finance them further, which spells their ruin.
('41', 328, 2, 6, 625538) I can understand youth movements which aim at doing such constructive work as teaching the ignorant peasants, spreading knowledge of sani tation, etc., during holidays; but to see them turn against their own parents and teachers and walk along streets in questionable company and help the breaking of law and order is a sorry spectacle.
('41', 328, 2, 7, 625875) May I request you to advise the politicians not to draw the students from their legitimate work to make their demonstration more effective?
('41', 328, 2, 8, 626015) The correspondent has written in the hope of my condemning the participation by the student world in active political work.
('41', 328, 2, 9, 626139) But I am sorry to have to disappoint him.
('41', 328, 2, 10, 626181) He should have known that in 1920 21 I had not an inconsiderable share in drawing students out of their schools and colleges and inducing them to undertake political duty carrying with it the risk of imprisonment.
('41', 328, 2, 11, 626395) I think it is their clear duty to take leading part in the political movement of their country.
('41', 328, 2, 12, 626491) They are doing so all the world over.
('41', 328, 2, 13, 626529) In India where political cons ciousness has till recently been unfortunately confined in a large measure to the English educated class, their duty is, indeed, greater.
('41', 328, 2, 14, 626697) In China and Egypt it was the students who have made the national movement possible.
('41', 328, 2, 15, 626782) They cannot do less in India.
('41', 328, 2, 16, 626812) What the Principal might have urged was the necessity of students observing the rules of non violence and acquiring control over the rowdies, instead of being controlled by them.

('41', 331, 1, 2, 631577) often result from their use.

('41', 331, 1, 5, 631729) Increased vitality is almost the universal experience of those that have fasted.
('41', 331, 1, 6, 631810) For real rest body and mind is possible only during fasting.

('41', 332, 3, 4, 633721) DEAR FRIEND, Though the translation of your very kind and energetic letter has been with me for three days, I am able to reach it only at the last moment.

('41', 332, 3, 6, 633982) The matter you have discussed is of tremendous importance.

SPEECH AT ASHRAM ON RAMANAVAMI DAY March 30, 1928 The Rama of whom we sing is not the Rama of Valmiki, nor even the Rama of Tulsi—although his Ramayana is very dear to me and I consider it an incomparable work, I never seem to have enough of it once I start reading it.
('41', 337, 6, 18, 641172) Today, however, we shall not think of Tulsidas’s Rama or the Rama of Girdhar’s Ramayana, much less Rama of Kalidasa or Bhavabhuti.
('41', 337, 6, 19, 641303) There is great beauty in Bhavabhuti’s Uttararamacharita.
('41', 337, 6, 20, 641360) However, here is not the Rama whose name we may recite to cross to the other shore or whose name we may repeat in moments of despair.
('41', 337, 6, 21, 641494) If someone is suffering unbearable pain I tell him to repeat Ramanama.
('41', 337, 6, 22, 641565) If someone is unable to sleep I tell him too to repeat Ramanama.
('41', 337, 6, 23, 641630) This Rama is not the son
('41', 337, 7, 24, 641655) 1 From the contents it is clear that the letter was written in 1928. 2 Last day of the National Week 3 Vide “What Can Our Mills Do?”, 15 3 1928.
('41', 338, 0, 1, 641800) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 339
('41', 338, 1, 2, 641842) of Dasharatha or the husband of Sita.
('41', 338, 1, 3, 641880) In fact he is not the embodied Rama.
('41', 338, 1, 4, 641917) The Rama that dwells in our hearts cannot possibly have a physical form; the heart is no larger than a thumb and the Rama who dwells in some niche there could not have a body, nor could he have been born on the ninth day of the month of Chaitra in a certain year.
('41', 338, 1, 5, 642181) He is birthless.
('41', 338, 1, 6, 642198) He is the Creator, the Lord of the universe.
('41', 338, 1, 7, 642243) Hence the Rama whom one wishes to remember, and whom one should remember, is the Rama of one’s own imagination, not the Rama of someone else’s imagination.
('41', 338, 1, 8, 642399) If we keep this in mind, many doubts that trouble us would not arise at all.
('41', 338, 1, 9, 642476) Many times we wonder how the Rama who slew Vali could be called the Perfect One.
('41', 338, 1, 10, 642557) I too come across many such questions, and I am amused.
('41', 338, 1, 11, 642613) What great achievement is there in having slain someone, by fair means or foul, or to have destroyed the ten headed Ravana, if ever there was one such.
('41', 338, 1, 12, 642765) In this modern age, even if a Ravana is born, not with twenty but countless hands, a child standing behind a cannon can, by firing a single ball, send all his arms and heads flying.
('41', 338, 1, 13, 642947) We would not regard such a child superhuman; we would look upon him as a big mons ter.
('41', 338, 1, 14, 643034) I believe that we do not wish to acquire the strength of a super mons ter.
('41', 338, 1, 15, 643109) We would not attain peace by worshipping him.
('41', 338, 1, 16, 643155) We should worship Him, the Inner Ruler, who dwells in the hearts of all, yet transcends all and is the Lord of all.
('41', 338, 1, 17, 643271) It is He of whom we sing: Nirbalke bal Rama 1. The song also mentions Draupadi’s despair.
('41', 338, 1, 18, 643361) Now, what had Draupadi to do with an embodied Rama?
('41', 338, 1, 19, 643413) Yet, the poet has sung that Rama saved Draupadi’s honour.
('41', 338, 1, 20, 643471) The Rama mentioned here is the One who is common to all and yet comprehended by none.
('41', 338, 1, 21, 643557) It is this Rama whom we remember.
('41', 338, 1, 22, 643591) Between this Rama, the Inner Ruler, and Krishna there is no difference.
('41', 338, 1, 23, 643663) We celebrate the festival of Rama’s birth so that we may practise some self restraint, and the children may enjoy innocent pleasures and learn some lesson by reading the Ramayana.
('41', 338, 1, 24, 643843) Man, who is himself embodied, cannot easily conceive God in any other form.
('41', 338, 1, 25, 643919) His imagination cannot go farther.
('41', 338, 1, 26, 643954) Therefore he conceives God as being incarnated in human form.
('41', 338, 1, 27, 644016) Hinduism has boundless tolerance.
('41', 338, 1, 28, 644050) Hence God has been described as descending in the forms of a fish, a boar and a man lion.
('41', 338, 1, 29, 644140) In this way having super imposed a form on God, men conceived Him as having a body and then imagined Him as taking birth.
('41', 338, 1, 30, 644262) And when we speak of His
('41', 338, 2, 31, 644287) 1 Rama, strength of the weak’, the opening words of a popular song
('41', 339, 0, 1, 644354) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 339, 1, 2, 644396) avatars to protect dharma whenever dharma declines and adharma flou rishes, it is true only in the manner and to the extent which I have just described; how else could we say that the birthless One took birth?
('41', 339, 1, 3, 644606) There is no reason to believe that any historical figure was the incarnation of God or God as a historical figure was born in human or any other form.
('41', 339, 1, 4, 644757) If a person is endowed with all the qualities of God, he may be called an incarnation of God.
('41', 339, 1, 5, 644851) It was because of their divine qualities that all those great men of the past were regarded by people as either plenary or partial incarnations.
('41', 339, 1, 6, 644996) And yet, knowing this, different devotees have described the same God in the Rama of Valmiki or Tulsidas and there is no harm in singing those bhajans.
('41', 339, 1, 7, 645148) If we bear in mind what I said earlier, we would not be deluded.
('41', 339, 1, 8, 645213) If someone wishes to confuse us confronting us with conundrums, we should tell him that we do not worship embodied Rama as conceived by anyone; we worship our own Rama who is flawless and formless.
('41', 339, 1, 9, 645411) As we cannot reach Him direct, we sing bhajans that describe Him as personified, and then try to apprehend Him in His purity.
('41', 339, 1, 10, 645537) So long as we are unable to see through the wall of the body, the qualities of truth and non violence will not become fully manifest in us.
('41', 339, 1, 11, 645677) When we think of pursuing truth, we must stop mistaking the body for ourselves, for we shall have to die in the pursuit of truth.
('41', 339, 1, 12, 645807) The same is true of non violence.
('41', 339, 1, 13, 645841) The body is the root of ego.
('41', 339, 1, 14, 645870) One who has attachment to the body cannot free himself of the ego.
('41', 339, 1, 15, 645937) I cannot become wholly free of violence so long as I have the feeling that this body is mine.
('41', 339, 1, 16, 646031) One who desires to have vision of God will have to transcend the body, to despise it, to court death.
('41', 339, 1, 17, 646133) It is only when we master these two qualities that we can be saved, that we can practise brahmacharya and so on.
('41', 339, 1, 18, 646246) How can we do without truth if we wish to practise such vows?
('41', 339, 1, 19, 646308) The face of truth is hidden by a golden lid.
('41', 339, 1, 20, 646353) 1 Why should we fear to speak the truth or to act truthfully?
('41', 339, 1, 21, 646415) How can we catch a glimpse of truth so long as we do not remove the glittering lid of untruth?
('41', 339, 1, 22, 646510) If anyone commits an offence, are we willing to love him instead of getting angry with him?
('41', 339, 1, 23, 646602) Although we sing that this world is insubstantial, do we know at all what the word implies?
('41', 339, 1, 24, 646694) “If you wish to know me,” says Rama, “you must flee the world.” But the body cannot be wished away.
('41', 339, 1, 25, 646794) Having trained ourselves to look upon the world as unreal, we may go about our
('41', 339, 2, 26, 646873) 1 Ishopanishad, v.
('41', 340, 0, 1, 646892) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 341
('41', 340, 1, 2, 646934) business as a matter of duty all the time and still find Rama.
('41', 340, 1, 3, 646997) That is the teaching of the Gita.
('41', 340, 1, 4, 647031) This is why I regard the Gita as a spiritual dictionary.
('41', 340, 1, 5, 647088) Tulsidas teaches us the same truth through beautiful poetry.
('41', 340, 1, 6, 647149) The key, however, is the one that I have given, namely, that the Rama in our hearts is the Ferryman who will take us across.

('41', 340, 3, 11, 647480) March 31, 1928
('41', 340, 4, 12, 647495) Mahatmaji, addressing the students, expressed satisfaction that his suggestions had been carried out.
('41', 340, 4, 13, 647597) He however regretted that the boys were not as clean as they ought to be.
('41', 340, 4, 14, 647671) Putting on khaddar, he said, indicated that they were clean both bodily and in their hearts.
('41', 340, 5, 15, 647764) The mill owners, Gandhiji continued, were not extending their helping hand by becoming liberal in donating money.
('41', 340, 5, 16, 647878) He was conferring with the mill owners and requesting them to pay all the money subscribed by them to the Tilak Swaraj Fund for the benefit of the children unconditionally without interfering in any way in the administration of the schools, which must be solely left to the Labour Union.
('41', 340, 5, 17, 648166) Even if they did not give any money these schools would go on.
('41', 340, 6, 18, 648229) God is great and if you have faith in Him you would get money from any source, provided you have true ideals.
('41', 340, 7, 19, 648339) To teachers, Gandhiji said that they must not make any use of books for imparting education, as books spoiled eyes and blunted the intellect.
('41', 340, 7, 20, 648481) He himself had experienced that.
('41', 340, 7, 21, 648514) He understood that in Russia they were conducting one thousand schools for peasants and that they were giving education without the aid of books by making all possible use of the senses.
('41', 340, 7, 22, 648701) He asked them to clean their own houses and streets themselves and not to depend on others for doing the same.
('41', 340, 8, 23, 648812) Concluding, Mahatmaji asked them to make their schools ideal in every way, so that the boys and girls of the mill owners might envy them and the mill owners might be tempted to send their children to the labour schools.
('41', 340, 8, 24, 649032) On truth depended the foundation of education, and they must always resort to truth.

('41', 341, 6, 12, 649858) 393. LETTER TO SHANTIKUMAR MORARJI
('41', 341, 7, 13, 649893) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, March 31, 1928
('41', 341, 8, 14, 649931) MY DEAR SHANTIKUMAR, I have your letter.
('41', 341, 8, 15, 649972) The terms that I think the mill owners should agree to are as follows : (1) The prices should be regulated by a special committee representing all interests.
('41', 341, 8, 16, 650130) (2) The production both as to kind and quantity should also be regulated by the said committee.
('41', 341, 8, 17, 650226) (3) Mills should cease to sell any mill cloth under the name of khadi and should cease within three months at the outside of the date of acceptance of terms to manufacture any cloth that is likely to compete with khadi and to this end the committee will specify from time to time what the mills may not manufacture.
('41', 341, 8, 18, 650542) (4) Mills will organize not only the sales of mill cloth but they
('41', 342, 0, 1, 650608) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 343
('41', 342, 1, 2, 650650) will sell khadi also through the agencies thus organized.
('41', 342, 1, 3, 650708) (5) Mills should use no foreign yarn, no foreign silk, no foreign wool nor artificial silk.
('41', 342, 1, 4, 650800) (6) Mills should whole heartedly identify themselves with the boycott of foreign cloth movement and to this end should put forth all their energy towards gaining control over piece goods merchants, other middle men and cotton market in so far as it may be possible.
('41', 342, 1, 5, 651066) (7) If a clear understanding is arrived at with mills, khadi depots will naturally become agencies for the sale of mill cloth under terms laid down by the said committee.
('41', 342, 1, 6, 651237) (8) Mills should hand to the said committee such funds as may be required from time to time for propaganda.
('41', 342, 1, 7, 651345) This, in my opinion, may not exceed one lakh of rupees.
('41', 342, 1, 8, 651401) This letter is being hurriedly dictated.
('41', 342, 1, 9, 651442) You mill therefore please supplement these conditions with those stated in the two issues of Young India 1 if there is any omission.
('41', 342, 1, 10, 651575) You will not publish this letter in any case, and, you will please remember that these are only my own personal views, and if anything substantial is to come out of these talks, [th]ere will have to be a formal meeti[ng of a]ll concerned.

('41', 343, 6, 10, 652511) 395. SATYAGRAHIS, BEWARE!
('41', 343, 7, 11, 652537) When member of the Hunter Committee asked General Dyer the leading question with reference to the Jallianwala Bagh: “Was it your idea to instil fear of the Government in the minds of the people by acting ruthlessly?” the latter, enthusiastically accepted the suggestion and replied in the affirmative.
('41', 343, 7, 12, 652839) However, the reign of terror had not begun with General Dyer.
('41', 343, 7, 13, 652901) It is the legacy of tradition and the monopoly of Indian bureaucracy.
('41', 343, 7, 14, 652971) It can, however, be said that General Dyer gained notoriety for this repression.
('41', 343, 7, 15, 653052) Hence we know it also as Dyerism.
('41', 343, 7, 16, 653086) As bureaucracy is dependent for its very existence on a policy of Dyerism, it does not hesitate to seek shelter under the latter when occasion arises.
('41', 343, 7, 17, 653237) According to it such an occasion has arisen in Bardoli.
('41', 343, 7, 18, 653293) Hence it may be said to have launched repression on the bania satyagrahis who are regarded as cowardly and submissive.
('41', 343, 7, 19, 653412) Eight of these satyagrahis have been served with notices that if they do not pay up their land revenue stipulated therein before the 12th of April, their lands will be confiscated.
('41', 343, 7, 20, 653593) The notice served on one bania gentleman shows the amount of revenue due as Rs. 160. Perhaps we could not have found fault with the Government if it had confiscated land worth Rs. 160, but to confiscate land worth thousands of rupees for the sake of Rs. 160 is nothing but repression.
('41', 343, 7, 21, 653878) Under this policy,
('41', 344, 0, 1, 653897) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 345
('41', 344, 1, 2, 653939) on certain occasions, the punishment for a slap is not ano ther slap but the gallows.
('41', 344, 1, 3, 654025) We shall call anyone who extorts a thousand rupees for a debt of one rupee a tyrant, a ten headed Ravana.
('41', 344, 1, 4, 654131) What reply will the banias, who are said to have forethought, give to this?
('41', 344, 1, 5, 654207) Will they betray cowardice or prove themselves worthy of having joined the army of satyagrahis?
('41', 344, 1, 6, 654303) Vallabhbhai has warned not once but repeatedly that the Government has by legislation acquired the right to confiscate land, to imprison people, etc., and that it has time and again given proof of the fact that it will not hesitate in the least to exercise those rights.
('41', 344, 1, 7, 654574) Hence neither they nor others should be flabbergasted by this notice of confiscation.
('41', 344, 1, 8, 654660) They should have faith that the Government will not be able to derive any benefit from the land which would be confiscated in this manner and that it would not go to a traitor who would come forward to purchase it if it is auctioned.
('41', 344, 1, 9, 654894) Land which has been filched in this manner is like unprocessed mercury which is bound to erupt as boils.
('41', 344, 1, 10, 654999) Land is not more precious than one’s pledge or one’s self respect.
('41', 344, 1, 11, 655066) There are myriads of landless people in this country.
('41', 344, 1, 12, 655120) During the last floods, many people’s lands were eroded and layers of sand have now been deposited over them.
('41', 344, 1, 13, 655230) Just as Gujaratis withstood the wrath of the heavens with courage and fortitude, may the satyagrahis of Bardoli similarly put up with this wrath of the Government and may they stand by their pledge!
('41', 344, 1, 14, 655429) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 4 1928
('41', 344, 2, 15, 655465) 396. THE NATIONAL WEEK
('41', 344, 3, 16, 655488) The forthcoming National Week is the ninth of its kind.
('41', 344, 3, 17, 655544) In this Week, we should take stock of the progress made by us.
('41', 344, 3, 18, 655607) However, instead of that we find despondency in many places.
('41', 344, 3, 19, 655668) For us this Week is the time for calculating the national sum total of achievement, for introspection and for self purification, for uniting the hearts of Hindus, Muslims, Parsis and other, for Hindus to welcome in their midst those men and women who have been regarded as untouchables and to serve them, and for Hindus, Muslims and others to take exclusively to khadi and boycott foreign cloth.
('41', 344, 3, 20, 656064) However, today we seem to have forgotten these limbs which
('41', 345, 0, 1, 656123) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 345, 1, 2, 656165) sustain the nation.
('41', 345, 1, 3, 656185) Those who have aith in any of these causes are making efforts to promote them.
('41', 345, 1, 4, 656264) But now all this is not beinng done on an extensive scale.
('41', 345, 1, 5, 656323) Today we do not hear people say, as they used to do in the past, that swaraj cannot be secured without these.
('41', 345, 1, 6, 656433) An attempt should be made during the National Week to bring about a change in this state of affairs.
('41', 345, 1, 7, 656534) Those who have an unswerving faith in constructive activity should make great efforts in this direction, irrespective of whether some or all national institutions make such an effort; it is only from such efforts that an allembracing activity will and must start again.
('41', 345, 1, 8, 656804) None should entertain any doubts that khadi is the one visible activity that can be taken up by children, men, women, Hindus, Muslims and all others.
('41', 345, 1, 9, 656954) The talk of boy cott is everywhere in the air.
('41', 345, 1, 10, 657001) However, there seems to be some confu sion regarding boycott at the moment.
('41', 345, 1, 11, 657077) Some persons advocate the boy cott of British goods, others of British cloth alone and that too until such time as a peaceful solution is arrived at, while yet others advocate the permanent boycott of foreign cloth.
('41', 345, 1, 12, 657293) All these things cannot go on at the same time.
('41', 345, 1, 13, 657341) After the first two intentions had been proclaimed for twenty years, the people found on deeper reflection in 1920 that the only way of boycotting foreign cloth which was possible as well as obligatory was to replace it by khadi.
('41', 345, 1, 14, 657571) Moreover, this idea of boycotting foreign cloth does not depend on any conditions but holds good for all time.
('41', 345, 1, 15, 657682) And that which is everlasting is beneficial even in small measure whereas that which is dependent on conditions is beneficial only if it materializes in an appropriate measure.
('41', 345, 1, 16, 657859) If the latter brings bout only partial results, it may even prove harmful.
('41', 345, 1, 17, 657934) Hence we ought to free ourselves from this delusion and make constant efforts to carry on propaganda for khadi for the sake of boycotting foreign cloth or, in other words, for the sake of the poor of India.
('41', 345, 1, 18, 658141) In order to do that : 1. those who do not already wear khadi should do so and advise others to do likewise; 2. all should spin as much as possible and inspire others to do likewise; 3. all should contribute as much as possible for this cause and collect funds from neighbours.
('41', 345, 1, 19, 658418) In this connection, what Shri Vithaldas Jerajani writes is worth
('41', 346, 0, 1, 658483) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 347
('41', 346, 1, 2, 658525) nothing : 1
('41', 346, 2, 3, 658537) The figures given here are worth pondering over.
('41', 346, 2, 4, 658586) Bombay is the barometer for gauging the feelings of politically conscious India.
('41', 346, 2, 5, 658667) It is not too great a venture for Bombay to reach the figures of the first year.
('41', 346, 2, 6, 658748) That is like a drop in the ocean in the matter of making the boycott a success.
('41', 346, 2, 7, 658828) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 1 4 1928

('41', 355, 3, 5, 671954) 413. PRAYER SPEECH AT ASHRAM [April 4, 1928] 1
('41', 355, 4, 6, 672001) The first lesson in emulating Hanuman is to apply all one’s senses to the task in hand.
('41', 355, 4, 7, 672089) In order to do this, one’s vision must remain unwavering and pure.
('41', 355, 4, 8, 672156) The eyes are the lamp of the body and, one may add, of the soul also.
('41', 355, 4, 9, 672226) For inasmuch as the soul dwells in the body, it can be looked at through the eyes.
('41', 355, 4, 10, 672309) A man might through his speech present a false show and deceive others, but his eyes would reveal him.
('41', 355, 4, 11, 672412) If he does not have a steady unwavering look in his eyes, his real nature will be betrayed.
('41', 355, 4, 12, 672504) Just as physical ailments are diagnosed by examining the tongue, spiritual maladies may be detected by looking at the eyes.
('41', 355, 4, 13, 672628) Hence children should be taught to look straight, right from their childhood.
('41', 355, 4, 14, 672706) Hanuman’s eyes had a steadfast gaze and showed that, just as Rama’s name was ever on his lips, it filled his heart and pervaded every fibre of his being.
('41', 355, 4, 15, 672860) I like the custom of installing Hanuman in our gymnasiums; this however does not mean that we wish to gain physical strength alone or that we worship merely Hanuman’s physical strength.
('41', 355, 4, 16, 673046) We should certainly become physically strong; but we should also know that Hanuman did not have the physique of a giant, he was the son of Vayu 2, hence his body was as light as a flower and yet wiry.
('41', 355, 4, 17, 673247) However, Hanuman’s distinctiveness lay not in his physical strength but in his devotion.
('41', 355, 4, 18, 673336) He was an incomparable devotee and servant of Rama.
('41', 355, 4, 19, 673388) He found fulfilment in serving Rama like a slave and he performed with the speed of wind whatever service was asked of him.
('41', 355, 4, 20, 673512) We therefore worship Hanuman and instal him in gymnasiums because though we
('41', 355, 5, 21, 673588) 1 According to Prajabandhu the speech was made on April 4 in connection with Hanuman Jayanti.
('41', 355, 5, 22, 673682) 2 Wind god

('41', 356, 1, 2, 673735) do physical exercise we are going to become servants—servants of India, servants of the world and, through these means, servants of God.
('41', 356, 1, 3, 673872) It is through this humble service that we shall catch a glimpse of God.
('41', 356, 1, 4, 673944) Hence we should not even say that we worship Hanuman only for his brahmacharya.
('41', 356, 1, 5, 674024) Every servant has to practise brahmacharya; how can anyone who has taken the vow of service enjoy the pleasures of sense?
('41', 356, 1, 6, 674146) It is necessary for one to practise self control even to render the limited service to one’s parents; it cannot be rendered if anyone yields to his passions as I did.
('41', 356, 1, 7, 674313) Similarly, how can anyone who would serve the Ashram, serve men and women, boys and girls, how can he afford to gratify his sensual desires?
('41', 356, 1, 8, 674454) And serving the Ashram is such a small matter; it is like a drop in the ocean.
('41', 356, 1, 9, 674533) Hence anyone who would serve the world should flee his desires.
('41', 356, 1, 10, 674597) However, mere fasting and penance are not sufficient to keep away from pleasures of sense; this can be achieved through a Hanuman like devotion.
('41', 356, 1, 11, 674742) Hence the key to brahmacharya and all other virtues is found in single minded devotion.
('41', 356, 1, 12, 674830) Every evening we recite :
('41', 356, 3, 13, 674856) The senses of him who fasts may well be quietened,but this does not help in controlling the desire for gratifying the passions; the mind very often becomes more restless when the senses become weak; then the mind runs more after the objects of pleasure; that too is calmed by the vision of Rama.
('41', 356, 3, 14, 675152) This is the message of Hanuman, the lesson to be learnt from his life.
('41', 356, 3, 15, 675223) Yesterday I used an adjective which I had never used previously to qualify brahmacharya.
('41', 356, 3, 16, 675312) I said that Hanuman’s brahmacharya was sattvik, and, while praising brahmacharya, I mentioned three distinct types of it—sattvik, rajasik and tamasik.
('41', 356, 3, 17, 675463) Whereas Hanuman’s brahmacharya was of a sattvik nature, Meghnad’s was rajasik.
('41', 356, 3, 18, 675542) One who practises the latter type of brahmacharya has anger and pride.
('41', 356, 3, 19, 675613) Total surrender is the mark of the sattvik type.
('41', 356, 3, 20, 675662) It cannot be said that either of these two was inferior to the other in physical strength.
('41', 356, 3, 21, 675753) Hanuman however could defeat Meghnad becaue the latter was full of pride, while Hanuman was full of devotion and so possessed additional
('41', 356, 4, 22, 675890) 1 When a man starves his senses, the objects of those senses disappear from him, but not the yearning for them; the yearning too departs when he beholds the Supreme.

('41', 357, 1, 4, 676289) We certainly wish to improve our physique by practising brahmacharya, but the under lying motive is that we wish to become devotees of Rama even through the means of our body and thereby serve the world.

('41', 357, 5, 14, 677455) The Government tempts our young men by locating liquor shops in or near our cheries, the living quarters of our community.
('41', 357, 5, 15, 677578) If industrial institutions took the place of such shops and if social workers befriended us instead of abkari contractors, we have no doubt that our progress would be assured in a very short time.
('41', 357, 5, 16, 677775) We, therefore, earnestly appeal to you for help to organize industrial schools in or near our living quarters to save our community from ruin.
('41', 357, 5, 17, 677918) We need not consider during the National Week what the Government has done or not done, but we are bound to consider what we have done and what we can do.
('41', 357, 5, 18, 678073) Whilst there is no doubt that public opinion against untouchability has been strengthening day by day, public action still remains weak.
('41', 357, 5, 19, 678210) We have not even been able to induce the keepers of public temples to throw their doors open to the

('41', 359, 3, 6, 680995) 416. ANNUAL REPORT OF THE A.I.S.A.
('41', 359, 4, 7, 681030) The All India Spinners’ Association has issued its second annual report.
('41', 359, 4, 8, 681103) It is a thoroughly businesslike and instructive document.
('41', 359, 4, 9, 681161) The letterpress occupies 31 octavo pages.
('41', 359, 4, 10, 681203) The appendices occupy 24 pages.
('41', 359, 4, 11, 681235) If I may advise the reader, I would suggest his reading the appendices first.
('41', 359, 4, 12, 681313) They will give him a detailed analysis of the income and the expenditure of the Association duly audited and certified.
('41', 359, 4, 13, 681433) He will discover at a glance how over 20 lakhs of rupees have been laid out for the promotion of the greatest, because the most extensive, national industry.
('41', 359, 4, 14, 681591) If he will study the figures carefully, he will perceive the value of investing a portion of his income in this industry, and the return he would get for his investment would be the prosperity of the poor villagers on whose toil his own income depends.
('41', 359, 4, 15, 681844) Among the appendices he will find also the resolutions of the All India Spinners’ Association defining its general policy, conditions on which loans are granted, conditions on which credit sales may be conducted by its depots and on which bounties are given to private khadi dealers and commissions to khadi hawkers.
('41', 359, 4, 16, 682161) He will also find in them the constitution of the All India Spinners’ Association, the names and locations of different agencies and other information of value.
('41', 359, 4, 17, 682322) Having glanced through the appendices, let him go through the report if he has a half hour or an hour to spare and he will know the way khadi has progressed.
('41', 359, 4, 18, 682480) He will know the condition of the All India Deshbandu Memorial Fund.
('41', 359, 4, 19, 682549) Whereas the total production during 1925 26 was Rs. 23,76,670, in 1926 27 it was Rs. 24,06,370 and the sales during the same period were Rs. 28,99,143 and Rs. 33,48,794, respectively.
('41', 359, 4, 20, 682733) Investors in khadi may therefore derive comfort that khadi is not a losing but a substantially progressive proposition.
('41', 359, 4, 21, 682853) As against 50,000 spinners according to the previous report, there were 83,339 serving 5,193 weavers during the year under report.
('41', 359, 4, 22, 682984) As against
('41', 360, 0, 1, 682995) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 361
('41', 360, 1, 2, 683037) 1,500 villages, now there are 2,381 villages where hand spinning is done through the agency of the Association.
('41', 360, 1, 3, 683149) And just as the figures about spinners and villages were understated in the last report, so are they under estimated in the report under notice.
('41', 360, 1, 4, 683294) There are 177 khadi production centres of which 62 are departmental, 41 aided and 74 independent.
('41', 360, 1, 5, 683392) There are 204 centres of which 115 are departmental, 44 aided and 45 independent, and the total number of workers under the direct control of the Central Office and in aided organizations is 748. This does not include those working in the independent organiz ations.
('41', 360, 1, 6, 683659) Of improvement in the quality of yarn the report states : 1
('41', 360, 2, 7, 683719) It is satisfactory to note that whilst there is improvement in the quality, the prices have undergone steady reduction.

('41', 360, 3, 9, 683966) I must skip over the other instructive paragraphs of the report.

SASTRI’S SELF DENIAL The decision of the Right Honourable Srinivasa Sastri to remain in South Africa beyond his term will gladden the hearts of the Indian settlers as it has pleased and eased the minds of those here who are interested in the South African question and who have been anxiously following the course of events in that sub continent.
('41', 361, 1, 3, 684742) Familiarity in Sjt.
('41', 361, 1, 4, 684762) Sastri’s case instead of making the Europeans indifferent or lukewarm has made them look to the Agent General as their friend and peacemaker.
('41', 361, 1, 5, 684904) By his punctilious impartiality combined with firmness wherever necessary Sjt.
('41', 361, 1, 6, 684983) Sastri has inspired them with trust as well as respect.
('41', 361, 1, 7, 685039) The grateful Indians have not been slow to discover and appreciate the worth of this distinguished countryman and they were urging him to prolong his stay, if it was at all possible.
('41', 361, 1, 8, 685222) Let them now demonstrate their affection and appreciation by becoming united and by being correct in the observance of all their part of the agreement.
('41', 361, 1, 9, 685374) I tender my congratulations to Sjt.
('41', 361, 1, 10, 685410) Sastri on his self denial.
('41', 361, 1, 11, 685437) For I know how anxious he was to return home at the end of his term.

('41', 361, 2, 13, 685528) 418. A MILL OWNER ON BOYCOTT
('41', 361, 3, 14, 685557) An Ahmedabad mill owner writes: 1
('41', 361, 4, 15, 685591) The letter is refreshingly candid.
('41', 361, 4, 16, 685626) I wish that the other mill owners would take the view that this correspondent takes of the possibility of standardization of prices and necessarily therefore of cloth.
('41', 361, 4, 17, 685794) It is refreshing too to find that fluctuations of cotton prices do not much affect prices of cloth.
('41', 361, 4, 18, 685894) And I would add in spite of the correspondent’s view to the contrary that it is possible to control cotton prices if it is possible for us to boycott foreign cloth.
('41', 361, 4, 19, 686059) For prices of our cotton are dominated by America only because we export large quantities of cotton and that too to the market for which America also caters.
('41', 361, 4, 20, 686217) If we consider it to be possible, as it has proved to be possible, to appeal successfully to the patriotism of the buyer of cloth it is equally possible to make a successful appeal to that of the grower of cotton.
('41', 361, 4, 21, 686431) Indeed the importance of foreign cloth boycott is derived from the knowledge that for it to succeed all the component parts of the nation have voluntarily to join the movement.
('41', 361, 4, 22, 686608) It cannot succeed
('41', 361, 5, 23, 686626) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('41', 362, 0, 1, 686663) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 363
('41', 362, 1, 2, 686705) unless there is willing and hearty co operation from the vast mass of the village population.
('41', 362, 1, 3, 686799) My faith in the movement persists because I know the masses to be sound.
('41', 362, 1, 4, 686872) Only the classes block the way because of their want of faith.
('41', 362, 1, 5, 686935) If they will only shed their fear and their unbelief and lead the movement, the masses will follow.
('41', 362, 1, 6, 687035) And this boycott is the only thing in which it is possible for the masses actively to join without having to make much sacrifice.
('41', 362, 1, 7, 687165) I do not share the view of the correspondent that artificail silk may be used with impunity in the manufacture of cloth in our mills.
('41', 362, 1, 8, 687299) His com parison of foreign dyes and foreign size with artificial silk is hastily made.
('41', 362, 1, 9, 687386) Just now we contemplate boycott only of foreign cloth, not of dyes and size.
('41', 362, 1, 10, 687463) All foreign yarns therefore, whether silk, wool or cotton, nautral or artificial, must be taboo; or if foreign artificial silk yarn may be used with impunity why not foreign cotton or wool or natural silk yarn?
('41', 362, 1, 11, 687674) But with foreign cotton it is a different thing.
('41', 362, 1, 12, 687723) We need not exclude from use foreign cotton, for it is a raw product.
('41', 362, 1, 13, 687793) What we must boycott for the sake of the starving masses living in enforced idleness for at least four months in the year is foreign yarn and cloth which the masses can spin and weave in their cottages.
('41', 362, 1, 14, 687996) The indigenous mill cloth too would be intolerable if it displaced these mases without finding for them an equivalent industry.
('41', 362, 1, 15, 688124) The mills have a place in the economy of national life only to the extent that they supplement the national industry of handspinning in millions of our cottages.
('41', 362, 1, 16, 688286) They will be a hindrance if they compete with them and supplant them.
('41', 362, 1, 17, 688356) Their natural tendency no doubt is to supplant both the village spinner and the village weaver.
('41', 362, 1, 18, 688452) It is only when the mill owners, mill agents and their share holders become truly national and conduct their affairs not to exploit the masses but for their benefit first and their own profits after, that they will be able to appreciate and not merely to join but of lead the boycott movement.
('41', 362, 1, 19, 688746) That, if they take a long view of the matter, they have nothing to lose and much to gain has been made clear by the foregoing letter.
('41', 362, 1, 20, 688880) Indeed it is a self evident proposition.
('41', 362, 1, 21, 688921) Boycott of foreign cloth, if it is the best assurance of steady work for the masses, is also an equal assurance to the mills of steady profits in the long run.
('41', 362, 1, 22, 689081) But the history of the mill industry at least during the past seven years of the mass movement does not fill one with much hope of the
('41', 363, 0, 1, 689216) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 363, 1, 2, 689258) mills rising to the occasion and realizing their duty to the nation.
('41', 363, 1, 3, 689327) Instead of looking upon khadi with favour and fostering it, our mills have entered into an unfair, unpartriotic and illegitimate competition with khadi.
('41', 363, 1, 4, 689480) The following are the figures of khadi manufactured by our mills during the respective years : 1925 1926 1927 Lb.
('41', 363, 1, 5, 689594) 2,28,87,970 2,72,36,337 3,39,77,851 Yards 6,50,48,487 7,43,13,280 9,43,80,368 They have sold this enormous quantity of coarse cloth as khadi and have not hesitated in some cases shamelessly to use the charkha label, etc., with the deliberate purpose of exploiting the khadi atmos phere created by Congreass organizations.
('41', 363, 1, 6, 689916) It gives one pain to have to say that the mills that thus manufactured coarse cloth and palmed it off as khadi did a distinct disservice to the nation.
('41', 363, 1, 7, 690068) If their eyes are now opened and if only to do belated reparation for the grave wrong done by them to the nation, they will head or at least join the boycott movement on the terms suggested by me or others equally effective.
('41', 363, 1, 8, 690293) This painful discovery of the figures has however a bright side to it.
('41', 363, 1, 9, 690364) It is a revelation even to an optimist and khadi expert like The Ashramme of the hold that khadi has acquired over the people.
('41', 363, 1, 10, 690491) It shows that a much larger number that we are aware of has in obedience to the nation’s call changed their taste and preferred to buy and use coarse cloth instead of the fine cloth they used to wear before.
('41', 363, 1, 11, 690699) They have undoubtedly often paid higher prices than they used to.
('41', 363, 1, 12, 690765) They have bought mill khadi largely under the mistaken belief that it was genuine and that it had the imprimatur of the Congress.
('41', 363, 1, 13, 690895) An ardent lover of the mases has in these figures and my legitimate deductions therefrom much food for thought and equal cause for hope.
('41', 363, 1, 14, 691032) As for my feared visit to Europe, I may assure the correspondent that I do not propose to visit Europe if an effective scheme of boycott materializes in the very near future.
('41', 363, 2, 15, 691207) Young India, 5 4 1928
('41', 364, 0, 1, 691229) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 365
('41', 364, 1, 2, 691271) 419. NOTES
('41', 364, 2, 3, 691282) AFRICANS AND INDIANS Deenabandhu Andrews, when he was here recently, drew my attention to what the Poet had written in the Press in connection with a movement in the Transvaal said to be going on on behalf of Indians to isolate themselves from the Africans and wanted me to give my opinion on it.
('41', 364, 2, 4, 691579) I do not think that any importance need be attached to the alleged movement.
('41', 364, 2, 5, 691656) For I feel that it has no bottom.
('41', 364, 2, 6, 691690) Indians have too much in common with the Africans to think of isolating themselves from them.
('41', 364, 2, 7, 691784) They cannot exist in South Africa for any length of time without the active sympathy and friendship of the Africans.
('41', 364, 2, 8, 691901) I am not aware of the general body of the Indians having ever adopted an air of superiority towards their African brethren, and it would be a tragedy if any such movement were to gain ground among the Indian settlers of South Africa.
('41', 364, 2, 9, 692135) Needless to say, I entirely associate myself with the opinion so forcibly expressed by the Poet condemning the movement.
('41', 364, 2, 10, 692256) If, as has been stated on behalf of the leaders of the socalled movement, “It is humiliating to the Indian sentiment and to the Indian national honour and civilization to think that our Agent General is trying to bring us down to such a low level”, it will ill befit us to repudiate such a sentiment when it is expressed by the South African whites in respect ouselves.
('41', 364, 2, 11, 692626) And what is more, the South African whites are able to translate their contempt The Ashramand prejudice against us into action whereas ours towards the South Africans can only react against ourselves.
('41', 364, 3, 12, 692827) WOMEN AND JEWELS A lady doctor in Tamil Nadu sends a letter accompanying her gift referred to in it.
('41', 364, 3, 13, 692928) As the letter, in my opinion, enhances the value of the gift and is likely to serve as an example to others, I compress its contents as follows, omitting the names of the donor, the Raja and the place :
('41', 364, 4, 14, 693131) Just a few lines to tell you that I sent you yesterday a parcel of diamond ring and a pair of ear rings which were given to me about 12 years ago in remembrance of service in the palace.
('41', 364, 4, 15, 693318) when the heir was born to the Raja.
('41', 364, 4, 16, 693354) It grieved me much when I came to know that the Raja did not have even the courage to invite you to his palace when you passed by and I was told that it was due to fear of the Government.
('41', 364, 4, 17, 693542) You can imagine my feeling when after your visit I looked at these jewels which before used to travel with me.
('41', 365, 0, 1, 693653) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 365, 1, 2, 693695) when I looked at them, bitterness rose in my breast and then it turned into deep sympathy for the starving millions about whom you spoke when you were here.
('41', 365, 1, 3, 693852) I said to myself, ‘Are not these jewels made out of the people’s money?
('41', 365, 1, 4, 693924) And, what claim have I to keep them as my own?’ I then made up my mind to send them on to you.
('41', 365, 1, 5, 694019) You could use them for khadi service and so help some of the starving millions.
('41', 365, 1, 6, 694099) I feel sure that it is a better use to make of them than that they should remain in a corner of my box.
('41', 365, 1, 7, 694203) A friend has valued them at Rs. 500. They are therefore insured for that amount.
('41', 365, 1, 8, 694284) I only hope that some generous person will give you more than the actual price, knowing the circumstancs in which these things are being sent to you.
('41', 365, 1, 9, 694434) You may make what use you like of this letter.
('41', 365, 1, 10, 694481) It is remarkable how we imagine fears even when there is no cause.
('41', 365, 1, 11, 694548) There are many Rajas who have openly and willingly supported khadi and therethrough the cause of the poor from whom, after all, as my correspondent correctly puts it, they derive their riches.
('41', 365, 1, 12, 694741) It is true that khadi has a political significance; but we have not yet come to the stage when support of khadi can be safely declared by the Government to be criminal.
('41', 365, 1, 13, 694910) Every philanthropic movement can be truned to political use, but it would be a sad day when on that account it is boycotted even as to its philanthropic aspect.
('41', 365, 1, 14, 695071) But it is only fair to state that the Raja to whom reference has been made by the lady doctor is not the only one who is afraid of supporting khadi or showing ordinary courtesy to a public servant like me.
('41', 365, 1, 15, 695277) It is well The Ashramhowever that the Raja’s boycott of me has stimulated the gift.
('41', 365, 1, 16, 695361) But I would like all the sisters who may chance to see this note to realize that it is not necessary to be able to emulate the fair donor to have occasions like the one that set her athinking about her duty to the starving millions.
('41', 365, 1, 17, 695594) Surely it is easy enough to realize that so long as there are millions of men and women in the country starving for want of food because of want of work, the sisters have no warrant for possessing costly jewels for adorning their bodies or often for the mere satisfaction of possessing them.
('41', 365, 1, 18, 695886) As I have remarked before now in these pages, if only the rich ladies of India will discard their superfluities and be satisfied with such decoration as khadi can give them it is possible to finance the whole of the khadi movement, not to take into consideration the tremendous moral effect that such a step on the part of the rich daughters of India will produce upon the nation and particularly the starving masses.
('41', 366, 0, 1, 696304) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 367
('41', 366, 1, 2, 696346) KARVE JUBILEE
('41', 366, 2, 3, 696360) It give me joy to publish the following appeal by Sjt.
('41', 366, 2, 4, 696415) V. M. Joshi, President of Karve Jubilee Committee : 1
('41', 366, 3, 5, 696469) Professor Karve is not an ordinary man who is satisfied if he satisfies an indulgent public which, if it proves itself exacting and imperious at times, issues a certificate of merit ninety nine times out of hundred if some little service is rendered to it during recreation hours.
('41', 366, 3, 6, 696750) Karve has obeyed a master that is never generous, never indulgent and ever exacting, though invariably just.
('41', 366, 3, 7, 696859) This master is his own conscience.
('41', 366, 3, 8, 696894) His self effacement, his single minded devotion to duty, his exhaustless energy, his honesty in all circumstances, his faith in the midst of opposition, his irrepressible optimism are a national asset of the first magnitude.
('41', 366, 3, 9, 697119) There may be two opinion about the work to which he has devoted his great gifts but there can be only one opinion about the gifts themselves.
('41', 366, 3, 10, 697261) And the latter are any day far more valuable and lasting than the work itself.
('41', 366, 3, 11, 697340) The organizers of the Jubilee have set before themselves a very modest task to collect Rs. 25,000 to be presented to Prof.
('41', 366, 3, 12, 697463) Karve for his work.
('41', 366, 3, 13, 697483) It is a sum that should readily come forth from the numerous men and women who have come under the influence of this giant among silent and selfless workers or who have profited by his labours of a lifetime.

('41', 373, 2, 3, 704697) THE ASHRAM,
('41', 373, 3, 4, 704709) SABARMATI, April 6, 1928

('41', 373, 4, 6, 704767) I do not perform any miracles nor do I believe in miracles.
('41', 373, 4, 7, 704827) I would advise you to be content with what God gives you bearing in mind that there are many who are in a worse plight than you are.
('41', 373, 4, 8, 704960) And, after all, physical blindness is not half as bad as moral blindness.

('41', 374, 2, 3, 705421) April 7, 1928
('41', 374, 3, 4, 705435) MY DEAR MALKANI, I have your letter.
('41', 374, 3, 5, 705472) I did not need your budget.
('41', 374, 3, 6, 705500) I must not ask you to cancel your policy.
('41', 374, 3, 7, 705542) I simply passed on to you what was burdening my mind.
('41', 374, 3, 8, 705596) My inquiries must not oppress you.
('41', 374, 3, 9, 705631) We all must try to look as we are.
('41', 374, 3, 10, 705666) And if we could do that we would not worry over any questions.
('41', 374, 3, 11, 705729) The Rs. 200 I shall find and that without any loss of self respect.
('41', 374, 3, 12, 705797) But you must always let me have the privilege of expecting the highest from you.

('41', 374, 3, 14, 705914) You are going to pay not a farthing.
('41', 374, 3, 15, 705951) Why should the daughters be married in an Amil family necessarily?

('41', 374, 3, 17, 706091) They belong to India and if you believe in my view of varnashrama, the matter becomes simple.
('41', 374, 3, 18, 706185) Of course you do not need to pay him anything beyond his, say, fare and food there.

('41', 376, 1, 2, 707221) 436. LETTER TO DR.
('41', 376, 1, 3, 707240) M. A. ANSARI
('41', 376, 2, 4, 707253) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 7, 1928
('41', 376, 3, 5, 707290) DEAR DR.
('41', 376, 3, 6, 707299) ANSARI, I have your letter.
('41', 376, 3, 7, 707327) I resign myself to your letter to the Viceroy.
('41', 376, 3, 8, 707374) Of course I entirely agree with you that if the States will give us assistance we shall receive it gladly.
('41', 376, 3, 9, 707481) But I know that they dare not give it to an institution that is frankly a creation of non co operation and nursed in its atmosphere.
('41', 376, 3, 10, 707614) But if they do with the certain knowledge that it is a non co operationg institution, we should gladly accept their assistance.
('41', 376, 3, 11, 707742) The proposed European visit is causing me much trouble just now.
('41', 376, 3, 12, 707807) I can’t make up my mind.
('41', 376, 3, 13, 707832) I know that I should not be so undecided like this.
('41', 376, 3, 14, 707884) But what is the use of my hiding my weakness?
('41', 376, 3, 15, 707930) I can’t account for it myself.
('41', 376, 3, 16, 707961) However, I should come to a decision in the course of the next frotnight at the latest.
('41', 376, 3, 17, 708049) Improvement in health has no attraction for me.
('41', 376, 3, 18, 708097) The meeting with M. Romain Rolland and a quiet conference with the chief men of Europe is what would take me to Eruope.
('41', 376, 3, 19, 708217) Let us see how God leads me.
('41', 376, 3, 20, 708246) What is the use of Begum Ansari and Zohra wanting me to stay in their new abode?
('41', 376, 3, 21, 708327) All the time I am there, they keep themselves at a safe distance hiding themselves behind the purdah.
('41', 376, 3, 22, 708429) If they want me to be there, they will have to expose to view their superfluous bangles and other jewellery so that I can ease them of the superfluities and turn them to good account.
('41', 376, 3, 23, 708613) So far as the Jamia collections are concerned, I suspect that we shall do nothing beyond getting collections from personal friends, and, in order that this can be done it is necessary to have that constitution and trust deed.
('41', 376, 3, 24, 708839) Do please therefore expedite it as soon as you can.
('41', 376, 4, 25, 708891) Yours sincerely,

('41', 381, 2, 3, 712898) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April, 8, 1928
('41', 381, 3, 4, 712936) MY DEAR PROFESSOR, You know perhaps that Krishnadas is not here at present.
('41', 381, 3, 5, 713012) He has however sent me your letter of the 25 March.
('41', 381, 3, 6, 713064) Why do you say that the Spinners’ Register will mean purchasing yarn from cottage to cottage?
('41', 381, 3, 7, 713158) I have not suggested any such thing at all.
('41', 381, 3, 8, 713202) 1 What I have suggested is that we should know the spinners with whom the middle men deal.
('41', 381, 3, 9, 713293) We do not want to do away with the middle men altogether.
('41', 381, 3, 10, 713351) We must not be at their mercy either, nor must we be in the dark as to what is actually paid to the spinners.
('41', 381, 3, 11, 713461) The Register, therefore, has to be taken periodically.
('41', 381, 3, 12, 713516) Once we know who the spinners are, where they are, what they get and what they do, you need not bother about them again, say for six months.
('41', 381, 3, 13, 713657) As a matter of fact there should be no difficulty in your coming in touch with the middle men themselves The Ashramand with the spinners through them.
('41', 381, 3, 14, 713808) I don’t know whether I am even now clear.
('41', 381, 3, 15, 713850) Not knowing the practical working of these, there may be difficulties of which I have no knowledge.
('41', 381, 3, 16, 713950) You will then write to me about those difficulties and I might be able to make concrete suggestions for overcoming them.
('41', 381, 3, 17, 714071) About the want of capital, I am going to confer with Jamnalalji and Shankerlal.
('41', 381, 3, 18, 714151) You do not say definitely how much you require.
('41', 381, 3, 19, 714199) Is Babu Shivaprasad Gupta ready to advance that sum without interest if repayment is guaranteed and if he is, what will be the period of such loan?
('41', 381, 3, 20, 714347) The last paragraph of your letter is bad.
('41', 381, 3, 21, 714389) You can’t afford to give way to despair under any circumstances.
('41', 381, 3, 22, 714454) You have to hold on to the Ashram no matter what difficulties face you.
('41', 381, 3, 23, 714526) You dare not take up any other work.
('41', 381, 3, 24, 714563) Please write regularly.
('41', 381, 3, 25, 714587) Are you now thoroughly restored, or is there still some
('41', 381, 4, 26, 714643) 1 Gandhiji had called upon units of the All India Spinners’ Association to collect data regarding the spinners supplying yarn to the A.I.S.A. depots.
('41', 381, 4, 27, 714793) Vide “Letter to J. B. Kripalani”, 12 3 1928 and “Notes” 15 3 1928, sub title, “Instructive Figures”.

('41', 382, 1, 2, 714936) difficulty?
('41', 382, 1, 3, 714948) If there is you should now find Dr. Ansari comparatively free.

('41', 382, 4, 7, 715102) 446. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('41', 382, 5, 8, 715134) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 8, 1928
('41', 382, 6, 9, 715171) MY DEAR JAWAHAR, I have your letter.
('41', 382, 6, 10, 715208) I do not remember Father having told me that he would be back in Bombay to confer with the mill owners during the last week of this month.
('41', 382, 6, 11, 715347) But he and I discussed the question of foreign cloth boycott at length and he had a conference with Seth Lalji, Shantikumar, Seths Ambalal, Kasturbhai and Mangaldas.
('41', 382, 6, 12, 715513) It was a good conference, but nothing defenite was done.
('41', 382, 6, 13, 715570) I have now heard that the mill owners are going to start their own Swadesh League which means of course that we are not coming to any terms.
('41', 382, 6, 14, 715711) The AshramI had a long discussion with Lalaji today, for he was here for two days.
('41', 382, 6, 15, 715794) He is enthusiastic about boycott of foreign cloth.
('41', 382, 6, 16, 715845) I have supplied him with literature.
('41', 382, 6, 17, 715882) He even suggested that I should invite a few leaders and confer with [them] about boycott.
('41', 382, 6, 18, 715973) I told him I had not the courage to do so.
('41', 382, 6, 19, 716016) He is of opinion that if intense boycott propaganda is to be taken up, I must not go out of the country, wherein of course I agree; but I cannot take up intense propaganda unless politically minded India is wholeheartedly with me and unless the agitation about temporary boycott of British cloth, principally British cloth, is given up.
('41', 382, 6, 20, 716353) We have, therefore, come to this provisional arrangement that if anything concrete takes place by spontaneous action on the part of the known leaders, I should give up the idea of going to Europe.
('41', 382, 6, 21, 716550) On the other hand [if] nothing of that kind happens and if otherwise I see my way clear, I should proceed and that Lalaji and others who are minded like him should cultivate an atmosphere for intense propaganda about foreign cloth boycott with or without the Assistance of mills.
('41', 382, 6, 22, 716830) I therefore suggest that you should confer with
('41', 383, 0, 1, 716878) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 383, 1, 2, 716920) Dr. Ansari and others.
('41', 383, 1, 3, 716943) I suppose they will all go to the Punjab and pass the resolution about foreign cloth boycott through khadi.
('41', 383, 1, 4, 717051) I would warn you against any mention of indigenous mill cloth.
('41', 383, 1, 5, 717114) You can simply say: “Whereas the only effective means of immediately demonstrating the united strength of the nation lies through boycott of foreign cloth, this Conference urges all concerned completely to boycott foreign cloth and adopt hand spun and handwoven khadi even though such adoption may necessitate revision of one’s taste about dress and some pecuniary sacrifice.’ You will also let me know the result of private discussions you may have with friends and advise me as to whethere I should give up the idea of going to Europe.
('41', 383, 1, 6, 717652) Dr. Ansari should really be able to decide.
('41', 383, 2, 7, 717696) Yours sincerely,
('41', 383, 3, 8, 717713) From a photostat: S.N. 13179
('41', 383, 4, 9, 717742) 447. LETTER TO SHANKARAN
('41', 383, 5, 10, 717767) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April, 8, 1928
('41', 383, 6, 11, 717805) MY DEAR SHANKARAN,
('41', 383, 7, 12, 717824) I was thinking of you only early this morning, that is, just after prayer when talking to Pyarelal and here is your letter.
('41', 383, 7, 13, 717948) Suppose that there is a colony of orphans shipwrecked on an island, that they are all unmarried males, that they have never known that they ever had any parents, suppose further that they have a knowledge of letters and that from their reading they under stood that they had all parents; suppose then that they in the course of their readings coem upon a philosophical book called “Our Spontaneous Origin”, should the orphans feel convinced philosophically that they were all spontaneous creation?
('41', 383, 7, 14, 718446) Just as the supposed philosophical book would not unsettle the conviction of the majority of the unsophisticated orphans, so should the philosophical book that you have read about the non existence of God not unsettle your belief in God.
('41', 383, 7, 15, 718684) If you will admit the fact of your having parents, how can you escape the fundamental fact of the First Cause?
('41', 383, 7, 16, 718795) Having made sure of that, I am indifferent whether you call that First Cause God or some other thing.
('41', 383, 7, 17, 718897) And having been also convinced of that fact it is wholly
('41', 384, 0, 1, 718954) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 385
('41', 384, 1, 2, 718996) unnecessary to inquire how that First Cause disposes of justice or to inquire about the injustice that we seem to see around us.
('41', 384, 1, 3, 719125) There are endless theories.
('41', 384, 1, 4, 719153) I believe in that of cause and effect, that is, of the law of karma.
('41', 384, 1, 5, 719222) It seems to answer all a man’s doubts.
('41', 384, 1, 6, 719261) But if they do not answer yours,you must wait, watch and pray and you will some day have the light.
('41', 384, 1, 7, 719361) But if you do not believe in the First Cause, there is no hope.
('41', 384, 1, 8, 719425) For to whom should you pray then?
('41', 384, 1, 9, 719459) Therefore hold fast to your belief in God, never mind the reasoning.
('41', 384, 1, 10, 719528) Can you reason out the existence of your parents?
('41', 384, 1, 11, 719578) Will you not say, ‘Whether I can reason or not the existence of my parents is an absolute fact with me’?
('41', 384, 1, 12, 719683) If you cannot prove it to the satisfaction of your inquirers, you will say ‘my reasoning is at fault but not the fact’.
('41', 384, 1, 13, 719803) Even so must you say to yourself, ‘Though I may not be able to reason out the existence of God, I must accept the experience of and the belief of mankind in the First Cause’.
('41', 384, 1, 14, 719978) If even now you are not satisfied, you must ask me again.
('41', 384, 2, 15, 720036) Yours sincerely,
('41', 384, 3, 16, 720053) From a photostat: S.N. 13175 and 13180
('41', 384, 4, 17, 720092) 448. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI
('41', 384, 5, 18, 720124) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 8, 1928
('41', 384, 6, 19, 720168) PRABHUDAS, For the last so many days or even months, I have wanted to write to you but how was it possible for me to find time for it ?
('41', 384, 6, 20, 720304) This, too, I am dictating immediately after the morning prayers.
('41', 384, 6, 21, 720369) I have got the shawl sent by you and when the time comes, I shall certainly use it.
('41', 384, 6, 22, 720453) But in this season, the occasion will never come.
('41', 384, 6, 23, 720503) I am getting fully acquainted with your activities and am pleased with them.
('41', 384, 6, 24, 720580) I even rejoice in them.

('41', 390, 1, 2, 728148) 456. A SEASONABLE PRODUCTION
('41', 390, 2, 3, 728177) Readers of Young India are familiar with the name of Richard B. Gregg, an American lawyer who was attracted to India over two years ago by the message of khadi and who has been studying the movement in a most minute manner ever since his arrival in India.
('41', 390, 2, 4, 728433) After a years’s labour, he has written a book on the movement which treats khadi in an almost original manner.
('41', 390, 2, 5, 728544) Every statement he has made is supported by facts and figures and footnotes give the authorities upon which Mr. Gregg has drawn.
('41', 390, 2, 6, 728673) The book is published by S. Ganesan, 18 Pycrofts Road, Triplicane, Madras, and is priced at Rs. 1 8 0. From cover to cover it occupies 225 pages of which 165 225 contain seven appendices.
('41', 390, 2, 7, 728861) The book contains 12 chapters.
('41', 390, 2, 8, 728892) Let the reader also understand that Mr. Gregg, when he writes of villages, writes of things he has somewhat seen.
('41', 390, 2, 9, 729006) The three opening paragraphs of his introduction show the reader the way in which Mr. Gregg has worked : 1
('41', 390, 3, 10, 729113) It was in order to remove this poverty that Mr. Gregg was driven to an examination of the various schemes proposed to that end and he was forced to the conclusion that the spinning wheel was the only real solution.
('41', 390, 3, 11, 729328) The author says: 2
('41', 390, 4, 12, 729347) This little book is a statement of how the project looks to one who had seven years of practical work and study in industrial and labour problem in America (much of it in cotton mills), together with two and a half years’ study in India of the khaddar movement.
('41', 390, 4, 13, 729609) The latter period included observation both in the villages and at the headquarters of the movement.
('41', 390, 4, 14, 729710) The investigation was undertaken primarily to clarify my own thinking.
('41', 390, 4, 15, 729781) The originality of Mr. Gregg’s examination of the problem consists in his approach to it from the engineering aspect which is the title of the first chapter, and he has no difficulty in showing that the The Ashrammaterial prosperity of a country is increased not merely by accumulation of power or machinery but by the right use of it.
('41', 390, 5, 16, 730117) 1 The paragraphs quoted are not reproduced here.
('41', 390, 5, 17, 730166) Gregg had written: “In former days India was regarded as a very rich country, and prior to the Mohammedan conquest at least, the wealth was widely distributed among her people.
('41', 390, 5, 18, 730343) But now, although India is still considered a source of much wealth, the Indian people are ranked among the poverty stricken of the world, .
('41', 390, 5, 19, 730484) as Professor Gilbert Slater of Madras University says: ‘The poverty of India is a grim fact.’ ” 2 Only an extract is reproduced here.
('41', 391, 0, 1, 730618) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 391, 1, 2, 730660) This is how he opens his argument :
('41', 391, 2, 3, 730696) Following Mr. Ford’s idea that the right use of power is more important than any particular kind of machinery, let us briefly examine the fundamentals of physical power and its utilization and then apply that as a test for the validity of the khaddar proposal.
('41', 391, 2, 4, 730957) We will first state the whole engineering argument in brief, and then consider it in a more detailed fashion.
('41', 391, 3, 5, 731067) All physical power is derived ultimately from the sum.
('41', 391, 3, 6, 731122) Coal and petroleum are, in effect, reservoirs from the stream of solar energy of past ages converted and stored up by vegetation.
('41', 391, 3, 7, 731252) Water power comes from the action of sunshine evaporating water from the oceans and transporting it to the land and rivers in the form of clouds and rain.
('41', 391, 3, 8, 731407) Even the mechanical energy of horses and cattle and man himself comes from food obtained from plants activated by sunshine.
('41', 391, 3, 9, 731531) All the power used in modern industry and in the economic activities of man in past ages came from his using some part of the never ending stream of solar energy.
('41', 391, 3, 10, 731694) The old Rigvedic hymns sang rightly of Savitar the Sun god: “Savitar .
('41', 391, 3, 11, 731765) Lord of every blessing;” and “God Savitar, the good eyed, hath come hither giving choice treasures unto him who worships” (R. V., x.
('41', 391, 3, 12, 731898) 149; i.
('41', 391, 4, 13, 731906) Any scheme which utilizes and efficintly transforms solar energy to a greater degree than was being done before is sound, from an engineering standpoint, and also from an economic point of view.
('41', 391, 5, 14, 732101) We do not usually think of the charkha as a machine, but it really is so.
('41', 391, 5, 15, 732175) It uses the available mechanical energy of a man, woman or child for producing material goods.
('41', 391, 5, 16, 732270) The handloom does likewise.
('41', 391, 5, 17, 732298) The mechanical energy is derived from the food eaten by the person.
('41', 391, 5, 18, 732366) Though in a different degree, manner and mode, the process is the same as that occurring in a steam engine or hydraulic power plant, namely, the transformation of solar energy into mechanical motion.
('41', 391, 6, 19, 732566) There are today great numbers of unemployed Indians.
('41', 391, 6, 20, 732619) They are, in effect, engines kept running by fuel (food), but not attached to any machines or devices for producing goods.
('41', 391, 6, 21, 732742) Mr. Gandhi proposes to hitch them to charkhas and thus save a vast existing waste of solar energy.
('41', 391, 7, 22, 732841) If we want to increase the use of mechanical power in India, this is the quickest and cheapest way.
('41', 391, 7, 23, 732941) The ‘engines’ are all present; a man is as efficient a transformer of fuel energy into mechanical motion as a steam engine is; the spinning and weaving machinery to be used is nearly all ready at hand in The Ashramsufficient quantity to supply all needs.
('41', 391, 7, 24, 733196) Any additional needs can be quickly and cheaply produced in India by artisans who need no further training in technical skill for this purpose; the speed and quantity of output possible
('41', 392, 0, 1, 733382) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 393
('41', 392, 1, 2, 733424) with charkha and handloom are more closely adapted to the needs of the Indian market and Indian producers than any other type or machinery; no foreign capital is needed to purchase the machinery, and therefore there will be no expensive interest payments or difficulties arising from absentee control; the maintenance of such a factory is inexpensive and can be done entirely by available workers without further training: the amount of training needed for operatives is a minimum and of a sort more easily acquired than for any other type of machinery; the ‘fuel’ or power cost for the man charkha system will be nothing above the present food bill of the nation; the material to be used is available in practically every Indian province at a minimum of transportation cost; and the market is everywhere.
('41', 392, 1, 3, 734230) I must resist the temptation to quote from the other chapters.
('41', 392, 1, 4, 734293) But if the foregoing excerpts have at all proved tempting for the reader, let me assure him that he will find that the chapters that follows are fully interesting and deeply instructive.
('41', 392, 1, 5, 734480) Let me close this hasty review with giving the names of the remaining 11 chapters.
('41', 392, 1, 6, 734563) It will be admitted that they are suggestive enough.
('41', 392, 2, 7, 734616) Chapters II Engineering details III Competition between mill cloth and khaddar IV Factors tending to decrease competition V Increased purchasing power VI Decentralized production and distribution VII Unemployment VIII Some cotton technology IX Does it work?
('41', 392, 2, 8, 734874) X Various objections XI Comparison of khaddar programme with other reform schemes XII Money price criteria Conclusion
