('41', 393, 0, 1, 735015) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 393, 1, 2, 735057) 457. PLACE OF KHADI
('41', 393, 2, 3, 735077) Lovers of khadi have been writing to me energetically warn ing me against coquetting with mill owners in the vain hope, as they call it, of securing their active co operation on terms beneficial to the nation in the prosecution of the campaign of boycott of foreign cloth.
('41', 393, 2, 4, 735350) I appreciate their warning.
('41', 393, 2, 5, 735378) Some of them are tried and experi enced workers in the khadi movement.
('41', 393, 2, 6, 735449) But I do not give up hope of the mill owners some day or other coming round to the national view.
('41', 393, 2, 7, 735547) After all as an out and out believer in the method of non violence, I may not let a single opportunity to slip of converting the mill owners to the nationalistic view, even as I may not pass by a single occasion of converting Englishmen to the Indian view of Indian’s good.
('41', 393, 2, 8, 735821) After all, if we are to win our freedom by non violent means, we shall have to knock at the doors of those who put obstacles in its way and plead with them to remove them.
('41', 393, 2, 9, 735993) And even as in a bloody revolution those who are supposed to stand in the way are made to pay the last penalty whether they are countrymen or otherwise, so in a non violent revolution are they, whether countrymen or foreigners, required to face satyagraha, if they will not listen to reason and wil obstinately stand in the way.
('41', 393, 2, 10, 736322) I therefore see no harm in having stated the conditions on which mill owners can co operate with the nation.
('41', 393, 2, 11, 736431) It would have been wrong not to have done so.
('41', 393, 2, 12, 736477) And if they accept the terms, I know that khadi, i.
('41', 393, 2, 13, 736529) e., the masses have nothing to lose.
('41', 393, 2, 14, 736566) For if the mills work not for exploiting the masses as they now do, but for serving them, they will supplement the products of the cottage spinning wheel and the handloom and not supersede them as they now do.
('41', 393, 2, 15, 736776) There is no doubt that if they hesitate to accept the terms stated by me, they will do so because the logical consequence repels them even as the logical consequence of Englishmen really becoming servants of the nation repels them.
('41', 393, 2, 16, 737008) I would therefore ask khadi lovers not to be afraid of my so called ‘coquetting’.
('41', 393, 2, 17, 737090) If we are strong in our faith, if khadi has the inherent vitality we claim for it, if it is the need of the masses, and if we persist in our effort with them, they will not fail to realize it.
('41', 393, 2, 18, 737283) Khadi will fail only when khadi lovers falter in their faith or if their faith is based on a mere shadow, i.e., if there is no grinding poverty among the masses, if they have no leisure hours during the year, or if, though The Ashramthey have spare hours, the spinning wheel is not the most
('41', 394, 0, 1, 737574) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 395
('41', 394, 1, 2, 737616) suitable and practicable occupation conceivable for many millions.
('41', 394, 1, 3, 737683) It is because of the implicit faith I have in khadi in terms of the propositions just stated and of the strength born of that faith that I am ‘coquetting’ with the mill owners.
('41', 394, 1, 4, 737860) It is quite likely, it is perhaps now practically certain, that no immediate good will come out of these negotiations.
('41', 394, 1, 5, 737979) But they will serve for further action or guidance if we have not meanwhile already achived boycott of foreign cloth.
('41', 394, 1, 6, 738097) It is therefore profitable to inquire, even at the risk of repe tition, what place khadi has in any scheme of boycott.
('41', 394, 1, 7, 738216) In my opinion, boycott of foreign cloth is both necessary and feasible only because it affects and benefits the masses and can be achieved only if they co operate.
('41', 394, 1, 8, 738380) Boycott of foreign cloth would have but a temporary value if it could be obtained solely by the indigenous mills.
('41', 394, 1, 9, 738494) And I hold it to be impossible in the near future to enforce the boycott through the single agency of mills.
('41', 394, 1, 10, 738603) In my opinion, it is khadi alone that has made such boycott a practical proposition.
('41', 394, 1, 11, 738688) Indeed it is so practical that if the politically minded India were to take up the sales of khadi, it is possible to manufacture in a year all the khadi that may be required by the nation even though there may be not a single yard of mill calico—foreign or indigenous—available.
('41', 394, 1, 12, 738967) I affirm this on the basis of the assumption that the villages will mostly manufa cture their own khadi and the organized centres will manufacture for those who are not self spinniers.
('41', 394, 1, 13, 739152) Experience of past seven years shows that if there is a sudden famine of cloth in the country and if the masses are encouraged they have sufficient skil and the indigenous machi nery for manufacturing their own khadi.
('41', 394, 1, 14, 739370) No doubt a revolution ary change in the mental outlook and sartorial tastes of politically minded India is necessary.
('41', 394, 1, 15, 739488) I have no doubt that if the bulk of them do not respond now, they will have to do so when they realize that khadi has become irresistible.
('41', 394, 1, 16, 739627) And to make it irresistible khadi workers have to work away with steadfastness, honesty, scientific skill and precision.
('41', 394, 1, 17, 739748) I have ‘coquetted’ with mill owners and discussed the possibility of immediate boycott of foreign cloth in association with them, in order to show that if they mean it they can give themselves the privilege of serving the nation at the same time that they serve themselves.
('41', 394, 1, 18, 740022) Meanwhile, let none doubt that khadi is silently and imperceptibly revolutionizing the national taste and will bring about the boycott in its own good time, if it not anticipated by some such combination as I have ventured to suggest.
('41', 394, 1, 19, 740257) Young India, 12 4 1928
('41', 395, 0, 1, 740280) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 395, 1, 2, 740322) 458. NOTES
('41', 395, 2, 3, 740333) BREACH OF PROMISE?
('41', 395, 3, 4, 740352) When I was in Berhampur, Ganjam District, last year, I was taken to a temple which I was told was open to all including the so called untouchables.
('41', 395, 3, 5, 740500) I was accompanied by some untouchable friends.
('41', 395, 3, 6, 740547) A few weeks after I received a letter that the trustees had declared prohibition against the entry of untouchables.
('41', 395, 3, 7, 740663) I was loath to believe the statement.
('41', 395, 3, 8, 740701) I, therefore, inquired and here is the reply to my inquiry : 1
('41', 395, 4, 9, 740764) If the information is correct, it is clear breach of promise by the trustees—a promise that was publicly made not merely to me but to the public of Berhampur through me.
('41', 395, 4, 10, 740934) I wonder whether the trustees have any defence of explanation to offer.
('41', 395, 4, 11, 741006) The untouchables have undoubtedly a clear case for offering satyagraha in this case.
('41', 395, 4, 12, 741091) I do hope however that the public of Berhampur will redeem their self respect by insisting on removal of the bar, if the bar does as a matter of fact exist.

('41', 398, 1, 2, 745596) 462. SPEECH TO TRAINEES AT KHADI VIDYALAYA, AHMEDABAD 1
('41', 398, 2, 3, 745652) [Before April 13, 1928] 2
('41', 398, 3, 4, 745678) The idea of the Khadi Seva Sangh was mine.
('41', 398, 3, 5, 745721) I felt that just as the Government has an organization, its naukarshahi, 3 it would be good for us also to have an organization of workers.
('41', 398, 3, 6, 745861) The Govern ment’s naukarshahi is called ‘shahi’ 4 because its members, although they are servants, function as rulers.
('41', 398, 3, 7, 745980) But we are not ‘shahi’ because we have to do real service.
('41', 398, 3, 8, 746039) For admission to this organization a course The Ashramof fixed period was prescribed because in order to be a khadi worker training and proficiency are required.
('41', 398, 3, 9, 746201) The science of khadi is a serious affair; its scope is extremely vast, because through this science we want to serve the 33 crore people of India and through them the whole world.
('41', 398, 3, 10, 746381) It is an empirical science; astronomy, on the contrary, is not an empirical science.
('41', 398, 3, 11, 746466) The science of khadi is empirical because its experiments and conclusions are accessible to experience.
('41', 398, 3, 12, 746570) Thirty three crores of people can have direct experience of it.
('41', 398, 3, 13, 746634) Hence its scope extends to where name of God reaches.
('41', 398, 3, 14, 746688) The vastness of this science can be realized from the fact that all the things that are done in textile mills we have to do in our homes.
('41', 398, 3, 15, 746826) Those who run these mills have had to read a number of technical books the study of which is essential for acquiring proficiency in the work.
('41', 398, 3, 16, 746968) Take only one process.
('41', 398, 3, 17, 746991) Just as in the mills they have to test cotton, we too have to do it.
('41', 398, 3, 18, 747060) These knowledge which they require as to the strength of cotton, cotton gathering, etc., is also required by us.
('41', 398, 3, 19, 747173) Our very first lesson is about cotton and it is a very important one.
('41', 398, 3, 20, 747243) There are indeed many things which we have to do but which the mills are not required to do.
('41', 398, 3, 21, 747336) For example, the mills do not have to bother whether in ginning the cotton seeds remain intact or are broken, but we cannot afford to be careless in the matter.
('41', 398, 3, 22, 747497) We want that the seeds should retain their properties.
('41', 398, 3, 23, 747552) We want to feed these to the cattle and extract oil from them.
('41', 398, 3, 24, 747615) Mills have nothing at all to do with all these
('41', 398, 4, 25, 747662) 1 The Khadi Vidyalaya was run at the Ashram for candidates selected for admission to the Khadi Seva Sangh.
('41', 398, 4, 26, 747769) 2 According to the source the speech was delivered during the National Week, i.e., between April 6 and 13. 3 Bureaucracy 4 “Royal”
('41', 399, 0, 1, 747900) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 399, 1, 2, 747942) things.
('41', 399, 1, 3, 747950) However rich we may be in resources, and however persistent in our efforts, it is all useless without a purpose.
('41', 399, 1, 4, 748063) That purpose is national service.
('41', 399, 1, 5, 748097) And it is so vast that one can go as deep into it as one chooses.
('41', 399, 1, 6, 748163) There is no end to the labours of the mills because they have a selfish motive, they have to earn money.
('41', 399, 1, 7, 748268) In their set up there is scope for punishment as well as for reward and, after all, what is the principle of reward if it is not one of punishment?
('41', 399, 1, 8, 748416) In our case there is no selfishness and no punishment.
('41', 399, 1, 9, 748471) But it is not proper that since there is no selfishness we should not work as much as they do in mills.
('41', 399, 1, 10, 748575) Our work is as deserving of efforts as it is selfless.
('41', 399, 1, 11, 748630) The more love and labour we pour into it, the quicker will be our victory.
('41', 399, 1, 12, 748705) Sir Jagadish Chandra Bose takes a leaf from a plant and very carefully and minutely examines it to see how many sections it has, whether it has organs of sense and whether it can feel as human beings do.
('41', 399, 1, 13, 748909) He then places the results of his experiments before the world.
('41', 399, 1, 14, 748973) Does he do this The Ashramfor money?
('41', 399, 1, 15, 749010) No Then does he do so for fame?
('41', 399, 1, 16, 749042) He does it without any selfish motive.
('41', 399, 1, 17, 749081) But his objective is gaining knowledge, whereas our experiments are not purely for the sake of knowledge.
('41', 399, 1, 18, 749187) Ours is an empirical science and we want to se its actual results.
('41', 399, 1, 19, 749254) We have to observe carefully how much cotton is obtained from a given quantity of raw cotton, how much yarn is prepared out of that cotton and how much cloth is woven out of that yarn.
('41', 399, 1, 20, 749439) And in this way we can calculate how many people have to put in how much labour in order to meet the cloth requirements of the whole country.
('41', 399, 1, 21, 749581) Acquire as much knowledge as you can in order to gain mastery of this science and carry out as many experiments as necessary.
('41', 399, 1, 22, 749707) For this, you should have enthusiasm, interest and dedication.
('41', 399, 1, 23, 749770) The person who cultivates this science with devotion will be granted the inner light by God.
('41', 399, 1, 24, 749863) But it is not enough for us merely acquire knowledge of this science.
('41', 399, 1, 25, 749933) Mere knowledge would be useful in mills only.
('41', 399, 1, 26, 749979) We need character in addition to this knowledge.
('41', 399, 1, 27, 750028) You have come here not for earning your livelihood but with a desire to serve, to dedicate your life to the cause of khadi, and for this character will be very essential.
('41', 399, 1, 28, 750199) How will you go among the people without character?
('41', 399, 1, 29, 750251) Who will accept your service?
('41', 399, 1, 30, 750281) Nobody bothers about the character of people working in mills but everybody will enquire about your character.
('41', 399, 1, 31, 750392) You have to go to the people as servants, not as tyrants.
('41', 399, 1, 32, 750450) If possible, you have to be
('41', 400, 0, 1, 750478) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 401
('41', 400, 1, 2, 750520) labourers living in their midst.
('41', 400, 1, 3, 750553) For doing this a disciplined life is needed.
('41', 400, 1, 4, 750598) And cleanliness will be the first sign by which you can show your character.
('41', 400, 1, 5, 750675) The impression which you will be able to create in the people by strict observance of the rules of cleanliness, you will not be able to do in any other way.
('41', 400, 1, 6, 750832) And what is desirable is that you should not follow these rules for the sake of following them but it should become impossible for you not to follow them.
('41', 400, 1, 7, 750987) You should so mould your nature that cleanliness becoemse a part of it; if you find uncleanliness anywhere you should be unable to bear it.
('41', 400, 1, 8, 751127) Uncleanliness anywhere, whoever may be responsible for it, should become an eyesore to us and unless it is removed we should find no joy in living.
('41', 400, 1, 9, 751275) We wish to offer ourselves as oblation in the national yajna.
('41', 400, 1, 10, 751337) In order to do so we have to become pure and clean.
('41', 400, 1, 11, 751389) Does it do any The Ashramgood burning a dirty thing?
('41', 400, 1, 12, 751442) But if your burn something fragrant, the atmoshepre is purified and the perfume spreads.
('41', 400, 1, 13, 751531) Therefore let us become pure like sandalwood and offer ourselves up in this sacrifice.
('41', 400, 1, 14, 751618) This is the purpose for which this Ashram has been established.
('41', 400, 1, 15, 751682) Let the Ashram become the incense in the national sacrifice and remove the foul smell wherever it may be found.
('41', 400, 1, 16, 751794) This is our ideal.
('41', 400, 1, 17, 751813) Indeed, this is not the Ashram’s ideal only, but that of every khadi worker.
('41', 400, 1, 18, 751890) And are you aware what a high place your work occupies?
('41', 400, 1, 19, 751946) If someone asked me what the place of khadi in relation to service of the cow or tanning was, I should surely say that it had the first place.
('41', 400, 1, 20, 752089) According to the grand simile of Tulsidas, this is the most benevolent activity, even though it seems dull:
('41', 400, 2, 21, 752197) How monotonous spinning appears!
('41', 400, 2, 22, 752230) The Punjabis tell me that it is a women’s work and that they cannot do it.
('41', 400, 2, 23, 752305) Then there is neither honour nor profit in khadi work.
('41', 400, 2, 24, 752360) If one becoemes expert in dairying or tanning, one can get big emoluments.
('41', 400, 2, 25, 752435) But in khadi there is no such attraction because it is the work of millions of people.
('41', 400, 2, 26, 752522) We requires seven lakh workers in order to organize khadi work throughout the country.
('41', 400, 2, 27, 752609) How can we afford to give them high salaries?
('41', 400, 2, 28, 752655) Perhaps seven
('41', 401, 0, 1, 752669) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 401, 1, 2, 752711) lakh cow workers or tanning experts may not be required by the country, but it would not do to have less than this number for khadi work.
('41', 401, 1, 3, 752849) 'This work is so important and it is required on such a big scale.
('41', 401, 1, 4, 752916) Despite its seeming monotony, there is hardly any other work more intresting than this.
('41', 401, 1, 5, 753004) If you start taking lots of interest in it, you would adorn yourself, the Ashram and the country as well.

('41', 407, 1, 2, 759475) 471. LETTER TO VITHALDAS JERAJANI SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 14, 1928
('41', 407, 2, 3, 759554) BHAISHRI VITHALBHAI, This letter is in reply to yours.
('41', 407, 2, 4, 759609) If the boycott becomes universal, we do not have enough chhayal 1 and dhotis.
('41', 407, 2, 5, 759687) We can meet the demands of those who will go about, if need be, in a langoti 2, but wear nothing except khadi.
('41', 407, 2, 6, 759798) To those, however, who are not ready to go to this extent but will take part in the boycott of foreign cloth if they can get some other cloth in its place, we may supply mill made dhotis and saris.
('41', 407, 2, 7, 759996) This means that the mills cannot manufacture any other cloth except what we decide and that, even in their shope, khadi will be sold as a substitute for the kinds of cloth which they do not manufacture.
('41', 407, 2, 8, 760199) I can realize that the mills will not agree to this, but we cannot come to any understanding with them as long as they do not agree.
('41', 407, 2, 9, 760332) My demand means that the mills should accept the permanent place of khadi.
('41', 407, 2, 10, 760407) If you do not understand this point, please ask me.
('41', 407, 2, 11, 760459) I do not want you to come here, leaving your work unattended there.
('41', 407, 2, 12, 760527) You may discuss the matter when you have occasion to come here and get the necessary opportu nity.
('41', 407, 3, 13, 760626) Blessings from BAPU

('41', 408, 3, 6, 760951) I am of the opinion that if a person has incurred debts he himself or his wife or children have to right to keep anything from the wealth amassed by him.

('41', 409, 0, 1, 762124) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 409, 1, 2, 762166) 473. SERVICE OF THE SUPPRESSED 1
('41', 409, 2, 3, 762199) The servant of the suppressed serves both himself and the society, as the oppressor ultimately oppresses himself, and the engi neer is always hoist with his own petard.
('41', 409, 2, 4, 762368) We were on the point of being pariahs of the world, having treated the bulk of our brethren as untouchables.
('41', 409, 2, 5, 762477) We are however likely to escape that catastrophe, as the Hindu society is trying to remove this blot in various ways and in many provinces.
('41', 409, 2, 6, 762617) By far the biggest and most successful of these efforts is perhaps the one conducted by Anasuyabehn in Ahmedabad.
('41', 409, 2, 7, 762731) I addressed two meetings last month, one under the auspices of the Sweepers’ Mahajan and the other a gathering of the children of the Labour Union schools.
('41', 409, 2, 8, 762887) 2 Most of these children belonged to the suppressed classes.
('41', 409, 2, 9, 762948) I take the following 3 from the report that was read at the meeting : I do not know of workmen’s children elsewhere receiving education under such orderly and careful organization and in such numbers.
('41', 409, 2, 10, 763149) The mill owners ought to welcome the enterprise.
('41', 409, 2, 11, 763198) On the contrary they are reported to have threatened to stop the monetary help they are at present giving.
('41', 409, 2, 12, 763305) I do hope not only that it is a false alarm, but that they will yearly add to their contributions.
('41', 409, 2, 13, 763404) In doing so I should humbly think they will be doing nothing beyond what they owe to their workmen.
('41', 409, 2, 14, 763504) A noteworthy feature of the enterprise is the large contribution of the workmen themselves towards the expenses, the ultimate aim being to conduct these schools wholly at their own expense.
('41', 409, 2, 15, 763694) This of course presupposes their economic betterment, a stimulation in them of the desire for sacrifice and for the education of their children.
('41', 409, 2, 16, 763839) In the mean while, the mill owners and other philanthropists should keep the enterprise going.
('41', 409, 3, 17, 763934) 1 The Gujarati original, of which this is a translation by Mahadev Desai, appeared in Navajivan, 15 4 1928. 2 Vide “Speech at Gathering of Students and Teachers, Ahmedabad”, 31 3 1928. 3 Not reproduced here
('41', 410, 0, 1, 764141) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 411
('41', 410, 1, 2, 764183) The sweepers’ meeting 1 was remarkable for the things it brought to light.
('41', 410, 1, 3, 764258) I heard them sing their songs with flawless pronunciation.
('41', 410, 1, 4, 764317) They were comparatively unlettered, but no one who listened to their songs could say that they belonged to the suppressed classes.
('41', 410, 1, 5, 764448) But they are indebted, underpaid, and addicted to drink.
('41', 410, 1, 6, 764505) Most of them beg and live on leavings from plates given to them by Hindus of higher castes.
('41', 410, 1, 7, 764597) Their condition makes the conclusion irresistible that we the so called high caste Hindus are responsible for their failings, and only the inherent strength of Hinduism is responsible for their good points.
('41', 410, 1, 8, 764804) Hinduism has helped them to retain some of their culture in spite of the oppression they have laboured under.
('41', 410, 1, 9, 764914) They would never have been reduced to their present state if we had regarded them as our own kith and kin.
('41', 410, 1, 10, 765021) Anasuyabehn may carry on welfare work among them, but who will look to their housing?
('41', 410, 1, 11, 765107) I have seen the hovels they live in.
('41', 410, 1, 12, 765144) It is the duty of the mill owners and the municipality to provide them with better houses, and even if the former fail in their duty the latter may not do so, for better housing is essential as much for the health of the city as for that of the workmen.
('41', 410, 2, 13, 765398) UNTOUCHABLES AMONG UNTOUCHABLES
('41', 410, 3, 14, 765430) I addressed a third meeting 2 which was full of painful experience.
('41', 410, 3, 15, 765498) There is a suppressed class night school under the Gujarat Vidyapith conducted by the students of the Vidyalaya.
('41', 410, 3, 16, 765611) They take considerable pains over the school, which until a short time ago had a very large attendance of Dhed children.
('41', 410, 3, 17, 765732) The teachers thought of the sweepers’ children and induced the sweepers to send their children to the school but as soon as these came, most of the Dheds withdrew their children form the school!
('41', 410, 3, 18, 765927) The teachers therefore turned to me to find a way out of the situation.
('41', 410, 3, 19, 765999) So I went there.
('41', 410, 3, 20, 766016) Very few Dhed parents attended the meeting.
('41', 410, 3, 21, 766060) One of them whom I tried to tackle said frankly, taking his stand on the traditional religion: “How may a Dhed touch a sweeper?” “But if the touch of the sweeper pollutes the Dhed, why should the higher castes touch the Dheds?,” I asked.
('41', 410, 3, 22, 766298) “We never ask them to do so,” he quickly rejoined, and floored me.
('41', 410, 4, 23, 766365) 1 Vide “Speech at Sweepers’ Meeting, Ahmedabad”, 27 3 1928. 2 No report of this meeting is available.
('41', 411, 0, 1, 766467) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 411, 1, 2, 766509) This is how we are hoist with our own petard.
('41', 411, 1, 3, 766555) If untouchability had been allowed go to on unchecked, each one of us should have considered the other untouchable and we should have been doomed.
('41', 411, 1, 4, 766702) But thank God, in spite of the orthodox Dheds and Banias and Brahmins, the snake of untouchability is breathing its last.
('41', 411, 1, 5, 766824) The teachers of course ought to adhere to their resolve.
('41', 411, 1, 6, 766881) They should not be angry with the Dheds, but neither should they let go a single sweeper boy for the sake of the Dhed boys.
('41', 411, 1, 7, 767005) Let them shower all their love and attention on the sweeper boys, and there their duty ends.
('41', 411, 1, 8, 767098) Their determination and faith will melt the hearts of the Dheds, who, as soon as they find the sweepers’ children growing in cleanliness and character, will not help sending their own children too.
('41', 411, 1, 9, 767296) The anti untouchability worker has to begin at the lowermost rung of the ladder.
('41', 411, 1, 10, 767377) There are, I know, some ‘reformers’ who are apt to think: ‘Better reform and serve our own castes before we reform and serve the Dheds.’ This way of thinking betrays impatience and ignorance, impatance because we fight shy of obstacles, and ignorance because we forget that all other reform of Hinduism is nothing worth until the main reform, viz., the removal of untouchability, is achieved.
('41', 411, 1, 11, 767770) This blot poisons the whole system, even as a drop of arsenic would poison a tankful of milk.
('41', 411, 1, 12, 767864) Remove this and you open the door for other reforms, retain this and you render other reforms nugatory.
('41', 411, 1, 13, 767968) The disease of a consumptive unless the root cause is tackled remains just the same whether you remove or do not remove a few abscesses on his body.
('41', 411, 2, 14, 768117) Young India, 19 4 1928

('41', 417, 10, 17, 774775) A message was received from Gandhiji wishing the Congress success and expressing the hope that the students would not forget the starving millions of the mother country, the most effective manner of helping whom was by wearing khadi.
('41', 417, 11, 18, 775009) The Hindu, 19 4 1928
('41', 417, 12, 19, 775030) 1 He was connected with the Peace Association, Jerusalem.
('41', 418, 0, 1, 775088) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 419
('41', 418, 1, 2, 775130) 485. OFF THE TRAIL
('41', 418, 2, 3, 775149) Remarkable are the attempts made by and on behalf of the Government to befog people’s minds and take them away from the main point by raising side issues and discovering or professing to discover flaws in evidence produced in support of the main point.
('41', 418, 2, 4, 775402) It does not suit the Government to admit that its history is a history of the ruin of India’s industries and India’s manhood.
('41', 418, 2, 5, 775528) One of such recent attempts is to discredit the oft told story in the Press and on the platform about the cutting off by the weavers of their own thumbs in order to escape the East India Company’ myrmidons who sought to compel them to wind silk.
('41', 418, 2, 6, 775774) If the weaver has no thumb he cannot do the work expected of him.
('41', 418, 2, 7, 775840) And the way the history has been discredited is by digging out the credentials of William Bolts on the strength of whose evidence the late Romesh Chandra Dutt First made the statement regarding the cutting off of thumbs.
('41', 418, 2, 8, 776061) The writer of the refutation is not able to say that William Bolts gave false evidence, but he says that William Bolts had no character to keep and that therefore his evidence is not worthy of credence.
('41', 418, 2, 9, 776264) And he further says that he was a dismissed servant of the Company under its resolution which described him as “a very unworthy and unprofitable servant of the Company, his conduct has been distinguished by a tenacious adherence to those pernicious principles relative to the rights of inland trade, in which he appears to have been so conspicuously oppressive”.
('41', 418, 2, 10, 776627) Who does not know the tricks of pettifogging lawyers to discredit witnesses by proving their bad character as if a man with a bad character was ever incapable of making a true statement?
('41', 418, 2, 11, 776814) I make bold to say that whatever the character of William Bolts, his testimony about the cutting off of thumbs need not be discredited unless it can be otherwise disproved, and there has been nothing brought forward to show that that testimony is unworthy to be believed.
('41', 418, 2, 12, 777086) On the contrary, what is more likely than that weavers in order to escape harrowing and continuous oppression would once for all render themselves physically unfit to do the work imposed upon them under unbearable punishment?
('41', 418, 2, 13, 777312) After all, the evidence of William Bolts is only part of the story of the ruin of India’s industries told by Romesh Chandra Dutt with such deadly effect and supported by the evidence of a variety of witnesses, the cumulative effect of whose evidence becomes irresistible.
('41', 418, 2, 14, 777584) The main point is whether the industry was or was not
('41', 419, 0, 1, 777638) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 419, 1, 2, 777680) ruined with the greatest deliberation.
('41', 419, 1, 3, 777719) If it was, it makes little difference if the evidence of one witness is rejected and it will lie ill in the mouth of the criminal to say that out of a hundred witnesses one has told an untruth.
('41', 419, 1, 4, 777913) But as I have said in this instance, there is nothing relevant brought forward to show that William Bolts’s testimony is not to be believed.
('41', 419, 1, 5, 778054) Let me however put before the reader a few relevant extracts from Dutt’s first volume of the Economic History of India.
('41', 419, 1, 6, 778174) He says :
('41', 419, 2, 7, 778184) It will appear from the facts stated in the last two chapters that large portions of the Indian population were engaged in various industries down to the first decade of the nineteenth century.
('41', 419, 2, 8, 778378) Weaving was still the national industry of the people; millions of women eked out the family income by their earnings from spinning; and dyeing, tanning and working in metals also gave employment to millions.
('41', 419, 2, 9, 778587) It was not, however, the policy of the East India Company to foster Indian industries.
('41', 419, 2, 10, 778674) It has been stated in a previous chapter that, as early as 1769, the Directors wished the manufacture of raw silk to be encouraged in Bengal, and that of silk fabrics discouraged.
('41', 419, 2, 11, 778854) And they also directed that silkwinders should be made to work in the Company’s factories, and prohibited from working outside “under severe penalties by the authority of the Government”.
('41', 419, 2, 12, 779042) This mandate had its desired effect.
('41', 419, 2, 13, 779079) The manufacture of silk and cotton goods declined in India, and the people who had exported these goods to the markets of Europe and Asia in previous centuries began to import them in increasing quantities.
('41', 419, 2, 14, 779286) So much was the importation of silk and cotton goods from England stimulated by these methods that whereas in 1794 it was £156, in 1813 it rose to £108, 824. In 1813 the Company’s charter was renewed and important evidence was taken at the enquiry prior to renewal.
('41', 419, 2, 15, 779552) “In respect of Indian manufactures,” says the author, “they—the Commons—sought to discover how they could be replaced by British manufactures, and how British industries could be promoted at the expense of Indian industries.” The commercial policy of England is thus described by Henry St. George Tucker :
('41', 419, 3, 16, 779858) What is the commercial policy which we have adopted in this country with relation to India?
('41', 419, 3, 17, 779950) The silk manufactures and its piecegoods made of silk and cotton intermixed have long since been excluded altogether from our markets; and of late partly in consequence of the operation of a duty of 67 per cent, but chiefly from the effect of superior machinery, the cotton fabrics, which hiterto constituted the staple of India, have not only been displaced in
('41', 420, 0, 1, 780312) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 421
('41', 420, 1, 2, 780354) this country, but we actually export our cotton manufactures to supply a part of the consumption of our Asiatic possessions.
('41', 420, 1, 3, 780479) India is thus reduced from the state of a manufacturing to that of an agricultural country.
('41', 420, 1, 4, 780571) Here is another testimony of the same character by H. H. Wilson :
('41', 420, 2, 5, 780637) It is also a melancholy instance of the wrong done to India by the country on which she has become dependent.
('41', 420, 2, 6, 780747) It was stated in evidence (in 1813) that the cotton and silk goods of India up to the period could be sold for a profit in the British market at a price from 50 to 60 per cent lower than those fabricated in England.
('41', 420, 2, 7, 780963) It consequently became necessary to protect the latter by duties of 70 and 80 per cent, on their value, or by positive prohibition.
('41', 420, 2, 8, 781095) Had this not been the case, had not such prohibitive duties and decrees existed, the mills of Paisley and Manchester would have been stopped in their outset, and could scarcely have been again set in motion, even by the power of steam.
('41', 420, 2, 9, 781331) They were created by the sacrifice of the Indian manufacture.
('41', 420, 2, 10, 781393) Had India been independent, she would have retaliated, would have imposed prohibitive duties upon British goods, and would thus have preserved her own productive industry from annihilation.
('41', 420, 2, 11, 781583) This act of self defence was not permitted to her; she was at the mercy of the stranger.
('41', 420, 2, 12, 781672) British goods were forced upon her without paying any duty, and the foreign manufacturer employed the arm of political injustice to keep down and ultimately strangle a competitor with whom he could not have contended on equal terms.
('41', 420, 2, 13, 781905) According to Thomas Munro “the Company’s servants assembled the principal weavers and placed a guard over them until they entered into engagements to supply the Company only.” The author then proceeds :
('41', 420, 3, 14, 782108) When once a weaver accepted an advance he seldom got out of his liability.
('41', 420, 3, 15, 782183) A peon was placed over him to quicken his deliveries if he delayed, and he was liable to be prosecuted in the courts of justice.
('41', 420, 3, 16, 782312) The sending of a peon meant a fine of one anna (about 1 1 2 d.) a day on the weaver, and the peon
('41', 420, 4, 17, 782410) was armed with a rattan, which was not unoften used to good purpose.
('41', 420, 4, 18, 782479) Fine was sometimes imposed on the weavers, and their brass utensils were seized for its recovery.
('41', 420, 4, 19, 782577) The whole weaving population of villages were thus held in subjection to the Company’s factories.
('41', 420, 4, 20, 782675) The control under which the weaver population was held was not merely a matter of practice, but was legalized by Regulations.
('41', 420, 4, 21, 782801) It was provided that a weaver who had received advances from the Company “shall on no account give to any other persons whatever, European or Native, either the labour or the produce engaged to the Company”; that on his failing to deliver the stipulate cloths, “the Commercial Resident shall be at liberty to place peons upon him in order to quicken his
('41', 421, 0, 1, 783155) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 421, 1, 2, 783197) deliveries’; that on his selling his cloths to others, the weaver “shall be liable to be prosecuted in the dewani Adalat”; that “weavers, possessed of more than one loom, and entertaining one or more workmen, shall be subject to a penalty of 35 per cent on the stipulated price of every piece of cloth that they may fail to deliver according to the written agreement”; that landlords and tenants “are enjoined not to hinder the Commercial Residents or their officers from access to weavers”;' and that they “are strictly prohibited from behaving with disrespect to the Commercial Residents” of the Company.
('41', 421, 1, 3, 783804) Is it to be wondered at if weavers living under such intolerable restraint broke loose from it by cutting off their own thumbs?
('41', 421, 1, 4, 783932) To revive an industry that was thus deliberately destroyed and which supplemented the resources of millions of people is the sacred duty of every Indian who loves his country and should be considered a privilege by every Englishman who would repent of the grave wrong done to a great country by his ancestors.
('41', 421, 1, 5, 784242) But instead of repentance, we see a painful persistence in the policy initiated 150 years ago and an equally painful effort made by every means possible to bolster up the wrong.
('41', 421, 1, 6, 784420) Young India, 19 4 1928

('41', 422, 5, 6, 784937) I have your letter.
('41', 422, 5, 7, 784957) I am daily making fresh discoveries which go to show that we may expect nothing from the mill owners at the present stage.
('41', 422, 5, 8, 785080) They will yeild only to pressure and the pressure of the Government is more felt than that of the Congress.
('41', 422, 5, 9, 785188) But we may not be impatient.
('41', 422, 5, 10, 785217) We need not put boycott of Indian mill made cloth in the same category as that of foreign cloth.
('41', 422, 5, 11, 785314) A negative attitude about mill cloth will be quite enough to keep the mills under wholesome check.

('41', 422, 5, 18, 786177) That will be the time for our mills to come in line with us.
('41', 422, 5, 19, 786238) The moment they do so we can complete boycott of foreign cloth inside of six months.
('41', 422, 5, 20, 786323) The programme definitely therefore has to be this : We leave Indian mills severely alone.
('41', 422, 5, 21, 786413) We carry on a whirl wind compaign for boycott of foreign cloth through khadi, asking people to count no sacrifice too great in adopting khadi.
('41', 422, 5, 22, 786556) We must have faith in ourselves and in our people and believe that they can make this which appears to me to be small sacrifice.

('41', 423, 1, 2, 786952) concentrate on any constructive work.

('41', 423, 1, 4, 787238) There is no organization behind it, there is no will working behind it.
('41', 423, 1, 5, 787310) All things considered, what will you advise me to do?

('41', 430, 9, 13, 795803) WORKING MEN 4
('41', 430, 10, 14, 795817) Sheth Ranchhodlal Amritlal has sent me the following scheme 5
('41', 430, 11, 15, 795879) of Industrial Insurance for clerks : I understand little of insurance, but I take it that in this age of insurance any scheme of industrial insurance devised for the benefit of the clerical workers would be to their good.
('41', 430, 11, 16, 796101) Only an insurance expert can offer helpful criticism of the scheme, and I take it that Sjt.
('41', 430, 11, 17, 796193) Ranchhodlal has framed the scheme in consultation with some large hearted expert.
('41', 430, 11, 18, 796275) There cannot be two opinions as to the fact that mill owners, no less than other business and commercial firms, ought to take a paternal interest in the welfare of their employees.
('41', 430, 11, 19, 796456) The relations between the employer and the employee have been up to now merely those of the master and servant, they should be of father and children.
('41', 430, 11, 20, 796607) I therefore welcome the scheme.

('41', 431, 1, 2, 797146) Medical relief should not, in my opinion, be free.
('41', 431, 1, 3, 797197) It should be genuine, prompt and cheap.
('41', 431, 1, 4, 797237) Free aid is likely to undermine their independent spirit.
('41', 431, 1, 5, 797295) Sometimes free aid is rendered perfunctorily and sometimes it is abused, from both of which evils the clerks should be saved.
('41', 431, 1, 6, 797421) The main grievance of the clerk and the working man is low pay and indifference to his welfafre.
('41', 431, 1, 7, 797518) The measures suggested in the scheme will be a direct and simple redress of the grievance, and I welcome them.
('41', 431, 1, 8, 797629) The condition of clerks is, in certain respects, undoubtedly much more pitiable.
('41', 431, 1, 9, 797710) I have a vivid picture of their condition before my mind.
('41', 431, 1, 10, 797768) It was given to me in 1915 in Calcutta by the Marwari Clerks’ Associa tion.
('41', 431, 1, 11, 797844) It was a tragic tale of their helplessness.
('41', 431, 1, 12, 797888) The number of clerks is small, their power of endurance and their capacity for union is feeble.
('41', 431, 1, 13, 797984) Whereas the clerk is the only earning member of his family, practically all the members of the workingman’s family are wage earners.
('41', 431, 1, 14, 798117) The clerks must bestir themselves to improve their own condition.
('41', 431, 1, 15, 798183) They must unite, and must educate their dependants, especially their wives, to engage in some gainful occupation.
('41', 431, 1, 16, 798297) They have lost all self confidence and are helpless.
('41', 431, 1, 17, 798350) Those who are honest, competent in their work, conscien tious and hard working need not despair of finding a suitable situation.
('41', 431, 1, 18, 798479) True social economics will teach us that the workingman, the clerk and the employer are parts of the same indivisible organism.
('41', 431, 1, 19, 798607) None is smaller or greater than the other.
('41', 431, 1, 20, 798650) Their interests should be not conflicting but identical and interdependent.

('41', 432, 1, 2, 798790) 498. LETTER TO ELISABETH KNUDSEN
('41', 432, 2, 3, 798823) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 22, 1928
('41', 432, 3, 4, 798861) DEAR MISS KNUDSEN, I was wondering why I have not heard from you for such a long time.
('41', 432, 3, 5, 798948) I am glad you have been having such success in Karachi.
('41', 432, 3, 6, 799004) Owing to the National Week I suspended both the oil massage and your massage, and owing to pressure of work since, I have not been able to resume them.
('41', 432, 3, 7, 799156) But in spite of the suspension I increased nearly two lb.
('41', 432, 3, 8, 799214) in weight.
('41', 432, 3, 9, 799225) As soon as the pressure decreases I hope to recommence massage.
('41', 432, 3, 10, 799289) Gangabehn is neither better nor worse.
('41', 432, 3, 11, 799328) For the last two days she has been having some fever.
('41', 432, 3, 12, 799382) The Calcutta patient left about ten days ago.
('41', 432, 3, 13, 799428) Mr. Kothari is in Darjeeling at the present moment.
('41', 432, 4, 14, 799480) Yours sincerely, MISS ELISABETH KNUDSEN C/O DR.
('41', 432, 4, 15, 799528) THIRANANDANI “NEW TIMES” BLDGS.
('41', 432, 4, 16, 799560) KARACHI
('41', 432, 5, 17, 799568) From a photostat: S.N. 13201
('41', 432, 6, 18, 799597) 499. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('41', 432, 7, 19, 799626) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 22, 1928 You will be perhaps sorry to hear that I have decided not to go to Europe this year.
('41', 432, 7, 20, 799749) There was not call for me to go in answer to the various invitations, but I felt that, if Rolland considered it worth while my going to meet him in furtherance of the common cause, I would go and incidentally respond to invitations from Europe.
('41', 432, 7, 21, 799994) Now there is the expected letter from him.
('41', 432, 7, 22, 800037) I send you a copy so that you can better understand my decision.
('41', 432, 7, 23, 800102) Rolland’s hesitation to let me go to Europe principally for the sake of meeting him shows that as an artist and as the interpreter of my message he does not regard it as necessary that I should leave all my important work here and go to Europe to meet him.
('41', 432, 7, 24, 800359) And as there is no call in him to ask me to go or to accept my
('41', 433, 0, 1, 800422) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 433, 1, 2, 800464) offer to go, I feel that if my letter to him was truthful, that is to say, if the deciding motive was to see him, I should consider his letter to be God’s guidance in answer to my prayer.
('41', 433, 1, 3, 800652) As days went by I was hardening my heart feeling more reluctant to go to Europe at the present moment and was feeling also that I had nothing to give to Europe, whereas my hands were absolutely full here.
('41', 433, 1, 4, 800857) The call of the Ashram is incessant.
('41', 433, 1, 5, 800894) It is becoming clearer day by day that if I am to do justice to the Ashram, which I claim to be my best creation, and if I cannot give it the whole of my time, I must at least give to it the major part of my time.
('41', 433, 1, 6, 801108) I had Burma in my mind if I did not go to Europe.
('41', 433, 1, 7, 801158) But now I feel that I don’t want to go to Burma either and I shall pass the summer in the Ashram, if Burma does not want me.
('41', 433, 1, 8, 801283) The heat does not trouble me.
('41', 433, 1, 9, 801313) I am getting on quite well.
('41', 433, 1, 10, 801341) And, of course, there are many other things which I can attend to if I am here.
('41', 433, 1, 11, 801421) On the whole, therefore, I think that I must not go.
('41', 433, 1, 12, 801474) But I can make this provisional decision that if everything goes well, I would go next year giving myself ample time from now to make all my preparations and dispositions so that I can go without difficulty, and then, perhaps, if I could do so and if the way is clear, taking America also to save time.
('41', 433, 1, 13, 801777) I had a long chat with Ambalal.
('41', 433, 1, 14, 801809) He said that he had sent his own subscription but that he could not move further unless there was a proper balance sheet published.
('41', 433, 1, 15, 801941) He was dissatisfied with the account keeping and he seemed to be keen on a Gujarati committee because he said that the bulk of the money was found by the Gujaratis.
('41', 433, 1, 16, 802106) So far as I could see I could not move him in his decision.
('41', 433, 1, 17, 802166) But he said that in giving his opinion he was more guided by other donors than by his own instinct.
('41', 433, 1, 18, 802266) Marichi described to me the condition of your teeth or rather your toothlessness.
('41', 433, 1, 19, 802348) To be toothless is by no means a great deprivation and it is decidedly a gain when one’s teeth are a source of disease rather than of health.
('41', 433, 1, 20, 802490) Remember that you have to finish the Shraddhanand series.
('41', 433, 1, 21, 802548) You should write something on Gregg’s book.
('41', 433, 1, 22, 802592) I hope Gurudev is much better now.
('41', 433, 2, 23, 802627) From a photostat: S.N. 14958
('41', 434, 0, 1, 802656) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 435

('41', 435, 1, 2, 803325) 502. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('41', 435, 2, 3, 803358) Sunday [Before April 23, 1928]
('41', 435, 3, 4, 803389) CHHAGANLAL,
('41', 435, 4, 5, 803401) Bhai Ramlal is a very good worker.
('41', 435, 4, 6, 803436) He is honest too, but is very short tempered.
('41', 435, 4, 7, 803482) As an atonement for this, I am sending him to you.
('41', 435, 4, 8, 803533) He has to serve you and do all the work you entrust to him.
('41', 435, 4, 9, 803593) He has liked the work.
('41', 435, 4, 10, 803616) If you do not like the arrangement or instead of finding his presence helpful, you find it burdensome, write to me.
('41', 435, 4, 11, 803732) I will call him back.
('41', 435, 4, 12, 803754) As you have difficulty in getting milk and milk products, I am sending pedas 4 from here.
('41', 435, 4, 13, 803844) Do not eat them as pedas but make powder of one or two, add warm water to it and mix it.
('41', 435, 4, 14, 803933) That will become milk and serve its purpose.
('41', 435, 4, 15, 803978) Similarly, soak gol papadi 5 in water, make gruel of the liquid and take it .
('41', 435, 4, 16, 804056) If you like the preparations, ask for the amount you would like to have.
('41', 435, 4, 17, 804129) Do not neglect your health.
('41', 435, 4, 18, 804157) Do not hesitate to write to me about your health and other difficulties.
('41', 435, 5, 19, 804230) Blessings from BAPU
('41', 435, 6, 20, 804250) From the Gujarati original: S.N. 32861
('41', 436, 0, 1, 804289) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 437
('41', 436, 1, 2, 804331) 503. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('41', 436, 2, 3, 804364) Tuesday [Before April 23, 1929] 1
('41', 436, 3, 4, 804398) CHHAGANLAL,
('41', 436, 4, 5, 804410) I have received your telegrams.
('41', 436, 4, 6, 804442) Knowing you well, I was not at all upset by your telegram.
('41', 436, 4, 7, 804501) The other telegrams proved your faith right.
('41', 436, 4, 8, 804546) As long as I am destined to take work from you, no harm will come to you.
('41', 436, 4, 9, 804620) I personally feel that you should not leave Utkal.
('41', 436, 4, 10, 804671) I would not like you to leave the place after falling ill.
('41', 436, 4, 11, 804730) Many old priests live there.
('41', 436, 4, 12, 804759) Where could they go?
('41', 436, 4, 13, 804780) We belong to the place as much as we belong to the Ashram or Rajkot.
('41', 436, 4, 14, 804849) After improving your health in Calcutta, if you feel strong enough to go back, do so.
('41', 436, 4, 15, 804935) I have sent Ramlalji with that hope.
('41', 436, 4, 16, 804972) Do not feel self conscious unnecessarily, ask for the facilities you need, look after your health and render service.
('41', 436, 4, 17, 805090) However, these are my views.
('41', 436, 4, 18, 805119) Do what you want and what is within your power.
('41', 436, 4, 19, 805167) My duty is to encourage you and your duty is to imbibe from it what you can.
('41', 436, 4, 20, 805244) There is so much to write but where is the time?
('41', 436, 5, 21, 805293) Blessings from BAPU
('41', 436, 6, 22, 805313) From the Gujarati original: S.N. 32859
('41', 436, 7, 23, 805352) 1 From the reference to Gandhiji’s advice to the addressee not to leave Utkal (Orissa), the letter appears to have been written before the letter to Maganlal Gandhi dated April 23, 1928, wherein Gandhiji wrote that the addressee “had left Orissa” as he fell ill and had gone to Almora

('41', 437, 1, 2, 805679) 504. LETTER TO RADHA GANDHI
('41', 437, 2, 3, 805707) [Before April 23, 1928] 1
('41', 437, 3, 4, 805733) RADHIKA,
('41', 437, 4, 5, 805742) I understand your condition from your letters to me and to others which they give me to read.
('41', 437, 4, 6, 805836) Everybody will feel reassured if you keep on writing like this.
('41', 437, 4, 7, 805900) I have received letters from Bhai Ramnandan also in which he says he will take proper care of you.
('41', 437, 4, 8, 805999) There is a letter from Brij Kishore Babu from Patna, in which also he says that he will go to your village 2 and arrange everything.
('41', 437, 4, 9, 806132) You have to show courage.
('41', 437, 4, 10, 806158) You should not, therefore, be disheartened by difficulties but should overcome them with patience and bear those that cannot be overcome.
('41', 437, 4, 11, 806296) Do let me know of even the smallest difficulty.
('41', 437, 4, 12, 806344) You must not lose heart.
('41', 437, 4, 13, 806369) One of the purposes in sending you out is that you should have some experience of the world and be tested by it.
('41', 437, 4, 14, 806482) We may also in this way have a measure of our strength and weakness.
('41', 437, 4, 15, 806551) In this vast land of ours there are countless ways of living and all kinds of hardships.
('41', 437, 4, 16, 806640) We have to live in the midst of all this and reform things wherever there is scope for reform; look at the thing in this light.
('41', 437, 4, 17, 806768) Nothing is decided as yet about my going to England.
('41', 437, 5, 18, 806821) Blessings from BAPU
('41', 437, 6, 19, 806841) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G. N. 11617
('41', 437, 7, 20, 806887) 1 The letter has “April, 1928” noted on it.
('41', 437, 7, 21, 806931) It must have been written before the addressee’s return to the Ashram following the death of her father Maganlal Gandhi at Patna on April 23, 1928 2 The addressee had gone to Bihar to teach a Bihari girl.

('41', 438, 1, 2, 807178) 505. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI April 23, 1928
('41', 438, 2, 3, 807235) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, As I write this letter, I have before me a telegram from Patna informing me that Maganlal is on his death bed.
('41', 438, 2, 4, 807367) Radha is there by chance.
('41', 438, 2, 5, 807393) The friends at Patna are doing their best for him.
('41', 438, 2, 6, 807444) Any moment there may be a telegram about his passing away.
('41', 438, 2, 7, 807503) What mystery of God’s will is this, that he whom I regard as my heir is preparing to go away, leaving his inheritance?
('41', 438, 2, 8, 807622) If only all of you who remain behind could follow in Maganlal’s footsteps!
('41', 438, 2, 9, 807697) I get the letters of both of you.
('41', 438, 2, 10, 807731) Wayne must have given you my message.
('41', 438, 2, 11, 807769) I think I have already informed you that he met me.
('41', 438, 2, 12, 807821) Ramdas is still in Kathiawar hawking khadi.
('41', 438, 2, 13, 807865) He should return in four or five days.
('41', 438, 2, 14, 807904) Chhaganlal fell ill and has, therefore, left Orissa and gone to Almora.
('41', 438, 2, 15, 807976) Prabhudas is already there on grounds of health.
('41', 438, 2, 16, 808025) But now he is doing khadi work all the time.
('41', 438, 2, 17, 808070) I want a sample of Sushila’s English handwriting and language.
('41', 438, 2, 18, 808133) What is her weight now?
('41', 438, 2, 19, 808157) What painting is she engaged on at present?
('41', 438, 2, 20, 808201) If Sorabji spends beyond his means, do not forget your duty, as a friend, of restraining him.
('41', 438, 2, 21, 808295) Never take advantage of his spend thrift nature.
('41', 438, 2, 22, 808344) Always remain within the bounds of propriety.
('41', 438, 2, 23, 808390) I have dropped for the present the idea of going to Europe.
('41', 438, 3, 24, 808450) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] I have just received a telegram saying that God has taken away Maganlal.
('41', 438, 5, 25, 808549) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 4736

('41', 442, 3, 4, 810774) KUNVERJI, I have your letter.
('41', 442, 3, 5, 810804) Consider with Jaisukhlal what should be done if the work at Balara stops.
('41', 442, 3, 6, 810878) I did not understand your intention in the last paragraph.
('41', 442, 3, 7, 810937) If however you have an offer of a better paid job and you feel inclined to accept it, I will not force you to remain in the khadi work.
('41', 442, 3, 8, 811073) If you remain in khadi work, you should do so merely in a spirit of service an without any thought of money, as Ramdas does.

('41', 442, 3, 10, 811263) I certainly like your work.
('41', 442, 3, 11, 811291) Personally, I should like to keep you in the Ashram.
('41', 442, 3, 12, 811344) But a proposal is under discussion just now that only those who observe brahmacharya should be allowed to live in the Ashram.
('41', 442, 3, 13, 811470) Nothing has been decided finally.
('41', 442, 3, 14, 811504) But I believe that there would be no difficulty in fixing you up at some other place if not in the Ashram.

('41', 443, 5, 10, 812145) 515. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('41', 443, 6, 11, 812176) Sunday [After April 23, 1928] 2
('41', 443, 7, 12, 812208) NARANDAS, I have received all your three letters.
('41', 443, 7, 13, 812258) l am unhappy that you are so very unhappy.
('41', 443, 7, 14, 812301) Till today, I never worried on your account.
('41', 443, 7, 15, 812346) I had assumed that you would neither feel hurt nor would misunderstand me.
('41', 443, 7, 16, 812421) Now you have felt a little hurt.
('41', 443, 7, 17, 812454) I assume that it will only be momentary.
('41', 443, 7, 18, 812495) About Radha and Santok, do as you think best.
('41', 443, 7, 19, 812541) I withdraw my opposition.
('41', 443, 7, 20, 812567) I have sent two letters to that effect to Chhaganlal regarding Santok and Radha.
('41', 443, 7, 21, 812648) I have written to him about Sanabhai also.
('41', 443, 7, 22, 812691) I have also asked him why, after deciding to keep him, he changed his mind.
('41', 443, 7, 23, 812767) You may pour out all your sufferings to me but never lose your self possession.
('41', 443, 7, 24, 812847) I do not have more time today.
('41', 443, 8, 25, 812878) Blessings from BAPU
('41', 443, 9, 26, 812898) From the Gujarati original S.N. 33325
('41', 443, 10, 27, 812936) 1 Radhabehn Chaudhri states that this letter was written shortly after Maganlal Gandhi’s death on April 23, 1928. 2 From the nature of reference to Santok and Radha, wife and daughter respectively of Maganlal Gandhi, addressee’s elder brother, the letter appears to have been written after the death of Maganlal in Patna on April 23, 1928. vide also the following item.

('41', 444, 1, 2, 813348) 516. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('41', 444, 2, 3, 813381) Tuesday [After April 23, 1928] 1
('41', 444, 3, 4, 813414) CHHAGANLAL, What shall I write to you?
('41', 444, 3, 5, 813453) Improve your health.
('41', 444, 3, 6, 813474) There is no urgency for going to Utkal.
('41', 444, 3, 7, 813514) Whenever you decide to go, do see me before going.
('41', 444, 3, 8, 813565) Kashi herself, at the moment, does not feel strong enough to go there.
('41', 444, 3, 9, 813636) Both of us believe that she will not be able to bear the cold there.

('41', 444, 3, 11, 813753) The very next day of [Maganlal’s] death, I started a movement that Santok should give away whatever property she has.

('41', 449, 7, 9, 818734) 524. MY BEST COMRADE GONE He whom I had singled out as heir to my all is no more.
('41', 449, 7, 10, 818816) Maganlal K. Gandhi, a grandson of an uncle of mine had been with me in my work since 1904. Maganlal’s father has given all his boys to the cause.
('41', 449, 7, 11, 818962) The deceased went early this month to Bengal with Seth Jamnalalji and others, contracted a high fever whilst he was on duty in Bihar and died under the protecting care of Brijkishore Prasad in Patna after an illness of nine days and after receiving all the devoted nursing that love and skill could give.
('41', 449, 7, 12, 819267) Maganlal Gandhi went with me to South Africa in 1903 in the hope of making a bit of fortune.
('41', 449, 7, 13, 819360) But hardly had he been store keeping for one year, when he responded to my sudden call to self imposed poverty, joined the Phoenix settlement and never once faltered or failed after so joining me.
('41', 449, 7, 14, 819557) If he had not dedicated himself to the country’s service, his undoubted abilities and indefatigable industry would have made him a merchant prince.
('41', 449, 7, 15, 819705) Put in a printing press he easily and quickly mastered the secrets of the art of printing.
('41', 449, 7, 16, 819796) Though he had never before handled a tool or a machine, he found himself at home in the engine room, the machine room and at the compositor’s desk.
('41', 449, 7, 17, 819944) He was equally at ease with the Gujarati editing of the Indian Opinion.
('41', 449, 7, 18, 820016) Since the Phoenix scheme included domestic farming, he became a good farmer.
('41', 449, 7, 19, 820093) His was I think the best garden at the settlement.
('41', 449, 7, 20, 820144) It may be of interest to note that the very first issue of Young India published in Ahmedabad bears the marks of his labours when they were much needed.
('41', 449, 8, 21, 820297) 1 This was sent in reply to the following telegram from C. Rajagopalachari: “Jamnalalji gone Patna.
('41', 449, 8, 22, 820397) Returning tomorrow.
('41', 449, 8, 23, 820417) You may resent suggestion but prayerfully press your going Europe now leaving scene of desolation in Jamnalalji’s hands who must postpone pilgrimage remain Ashram.
('41', 449, 8, 24, 820581) Wire reply Martaluminium.”
('41', 450, 0, 1, 820608) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 451
('41', 450, 1, 2, 820650) He had a sturdy constitution which he wore away in advancing the cause to which he had dedicated himself.
('41', 450, 1, 3, 820756) He closely studied and followed my spiritual career and when I presented to my co workers brahmacharya as a rule of life even for married men in search of Truth, he was the first to perceive the beauty and the necessity of the practice and, though it cost him to my knowledge a terrific struggle, he carried it through to success, taking his wife along with him by patient argument instead of imposing his views on her.
('41', 450, 1, 4, 821176) When satyagraha was born, he was in the forefront.
('41', 450, 1, 5, 821227) He gave me the expression which I was striving to find to give its full meaning to what the South African struggle stood for, and which for want of a better term I allowed to be recognized by the very insufficient and even misleading term “passive resistance”.
('41', 450, 1, 6, 821488) I wish I had the very beautiful letter he then wrote to me giving his reasons for suggesting the name ‚ŒÊª˝„U which I changed to ‚àÿÊª˝„U. 1 He argued out the whole philosophy of the struggle step by step and brought the reader irresistibly to his chosen name.
('41', 450, 1, 7, 821749) The letter I remember was incredibly short and to the point as all his communications always were.
('41', 450, 1, 8, 821848) During the struggle he was never weary of work, shirked no task and by his intrepidity he infected everyone around him with courage and hope.
('41', 450, 1, 9, 821990) When everyone went to jail, when at Phoenix courting imprisonment was like a prize to be won at my instance, he stayed back in order to shoulder a much heavier task.
('41', 450, 1, 10, 822156) He sent his wife to join the women’s party.
('41', 450, 1, 11, 822200) On our return to India, it was he again who made it possible to found the Ashram in the austere manner in which it was founded.
('41', 450, 1, 12, 822328) Here he was called to a newer and more difficult task.
('41', 450, 1, 13, 822383) He proved equal to it.
('41', 450, 1, 14, 822406) Untouchability was a very severe trial for him.
('41', 450, 1, 15, 822454) Just for one brief moment his heart seemed to give way.
('41', 450, 1, 16, 822510) But it was only for a second.
('41', 450, 1, 17, 822540) He saw that love had no bounds and that it was necessary to live down the ways of ‘untouchables’, if only because the so called higher castes were responsible for them.
('41', 450, 1, 18, 822709) The mechanical department of the Ashram was not a continuation of the Phoenix activity.
('41', 450, 1, 19, 822797) Here we had to learn weaving, spinning, carding, and ginning.
('41', 450, 1, 20, 822859) Again I turned to Maganlal.
('41', 450, 1, 21, 822887) Though the conception was mine, his were the hands to reduce it to execution.
('41', 450, 1, 22, 822965) He learnt weaving and all the other processes that cotton had to go through before it became khadi.
('41', 450, 1, 23, 823065) He was a born mechanic.
('41', 450, 2, 24, 823089) 1 Vide “Satyagraha in South Africa (Chapter XII: The Advent of Satyagraha)”.
('41', 451, 0, 1, 823166) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 451, 1, 2, 823208) When dairying was introduced in the Ashram he threw himself with zeal in the work, studied dairy literature, named every cow and became friends with every animal 1 on the settlement.
('41', 451, 1, 3, 823391) And when tannery was added, he was undaunted and had proposed to learn the principles of tanning as soon as he got a little breathing time.
('41', 451, 1, 4, 823531) Apart from his scholastic training in the High School at Rajkot, he learnt the many things he knew so well in the school of hard experience.
('41', 451, 1, 5, 823672) He gathered knowledge from village carpenters, village weavers, farmers, shepherds and such ordinary folk.
('41', 451, 1, 6, 823779) He was the Director of the Technical Department of the Spin ners’ Association, and during the recent floods in Gujarat, Vallabh bhai put him in charge of building the new township Vithalpur.
('41', 451, 1, 7, 823970) He was an exemplary father.
('41', 451, 1, 8, 823998) He trained his children—one boy and two girls, all unmarried still—so as to make them fit for dedication to the country.
('41', 451, 1, 9, 824119) His son Keshu is showing very great ability in mechanical engineering, all of which he has picked up like his father from seeing ordinary carpenters and smiths at work.
('41', 451, 1, 10, 824288) His eldest daughter Radha, eighteen years old, recently shouldered a difficult and delicate mission to Bihar in the interest of women’s freedom.
('41', 451, 1, 11, 824433) Indeed he had a good grasp of what national education should be and often engaged the teachers in earnest and critical discussion over it.
('41', 451, 1, 12, 824572) Let not the reader imagine that he knew nothing of politics.
('41', 451, 1, 13, 824633) He did, but he chose the path of silent, selfless constructive service.
('41', 451, 1, 14, 824705) He was my hands, my feet and my eyes.
('41', 451, 1, 15, 824743) The world knows so little of how much my so called greatness depends upon the incessant toil and drudgery of silent, devoted, able and pure workers, men as well as women.
('41', 451, 1, 16, 824914) And among them all Maganlal was to me the greatest, the best and the purest.
('41', 451, 1, 17, 824991) As I am penning these lines, I hear the sobs of the widow bewailing the death of her dear husband.
('41', 451, 1, 18, 825090) Little does she realize that I am more widowed than she.
('41', 451, 1, 19, 825147) And but for a living faith in God, I should become a raving maniac for the loss of one who was dearer to me than my own sons, who never once deceived me or failed me, who was a personification of industry, who was the watchdog of the Ashram in all its aspects—material, moral and spiritual.
('41', 451, 1, 20, 825438) His life is an inspiration for me, a standing demonstration of the efficacy and the supremacy of the moral law.
('41', 451, 1, 21, 825550) In his own life he proved visibly for me
('41', 451, 2, 22, 825591) 1 The source has “cattle”.

('41', 452, 1, 2, 825660) not for a few days, not for a few months, but for twenty four long years—now alas all too short—that service of the country, service of humanity and self realization or knowledge of God are synonymous terms.
('41', 452, 1, 3, 825868) Maganlal is dead, but he lives in his work whose imprints he who runs may read on every particle of dust in the Ashram.
