('41', 452, 2, 5, 826011) 525. A MORAL STRUGGLE
('41', 452, 3, 6, 826033) I am a husband aged 30. My wife is about the same age.
('41', 452, 3, 7, 826088) We have five children, of which two are fortunately dead.
('41', 452, 3, 8, 826146) I know the responsibility for the rest of our children.
('41', 452, 3, 9, 826202) But I find it difficult, if not impossible, to discharge that responsibility.
('41', 452, 3, 10, 826280) You have advised self restraint.
('41', 452, 3, 11, 826313) Well, I have practised it for the last three years, but that is very much against my partner’s wish.
('41', 452, 3, 12, 826414) She insists on what poor mortals call the joys of life.
('41', 452, 3, 13, 826470) You from your superior height may call it a sin.
('41', 452, 3, 14, 826519) But my partner does not see it in that light.
('41', 452, 3, 15, 826565) Nor is she afraid of bearing more children to me.
('41', 452, 3, 16, 826615) She has not the sense of responsibility that I flatter myself with the belief I have.
('41', 452, 3, 17, 826701) My parents side more with my wife than with me and there are daily quarrels.
('41', 452, 3, 18, 826778) The denial of satisfaction to my wife has made her so peevish and so irritable that she flares up on the slightest pretext.
('41', 452, 3, 19, 826902) My problem now is how to solve the difficulty.
('41', 452, 3, 20, 826949) The children I have are too many for me.
('41', 452, 3, 21, 826990) I am too poor to support them.
('41', 452, 3, 22, 827021) The wife seems utterly irreconcilable.
('41', 452, 3, 23, 827060) If she does not have the satisfaction she demands, she may even go astray or go mad or commit suicide.
('41', 452, 3, 24, 827163) I tell you, sometimes I feel that if the law of the land permitted it, I would shoot down all unwanted children as you would stray dogs.
('41', 452, 3, 25, 827300) For the last three months I have gone without the second meal, without tiffin.
('41', 452, 3, 26, 827379) I have business obligation which prevent me from fasting for days.
('41', 452, 3, 27, 827446) I get no compassion from the wife because she cosiders I am a humbug.
('41', 452, 3, 28, 827516) I know the literature on birth control.
('41', 452, 3, 29, 827556) It is temptingly written.
('41', 452, 3, 30, 827582) And I have read your book on self restraint.
('41', 452, 3, 31, 827627) I find myself between the devil and the deep blue sea.
('41', 452, 4, 32, 827682) The foregoing is a faithful paraphrase of a heart rending letter from a young man who has given me his full name and address and whom I have known for some years.
('41', 452, 4, 33, 827845) Being afraid to give his name, he
('41', 453, 0, 1, 827879) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 453, 1, 2, 827921) tells me he wrote twice before anonymously hoping that I would deal with his communications in the pages of Young India.
('41', 453, 1, 3, 828042) I receive so many anonymous letters of this type that I hesitate to deal with them, even as I have considerable hesitation in dealing with this letter, although I know it to be perfectly genuine and know it to be a letter from a striving soul.
('41', 453, 1, 4, 828286) The subject matter is so delicate.
('41', 453, 1, 5, 828321) But I see that I may not shirk an obvious duty claiming as I do claim a fair amount of experience of such cases and more especially because my method has given relief in several similar cases.
('41', 453, 1, 6, 828514) The condition in India, so far as English educated Indians are concerned, is doubly difficult.
('41', 453, 1, 7, 828609) The gulf between husband and wife from the point of view of social attainments is almost too wide to be bridgeable.
('41', 453, 1, 8, 828725) Some young men seem to think that they have solved it satisfactorily by simply throwing their wives overboard, although they know that in their caste there is no divorce possible and therefore no remarriage on the part of their wives possible.
('41', 453, 1, 9, 828969) Yet others—and this is the far more numerous class—use their wives merely as vehicles of enjoyment without sharing their intellectual life with them.
('41', 453, 1, 10, 829119) A very small number—but daily growing—has a quickened conscience and are faced with the moral difficulty such as my correspondent is faced with.
('41', 453, 1, 11, 829264) In my opinion, sexual union to be legitimate is permissible only when both the parties desire it.
('41', 453, 1, 12, 829362) I do not recognize the right of either partner to compel satisfaction.
('41', 453, 1, 13, 829433) And if my position is correct in the case in point, there is no more obligation on the part of the husband to yield to the wife’s importunities.
('41', 453, 1, 14, 829578) But this refusal at once throws a much greater and more exalted responsibility on the husband’s shoulders.
('41', 453, 1, 15, 829685) He will not look down upon his wife from his isolent height but will humbly recognize that what to him is not a necessity is to her a fundamental necessity.
('41', 453, 1, 16, 829842) He will therefore treat her with the utmost gentleness and love and will have confidence in his own purity to transmute his partner’s passion into energy of the highest type.
('41', 453, 1, 17, 830017) He will therefore have to become her real friend, guide and physician.
('41', 453, 1, 18, 830088) He will have to give her his fullest confidence and with inexhaustible patience explain to her the moral basis of his action, the true nature of the relationship that should subsist between husband and wife and the true meaning of marriage.
('41', 453, 1, 19, 830329) He will find in the process that many things that were not clear to him before will be clear and he will draw his partner closer to him if his own restraint is truthful.
('41', 453, 1, 20, 830499) In the case in point I cannot help saying that the desire not to
('41', 454, 0, 1, 830564) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 455
('41', 454, 1, 2, 830606) have more children is not enough reason for refusing satisfaction.
('41', 454, 1, 3, 830673) It appears almost cowardly to reject one’s wife’s advances merely for fear of having to support children.
('41', 454, 1, 4, 830779) A check upon an unlimited increase in the family is a good ground for both the parties jointly and individually putting a restraint upon sexual desires, but it is not sufficient warrant for one to refuse the privileges of a common bed to the other.
('41', 454, 1, 5, 831028) And why this impatience of children?
('41', 454, 1, 6, 831065) Surely there is enough scope for honest, hard working and intelligent men to earn enough for a reasonable number of children.
('41', 454, 1, 7, 831191) I admit that for one like my correspondent who is honestly trying to devote his whole time to the service of the country it is difficult to support a large and growing family and at the same time to serve a country, millions of whose children are semi starved.
('41', 454, 1, 8, 831452) I have often expressed the opinion in these pages that it is wrong to bring forth progeny in India so long as she is in bondage.
('41', 454, 1, 9, 831581) But that is a very good reason for young men and young women to abstain from marriage, not a conclusive reason for one partner refusing sexual co operation to the other.
('41', 454, 1, 10, 831751) That co operation can be lawfully refused, it is a duty to refuse, when the call for brahmacharya on the highest ground of pure religion is imperative.
('41', 454, 1, 11, 831903) And when such a call has clearly come, it will have its healthy reaction upon the partner.
('41', 454, 1, 12, 831994) Assuming, however, that it does not produce such reaction in time, it will still be a duty to adhere to restraint even at the risk of losinng the life or the sanity of one’s partner.
('41', 454, 1, 13, 832177) The cause of brahmacharya demands sacrifices no less heroic than, say, the cause of Truth or of one’s country.
('41', 454, 1, 14, 832288) In view of what I have said above, it is hardly necessary to state that artificial control of births is an immoral practice having no place in the conception of life that underlies my argument.
('41', 454, 1, 15, 832482) Young India, 26 4 1928
('41', 455, 0, 1, 832505) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 455, 1, 2, 832547) 526. TO EUROPEAN FRIENDS
('41', 455, 2, 3, 832572) It is not without deep sorrow that I am now able to announce that the much talked of visit of mine to Europe is not to come off this year at any rate.
('41', 455, 2, 4, 832723) To those in Austria, Holland, England, Scotland, Denmark, Sweden, Germany and Russia who had sent me kind invitations I can only say that their disappointment will be no greater than mine.
('41', 455, 2, 5, 832912) Somehow or other I dread a visit to Europe and America.
('41', 455, 2, 6, 832968) Not that I distrust the peoples of these great Continents any more than I distrust my own, but I distrust myself.
('41', 455, 2, 7, 833082) I have no desire to go to the West in search of health or for sightseeing.
('41', 455, 2, 8, 833157) I have no desire to deliver pubic speeches.
('41', 455, 2, 9, 833201) I detest being lionized.
('41', 455, 2, 10, 833226) I wonder if I shall ever again have the health to stand the awful strain of public speaking and public demonstrations.
('41', 455, 2, 11, 833345) If God ever sent me to the West, I should go there to penetrate the hearts of the masses, to have quiet talks with the youth of the West and have the privilege of meeting kindred spirits—lovers of peace at any price save that of Truth.
('41', 455, 2, 12, 833581) But I feel that I have as yet no message to deliver personally to the West.
('41', 455, 2, 13, 833657) I believe my message to be universal but as yet I feel that I can best deliver it through my work in my own country.
('41', 455, 2, 14, 833774) If I can show visible success in India, the delivery of the message becomes complete.
('41', 455, 2, 15, 833860) If I came to the conclusion that India had no use for my message, I should not care to go elsewhere in search of listeners even though I still retained faith in it.
('41', 455, 2, 16, 834025) If, therefore, I ventured out of India, I should do so because I have faith, though I cannot demonstrate it to the satisfaction of all, that the message is being surely received by India be it ever so slowly.
('41', 455, 2, 17, 834234) Thus whilst I was hesitatingly carrying on the correspondence with friends who had invited me, I saw that there was need for me to go to Europe, if only to see M. Romain Rolland.
('41', 455, 2, 18, 834413) Owing to my distrust of myself over a general visit, I wanted to make my visit to that wise man of the West the primary cause of my journey to Europe.
('41', 455, 2, 19, 834564) I therefore referred my difficulty to him and asked him in the frankest manner possible whether he would let me make my desire to meet him the primary cause of my visit to Europe.
('41', 455, 2, 20, 834744) In reply I have a noble letter from him through Mirabai (Miss Slade) wherein he says that in the
('41', 456, 0, 1, 834841) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 457
('41', 456, 1, 2, 834883) name of truth itself, he will not think of letting me go to Europe if a visit to him is to be the primary cause.
('41', 456, 1, 3, 834996) He will not let me interrupt my labours here for the sake of our meeting.
('41', 456, 1, 4, 835070) I read in his letter no false humility.
('41', 456, 1, 5, 835110) I read in it a most genuine expression of truth.
('41', 456, 1, 6, 835159) He knew when he wrote his reply that my desire to go to Europe to meet him was not for a mere courteous discussion but in the interest of the cause as dear to him as to me.
('41', 456, 1, 7, 835332) But evidently he was too humble to bear the burden of calling me merely so that in furtherance of the common interest we might by mutual talks understand each other better.
('41', 456, 1, 8, 835505) And I wanted him to shoulder that very burden, if he felt that truth required us to meet each other face to face.
('41', 456, 1, 9, 835619) His reply therefore I have taken as a clear answer to my prayer.
('41', 456, 1, 10, 835684) Apart from this visit, I felt within me no imperative call.
('41', 456, 1, 11, 835744) I have taken the public into my confidence as, against my wish, the fact that a visit to Europe during this season was under serious contemplation was published in the papers.
('41', 456, 1, 12, 835920) I regret my decision but it seems to be the correct one.
('41', 456, 1, 13, 835977) For whilst there is no urge within to go to Europe, there is an incessant call within for so much to do here.
('41', 456, 1, 14, 836087) And now the death of my best comrade seems to keep me rooted to the Ashram.
('41', 456, 1, 15, 836163) But I my say to the many friends in Europe, that next year, if all is well and if they still will have me I shall try to undertake the postponed tour, under the strict limitations mentioned by me and this I shall do whether I am ready to deliver my message or not.
('41', 456, 1, 16, 836428) To see my numerous friends face to face will be no small privilege.
('41', 456, 1, 17, 836496) But let me conclude this personal explanation by saying that if ever I am privileged to visit the West, I shall go there without changing my dress or habits, save in so far as the climate may require a change and self imposed restrictions may permit.
('41', 456, 1, 18, 836747) My outward form is I hope an expression of the inward.
('41', 456, 1, 19, 836802) Young India, 26 4 1928
('41', 457, 0, 1, 836825) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 457, 1, 2, 836867) 527. FOUR MONTHS’ WORK
('41', 457, 2, 3, 836890) The Vaishya Vidyashram, Sasavane, which started the consturctive programme in right earnest last year has sent the following report 1 of work during four months ending Chaitra : The foregoing resume of four months’ increasing work is proof, if proof be still necessary, of what earnest effort can do.
('41', 457, 2, 4, 837191) Where the wheel is reported to have failed, it was not the wheel that failed, but the wheel mesters that failed because they had no faith.
('41', 457, 2, 5, 837330) Schoolboy all the world over will respond to honest endeavour as the boys of the Sasavane Ashram have done.
('41', 457, 2, 6, 837438) And from the figures that are published from time to time in these columns, anyone who cares can work out an arithmetical calculation showing how many children working, say, at least one hour per day at the weel or the takli can spin enough yarn to clothe the whole nation.
('41', 457, 2, 7, 837712) Oh for an imagination that will visualize the simple beauty of the wheel as a sure solvent of the economic distress or the country!
('41', 457, 3, 8, 837844) Young India, 26 4 1928
('41', 457, 4, 9, 837867) 1 Not reproduced here

('41', 462, 3, 4, 843071) DEAR MR. PETIT, Whilst I was thinking of applying to you for a contribution for the expenses I am incurring in connection with the position of emigrants abroad, I received a long confidential cablegram from the Rt.

('41', 462, 3, 11, 843787) Totaramji gives his spare time to teaching Hindi to the children in the Ashram.

('41', 462, 3, 15, 844146) I am managing all the expenses connected with Ashram activities through the generosity of private friends, but I think that the expenses on account of activity in connection with the emigrants should be borne by the Association.
('41', 462, 3, 16, 844375) I would therefore like you to consider this letter as if it was divided into two parts, the first with reference to the general expenses which in my books amount to roughly Rs. 5,000 to date.

('41', 463, 6, 8, 845252) 535. LETTER TO JUGALKISHORE
('41', 463, 7, 9, 845280) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 27, 1928
('41', 463, 8, 10, 845318) MY DEAR JUGALKISHORE, I was glad to receive your letter after such a long absence.
('41', 463, 8, 11, 845401) I was wondering how you were faring at the P. M. V. 1
('41', 463, 9, 12, 845455) My plan about the spinners’ register is not half as ambitious as you think, though we cannot be too accurate nor too insistent on every worker coming in the closest touch with the spinners and yet, strange as it may appear though we represent spinners above everybody else, our workers are least in touch with them!
('41', 463, 9, 13, 845771) But even if we do not come in such close contact with them and understand their lives as we understand our blood sisters, we should at least know who and where they are, who are supplying us with their yarn.
('41', 463, 9, 14, 845979) I have therefore said that we should trace the residence and names of every spinner whose yarn is received in the bazaar.
('41', 463, 9, 15, 846101) Let us at least have that very rudimentary contact with them.
('41', 463, 9, 16, 846163) This does not require the elaborate register mentioned by Satis Babu in his Manual.
('41', 463, 9, 17, 846247) Even he is not able to enforce that register when he buys yarn at the Feni Bazaar.
('41', 463, 9, 18, 846330) His register was and is in complete operation at his Atrai Dept.
('41', 463, 9, 19, 846395) where he brought into being the spinners for the first time and kept touch with them.
('41', 463, 9, 20, 846481) The largest quantity of yarn however received by him is at
('41', 463, 10, 21, 846540) 1 Prem Mahavidyalaya
('41', 464, 0, 1, 846561) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 465
('41', 464, 1, 2, 846603) the Feni Bazaar.
('41', 464, 1, 3, 846620) My register therefore is really a census register to be taken once for all or periodically.
('41', 464, 1, 4, 846712) You see therefore you do not require the staff suggested by you for my simple measure.
('41', 464, 1, 5, 846799) Nobody has complained that the Gandhi Ashram will not give this list.
('41', 464, 1, 6, 846869) I think I saw the argument advanced by Dhiren about the difficulty of tracing every spinner and I wrote combating that argument and showing a way out of the difficulty.
('41', 464, 1, 7, 847038) The difficulty raised by Dhiren was not raised by him alone.
('41', 464, 1, 8, 847099) It is a difficulty common to almost all and all are gradually getting over the difficulty.
('41', 464, 1, 9, 847190) I quite agree with you that in order to establish a living contact with the spinners, we must have women workers.
('41', 464, 1, 10, 847304) Tell Shanti Devi I would like her to make a start.
('41', 464, 1, 11, 847355) Now about your scheme.
('41', 464, 1, 12, 847378) I like the general idea.
('41', 464, 1, 13, 847403) How far you can give effect to it there, I do not know.
('41', 464, 1, 14, 847459) Because after all you want honest and able teachers who know their work.
('41', 464, 1, 15, 847532) We have not too many as yet.
('41', 464, 1, 16, 847561) But make out your scheme and send it to Jamnalalji unofficially in the first instance and see how it appeals to him.
('41', 464, 1, 17, 847678) Tell me how Bharat is doing there and how spinning is going on among the students.
('41', 464, 1, 18, 847761) By this time you know about Maganlal’s death.
('41', 464, 2, 19, 847807) Yours sincerely,
('41', 464, 3, 20, 847824) From a photostat: S.N. 13204

('41', 466, 1, 2, 849563) this letter which gives you the assurance that throughout your stay with me, there will be no difficulty about your support, and that you would be coming to India at my invitation.

('41', 467, 1, 2, 850875) 539. LETTER TO KALYANJI MEHTA April 28, 1928
('41', 467, 2, 3, 850920) BHAISHRI KALYANJI, You know I cannot attend the Conference.
('41', 467, 2, 4, 850980) I am sorry I cannot, but just now I am helpless.
('41', 467, 2, 5, 851029) The contribution of the Raniparaj men and women to the present movement is as much a matter of satisfaction to us as it is worthy of them.
('41', 467, 2, 6, 851168) I regard this move ment as one for developing fearlessness and for self purification.
('41', 467, 2, 7, 851254) How can they who call themselves Raniparaj live in fear?
('41', 467, 2, 8, 851311) In the sacrificial effort of self purification, how could they afford to have vices like drinking, gambling and wearing foreign cloth?
('41', 467, 2, 9, 851446) I trust, therefore, that the Raniparaj men and women will give increasing importance to the spinning wheel, use more and more khadi and abstain from drinking and give up other vices.
('41', 467, 3, 10, 851629) Vandemataram from MOHANDAS

('41', 467, 5, 12, 851700) 540. THE MEANING OF VOLUNTARY POVERTY 1
('41', 467, 6, 13, 851740) Chhaganlal Joshi is the Secretary to the Managing Committee of the Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati.
('41', 467, 6, 14, 851837) He had a university scholarship for post graduate study in economics and ever since he gave up that scholarship to take part in the non co operation movement he has been in the Ashram.
('41', 467, 6, 15, 852022) About a fortnight ago he had a summons from a first class magistrate to appear as witness in a criminal case.
('41', 467, 6, 16, 852132) The policeman who came to serve the summons behaved most carelessly.
('41', 467, 6, 17, 852201) He came shouting for Chhaganlal Joshi.
('41', 467, 6, 18, 852240) This I heard and directed him to Sjt.
('41', 467, 6, 19, 852278) Chhaganlal Joshi.
('41', 467, 6, 20, 852296) He gave him the summons.
('41', 467, 6, 21, 852321) Chhaganlal asked him to wait until he had read it, but “take it if you care” he said and went away.
('41', 467, 6, 22, 852421) Chhaganlal read out the summons to me.
('41', 467, 6, 23, 852460) He seemed to be knowing nothing about the case, and he did not know what to do.
('41', 467, 6, 24, 852540) He had no time of his own, nor had he any money for railway fare.
('41', 467, 6, 25, 852606) For all his time and money belonged to the Ashram, as every member is
('41', 467, 7, 26, 852676) 1 The Gujarati original of which this is a translation by Mahadev Desai appeared in Navajivan, 29 4 1928.

('41', 468, 1, 2, 852824) supposed to have given his all to the Ashram.
('41', 468, 1, 3, 852870) The money in possession of the Ashram is all public money ear marked by the donors for the purpose for which it exists, and could certainly not be utilized for railway fare to respond to a summons.
('41', 468, 1, 4, 853068) And so Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 5, 853080) Chhaganlal Joshi was in the predicament of the pauper of Orissa, the only difference being that whilst the latter could receive and use for himself whatever others gave him the former could not use a donation except for the purpose of the Ashram.
('41', 468, 1, 6, 853327) Herein lies the beauty as well as the restraint of voluntary poverty.
('41', 468, 1, 7, 853397) What then would an Orissa pauper do if he was served with a sum mons as in this case?
('41', 468, 1, 8, 853483) The policeman had not cared to explain to him the meaning of the summons, nor to pay him the railway fare to enable him to go to the court.
('41', 468, 1, 9, 853623) In the present case the magistrate’s court was some miles away from Ahmedabad near a station on the Prantij line.
('41', 468, 1, 10, 853737) The Oris sa pauper would be absolutely helpless and would not know what to do.
('41', 468, 1, 11, 853816) So Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 12, 853824) Chhaganlal decided to sit still and suffer the consequences.
('41', 468, 1, 13, 853885) Otherwise his voluntary poverty would have no meaning, nor could he serve the poor if he did not behave like them.
('41', 468, 1, 14, 854000) This inevitable inability to respond to the summons was interpreted by the magistrate as contempt of court and he issued a warrant of arrest against Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 15, 854154) The man serving the warrant said: “We will not arrest you, if you promise to attend on the due date.” “I would willingly promise,” said Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 16, 854295) Joshi, “provided I got the railway fare and allowance.” The man had no authority to make the payment and so he produced Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 17, 854420) Joshi before a first class magistrate in Ahmedabad.
('41', 468, 1, 18, 854472) The latter had no time to go into the ase.
('41', 468, 1, 19, 854515) Joshi explained how he failed to obey the summons, but the magistrate trained in the traditions of the bureaucracy said : “I am afraid I can do nothing.
('41', 468, 1, 20, 854668) I am prepared to release you on bail, and you may if you like agitate later on.” If he was prepared to give bail, without getting the fare and the allowance, why should he not have obeyed the original summons?
('41', 468, 1, 21, 854878) The sun was blazing overhead when Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 22, 854917) Joshi was ordered to proceed to the police station.
('41', 468, 1, 23, 854969) He refused any longer to walk and the policemen in charge were compelled to hire a carriage.
('41', 468, 1, 24, 855062) Ultimately Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 25, 855078) Joshi was taken to Talod under a full police escort and produced before the magistrate.
('41', 468, 1, 26, 855166) The moment the magistrate saw Sjt.
('41', 468, 1, 27, 855201) Joshi he
('41', 469, 0, 1, 855210) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 469, 1, 2, 855252) realized his mistake, paid him the fare and allowance and released him on parole.
('41', 469, 1, 3, 855334) It is reported that this simple act of courage had a very good effect on the people of Talod who were greatly delighted.
('41', 469, 1, 4, 855455) Those who have accepted voluntary poverty can by acting in the manner of Chhaganlal Joshi easily hasten the end of the injustice and tyranny that seems today to be the lot of the poor.
('41', 469, 1, 5, 855640) The thoughtless discourtesy of the magistrate in the case was remarkable.
('41', 469, 1, 6, 855714) He issued summons without the least inquiry and having done so did nothing to provide the man summoned with the wherewithal to obey the summons.
('41', 469, 1, 7, 855859) I am told that it is not the practice to pay the witnesses railway fare and allowance in advance.
('41', 469, 1, 8, 855957) If that is the case, it means terrible hardship for the poor.
('41', 469, 1, 9, 856019) The issue of warrant in the case betrayed the magistrate’s criminal negligence.
('41', 469, 1, 10, 856099) He had no evidence of the proper service of the summons.
('41', 469, 1, 11, 856156) He did not care to inquire whether Sjt.
('41', 469, 1, 12, 856196) Joshi had at all received the summons.
('41', 469, 1, 13, 856235) One can only imagine what terrible injustice lies hidden in this Government’s department of “justice”.
('41', 469, 1, 14, 856338) It is difficult to say what would have happened in Talod had Sjt.
('41', 469, 1, 15, 856404) Chhaganlal been the dumb pauper of Orissa.
('41', 469, 1, 16, 856447) What a shower of abuse he might have received and how fiercely the magistrate might have bullied him!
('41', 469, 1, 17, 856549) The man who had been so much sinned against might have been branded as a sinner.
('41', 469, 1, 18, 856630) Though the Government is responsible for this reckless and insolent behaviour towards the poor, one cannot help observing that the Indian officials who behave in this fashion have absolutely no excuse to do so.
('41', 469, 1, 19, 856841) It is possible that this high handedness was there even in pre British days.
('41', 469, 1, 20, 856918) But a wrong does not become right if it can be proved to be pre British.
('41', 469, 1, 21, 856991) And if even Indian officials do not mend their ways, those who have accepted voluntary poverty ought to correct them through satyagraha.

('41', 470, 1, 2, 857192) 541. SOUL OF THE ASHRAM
('41', 470, 2, 3, 857216) When Shri Vallabhbhai received the news of Maganlal Gandhi’s death, he wired: “The soul of the Ashram has departed.” There was no exaggeration in this.
('41', 470, 2, 4, 857368) I cannot imagine the existence of Satyagraha Ashram without Maganlal.
('41', 470, 2, 5, 857438) Many of my activities were started because I knew that he was there.
('41', 470, 2, 6, 857507) If ever there was a person with whom I identified myself, it was Maganlal.
('41', 470, 2, 7, 857582) We often have to consider whether certain matters will hurt another person, even if that person be one’s own son or wife.
('41', 470, 2, 8, 857704) I never had to entertain such fear with regard to Maganlal.
('41', 470, 2, 9, 857764) I never hesitated to set him the most difficult tasks.
('41', 470, 2, 10, 857819) I very often put him in embarrassing situations and he silently bore with them.
('41', 470, 2, 11, 857899) He regarded no work as too mean.
('41', 470, 2, 12, 857932) If I were fit to be anyone’s guru, I would have proclaimed him my first disciple.
('41', 470, 2, 13, 858014) In all my life I gave only one person the freedom to regard me as his guru and I had my fill of it.
('41', 470, 2, 14, 858114) The fault was not his, as I could see; only I had imperfections.
('41', 470, 2, 15, 858179) Anyone who becomes a guru should possess the power of conferring on the pupil the capacity to carry out whatever task is assigned to him.
('41', 470, 2, 16, 858317) I had not that power and still do not have it.
('41', 470, 2, 17, 858364) But if Maganlal was not a disciple, he was certainly a servant.
('41', 470, 2, 18, 858428) I am convinced that no master could possibly find a servant better or more loyal than Maganlal.
('41', 470, 2, 19, 858524) This may be a conjecture, but I can assert from my experience that I have not found another servant like him.
('41', 470, 2, 20, 858634) It has been my good fortune always to have found co workers, or servants if you like, who were faithful, virtuous, intelligent and industrious.
('41', 470, 2, 21, 858778) Still, Maganlal was the best of all these co workers and servants.
('41', 470, 2, 22, 858845) The three streams of knowledge, devotion and action continuously flowed within Maganlal and, by offering his knowledge and his devotion in the yajna of action, he demonstrated before everyone their true form.
('41', 470, 2, 23, 859054) And because in this way each action of his was full of awareness, knowledge and faith, his life attained the very summit of sannyasa.
('41', 470, 2, 24, 859188) Maganlal had renounced his all.
('41', 470, 2, 25, 859220) I never saw an iota of self interest in any of his actions.
('41', 470, 2, 26, 859280) He showed—not once, not for a short time but time after time for twenty four years incessantly— that true sannyasa lay in selfless action or action without desire for reward.
('41', 470, 2, 27, 859455) Maganlal’s father entrusted all his four sons to me one after
('41', 471, 0, 1, 859517) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 471, 1, 2, 859559) another for serving the country.
('41', 471, 1, 3, 859592) Maganlal was entrusted to me in 1903. He accompanied me to South Africa to earn a living.
('41', 471, 1, 4, 859682) In 1904, I invited him along with other friends to embrace poverty in order to serve the country.
('41', 471, 1, 5, 859780) He heard me calmly and embraced poverty.
('41', 471, 1, 6, 859821) From that time on until his death, his life was an un interrupted flow.With each day I realize more and more that my mahatmaship, which is a mere adornment, depends on others.
('41', 471, 1, 7, 859997) I have shone with the glory borrowed from my innumerable co workers.
('41', 471, 1, 8, 860066) However, no one has done more to add to this glory than Maganlal.
('41', 471, 1, 9, 860132) He co operated with me fully and with intelligence in all my activities—physical or spiritual.
('41', 471, 1, 10, 860227) I see no better instance than Maganlal of one who made a tremendous effort to act as he believed.
('41', 471, 1, 11, 860325) Maganlal was awake all the twenty four hours esta blishing unity of thought and action.
('41', 471, 1, 12, 860413) He used up all his energy in this.
('41', 471, 1, 13, 860448) If I have not exaggerated, consciously or unconsciously, in this sketch, one can say that a country in which dharma can be so embodied must triumph and so must its dharma.
('41', 471, 1, 14, 860620) Hence I wish that every servant of the country should study Maganlal’s life and if it commends itself to him imitate it with deter mination.
('41', 471, 1, 15, 860761) What was possible for Maganlal is possible for every man who makes the effort.
('41', 471, 1, 16, 860840) Maganlal could become a true leader because he was a true soldier and I find those who could put up with his fire weeping around me now.
('41', 471, 1, 17, 860977) This country, as also the world, is in need of true soldiers.
('41', 471, 1, 18, 861039) Service of the country, service of the world, self realization, vision of God—these are not separate things but different aspects of the same thing.
('41', 471, 1, 19, 861188) Maganlal realized the truth of this in his own life and made others do so.
('41', 471, 1, 20, 861263) Those who are curious can study his life and find this out.
('41', 471, 1, 21, 861323) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 29 4 1928

('41', 473, 8, 20, 863639) 545. LETTER TO LAJPAT RAI
('41', 473, 9, 21, 863665) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 29, 1928
('41', 473, 10, 22, 863703) DEAR LALAJI, I have your characteristic letter.
('41', 473, 10, 23, 863751) I am glad you had an ocular demonstration of what form untouchability takes in the south.
('41', 473, 10, 24, 863841) I wish you could have been there longer to see the unapproachables and the
('41', 474, 0, 1, 863916) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 475
('41', 474, 1, 2, 863958) invisibles face to face, and to talk to them.
('41', 474, 1, 3, 864004) And in this connection let me tell you what an important part khadi is playing in reaching even the unapproachables and invisibles, because it is khadi that makes it possible to establish contacts which before were impossible or unthinkable.
('41', 474, 1, 4, 864246) However this is by the way and written not to influence you in favour of khadi through a side issue.
('41', 474, 1, 5, 864347) I am therefore glad that yu are making a serious study of the subject.
('41', 474, 1, 6, 864418) And I am glad, too, that you are determined not to come to any hasty decision.
('41', 474, 1, 7, 864497) Whatever conclusions you may ultimately form, I would like you to feel about them as you feel about untouchability.
('41', 474, 1, 8, 864613) No argument against untouchability from the so called sanatana quarters or any quarter could possibly dislodge you from the position you hold.
('41', 474, 1, 9, 864756) I would like you therefore to make a thorough study of the problem before coming to any conclusion whatsoever.
('41', 474, 1, 10, 864867) I want you for khadi.
('41', 474, 1, 11, 864889) I know what a gain it would be.
('41', 474, 1, 12, 864921) But I do not want you as a patron on whose certificate I may trade.
('41', 474, 1, 13, 864989) I want you as a fellow worker who will not be dislodged from his position and who would be working for the cause of khadi to the best of his ability.
('41', 474, 1, 14, 865139) For the present, therefore, I would like you, after you study, to discuss the subject with me if you have any doubts before you commit yourself.
('41', 474, 1, 15, 865284) By all means carry on correspondence with me or those who may be hostile to khadi, but I would like you to promise that you will not commit yourself before discussing with me the criticism that may apear to you to be convincing and unanswerable.
('41', 474, 1, 16, 865530) Let me assure you that there are in the khadi movement people who have made a thorough study of the subject and who will leave khadi without a moment’s hesitation if they found that the premises on which they proceeded were insupportable.
('41', 474, 1, 17, 865769) Yes, indeed, Maganlal’s death is the heaviest blow I could have received.
('41', 474, 1, 18, 865843) But in the battle for freedom, we have little time to shed tears over the departure of the dearest.
('41', 474, 2, 19, 865943) Yours sincerely,

('41', 478, 1, 2, 868525) 550. LETTER TO S. RAMANATHAN THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 1, 1928
('41', 478, 2, 3, 868589) MY DEAR RAMANATHAN, I have your letter about .
('41', 478, 2, 4, 868636) 1 I see your law is at fault.
('41', 478, 2, 5, 868666) If you have no writing from .
('41', 478, 2, 6, 868696) , I am sure that we cannot pay ourselves for any loss incurred owing to the negligence or fraud of workers, even though the latter may have furnished cash security.
('41', 478, 2, 7, 868861) Do you not see that it is a dangerous doctrine?
('41', 478, 2, 8, 868909) If such were the law, employees would be at the mercy of employers who would be judges and executioners combined.
('41', 478, 2, 9, 869023) What may appear to an employer to be negligence or fraud, may not honestly appear to be that to an employee and may not be such even in law.
('41', 478, 2, 10, 869164) A well ordered society, therefore, requires unequivocal written documents, if securities furnished by employees are to be appropriated for patent negligence or fraud.
('41', 478, 2, 11, 869331) Whatever, therefore, you do about .
('41', 478, 2, 12, 869367) I suggest that you should take a written document from all the employees from whom you have taken securities.
('41', 478, 2, 13, 869477) About .
('41', 478, 2, 14, 869485) , I suggest that you state the facts that you may have in your possession in proof of his dishonesty, tell him that you hold the security as guarantee for the damage sustained in accordance with the custom of the association and in accordance with the verbal agreement between him and yourself and offer to take him to a court of law if he wishes or to submit it to arbitrators, one to be appointed by him and one by us.

('41', 479, 2, 4, 870337) DEAR DR.
('41', 479, 2, 5, 870346) BIDHAN, Your letter flatters me, 1 but I must not succumb to my pride.
('41', 479, 2, 6, 870417) Apart from the fact that as a non co operator I may have nothing to do with the University that is in any way connected with Government, I do not consider myself to be a fit and proper person to deliver Kamala lectures 2. I do not possess the literary attainment which Sir Ashutosh undoubtedly contemplated for the lecturers.
('41', 479, 3, 7, 870743) You are asking me to shoulder a responsibility which my shoulders cannot bear.
('41', 479, 3, 8, 870822) I am keeping fairly fit.
('41', 479, 3, 9, 870847) I am biding my time and you will find me leading the country in the field of politics when the country is ready.
('41', 479, 3, 10, 870960) I have no false modesty about me.
('41', 479, 3, 11, 870994) I am undoubtedly a politician in my own way, and I have a scheme for the country’s freedom.
('41', 479, 3, 12, 871086) But my time is not yet and may never come to me in this life.
('41', 479, 3, 13, 871148) If it does not, I shall not shed a single tear.
('41', 479, 3, 14, 871196) We are all in the hands of God.
('41', 479, 3, 15, 871228) I therefore await His guidance.

('41', 481, 0, 1, 873401) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 481, 1, 2, 873443) 553. SPEECH AT OPENING OF CRECHE, AHMEDABAD 1
('41', 481, 2, 3, 873489) May 1, 1928 Perhaps it is quite appropriate that this creche is being opened by one who calls himself a labourer, though let me confess to you that it was not without some hesitation that I accepted the invitation when it was brought to me by Sheth Kasturbhai, not because I did not like the object, but because I was so preoccupied, and nothing would have pleased me better than that you should have got this function performed by someone more deserving than myself preferably a mill owner.
('41', 481, 2, 4, 873981) But my regard for Sheth Kasturbhai prevailed and I had to yield.
('41', 481, 2, 5, 874046) When I established my Ashram in Ahmedabad the consideration which weighed with me was not merely that it was the capital of Gujarat, nor that it was a busy commercial centre but that it was a great centre of textile industry and I felt that I could reasonably count on the help of the mill agents and be able to render some service to the city.
('41', 481, 2, 6, 874391) Today I am glad to be able to say that these expectations of mine have not been altogether unfulfilled.
('41', 481, 2, 7, 874495) Though I have a recollection of some bitter experiences I have also a number of sweet recollections of my relations with the mill owners.
('41', 481, 2, 8, 874633) I have not yet given up hope of Ahmedabad.
('41', 481, 2, 9, 874676) I still expect great things of it.
('41', 481, 2, 10, 874711) It has much to accomplish yet, and among other things, speaking as a labourer myself, and as one who has tried to enter into the innermost feelings of the working class I say that Ahmedabad has much to do yet towards the amelioration of the condition of the labouring class.
('41', 481, 2, 11, 874986) My connection with the labour of this place is not of yesterday.
('41', 481, 2, 12, 875051) It is as old as my first coming to this city, and so I make bold to tell you that you have not yet done your part towards your labouring population.
('41', 481, 2, 13, 875200) In some cases the labourers have not been provided with even the primary amenities of life.
('41', 481, 2, 14, 875292) There are exceptions, however.
('41', 481, 2, 15, 875323) Some mill owners have made some effort in the direction, and the present one is an instance in point.
('41', 481, 2, 16, 875425) The sentiments about the welfare of the mill hands that Sheth Kas turbhai has just now uttered before you reflect credit on him and the city of Ahmedabad.
('41', 481, 2, 17, 875580) Sheth Kasturbhai was delighted with Port Sunlight, and rightly.
('41', 481, 2, 18, 875644) But Port Sunlight cannot be our ideal.
('41', 481, 2, 19, 875683) Messrs Lever Bros.
('41', 481, 2, 20, 875702) represent to my mind the minimum standard that an
('41', 481, 3, 21, 875752) 1 Kasturbhai Lalbhai, Agent, Raipur Manufacturing Company, had requested Gandhiji to perform the opening ceremony.
('41', 482, 0, 1, 875867) VOL. 41: 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 483
('41', 482, 1, 2, 875909) employer must do for his employees.
('41', 482, 1, 3, 875945) To do less would be a discredit.
('41', 482, 1, 4, 875978) But we cannot afford to rest content with that.
('41', 482, 1, 5, 876026) We must think in terms of our own civilization, and if the picture presented to us in the Mahabharata and the Ramayana of the social conditions prevailing in the ancient times be correct, our ideal would seem to go much farther than Port Sunlight.
('41', 482, 1, 6, 876274) I have read a lot of li terature about Port Sunlight, and I am an ardent admirer of their welfare work, but I maintain that ours is a higher ideal.
('41', 482, 1, 7, 876422) In the West there is still a watertight division between the employer and the employees.
('41', 482, 1, 8, 876511) I know it is impertinent to talk of our ideal, while the curse of untouchability still stalks through the land.
('41', 482, 1, 9, 876623) But I should be untrue to myself and be failing in my duty to you if I did not place before you what I regard as the highest ideal.
('41', 482, 1, 10, 876755) The relation between mill agents and mill hands ought to be one of father and childeren or as between blood brothers.
('41', 482, 1, 11, 876873) I have often heard the mill owners of Ahmedabad refer to themselves as ‘masters’ and their employees as their servants.
('41', 482, 1, 12, 876993) Such loose talk should be out of fashion in a place like Ahmedabad which prides itself on its love of religion and love of ahimsa.
('41', 482, 1, 13, 877124) For that attitude is a negation of ahimsa, inasmuch as our ideal demands that all our power, all our wealth and all our brains should be devoted solely to the welfare of those who through their own ignorance and our false notions of things are styled labourers or ‘servants’.
('41', 482, 1, 14, 877400) What I expect of you therefore is that you should hold all your riches as a trust to be used solely in the interests of those who sweat for you, and to whose industry and labour you owe all your position and prosperity.
('41', 482, 1, 15, 877620) I want you to make your labourers co partners of your wealth.
('41', 482, 1, 16, 877682) I do not mean to suggest that unless you legally bind yourselves to do all that, there should be a labour insurrection.
('41', 482, 1, 17, 877802) The only sanction that I can think of in this connection is of mutual love and regard as between father and son, not of law.
('41', 482, 1, 18, 877927) If only you make it a rule to respect these mutual obligations of love, there would be an end to all labour disputes, the workers would no longer feel the need for organizing themselves into unions.
('41', 482, 1, 19, 878126) Under the ideal contemplated by me, there would be nothing left for our Anasuyabehns and Shankerlals to do; their occupation would be gone.
('41', 482, 1, 20, 878266) But that cannot happen until there is a single mill hand who does not regard the mill in which he works as his own, who complains of sweating and overwork, and who therefore nurses in his breast nothing but ill will towards his employers.And where is the difficulty?
('41', 482, 1, 21, 878533) You have told us and it is recognized everywhere that the mill 
('41', 483, 0, 1, 878597) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 483, 1, 2, 878639) owners stand only to gain by doing all this.
('41', 483, 1, 3, 878684) Messrs Lever Bros.
('41', 483, 1, 4, 878703) lost nothing by doing all that they did.
('41', 483, 1, 5, 878744) They felt so encouraged that they even tried to create another Port Sunlight in Natal.
('41', 483, 1, 6, 878831) As our experience gradually broadens we are beginning to see more and more clearly that the more we give to our workers the more we stand to gain.
('41', 483, 1, 7, 878978) From the moment your men come to realize that the mills are theirs, no less than yours, they will begin to feel towards you as blood brothers, there would be no question of their acting against the common interest and the need for having a heavy supervisory establishment over them.
('41', 483, 1, 8, 879261) You have given me credit for keeping the city of Ahmedabad free from a labour upheaval such as Bombay is at present passing through.
('41', 483, 1, 9, 879394) Well, I cannot quite disclaim that credit, for does anyone among you for a moment doubt that things would have been otherwise here, but for the work that Shrimati Anasuyabehn and Sjt.
('41', 483, 1, 10, 879578) Shankerlal have been doing?
('41', 483, 1, 11, 879606) It is true perhaps that you the mill owners of Ahmedabad are more tactful than the Bombay mill owners.
('41', 483, 1, 12, 879709) In case of an upheaval you do not employ hooligans to crush your men as some employers in the West do, and I fancy that you have deliberately abjured that weapon of suppressing the aspirations of labour.
('41', 483, 1, 13, 879913) My critics tell me that this is all moonshine, and that you would not hesitate to resort to such means, if you could.
('41', 483, 1, 14, 880031) But I believe that they are mistaken and I want you to prove by your conduct that they are mistaken.
('41', 483, 1, 15, 880132) I hope you will help to bring near the time when the sort of work that Sjt.
('41', 483, 1, 16, 880208) Banker Shrimati Anasuyabehn are doing would be rendered needless, and pending that consummation give them all the help, all the encouragement that they need in their work.
('41', 483, 1, 17, 880380) Now perhaps you understand why I have dared to appropriate a little credit for the peace that prevails here today.
('41', 483, 1, 18, 880495) It belongs not to me but to Shrimati Anasuyabehn and Sjt.
('41', 483, 1, 19, 880553) Shankerlal Banker.
('41', 483, 1, 20, 880572) They live, move and have their being among the labourers, which I am unable to do.
('41', 483, 1, 21, 880655) If you aid the efforts of these friends you will find there will not be much need left for erecting creches like this one or for providing medical relief.
('41', 483, 1, 22, 880810) I do not wish to detract from the merit of these efforts of yours, but I ask you whether any well to do man would care to send his children to a creche like this.
('41', 483, 1, 23, 880973) Our endeavour should be to bring about a state of things under which there would be no occasion for a mill hand’s baby to be torn from its mother, and when a factory hand’s child would receive the same opportunities for education that our own children have.
('41', 483, 1, 24, 881231) Young India, 10 5 1928

('41', 484, 1, 2, 881297) APPENDICES
('41', 484, 2, 3, 881308) APPENDIX I RESOLUTION ON HINDU MUSLIM UNITY 1
('41', 484, 3, 4, 881354) PART A—POLITICAL RIGHTS
('41', 484, 4, 5, 881378) This Congress resolves : (1) That in any future scheme of constitution, so far as representation in various legislatures is concerned, joint electorates in all the provinces and in the Central Legislature be constituted; (2) That, with a view to giving full assurances to the two great communities that their legitimate interests will be safeguarded in the Legislatures such representation of the communities should be secured for the present, and if desired, by the reservation of seats in joint electorates on the basis of population in every province and in the Cental Legislature : Provided that reciprocal concessions in favour of minorities may be made by mutual agreement so as to give them representation in excess of the proportion of the number of seats to which they would be entitled on the population basis in any province or provinces and the proportions so agreed upon for the provinces shall be maintained in the representation of the two communities in the Central Legislature from the provinces.
('41', 484, 4, 6, 882392) In the decision of the reservation of seats for the Punjab, the question of the representation of Sikhs as an important minority will be given full consideration; 3(a) That the proposal made by the Muslim leaders that the reforms should be introduced in the N.W.F. Province and British Baluchistan on the same footing as in other provinces is, in the opinion of the Congress, a fair and reasonable one, and should be given effect to, care being taken that simultaneously with other measures of administrative reform an adequate system of judicial administration shall be introduced in the said provinces; (b)(i) That with regard to the proposal that Sind should be constituted into a separate province, this Congress is of opinion that the time has come for the redistribution of provinces on a linguistic basis—a principle that has been adopted in the constitution of the Congress; (ii) This Congress is also of opinion that such readjustment of provinces be immediately taken in hand and that any province which demands such reconstitution on linguistic basis be dealt with accordingly; (iii) This Congress is further of opinion that a beginning may be made by reconstituting Andhra, Utakl, Sind and Karnatak into separate provinces; 4. That, in the future constitution, liberty of conscience shall be guaranteed
('41', 484, 5, 7, 883707) 1 Passed at the annual session of the Indian National Congress at Madras on December 26, 1927; vide letters to Ansari, 25 12 1927 and 28 12 1927.
('41', 485, 0, 1, 883853) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 485, 1, 2, 883895) and no legislature, Central or Provincial, shall have power to make any laws interfering with liberty of conscience; ‘Liberty of conscience’ means liberty of belief and worship, freedom of religious observances and association and freedom to carry on religious education and propaganda with due regard to the feelings of others and without interfering with similar rights of others; 5. That no bill, resolution, motion or amendment regarding intercommunal matters shall be moved, discussed or passed in any legislature, Central or Provincial, if a three fourths majority of the members of either community affected thereby in that legislature oppose the introduction, discussion or passing of such bill, resolution, motion or amendment.
('41', 485, 1, 3, 884632) “Intercommunal matters” means matters agreed upon by such a joint Standing Committee of both communities—of the Hindu and Muslim members of the legislature concerned appointed at the commencement of every session of the legislature.
('41', 485, 1, 4, 884865) PART B—RELIGIOUS AND OTHER RIGHTS
('41', 485, 2, 5, 884899) This Congress resolves that :
('41', 485, 3, 6, 884929) 1. Without prejudice to the rights Hindus and Mussalmans claim, the one to play music and conduct processions wherever they please and the other to slaughter cows for sacrifice or food wherever they please, the Mussalmans appeal to the Mussalmans to spare Hindu feelings as much as possible in the matter of the cow and the Hindus appeal to the Hindus to spare Mussalman feelings, as much as possible in the matter of music before mosques.
('41', 485, 3, 7, 885369) And therefore, this Congress calls upon both the Hindus and Mussal mans not to have recourse to violence or to law to prevent the slaughter of a cow or the playing of music before a mosque.
('41', 485, 4, 8, 885559) 2. This Congress further resolves that every individual or group is at liberty to convert or reconvert another by argument or persuasion but no individual or group shall attempt to do so, or prevent its being done by force, fraud or other unfair means such as the offering of material inducement.
('41', 485, 4, 9, 885856) Persons under eighteen years of age should not be converted unless it be along with their parents or guardians.
('41', 485, 4, 10, 885968) If any person under eighteen years of age is found stranded without his parents or guardian by persons of another faith he should be promptly handed over to persons of his own faith.
('41', 485, 4, 11, 886151) There must be no secrecy as to the person, place, time and manner about any conversion or reconversion, nor should there be any demonstration of jubilation in support of any conversion or reconversion.
('41', 485, 5, 12, 886353) Whenever any complaint is made in respect of any conversion or reconversion, that it was effected in secrecy or by force, fraud or other unfair means,
('41', 485, 6, 13, 886504) 1 This section, according to The Hindu, 27 12 1927, was originally drafted by Gandhiji and adopted with a few verbal changes by the Congress.
('41', 486, 0, 1, 886646) VOL. 41 : 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 487
('41', 486, 1, 2, 886689) or whenever any person under eighteen years of age is converted, the matter shall be enquired into and decided by arbitrators who shall be appointed by the Working Committee either by name or under general regulations.
('41', 486, 2, 3, 886908) The resolution was moved by Mrs. Sarojini Naidu and was seconded by Mr. Abul Kalam Azad.
('41', 486, 3, 4, 886997) The resolution was put and carried unanimously.

('41', 486, 5, 6, 887112) APPENDIX II
('41', 486, 6, 7, 887124) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU 1
('41', 486, 7, 8, 887155) ALLAHABAD,
('41', 486, 8, 9, 887166) January 11, 1928
('41', 486, 9, 10, 887183) MY DEAR BAPUJI,
('41', 486, 10, 11, 887199) The Working Committee is now meeting in Banaras and so I cannot go to Bombay or Sabarmati for some time.
('41', 486, 11, 12, 887304) I am loath to inflict another letter on you so soon after my last but I am very much troubled by your criticisms of the Congress resolutions and I feel I must write to you again.
('41', 486, 11, 13, 887483) You are always very careful with you words and your language is studiously restrained.
('41', 486, 11, 14, 887570) It amazes me all the more to find you using language which appears to me wholly unjustified.
('41', 486, 11, 15, 887663) You have condemned in general language the proceedings of the Subjects Committee and specially selected some resolutions for greater criticism and condemnation.
('41', 486, 11, 16, 887824) May I point out that it is always unsafe to judge on hearsay evidence?
('41', 486, 11, 17, 887895) You were not present yourself and it is quite conceivable that the opinions you may have formed after a personal visit to the Subjects Committee may have been different.
('41', 486, 11, 18, 888065) Yet you have chosen to condemn and judge unfavourably the whole Committee, or at any rate a great majority of it, simply basing your judgment on the impressions of a few persons.
('41', 486, 11, 19, 888244) Do you think this is quite fair to the Committee or the Congress?
('41', 486, 11, 20, 888310) You have referred to discipline and to the Working Committee as the National Cabinet.
('41', 486, 11, 21, 888396) May I remind you that you are a member of the Working Committee and it is an extraordinary thing for a memebr on the morrow of the Congress to criticize, and run down the Congress and its principal resolutions.
('41', 486, 11, 22, 888607) There has been a general chorus of congratulation on the success of the Madras Congress.
('41', 486, 11, 23, 888696) This may be wrong or without sufficient basis but undoubtedly there was this general impression in the country and atmosphere counts for a great deal in all public work.
('41', 486, 11, 24, 888866) And now most people who thought so feel a bit dazed at your criticisms and wonder if their previous enthusiasm was not overdone or mistaken.
('41', 486, 12, 25, 889007) 1 Vide Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru, 17 1 1928.
('41', 487, 0, 1, 889053) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 487, 1, 2, 889095) You have described the Independence Resolution as “hastily conceived and thoughtlessly passed”.
('41', 487, 1, 3, 889191) I have already pointed out to you how the country has discussed and considered this question for years past, and how I have personally thought over it, discussed it, spoken about it in meetings, written about it and generally been full of it for the last five years or more.
('41', 487, 1, 4, 889466) It seems to me that under the circumstances no stretch of language can justify the use of the words “hastily conceived”.
('41', 487, 1, 5, 889587) As for “thoughtlessly passed” I wonder if you know that the resolution was discussed in the Subjects Committee for about three hours and more than a dozen speeches for and against were made.
('41', 487, 1, 6, 889778) Ultimately as you know it was passed almost unanimously both in the Committee and the open Congress.
('41', 487, 1, 7, 889879) Were all the people in the Committee and the Congress who voted for it “thoughtless”?
('41', 487, 1, 8, 889965) Is this not rather a large assumption?
('41', 487, 1, 9, 890004) And why should it not be said with greater truth that the small minority opposed to the resolution were mistaken?
('41', 487, 1, 10, 890118) You mention that last year the resolution was rejected by the Committee.
('41', 487, 1, 11, 890191) I do not know what inferene you draw from this but to me it seems obvious that this can only mean that the Committee and the Congress have been eager to pass it in the past as in the present but refrained from doing so out of regard for you.
('41', 487, 1, 12, 890433) I hope will agree with me that it is not healthy politics for any organization to subordinate its own definite opinion on a public issue out of personal regard only.
('41', 487, 1, 13, 890599) I am not referring here to the merits of the resolution.
('41', 487, 1, 14, 890656) But I shall only say this that after prolonged and careful thought a demand for independence and all that this implies has come to mean a very great deal for me and I attach more importance to it than to almost anything else.
('41', 487, 1, 15, 890882) I have thought over every word you said the other day in Madras on this question and it has merely confirmed me in my opinion.
('41', 487, 1, 16, 891009) But I doubt if anyone outside a small circle understands your position in regard to this.
('41', 487, 1, 17, 891099) I am sure that none of the others—liberals, etc.,— who want dominion status think in the same way with you.
('41', 487, 1, 18, 891207) Yesterday Sir Ali Imam addressed a meeting here on the Simon boycott.
('41', 487, 1, 19, 891277) I also spoke for a few minutes and like King Charles’ head independence cropped up and I laid stress on it.
('41', 487, 1, 20, 891385) After the meeting Ali Imam told me that I did well in laying stress on this; he and his friends would probably come round to this position sooner or later but for the time being they had to be a little restrained as they wanted to carry many people with them.
('41', 487, 1, 21, 891645) I am sure most liberals welcome the Independence Resolution, whatever they may say about it, as they feel that it strengthens their position.
('41', 487, 1, 22, 891787) But whether they like it or not, it passes my comprehension how a national organization can have as its ideal and goal dominion status.
('41', 487, 1, 23, 891923) The very idea suffocates and strangles me.
('41', 487, 2, 24, 891966) I took no special interest in the resolution on the boycott of British goods chiefly because I felt that it would meet with your strong disapproval and the boycott could not succeed unless a more or less unanimous effort was made.
('41', 487, 2, 25, 892197) But I have no doubt that it can be made into a partial success if there was some unanimity in our own ranks.
('41', 487, 2, 26, 892306) You must have read about the wonderful effectiveness of the boycott in China.
('41', 488, 0, 1, 892384) VOL. 41 : 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 489
('41', 488, 1, 2, 892427) There was nothing special in China which we have not got and there is no fundamental reason why we cannot succeed where they succeeded.
('41', 488, 1, 3, 892563) But granting that it is not likely to succeed is it such a laughing matter after all?
('41', 488, 1, 4, 892649) Has our boycott of foreign cloth by khaddar succeeded so remarkably?
('41', 488, 1, 5, 892718) Has our spinning franchise succeeded?
('41', 488, 1, 6, 892756) They have not but you do not hesitate to them on the country and the Congress because you felt, and rightly, that they would be good for the nation even if they did not wholly succeed.
('41', 488, 2, 7, 892941) I remember how Kelkar, Aney and Co., even as members of the Working Committee, used to make fun of the Congress resolutions on khadi, and it is very painful for me to think that you are also ridiculing important Congress resolutions.
('41', 488, 2, 8, 893175) The Kelkars and Aneys do not count and I do not care what they say or do.
('41', 488, 2, 9, 893249) But I do care very much for what you say and do.
('41', 488, 3, 10, 893298) Having singled out two resolutions for your special condemnation you casually refer to the others as “several irresponsible resolutions”.
('41', 488, 3, 11, 893436) Excepting the Unity Resolution every other resolution of the Congress may come under this heading.
('41', 488, 3, 12, 893535) And so the labours of the 200 and odd persons in the Subjects Committee and the larger number in the Congress are summarily and rather contemptuously disposed of.
('41', 488, 3, 13, 893698) It is very hard luck on the unhappy persons who, though wanting perhaps in foresight and intelligence, did not spare themselves and tried to do their best.
('41', 488, 3, 14, 893854) We have all sunk to the level of the schoolboys’ ‘debating society’ and you chastize us like an angry school master, but a school master who will not guide us or give us lessons but will only point out from time to time the error of our ways.
('41', 488, 3, 15, 894097) Personally I very much wish that we were more like real schoolboys, with the life and energy and daring of schoolboys, and a little less like the right honourable and honourable gentlemen who are for ever weighing the pros and cons and counting the cost.
('41', 488, 4, 16, 894352) You know how intensely I have admired you and believed in you as a leader who can lead this country to victory and freedom.
('41', 488, 4, 17, 894476) I have done so in spite of the fact that I hardly agreed with anything that some of your previous publications—Indian Home Rule, etc.,—contained.
('41', 488, 4, 18, 894622) I felt and feel that you were and are infinitley greater than your little books.
('41', 488, 4, 19, 894703) Above everything I admire action and daring and courage and I found them all in you in a superlative degree.
('41', 488, 4, 20, 894812) And I felt instinctively that, however much I may disagree with you, your great personality and your possession of these qualities would carry us to our goal.
('41', 488, 4, 21, 894971) During the N. C. O. period you were supreme; you were in your element and automatically you took the right step.
('41', 488, 4, 22, 895084) But since you came out of prison something seems to have gone wrong and you have been very obviously ill at ease.
('41', 488, 4, 23, 895198) You will remember how within a few months or even weeks you repeatedly changed your attitude—the Juhu statements, the A.I.C.C. meeting at Ahmedabad and after, etc.,—and most of us were left in utter bewilderment.
('41', 488, 4, 24, 895411) That bewilderment has continued since then.
('41', 488, 4, 25, 895455) I have asked you many times what you expected to do in the future and your answers have been far from satisfying.
('41', 488, 4, 26, 895569) All you
('41', 489, 0, 1, 895577) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('41', 489, 1, 2, 895619) have said has been that within a year or eighteen months you expected the khadi movement to spread repidly and in a geometric ratio and then some direct action in the political field might be indulged in.
('41', 489, 1, 3, 895824) Several years and eighteen months have passed since then and the miracle has not happened.
('41', 489, 1, 4, 895915) It was difficult to believe that it would happen but faith in your amiazing capacity to bring off the improbable kept us in an expectant mood.
('41', 489, 1, 5, 896058) But such faith for an irreligious person like me is a poor reed to reply on and I am beginning to think if we are to wait for freedom till khadi becomes universal in India we shall have to wait till the Greek Kalends.
('41', 489, 1, 6, 896276) Khadi will grow slowly, and if war comes it will grow very fast, but I do not see how freedom is coming in its train.
('41', 489, 1, 7, 896394) As I mentioned before you our khadi work is almost wholly divorced from politics and our khadi workers ae developing a mentality which does not concern itself with anything outside their limited sphere of work.
('41', 489, 1, 8, 896605) This may be good for the work they do, but little can be expected from them in the political field.
('41', 489, 2, 9, 896705) What then can be done?
('41', 489, 2, 10, 896728) You say nothing,—you only criticize and no helpful lead comes from you.
('41', 489, 2, 11, 896800) You tell us that if the country will not even take to khadi how can we expect it to do anything more difficult or daring.
('41', 489, 2, 12, 896922) I do not think the reasoning is correct.
('41', 489, 2, 13, 896963) If the country does not go ahead politically by one method, surely it is up to our leaders to think of other or additional methods.
('41', 489, 3, 14, 897095) Reading many of your articles in Young India—your autobiography, etc., —I have often felt how very different my ideals were from yours.
('41', 489, 3, 15, 897231) And I have felt that you were very hasty in your judgments, or rather having arrived at certain conclusions you were over eager to justify them by any scrap of evidence you might get.
('41', 489, 3, 16, 897415) I remember how in an article on the “Two Ways” or some such title—you gave some newspaper cuttings from America about crimes and immorality and contrasted American civilization with Indian.
('41', 489, 3, 17, 897605) I felt it was something like Katharine Mayo drawing conclusions from some unsavoury hospital statistics.
('41', 489, 3, 18, 897710) Your long series of articles based on the French book—“Towards Moral Bankruptcy”—also made me feel the same way.
('41', 489, 3, 19, 897823) You misjudge greatly, I think, the civilization of the West and attach too great an importance to its many failings.
('41', 489, 3, 20, 897940) You have stated somewhere that India has nothing to learn from the West and that she had reached a pinnacle of wisdom in the past.
('41', 489, 3, 21, 898071) I certainly disagree with this viewpoint and I neither think that the so called Ramaraj was very good in the past, nor do I want it back.
('41', 489, 3, 22, 898209) I think that western or rather industrial civilization is bound to conquer India maybe with many changes and adaptations, but none the less, in the main, based on industrialism.
('41', 489, 3, 23, 898387) You have criticized strongly the many obvious defects of industrialism and hardly paid any attention to its merits.
('41', 489, 3, 24, 898503) Everybody knows these defects and the utopias and social theories are meant to remove them.
('41', 489, 3, 25, 898595) It is the opinion of most thinkers in the West that these defects are not due to industrialism as such but to the capitalist system which is based on exploitation of others.
('41', 489, 3, 26, 898769) I believe you have stated that in your
('41', 490, 0, 1, 898808) VOL. 41 : 3 DECEMBER, 1927 1 MAY, 1928 491
('41', 490, 1, 2, 898851) opinion there is no necessary conflict between capital and labour.
('41', 490, 1, 3, 898918) I think that under the capitalist system this conflict is unavoidable.
('41', 490, 2, 4, 898989) You have advocated very eloquently and forcefully the claims of the Daridranarayana—the poor in India.
('41', 490, 2, 5, 899092) I do believe that the remedy you have suggested is very helpful to them and if adopted by them in large number will relieve to some extent their misery.
('41', 490, 2, 6, 899245) But I doubt very much if the fundamental cause of poverty are touched by it.
('41', 490, 2, 7, 899322) You do not say a word against the semi feudal zamindari system which prevails in a great part of India or against the capitalist exploitation of both the workers and the consumers.
('41', 490, 3, 8, 899503) But I must stop.
('41', 490, 3, 9, 899520) I have already exceeded all reasonable limits and I hope you will forgive me.
('41', 490, 3, 10, 899598) My only excuse is my mental agitation.
('41', 490, 3, 11, 899637) I did not want to become the secretary of the A.I.C.C. as I wanted perfect freedom to say and do what I considered necessary.
('41', 490, 3, 12, 899763) But Ansari pressed me on the ground that many of my resolutions and specially the Independence Resolution, had been passed by the Congress and I thus had full freedom to work on my own lines.
('41', 490, 3, 13, 899955) I could not answer this argument and had to accept.
('41', 490, 3, 14, 900007) Now I find that every effort is being made to belittle and ridicule these very Congress resolutions and it is a painful experience.
('41', 490, 4, 15, 900139) Yours affectionately, JAWAHARLAL
